1
Listen
Share
SUNDAY
When traveling from the U.S., prepare to be jet lagged when you arrive in Lisbon (especially if you use a long flight to catch up on all of your Netflix and HBOMax). By the time I arrived at the Corinthia Hotel in Lisbon, I was out of sorts. I ordered a pot of mint tea (it was late morning there) and scurried up to my room. Corinthia Lisbon was my travel partner for a portion of my Lisbon stay and they spared no detail in making me feel right at home. I was fortunate enough to snag one of their recently renovated Maritime Suites. I hesitate to use the word suite though ‚Äî with two bathrooms, two televisions, an office, a walk-in closet, and nightly pastries with turn-down service ‚Äî it felt more like an apartment.
After a jaw-dropping twirl through my suite ‚Äî I noted a make-up vanity, two televisions, rainforest showerhead shower, a bidet and a fluffy king-sized mattress ‚Äî I decided to climb into my huge floor tub with massive up-to-the-ceiling windows boasting a view of city life below. The suite comes with decadent toiletries so I opted for the bath gel (which is also a bubble bath) and a packet of bath salts. I positioned my teapot on the cushion seating adjacent to the tub and sipped hot tea while luxuriating in my bubble bath.
After a quick nap, I decided to leave my comfortable enclave long enough to eat. The LX Factory boasts art murals, eclectic mix of restaurants and shops, live music and a bohemian flea market every Sunday. I settled on a Mexican restaurant, and sat outside for top-tier people watching and margarita drinking. At the flea market I scored a patterned brass ring and an ear cuff with colored stones for 20 Euros.
Back at the Corinthia, I went downstairs to the hotel spa. The spa is one of the largest indoor spas in Lisbon, and comes complete with treatment rooms, a salon, a full-sized indoor pool with outdoor patio, and a water therapy circuit. The therapy circuit was the perfect choice for my jet lag: a series of very cold, followed by warm and hot streams, jets, pools, and whirlpools, along with a sauna and steam room. I blissfully lost track of time in the circuit. Several times I fell asleep and eventually came to, more relaxed than ever as the jets intentionally and methodically worked out every knot and lulled me back to sleep. I spent about two and a half hours there on the first day, and returned each day of my stay.
That night, I dined at Erva, one of the hotel‚Äôs incredible restaurants. It was here that I fell in love with green wine, an effervescent libation native to Portugal that is actually white in color. As it was explained to me, the grapes are not fully ripened when fermented (hence the word green), so the wine is lower in sugar and alcohol content (in comparison to white or red wine). You can find it anywhere in Lisbon, and it pairs perfectly with any seafood meal. Speaking of seafood, the grilled squid and the lamb croquettes that I ordered were phenomenal.
MONDAY
Still jet lagged, I awoke late and opted for another visit to the hotel spa. Motivated by hunger and a desire to explore the must-see areas on my list, I took an Uber to Pink Street. Given that I was a solo traveler, I had been told by the concierge that it was best to visit this area in the day (at night it becomes a bit more clubby). There I got my obligatory photo, beneath the famed art installation of colorful, rainbow umbrellas and standing atop concrete that actually is pink in color.
From there, I walked over to Time Out Market Lisboa. This place is a food lover‚Äôs dream. You can find sushi, croquettes, steak, seafood, desserts, cocktails and more. I opted for a grilled seafood platter that came with a generously-portioned fish fillet, calamari, and shrimp served with a plate of broccoli. While it is supposed to be a platter for two, I was that hungry and it was that good. It was one of my best meals in Lisbon; I would eventually make my way back there again on my last night there.
From here, I took an Uber to happy hour at Go A Lisboa, a rooftop bar with gorgeous views, R&B music vibes and Morocco-inspired furniture.
TUESDAY and WEDNESDAY
I left Lisbon and headed South to the stunning Algarve region. From Lisbon, the travel possibilities are endless: next time, I may choose to explore Porto or Evora. It‚Äôs easy and affordable to zip around the country via the high speed train. Not only is it chic, sophisticated, and comfortable ‚Äî it‚Äôs also a safe alternative if you‚Äôre traveling solo and want to avoid driving on unfamiliar roads.
THURSDAY
Back in Lisbon, I kicked off my day with a visit to the Museu Nacional do Azulejo (the National Tile Museum) to learn about this form of artistry which is heavily featured throughout the streets of Lisbon ‚Äî so much so that it is internationally recognized as part of the city‚Äôs brand. You‚Äôll learn about etymology (e.g., azulejo, the Portuguese word for tile, has Arabic derivations) and witness the opulence of centuries-old Portuguese churches (think: all gold everything).
For dinner, I visited Bairro do Avillez in the Chiado neighborhood. The venue is open from 12pm ‚Äî 12am daily, and boasts several different restaurants, each with its own distinct flavor and style. I sat outside and enjoyed a seafood and soupy rice dish that was filling and decadent thanks to the copious amounts of the lobster meat, shrimp and clams. It was one of my pricier meals in Lisbon but incredibly satisfying.
I worked some of my dinner off with a short walk to the famed Tasca do Chico, an understated, slightly cramped bar featuring incredibly live fado musicians each night. Given the close quarters, you will likely be seated with strangers; this lends itself to an friendly, social ambiance where guests interact and greet one another. I spent most of my time lost in the soulful traditional fado music. While I could not understand the words, I felt them somehow and the Portuguese guitar provided the perfect backdrop to this emotional, auditory experience. I met the most amazing crew during the second showing of the night (fellow New Yorkers!). I also finally sampled ginja, a potent, cherry-based liqueur that originates in Lisbon.
FRIDAY
I had an early morning meet-up with Naky, my tour guide and also the creator of the Africa in Lisbon tour, in the harbor-facing plaza of Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio (Commerce Square). Our group was primarily composed of Black American tourists. We also had a Portuguese woman in our group. It became clear very early on that she had not learned anything in school about her country‚Äôs prolific slave trading, or how it treated Black people both during and post-slavery. According to her, the myth of the ‚Äúgood colonizer‚Äù permeated her upbringing with romanticized tales of gentle Portuguese conquerors who fell in love with their colonized inhabitants and built families with them ‚Äî while the Spanish and British raped and pillaged their conquests throughout the world. She was incredulous to discover on Naky‚Äôs tour that those favorable depictions of her country were false.
Africa in Lisbon is a walking tour and I highly recommend it to all, regardless of race or nationality. After a day spent discussing some heavier topics, the tour ended with levity: a group lunch and cocktails al fresco at Mambo, a restaurant featuring delicious African cuisine.
From here, I walked to Java, a gorgeous rooftop bar with an exquisite breeze and impressive water views. It was another rooftop on my Lisbon list, and well worth the trip.
Afterwards, I hopped in an Uber and met my new friends at the incredibly popular Cervejaria Ramiro, a seafood restaurant in the Alfama neighborhood. The menu is extensive ‚Äî we feasted on sea snails and barnacles ‚Äî right along with the more familiar shrimp and clams. All were phenomenally flavorful and well-priced at this unpretentious neighborhood gem. Their buttered bread is also worth mentioning. Come prepared to eat well and ready to take a walk on the wilder side in terms of your palate and menu selections.
SATURDAY
Despite the rain, there was already a line formed outside when I arrived at Nicolau for brunch. I heard it was Instagrammable and delicious ‚Äî and it certainly was (although smaller than I‚Äôd imagined). I was seated at a lovely corner table where I could watch the rain from a dry seat. The menu is perfect for those with a sweet tooth but I opted for toast with fluffy cheese and prosciutto. The plan was to head to the world-famous Flea Market, but the rain forced me to make a last-minute schedule change.
I took an Uber to Museu de Arte, Arquitetura e Tecnologia (MAAT). The views here are breathtaking ‚Äî rain or shine. I explored the two exhibits and then popped next door to have a drink at the MAAT Caf√© & Kitchen. The ambiance is perfection ‚Äî light jazz music, indoor foliage and a sweeping view of the water that steals the show entirely. For every 30 Euros you spend at the caf√©, you get one free adult admission to the museum. Next time I visit the MAAT, I will start at the MAAT Caf√© (I hear the food is excellent).
Lisbon is known for, among other things, a custard pastry called pastel de nata. From MAAT, I walked over to the famous Pasteis de Belem to sample the most famous pastel de nata of all, derived from a secret recipe that has been shared with the masses since 1837. My pastels were piping hot, fresh from the oven and melt-in-your-mouth memorable. It‚Äôs worth the trip to Belem but remember that the line is for people waiting to be seated; you don‚Äôt have to wait in it if you‚Äôre purchasing your pastels to-go. While in Belem, I visited the Tower of Belem. It‚Äôs a major tourist attraction as it is one of the only original buildings to have survived an earthquake in 1755 that decimated much of the region. I saw a bride nearby taking captivating photos with the picturesque, imposing tower behind her.
After a day filled with delicious food ‚Äî both savory and decadent ‚Äî and cocktails, I wasn‚Äôt starving. But given that it was my last night, I went back to Time Out Lisbon for my favorite meal thus far: the grilled seafood platter. It was just as delicious as I remembered it. I sat next to a couple on a date and was slightly embarrassed by the fact that they were sharing the same platter that I had polished off alone for the second time that week. I also grabbed a pastel de nata from Manteigiara, a modern-day confectionaries with a recipe that many prefer to Pasteis de Belem. My personal opinion? I preferred the pastry of Pasteis de Belem and the custard filling of Manteigiara. For that reason, I‚Äôll likely reach for Manteigiara next time. Definitely sample them both and form your own opinion.
To round out the evening, I met my new friends at Museu do Fado for one last night of fado music. I preferred the ambience of Tasca do Chico where we had all met a few nights prior but the performers at the museum were top-notch. Once again, the Portuguese guitar and the melodious fado lyrics, enveloped us with their haunting and enchanting beauty. It was a perfect farewell to a city that had, in such a short time, become so dear. At√© a pr√≥xima, Lisboa.

Title: Old Lisbon Never Gets Old
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We are a group of ordinary yet extraordinary travel lovers sharing our experiences of exploring the world with the world.

--
11
Listen
Share
Lisbon is old, but it never gets old. This is the fourth visit for us since October 2021. The more Teresa and I come here, the more we want to return again.
Visiting a city for just a few days creates an artificial impulse to see and do as much as possible, to check main attractions off a list. But now that we have already seen a good number of the tourist highlights, there‚Äôs absolutely no pressure to do anything other than to fl√¢neur ‚Äî to wander about without a plan, following our noses and keeping our eyes open for the unexpected. Just taking a stroll from our hotel to the city center and back is enough fun for a day. Being less dazzled by the monuments, churches and palaces allows the quirkiness of Lisbon to better reveal itself.
For example, here‚Äôs a statue of a purple woman, brandishing a dust buster right next to Lisbon‚Äôs famous antique elevator in the Chiado shopping district:
By the waterfront, I saw an old man painting and piling up stones into works of art. Here‚Äôs a shark he made (below left, in the lower right corner) and a supine mermaid (below right):
Teresa and I are still entranced by the winding, cramped streets of the old Alfama and Mouraria districts that surround St. George‚Äôs Castle. They offer surprising bursts of color and beauty: pink and turquoise laundry on a line that mirrors pink and turquoise buildings the next block over. A yellow budgie in a cage against a yellow wall. A peacock done in azulejos (tile art) on a random wall ‚Äî and look at the unpredictable azulejos blue egg that peacock guards!
It is distressing, though, to see the many buildings that have fallen into disrepair in Lisbon, their windows broken or boarded up, doors chained shut, plaster falling off the walls. We found one grand apartment complex in the tony downtown Com√©rcio district that was in bad shape. It bore a grey, mildewy banner advertising luxury apartments for sale, but obviously, the deal had gone sour years ago. No one had even bothered to pull down the embarrassing sign. (In case you are curious, the website displayed on the sign (below) no longer exists).
Clearly, Lisbon still has its challenges. One taxi driver told us the city is sinking due to last year‚Äôs prolonged drought. This sounded counter-intuitive, but he explained that the drought caused the water table beneath the city to drop. That exposed many of the old wooden pylons in the underground river that prop up the city from below. When the pylons began to dry out, they began to rot and weaken. Even though last year‚Äôs drought was ended by catastrophic floods in December, the damage has been done. As climate change persists, the problem will only get worse.
One afternoon I went out to drop off our laundry, and then decided to wander into the backstreets of the Bairro Alto neighbourhood. I decided that at each intersection I would simply take whatever turn went most steeply uphill. I zigged and zagged along quiet little backstreets, with the odd cafe on a corner or bakery shop, and then round the last corner I came to an open hilltop with a little park, two posh hotels, and a spectacular lookout. This turned out to be the Miradouro de Santa Catarina, a viewpoint that bore an optimistic message for all who made it up to the promontory:
Behind the viewpoint, in the center of the little park, a jagged rocky peak jutted up. No‚Äîon second glance it was a stone sculpture of a giant, his hair and beard wild as if in a tempest, his eyes bulging with fury. In front of him stood a small bronze man, with what I swear looked like a smartphone in his hands. His head looked up, as if he had just been texting and then discovered this menacing monster right in front of him.
Well, this was not a modern cautionary tale for our device-addicted times. A plaque identified the statue as Adamastor. It turned out to be a sculpture of a pivotal character in Os Lusiadas, a Portuguese epic poem written by Lu√≠s de Cam√µes the mid 1500s. The epic is to Portugal what the Odyssey is to Greece: a mythic rendering of Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama‚Äôs sea voyage to India in 1497‚Äîthe first such by any European. This was the voyage that marked the beginning of Portugal‚Äôs global empire and rise to power.
In the poem, da Gama and his crew must sail around the treacherous southern tip of Africa, then known as the Cabo das Tormentas, the ‚ÄúCape of Torment.‚Äù Suddenly the Titan Adamastor rises from the wild seas, blocking their passage. He is both the rock of the Cape itself, and an embodiment of the terror of the unknown. Indeed, sailors of that time really believed that monsters inhabited uncharted seas. In facing their fears and successfully rounding the cape, da Vasco‚Äôs crew proved they had the spirit Portugal needed to reach their destination and find their destiny. In both the poem and in real life, da Gama renamed this treacherous place ‚ÄúThe Cape of Good Hope.‚Äù
Standing on this magnificent viewpoint overlooking the ocean, I feel the aptness of that metaphor today, and not just for Portugal. Really for all of us. Adamastor looms. Do we have what it takes to face the terror of our future? I honestly don‚Äôt know. But I think we have got to look up from our phones and start paying attention! That sign, ‚ÄúYes, life is good,‚Äù feels a little less comforting.
No wonder for me this tattered yet pretty city never gets old. Just when I think I know my way around, Lisbon confronts me with a big existential question.

Lisbon may not be the first city that comes to mind for most people wanting to visit a European capital. However, don‚Äôt let this be a reflection on what the city has to offer. On the contrary, having been asked for pointers quite a few times over the years, I‚Äôve decided to compile a list of 7 things that are off the beaten path, absolutely worth doing should you visit or live there. These should give you a small taste of the potential that this three thousand year old city hides.
Lisbon has a 4km long aqueduct built in the 18th century. Many people know of the large arch that cuts across the Alc√¢ntara valley:
However, far less well known is the fact that it cuts deep into the city centre, and that you can walk inside it, and see some beautiful monuments on the way. This path is part of the City-wide ‚ÄúWater Museum‚Äù that is currently being developed and begins at the ‚ÄúM√£e d‚Äô√Ågua‚Äù, the largest water reservoir of the structure.
This gorgeous monument offers some great views of the city which I shall not spoil for you here. The next step is to head to nearby Pr√≠ncipe Real and head underneath the park into another reservoir, the Patriarcal.
This is where you can take a really pleasant guided tour along 4oom of tunnels that pass underneath the streets of the city.
At the time of writing, the tunnels lead all the way to the S√£o Pedro de Alc√¢ntara view point, where you can join other tourists. However, the city is currently expanding the length of tunnels accessible by foot.
Portugal does not have a rich history of beer. The Portuguese are well known for their love of wine, having some of the best bottles in the world produced there, and the Portuguese culture is built much more around wine that it is around beer. It is quite ordinary to see people drinking wine at lunch and dinner rather than beer, as is more common in Northern and Eastern Europe. Having said that, Lisbon and Oporto have jumped on the craft beer bandwagon with roaring success, and these local delicacies can be enjoyed at a variety of places throughout the capital. There is a great list of places here which I will summarise:
Update: Check out Musa in Marvila.
The reason Lisbon was built in its current location, and one of the main factors of its historical prominence, is the Tagus river delta. The Tagus is the longest river in the Iberian peninsula and its enormous reverse-delta is home to dolphins, flamingos and amazing views over the city. One of the best things to do in the city is to hop on a sail-boat and do a 2 hour cruise of the delta at sunset.
Lisbon is quite unique in comparison to the other European capitals when it comes to museums. You won‚Äôt find a Louvre, National Gallery, or Prado here. What you will find however, is a large amount of excellent small to mid-sized museums all over the city, catering to every taste. I‚Äôll spare the reader another long list and link to this blog which has a comprehensive one. To that list I‚Äôll add a couple more that should be at the top of your list:
2. Under-dogs Gallery ‚Äî Lisbon‚Äôs best street art gallery. It doesn‚Äôt limit itself to just street art, however:
Lisbon‚Äôs music scene is UGE as some might say. The city offers a regular serving of all types of genres, scenes and festivals all year round. The centuries-old multicultural environment has always been a fertile ground for original music output, and you can hear European, Brazilian, African, Indian and SE Asian music scenes come together in a setting unmatched anywhere else in the world.
A few highlights:
Venues:
Labels:
Events:
Special mention to this wine bar located inside one of the watering holes that used to quench the city‚Äôs thirst. Incidentally, it‚Äôs one of the end points of the aforementioned aqueduct, although this stretch isn‚Äôt accessible to the public (maybe try asking the owners of the wine bar).
With the largest amount of sunlight hours per year of any European capital, it‚Äôs only natural that Lisbon‚Äôs sunsets would live up to the city‚Äô sunny reputation. Great spots to enjoy these are:
Equally stunning are the sunrises from some of the nightclubs like Lux.
‚Äî
I hope this brief list gives you some idea of the huge amount of things to do there. If you have any more tips or have specific questions, feel free to leave them in the comments!

Title: Lisbon
Lisbon ‚Äî A City by the Waters
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up

Just a short flight from London is the city of Lisbon. The Portuguese capital has become hugely popular lately as a travel destination. With cute architecture, delicious cuisine and gorgeous views, it is no wonder why so many people are stopping by. A few days in Lisbon is a welcomed break, with sunshine and lots to see, do and eat. A perfect place for a weekend getaway!
Located on the West side of Portugal, the city‚Äôs airport is a travel hub for those flying in. In fact, I was surprised by the large size of the airport and the number of flights coming in from London, the rest of Europe and the States. TAP Portugal are aggressively expanding but has been relatively less heard of in the travel world. I was pleasantly surprised by the flights to and from London and would recommend flying with them when planning your visit it Lisbon. Added bonus is that the airline‚Äôs flight crew has been named most handsome crew!
Top tip for booking flights is to use sites such as Kayak to find the best deals.
Once you have landed, get yourself an Uber (referral) or try out Kapten (code) and head towards your hotel. Lisbon is a relatively small city, so a cab ride into the city is pretty affordable and quick! I am a big fan of using Airbnb when I travel and was so glad to have done so in Lisbon! I stayed at Joanna‚Äôs flat, where I had a large, comfortable and artsy room, in the quiet back streets of the city. It gave me a real taste of living like a local, where the hosts gave me loads of tips and recommendations. Their dogs and cats were super friendly too!
For those who haven‚Äôt had their first Airbnb experience, what are you waiting for?! Give it a go in Lisbon and you won‚Äôt be disappointed. Make sure to use my referral code and do loads of research on the property before you book. Those who have had bad experiences tend to forget to checkout the comments, reviews and photos! For those looking for more traditional accommodation, make sure to use sites like Booking.com, Agoda and even Hostelworld to get the best deals. Hotels are all pretty affordable in Lisbon, so choose one that is central and looks comfortable!
‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî -
Start your visit with a trip to the Time Out Market, an enormous food market in the centre of town serving up some unique and delicious dishes. The food hall is packed with restaurants and stalls, serving up some of the most incredible seafood, cold cut meats and delicious local dishes! Do be mindful that during peak hours, it might take a while to get a seat and table. Make sure to check out the store that only sells canned food!
Lisbon is famously known as the City of Seven Hills. This means that pretty much every corner or street you walk down, you will somehow end up walking up one of the hills. This also means that there are numerous lookout points around the city that all offer some incredible views! There is something mesmerizing about those tiled roofs, all in that gorgeous orange!
A walk around Lisbon and you will discover endless cute little streets, squares, monuments and beautifully decorated buildings. This makes getting lost a real treat!
For those who don‚Äôt fancy too much hill walking, take the famous Tram 28 and go for a little tour around town. It is a great way to get away from the heat while seeing loads of the city.
The best way to get to know a city is through a free walking tour! They are usually run by genuine people who know the city and you will end up only paying for what you want. These are normally tip based services and you quite literally decide how much the tour was worth at the end. I usually look for tours run by Sandeman‚Äôs- they are really enjoyable, dynamic and run by fun guides!
The tour gives you a deep understanding of the city‚Äôs history, local heroes, top spots and great tips for the rest of your stay in Lisbon. Some of my highlights were the oldest book store in the world, endless squares, the Santa Justa lift and some incredible city stories!
Just outside of the center of Lisbon is the historical area of Belem. You should spend at least half a day or a morning in this area. The first stop would be to get to Past√©is de Bel√©m early in the morning, before the queues start. This is the world most famous bakery shop that sells the best pastel de nata in town. It is freshly made in store and the queue gets really long. So definitely get there for their 8am opening. You cannot beat a hot pastry first thing in the morning, with a nice cup of coffee.
After your heavy and sweet breakfast, you could stop by the Palace and do a quick tour, or check out the Jer√≥nimos Monastery. I skipped the Palace and headed for the later, where I was met with a grand looking building with incredible interiors. This monastery was opened in 1495 and still has regular services.
The last part of the morning in Belem would be a nice gentle stroll down the riverside. You will first see Padr√£o dos Descobrimentos, a monument representing the concept of Portuguese exploration.
It is such a nice little walk along the river, with plenty of cafes and restaurants to sit at and people watch. Before you know it, you will have reached the Belem Tower, a medieval defensive tower that is worth stopping for photos. What a nice morning spent in Belem!
This neighborhood in central Lisbon is worth exploring and wondering around. It has this really nice vibe to it, with low buildings and lots of bars! Definitely a spot to pop by for some drinks! Wine lovers have to head to BA Wine Bar ‚Äî this is a cute little spot serving up some great local wines!
One of the best things I managed to experience in Lisbon was an intimate Fado performance. Fado is a music genre from 1820s and usually played by a small band with some very intense singing and usually portraying some very emotional and sad events. The songs are all in Portuguese but you can really feel the emotions from the music and the singing alone. It is an experience really worth having! So much emotion. I would suggest heading to Mascote da Atalaia in Barrio Alto the day before to book a spot for dinner the next day. The food is decent, there is this amazing sparkling white wine on tap and the music is just completely out of the world!
The last area of Lisbon worth mentioning is Alfama. During the day, the tiny and cobbled streets are filled with old grandmas shouting at each other and having a good time. At night, it is where all the bars and parties are at! This former red light district was ironically the only area in the whole of Lisbon that did not get destroyed during the last massive earthquake! You can walk down the streets at night and head into any bar, fado or restaurant, to really get a taste of Lisbon‚Äôs night life!
One of my favorite travel shows is Somebody Feed Phil. This short series is really centered around places to eat and is based around a city per episode. When Phil was in Lisbon, there was one restaurant that I just knew I had to go check out ‚Äî Ponto Final. A short ferry ride from the centre of Lisbon and you will be on the other side, with some of the best views of the city. About a 15 minute walk along the waters and you will come across this cute little restaurant literally on the side of the water! Make sure to call well in advance if you want a table on the edge. It is definitely worth it, especially with the view of the whole of Lisbon. Perfect while you feast on the freshest seafood ever ‚Äî grilled fish, octopus and all. I spent a ridiculous amount of time here for lunch (3 hours!). It was so relaxing with incredible food and great wine too! A definite must when in Lisbon.
For more traditional Portuguese or local food, there are two decent spots in town. One is Taberna da Rua das Flores, a super cute and artisan tavern-like contemporary restaurant. The food was seasonal, with black boards as menu. The staff are nice enough to point out each dish in detail and recommended things to try. Its like Portuguese tapas, sharing small plates and trying lots of different things! The dim lighting and vibe makes this place really intimate for dates as well!
Word of caution ‚Äî this place is very popular! I went at around 6pm and was asked to come back 1.5 hours later! It is a small place and it is fair enough. Pop your name down and then head next door to By The Wine for some quality local wines and snacks.
For a more traditional setting, try out Casa do Alentejo. This is an old palace that was built around the 17th century and contains some beautiful mosaics and interior designs. Finding the spot was a bit challenging but once inside from the busy high street, you enter into a tranquil courtyard and get absolutely transported into some Spanish or Moorish setting. I spent some time walking around just to see the place! The stairs and the interior were all really well designed and preserved.
Food was served upstairs and consisted of great local dishes from the Alentejo region, with the likes of lamb stews, pork loins and rabbit. What makes this place so special is the dining hall. One of the most incredibly designed places I have eaten at!
Peri Peri What? How can you come to Portugal and not try out the famous Peri Peri chicken? Rumour has it that Frangasqueira Nacional has the best chicken in town. This little take out spot is famous for the meat and runs out of chicken on most days! I was so looking forward to this but only to find out that it was closed on a bank holiday! Feeling gutted, I walked aimless around the empty streets to find an alternative. Luckily, I walked into a little park with a small spot for dinner. In a green house like building is Esplanada Cafe. This is such a cute spot with large open windows and is a perfect place to sit and sip wine and enjoy some gorgeous chicken! One of the most relaxed evenings I had in Lisbon!
Lisbon was such a lovely city to explore and enjoy. This is a perfect destination for a long weekend. Spend a few days in the city and you will be eating great seafood, getting lost in beautiful architecture and learning so much about the history and life of this great city! Stay tuned for my next post ‚Äî a day trip to Sintra!
Haven‚Äôt got that almighty travel backpack? Or in the market looking for the best mini suitcase? I got you covered with some of my go to travel essentials:

Posted: 10/28/2021 | October 28th, 2021
When I first went to Lisbon in 2012, I immediately fell in love with it. Hilly, colorful, beautiful, and full of wonderful food ‚Äî it was everything I wanted. And the fact that it was very inexpensive didn‚Äôt hurt either.
Pre-COVID, Lisbon‚Äôs secret got out. Tourists flocked here in droves, and it became a magnet for digital nomads. While the crowds are greater and the prices are higher than before, Lisbon‚Äôs charm hasn‚Äôt been fully lost. The food scene is still excellent (and underrated if you ask me). The bars are lively. And the street scene is always intoxicatingly fun.
Plus, compared to other capitals in Europe, Lisbon is still a bargain.
The city‚Äôs 11 neighborhoods all have their own unique characteristics, providing visitors with a wide variety of locales to choose from. From achingly charming Alfama to the always swinging Bairro Alto, there‚Äôs something for everyone.
But before we dive in, here are some of the most common questions I get about Lisbon:
What‚Äôs the best neighborhood for budget travelers? Baixa and Rossio are home to many of the city‚Äôs hostels, making it a good hub for budget travelers.
What‚Äôs the best neighborhood for families? Modern, somewhat futuristic-looking Parque das Na√ß√µes is loaded with family-oriented attractions, including the Oceanarium, Europe‚Äôs largest indoor aquarium.
What‚Äôs the best neighborhood for partying? Crammed with tiny bars and restaurants, Bairro Alto is the place to go at night in Lisbon.
What is the best neighborhood, overall? Alfama is a fun place to hang out for a while. It‚Äôs old (it survived the big earthquake of 1755) so it still has a timeworn atmosphere. And it‚Äôs the best place to pop into a bar to catch a fado concert.
So, with those questions answered, here‚Äôs a breakdown of seven neighborhoods with suggested accommodations for each:
Lisbon Neighborhood Overview
Located beneath the walls of S√£o Jorge (St. George) Castle, this hilly medieval district ‚Äî one of the oldest neighborhoods in Lisbon, along with nearby Alfama ‚Äî actually means ‚ÄúMoorish Quarter,‚Äù because it was once where the Moors resided centuries ago.
Today it has a large Asian population, who go about their daily lives in a neighborhood that oozes with charm and history: its winding cobblestone streets are flanked by medieval buildings. And one of its main historical reputations is that it is the birthplace of fado, a singular Portuguese genre of music that can best described as mesmeric and melancholy.
Best Places to Stay in Mouraria:
There wasn‚Äôt much to see here about three decades ago. Then the city deemed this eastern swath the home of Expo ‚Äô98, otherwise known as the World‚Äôs Fair, and the area was transformed into a modern, somewhat futuristic park. If you‚Äôre into contemporary architecture, this is the place for you. If you‚Äôre a traveling family, this is also the place for you. The area includes cable cars, Europe‚Äôs biggest aquarium, a waterfront promenade (with lots of great public art), and an interactive science museum. It‚Äôs also very quiet here.
The Best Places to Stay in Parque das Na√ß√µes
Literally meaning High or Upper Neighborhood, Bairro Alto oozes with tranquil Portuguese charm. Once the sun goes down, though, the party starts ‚Äî especially on Friday and Saturday nights, when there are street parties galore. Tiny bars spill out onto the sidewalks, candle-lit eateries serve up local staples, and people everywhere are just in party mode.
During the day, come for the outstanding viewpoints and the awe-inducing Baroque churches. At night, come to wander the narrow 16th-century streets and do a street-party crawl. But don‚Äôt wear out the soles of your shoes ‚Äî jump on the classic funicular (cable car, one of several the city is known for) up or down the hill.
The Best Places to Stay in Bairro Alto
Some of Europe‚Äôs most charming neighborhoods include Trastevere in Rome, Mala Strana in Prague, and Montmartre in Paris. Add Alfama to that list. It‚Äôs achingly charming, especially when you add in some fado ‚Äî Portugal‚Äôs heartbreaking, melancholic genre of music that you can hear everywhere in Alfama.
The neighborhood was one of the few districts that survived the infamous 1755 earthquake. So, stroll its narrow, hilly streets and get a sense of what pre-quake Lisbon was like. It‚Äôs also home to S√£o Jorge Castle, Lisbon Cathedral, and the decorative tile-loaded S√£o Vicente de Fora Monastery.
The Best Places to Stay in Alfama
Translated as ‚ÄúSodr√©‚Äôs Wharf,‚Äù this micro-neighborhood is dominated by the city‚Äôs main food market, Mercado da Ribeira, which today is also known as the Time Out Market. It‚Äôs a collection of stalls from some of Lisbon‚Äôs best restaurants and food purveyors and the place to go for food-loving travelers. The streets surrounding the market are flanked by various bars and restaurants, and street parties break out here seemingly 24/7.
At night, don‚Äôt miss Pink Street, a pink-painted pedestrian street teeming with fun-loving people every night of the week.
The Best Places to Stay in Cais do Sodr√©
This is the river meets history, where Vasco de Gama and Christopher Columbus embarked and disembarked. It‚Äôs where Portugal‚Äôs one-time powerful empire set sail for the rest of the world. Today Bel√©m is an aesthetically pleasing part of town that is also crammed with great museums. Be sure to check out the Museum of Art, Architecture, and Technology (MAAT), the Berardo Collection, the Folk Art Museum, the National Archeology Museum, and the Maritime Museum, not to mention the Jer√≥nimos Monastery.
Also, next to the monastery is Past√©is de Bel√©m, one of the best/busiest places in the city to get the famous past√©is de nata (egg custard tart).
Best Places to Stay in Bel√©m:
It‚Äôs not officially a neighborhood, but this long avenue has its very own vibe. Need some designer shoes? A designer handbag? A designer anything? This is the area to shop ‚Äôtil you drop. The long and wide Champs-√âlys√©es-like street is also a lovely place to stroll. And it‚Äôs all very parklike. While the verdant Avenida is bustling at times because of the traffic, it can be very tranquil too.
Where to Stay on Avenida da Liberdade:
These two neighborhoods make up much of the city‚Äôs main tourist core. Lined with pedestrian streets, there is a lot of Neoclassical architecture here, built after the massive earthquake in 1755. There are tons of eateries, as well as tacky souvenir shops to browse around the district, and the popular Museum of Contemporary Art can also be found here. Be sure to spend some time strolling around the popular Commerce Square.
***
Lisbon is a fascinating and underrated metropolis. It gets much less attention than other Western European capitals, but I think it should be on everyone‚Äôs must-see list. And if you‚Äôve already been, put it on your must-see-again list. It‚Äôs worth it.

It cuts out the fluff found in other guidebooks and gets straight to the practical information you need to travel and save money in Europe. You‚Äôll find suggested itineraries, budgets, ways to save money, on and off the beaten path things to see and do, non-touristy restaurants, markets, and much more! Book Your Accommodation You can book your hostel with Hostelworld as they have the biggest inventory and best deals. If you want to stay somewhere other than a hostel, use Booking.com as they consistently return the cheapest rates for guesthouses and cheap hotels.
Here‚Äôs a complete list of my favorite hostels in Lisbon.

Looking for the Best Companies to Save Money With? Check out my resource page for the best companies to use when you travel. I list all the ones I use to save money when I‚Äôm on the road. They will save you money when you travel too.
Need a Guide? Lisbon has some really interesting tours. My favorite company is Take Walks. They have expert guides and can get you behind the scenes at the city‚Äôs best attractions. Their Lisbon in a Day tour is a great way to see a lot if you‚Äôre on a tight budget!

Title: I Traveled From Barcelona to Lisbon by Train
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When we began planning to relocate to Portugal in 2022, I was excited for the opportunity to ditch my car and use public transit ‚Äî especially trains ‚Äî to get around.
And for the most part that's what we've done: we don't own a car, and we get around the center of Lisbon by public transit, with the occasional bit of frustration when a bus arrives late or a metro carriage is packed to the brim with commuters.
Comboio Portugal's trains can get you around most of Portugal without too much difficulty, but we were disappointed to discover that there were no easy routes out of Portugal and into Spain ‚Äî much less into the greater continental system of trains that crisscross Europe.
But what do I mean by an "easy route?"
The main issue is that ‚Äî due to a limited number of train schedules ‚Äî it is not possible to travel from one end of the peninsula to the other without an overnight stay somewhere near the middle. The limited number of departures ‚Äî and indeed the speed of the route itself ‚Äî mean that it's not possible to do even if you catch the first train out of Lisbon or Barcelona early in the morning.
Badajoz is a Spanish city in the ancient and contested border region of Extremadura (Estremoz in Portuguese). It‚Äôs a medium-sized city that seems to be well-accommodated, with historical relevance dating back to pre-Roman times.
But key to our attention is the fact that Badajoz is the current nexus of Portugal's train service, Comboio Portugal, and Spain's primary rail carrier, Renfe. Here the two services join at a small but functional station.
But your problems originating from Lisbon actually begin before you reach Badajoz, at a small city in Santar√©m called Entroncamento.
Entroncamento is where the relatively-fast Intercidades train service from Lisboa Oriente switches to the slow, frequently-stopping Regional service from Comboio Portugal. There are no direct trains from Lisbon to Badajoz, and you must switch at Entroncamento, with the same being true going the other direction.
The Regional service from Entroncamento is on a small, two-carriage train that makes 16 stops along the way and takes almost 3 hours to make the journey between Entroncamento and Badajoz. It's not entirely uncomfortable, but it is not fast, and the stops are frequent. But they are also some of the most charming stops along the route, and they offer some of the most beautiful vistas of Portugal's interior.
The leg from Badajoz to Madrid is likewise beautiful. It's accomplished on Renfe's Alvia service, and is much more comfortable than the journey between Badajoz and Entroncamento. The Alvia has comfortable, assigned seats, air conditioning, and a cafeteria car. It's much more like the Comboio Portugal Intercidades service, and it offers gorgeous views of Spain's snow-capped Sierra de Gredos mountains.
Gazing out the window of either the Renfe or CP trains, it's easy to imagine the Iberian countryside of Hemingway's cock and bull stories ‚Äî gentle brooks that wind past the ruins of old stone fences, among low-slung green hills dotted with the outlines of black bulls and cork trees. This scene blends uninterrupted on either side of the border for a 100km stretch, making it impossible to know which country you're in.
On the Portuguese side of the line, I saw a farmer with a plow yoked to a mule, manually plowing the soil with equipment that Iberian farmers have used for a thousand years. I could barely believe my eyes.
Our goal is to reach Barcelona, and we don't mind leaving on the earliest train out of Lisboa Oriente. And in all of our scenarios we will select the fastest services available.
That will be the 07:39 AM Intercidades (IC) departing from Lisboa's Oriente station. Oriente is a lovely station that's easy to navigate and can be reached from the Lisbon Metro's red line. The IC ride from Oriente to Entroncamento is the shortest leg of the entire journey, clocking in at a little under an hour and placing you there by 08:30 AM assuming everything goes right (it often does not on Comboio Portugal).
Here you have a few moments to top off snacks and water and locate your train to Badajoz. The Entroncamento station is pretty spartan and has limited facilities, so it's really best to get anything you'll need for the entire stretch to Badajoz before you leave Oriente.
In Entroncamento, you switch trains onto the slow-rolling and frequently-stopping Regional service departing at 09:06 AM. This train has two cars and unassigned bench seating. It's far from comfortable and at 3 hours it can be a test of patience.
By the time you roll into Badajoz at 12:54 PM you will have lost an hour crossing the Spanish border.
You will also need to find some way to occupy several hours, as the next train departing for Madrid is at 05:43 PM on Renfe's Alvia service.
Here is where a key decision emerges on your trip from Lisbon to Barcelona ‚Äî spend a long evening and night in Badajoz, waking the next morning to catch the first train to Madrid at 08:16 AM, or continue on to Madrid, arriving at 10:39 PM, where you will spend the night and have many options for reaching Barcelona the following day. Your choice basically comes down to: where would I rather sleep?
The good news, I suppose, is that 10:39 PM is a perfectly acceptable time to find a meal in Spain, where dinners often do not begin until 9:00 PM or later. But if you are already tired, Badajoz seems to have plenty to offer and ‚Äî at least as far as I can tell ‚Äî would not be a bad place to spend the night. And spending the night here would certainly allow you to eventually roll into Barcelona a little earlier in the day.
The leg from Badajoz to Madrid is a little under 5 hours whether you take the 08:16 AM or the 05:43 PM, but it is comfortable, with the Alvia offering assigned seats and both 1st and 2nd class carriages. There is a well-equipped cafeteria car and frequent trips up and down the aisles by the food cart.
Assuming that you decided to spend the night in Badajoz and take the 08:16 AM Alvia the following morning, you would arrive in Madrid a little past noon, and would then have many options for traveling on to Barcelona. All of them can be on Renfe's AVE high speed rail service, which was slightly nicer than the Alvia service and comparable to Comboio Portugal's Alfa Pendular high speed service.
This is the route I actually took a few weeks back. It was long ‚Äî and I made the trip hung over from a night of drinking with colleagues in Barcelona ‚Äî but it got me home.
As with the trip originating in Lisbon, we want to get as far as possible in a given day, so we don't mind leaving early. During my trip a few weeks ago, I intentionally chose a later train as I knew the earliest train out ‚Äî at 5:50 AM ‚Äî would be too early for me, and as we'll see in a moment, sacrificing sleep to get out as early as possible is not going to do anything for getting home faster when going west.
The AVE service is nice and fast, with comfortable seats that you can select in first and second class. I bought a first class seat because I wanted to be as comfortable as possible with a belly full of last night's cocktails ‚Äî not that it helped much as the train jostled from side-to-side as it chugged slowly out of the ancient Catalonian principality.
The countryside here looks a lot different than it does coming from the west, but during this time of the year it was beautiful. Fruit orchards (I couldn't tell if they were cherries, plums, peaches, or some other variety of stone fruit blossoms) were in full bloom, creating rows of pink and white blossoms that striped the countryside all the way to Madrid.
The AVE service should drop you in Madrid at a very respectable 9:10 AM. But the problem is that on most days, there are only two trains departing Madrid for Badajoz: 8:30 AM and 4:17PM. And you've already missed one of them.
So you must again ask yourself where you'd prefer to spend the night.
Even though it feels like you haven't made it very far, there's a strong case to be made for spending an evening in Madrid vs. Badajoz. Madrid is a major city with many restaurants and attractions that can be used to blow your time. It's almost worth it just to exit the train station here so you can see the beautiful edificio of Madrid's Puerta de Atocha railway station. But there are also museums, parks, the botanical gardens, and more just a short distance from the station.
I chose to spend the night in Madrid and got a small room near the train station so that I could pull out on the first train to Badajoz the next morning. Given the hangover, I did not do any sightseeing. But you're smarter than me and won't have that particular problem. Right? I did eat some of the worst croquettes I've ever had that night.
Sorry Spain ‚Äî Portugal's are just better.
That first train leaves at 8:30 AM, and at least for me, navigating the train station was a little confusing, so I suggest leaving yourself enough time to figure out how to get to the right train. The arrival and departure terminals are in separate buildings, so make sure you go to the right one.
The Alvia train to Badajoz is fine, with all of the amenities you need to be comfortable, but with slightly less-comfortable seats than the AVE even in first class. It speeds along just south of Spain's Sierra de Gredos mountains. With their snow-capped peaks, they make for a gorgeous backdrop to the aforementioned cow pastures and cork trees. It's a little like Texas hill country, but with some very serious hills.
By the time you reach Badajoz at 1:34 PM in the afternoon you will have made a 5 hour haul across the Iberian peninsula, but it places you in Badajoz with enough time to catch the trains on to Lisbon, where you will pick up an hour as you cross the border.
The first train to Portugal departs at 2:09 PM in the afternoon, so you have a bit of time to get snacks and water before moving on. If you miss it, there's another train to Lisboa Oriente station at 7:41 PM, but it obviously puts you in Lisbon much later at night (after 10:00 PM). This may not matter as much for a tourist, but as I was eager to get home to my family, my calculations were always focused on getting home as early in the day as possible.
Both services require taking the slow moving Regional service to Entroncamento ‚Äî the reverse of what I described in the first westward-bound trip ‚Äî and switch to an Intercidades service for the final leg of the journey to Lisbon's Oriente Station.
The Regional service to Entroncamento sits on an inconspicuous track that's on the perimeter of the main platforms. It's clearly labeled as a Comboio Portugal train, and when we arrived I assumed it was the train I needed to board. But we were made to enter the terminal anyway, and not permitted to re-enter the platform until its scheduled departure.
The Regional service to Entroncamento also departed late, but the conductor mostly made up the time during the trip. It was interesting to observe the people getting on and off along this route. Many of its stops were extremely rural, and I saw a mixture of different commuters: cyclists fully-decked in their cycling gear who brought bicycles aboard and got off after a few stops, grannies with grocery bags in either hands who rode the train for just one stop, and younger folks who looked like they were taking the full ride for a weekend of partying in Lisbon. Sometimes the conductor stepped out to help the older passengers on or off the train with their grocery bags or boxes, and it was easy to imagine that this cast of regulars were people he knew well and saw multiple times a week.
We arrived about 10 minutes late and discovered that CP had held the outbound train to Lisbon, allowing us to board and make the 4:52 PM arrival time in Lisbon.
This was much to the current passengers' consternation, but much to my relief and gratitude.
While I'm glad I made the cross-peninsular trip by train, it's not something I would want to do regularly. Nor, perhaps, would I want to do it with a large family and lots of luggage in tow.
But if you have a few days to burn and nowhere better to be, and you don't mind a slow moving tour of the Iberian countryside, this is an excellent option.
I should point out that overall the cost of the trip was actually comparable to a round-trip airline ticket. The Portuguese leg of the trip comes out to about ‚Ç¨25 one way. The leg between Portugal and Madrid is another ‚Ç¨45. And a first class ticket on the AVE between Madrid and Barcelona, in either direction, comes out to about ‚Ç¨119. This is all in one direction.
If cost is your limiting factor ‚Äî and especially travel time ‚Äî air travel makes more sense.
But there are plenty of good reasons to take the train if you can: reduced environmental impact, the ability to get up and walk around to stretch your legs and take in views, choices for food and drink in the cafeteria cars, and beautiful views of the countryside are all compelling reasons to consider travel-by-train. And while the trains (at least in Spain) require you to run your bags through a screening process, it was nothing compared to the headache that is air travel in the year 2025.
I'd like to see more options for getting places by rail, so I try to take the trains whenever it's feasible. My hope is that the more we use trains, the more countries see the demand for expanded routes and increased optimization in existing routes.
While I might not take this route frequently, I'm at least comfortable in the implications that it brings and can pack and plan accordingly. And if you believe the hype, plans are in the works to bring high speed service between Lisbon and Madrid. If accomplished, this would result in something like 3 hours of travel time between the peninsula's capitals and would make getting on to Barcelona in a day an easy feat.
But I'm afraid the Portuguese cynicism for major works like this has already worn me down, and I'm not expecting this to be the case any time soon.
Even if I don't plan on going from coast to coast, I know I can make it from capital to capital in a single day, and that's a thing I might try to do more often now that I've done it once.
And maybe at some point, I'll make the cross-peninsula trek and just keep going ‚Äî into France and the heart of Europe. But that's a feat for someone with way more time on their hands than me right now.

When you think of finding your way around in places that are unknown, you rely on GPS and your phone to help you get there. Back in 2016, when I was exploring Lisboa (Lisbon), Portugal, I found myself in the Alfama district. It‚Äôs one of the oldest neighborhoods in the city and possibly one of the most confusing places you could be in.
As I walked through the neighborhood, I found myself lost in a seemingly endless maze of narrow, winding staircases and hidden alleys. Without the help of GPS or the internet, I had to rely on my sense of direction to find my way around. Turns out, that sense was non-existent.
Despite feeling completely disoriented, exploring Alfama was an adventure in itself. Around every turn, I found unexpected surprises: charming courtyards, hidden plazas, and laundry drying in the sun. It was like I had stepped back in time, and I was happy to be lost in this labyrinth.
Eventually, I managed to find my way back to civilization, but I wouldn‚Äôt have regretted getting lost in Alfama. Navigating through the district‚Äôs twisting streets turned out to be a memorable experience.
Exploring Alfama district is an unforgettable experience of getting lost in a labyrinthine of narrow streets and it‚Äôs one of the most interesting neighborhood designs I‚Äôve ever seen. After all, getting lost in such an ancient area is not a bad thing, but a chance to explore its wonders one inch at a time.

Title: What You Need to Know About Lisbon‚Äôs Culture of Illegal Chinese Restaurants
Content:

Lisbon is one of the most beautiful cities in Europe and Portugal‚Äôs main centre of education, economy and culture. Its picturesque alleys of Bairro Alto and the fancy boulevards from Rossio to Tejo are just a fraction of places to go and see during the day. And by night, you‚Äôll hear traditional Fado tunes coming out of every bar, inviting you to join the vibrant nightlife. Lisbon‚Äôs atmosphere is overall an exciting mix of fast-paced city life and Mediterranean flair that provides the needed balance between work and life.
But when you go off the usual streets and places full of tourists, you may experience a whole different side of Lisbon, one that isn‚Äôt mentioned in any common guide and for outsiders quite difficult to access. Without knowing the right places beforehand, it‚Äôs practically invisible. I talk about Lisbon‚Äôs rising underground scene of secret Chinese restaurants.
‚ÄúYou probably mean the ‚Äûillegal‚Äú Chinese. There are three of them close to Martim Moniz. One at the end of the street Beco da Oliveira and two are in a building in street Rua do Terreirinho (number 40 if I remember correctly).‚Äù ‚Äî Henning, Erasmus Student from Lisbon on Hubble
The most prominent spot for such restaurants is around the metro station Martim Moniz in the neighborhood of Mouraria. They are often hidden in apartment buildings and back alleys, and the more you proceed into the side streets of Mouraria, the creepier it gets.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not pretty sure about the name of the restaurant but I think it is Chin√™s Clandestino. As the name says, it is a clandestine restaurant, so it‚Äôs like a secret spot to have a nice meal. Here you have the address: Mouraria ‚Äî Rua da Guia, 9, 2 Dto, Mouraria, Lisboa. Have fun!‚Äù ‚Äî Daniela, World Citizen on Hubble
The friendly and colorful Lisbon you once knew (well, a few minutes ago) is gone. Streets are plastered with garbage instead of the azure blue Azulejo tiles. Now, heated discussions in all kinds of languages come in place of the relaxing, traditional melodies from the Old Town. You would love nothing more than to turn around, hop onto the metro back to Bairro Alto and quickly forget about your unsuccessful adventure, but the goal is already within your reach. You can‚Äôt go back now, can you?
‚ÄúThere are two in Rua do Benformoso 59. Just knock on the door on the 1st floor or try the one on the 2nd floor.‚Äù ‚Äî Nanxi, Foodie on Hubble
You wind up standing in front of a slightly rundown house. The door is open most of the time and leads to a dark hallway. It feels like you‚Äôre in a movie‚Ä¶No, not the one‚Äôs with a happy ending. You dare to go upstairs. The smell of food fills your nose but the fear of getting kidnapped and waking up tomorrow without a kidney is the only thing you can think of.
Nervously, you read the number of the apartment where you have to go from a little, crumpled-up piece of paper which you got from your Airbnb host. It‚Äôs the right place. You gather all your courage and knock on the door. You regret it, why did you even come here, you should have gone to McDonal ‚Äî ‚Ä¶ Suddenly, an old, Asian lady opens the door and invites you warmly in. Although you don‚Äôt understand a word, it feels like everyone is very kind to you. Maybe this isn‚Äôt so bad at all. At least your organs are safe.
In the restaurant, it‚Äôs a completely different world. A bit modest, but clean, traditional and cozy. A few people are having dinner, others play ancient board games. The old lady sits down and continues to watch a TV show while you proceed to one of the 8 tables in total. There‚Äôs no pressure. You sit down, choose a meal and after all the stress you get rewarded with incredible amounts of tasty food at a good price. Regular restaurants have nothing on the unmatched dishes and familiar vibe. It‚Äôs like you would eat at your grandparent‚Äôs home, well if your grandparents should be from Asia and‚Ä¶ I mean you get it.
I can‚Äôt recommend those places enough. Instead of going to the same locations over and over again, you should try one of these secret restaurants. It‚Äôs an exciting part of everyday life in Lisbon and when you want to see its true nature while having a cheap night-out, this is it!

Title: Lisbon‚Äôs Quiosques Helped Me Rediscover Backgammon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Portugal  Calling is a new publication on Medium managed by a Portuguese editorial team featuring a wide range of topics about life, language, and Portuguese culture.

--
3
Listen
Share
Like most children, when I was very little, there were things in our house that I was not allowed to touch. Things like the grandfather clock in our living room, which I was told would fall over on me. Or the record player, which I actually did touch, and did break the stylus on, and which never worked again. And of course common dangerous kitchen things like the stove, oven, or kitchen knives.
But of all the things I was not allowed to touch, the weirdest and seemingly most harmless one was a small, gray, leather-bound case that my mom kept in her room. It was about the same size as one of our encyclopedias, but thinner, and had a handle for carrying. The brass latches kept both sides of the case firmly closed. At the time, it felt like the perfect child-sized suitcase for pretending I was going on a trip somewhere. ‚ÄúAloha! I‚Äôm off to Hawaii with my cool little suitcase!‚Äù, I might‚Äôve pretended. Except that I definitely was not allowed to use this little case as a prop.
But within this tantalizing little case was something special to my mom. Something she worried I would either damage, or lose the pieces to, or spill something on, or maybe she just thought I‚Äôd swallow a piece. It was a backgammon board; a game my mom would later reveal to me in the hopes of having a partner for playing. But she would be disappointed, as it turned out, because backgammon is kind of confusing for a kid.
While we tried to play a few times, most of our games ended in mutual frustration, and for the time being I decided backgammon was boring and not something I wanted to learn to play.
The trajectory of gaming for me was not a straight line from my first encounter with backgammon to rediscovering it decades later. As a kid I played a lot of the basic Milton Bradley and Parker Bros. stuff ‚Äî Monopoly, Trouble, Guess Who, Clue ‚Äî and as I entered my junior high years I began playing tabletop role playing games. During weekends in high school, I would go to a tennis meet, then head to a friend‚Äôs house at Fort Polk where half of our team would engage in UNO or Risk and the occasional groan-inducing session of Axis and Allies.
It wasn‚Äôt until I was in early college, and I met my friend Lyle, that I got into what were then called ‚ÄúEuropean-style board games‚Äù: Ticket to Ride, Puerto Rico, Game of Thrones, and more. The vast world of tabletop gaming ‚Äî with its myriad choices of engines, strategies, settings, and pleasant little game pieces ‚Äî opened up to me and hooked me. It was revelatory.
After I got married in 2010, I introduced my wife to the world of adult board games, and she got into them as well. By 2012, we were hosting weekly game nights at our house in Atlanta. My wife would prepare a delicious meal for everyone, and we‚Äôd kick things off with a warmup game like Citadels, Epic Spell Wars of the Battle Wizards (we lovingly call this game Wizards of Skullfuck Mountain because none of us could be bothered to remember the name), or something else that played quickly. Then we‚Äôd eat, and get into the real main course ‚Äî a good multiplayer board game‚Äî which might last for 2‚Äì3 hours.
This went on for many years until the complications of life finally intruded on everyone, and we had a kid.
Around the same time in 2012, I was being introduced to the ancient Asian strategy game of Go by a coworker. I was fascinated by the simplicity of the game, but continuously challenged by its complex strategies. At this point I was mostly dabbling ‚Äî we‚Äôd play a few games on a mobile app each week, but eventually I changed jobs, we lost touch, and I didn‚Äôt think about Go for a while.
Then in 2014, I got an itch to play Go again, and got a physical Go board and pieces and brought them to work. I sat it on my desk and friends and I would take turns playing throughout the day. One day an outside consultant I had hired walked by my desk and noticed our Go board and revealed that he was deeply into Shogi and Go. This let to a renewed interest in Go for myself, and an introduction to the intricacies and deep strategies of Go for some of my coworkers. While some of them got deeply into it (one of them is now the head of Atlanta‚Äôs Go Club and a highly-ranked player), I played occasionally but did not invest a lot of time in practicing. Consequently, I am not very good at Go but I still love the game.
Fast forward to 2024. I still love games. And our daughter does too. Among her favorites are Splendor, Azul, Ghost Blitz, and chess. A lot of my free time in Lisbon is spent sitting at the park quiosque reading, writing, and drinking a cold beer on a nice day. While the kid runs circles around the quiosque with her friends climbing trees and playing tag, my wife and I sit at the quiosque‚Äôs small tables making small talk, looking at our phones, or planning out the week‚Äôs activities. Sometimes friends join us, and when they do there is plenty of good conversation to keep our brains occupied. But when it's just us, it's nice to have something to do beyond just chatting.
This got me thinking about small games to occupy ourselves. It's not unusual to see people playing cards, but I don't love the way cards occupy your hands, and I honestly don't really enjoy most of the two-player card games. I thought about Go, but I have consistently failed to get my wife interested in Go, and with its hundreds of small pieces, it could make for a real mess if the kit came open accidentally or a pigeon decided that one of the pieces looked particularly tasty. Then I thought about dice, but I don't know any simple games involving dice.
But then a thought entered my mind: what about backgammon?
Backgammon has its own portable case and is available in very small form-factors.
Backgammon is for two players.
Backgammon has limited pieces to lose.
Backgammon has a relaxed pace, and allows your hands to be free to smoke or drink.
But what I couldn't remember is anything about playing it, so I started doing some reading and watching some videos and realized that backgammon was actually pretty easy to learn, but that there was ample room for strategy. Things clicked and finally fell into place for me, and I thought that I'd like to order a small backgammon set to try.
I found what appeared to be a nice, travel-sized set on Amazon Espanha: a travel set from Yellow Mountain. As we had a trip coming up to Alcaide for the Festa de Cogumelos, I knew my wife and I would have an opportunity to play for a few days: during our time relaxing at the hotel.
For two people on the move wanting to learn to play, it was a good set. The Yellow Mountain set is probably overpriced, but it‚Äôs nice for anyone looking for a travel-sized board. When fully opened it lays flat on a table, has a felt game board, and the checkers are magnetized, making it easier to keep up with them. It comes with a set of backgammon rules. My only real complaint is that the miniature dice feel cheap, and that the magnetized checkers sometimes make them hard to stack.
After our arrival at the hotel, we sat in the lounge and played for several hours while we had drinks and snacks. I explained the basics of the game to my wife and she quickly caught on.
Since then, we‚Äôve played hours of backgammon while we're at the quiosque, but we have also started playing more at home. We are having a great time challenging each other and figuring things out for ourselves. It‚Äôs so nice to have an interesting, casual game to play while we hang out at the quiosque. I‚Äôm looking forward to having it this coming spring and summer.
And there's a lot of strategy that we have yet to discover. We didn't begin using the doubling cube ‚Äî a dice that effectively lets both players bet on the outcome of the game in order to win more points ‚Äî though we eventually added it into play and have slowly started to increase the number of points needed to win a game (we're up to 9 points now). But the doubling cube absolutely adds another element of strategy to the game.
Neither of us has yet to score a gammon or backgammon, which occurs when one player manages to "bear off" all of their pieces out of their home board before the other player has a single piece in. Most of our games wind up being very close, and I'm confident there are strategies we are overlooking for blocking each other from scoring. The defining moment of each game is always when one of us gets our last piece past the last opponent on the board, at which time it becomes a race to bear off all of our pieces.
For Christmas, my wife bought me a nice, handmade home board from a Greek company called Manopoulos ‚Äî it's gorgeous and the pieces and game board are so satisfying to hold and touch! It's too big for the quiosque, but that's okay. It's a wonderful board to use at home and we look for any opportunity to pull it out and play a few rounds. It‚Äôs something that will be in our family for years.
And you know what? I‚Äôll probably let my daughter touch it, though thus far she has shown little interest in backgammon after watching us play many rounds.
I‚Äôm glad I remembered that little suitcase from my childhood, and that my mom at least tried teaching me a game that ‚Äî although I didn‚Äôt find interesting at the time ‚Äî I would remember later in life. It at least made backgammon a possibility in my mind and made it an option to consider when I was looking for a casual, portable, strategic, two-player boardgame.
I think my mom would be happy to know that I rediscovered backgammon and learned how to play. And I'm glad I did! The gameplay is the perfect pace for nice days at the quiosque.
And when she eventually returns to Lisbon for a visit, I look forward to surprising her with my knowledge of backgammon, and playing a few games with her at the quiosque over a cold beer.

Content:

21st August 2013 Lisbon, Portugal
The ship‚Äôs engine whirled, shook and rattled to a stop as outside, the crew scuttled about to pull thick ropes around the metal structures on Lisbon‚Äôs port to hold the cruise ship in place for the day. The sun‚Äôs rays enveloped the entire city from the top of the mountains, over brightly-coloured houses all in pastel, before reaching over one magnificent church standing tall at sea level.
‚ÄúLisbon was a city full of history and culture. Many buildings and markets were kept as it was a hundred years before, portraying the old ways of life.‚Äù
We went ashore after having breakfasted on the ship and rode a century-old tram around different city quarters, with assurance from the driver that this tram line was used as regular transportation in the city.
The tram climbed up steep hills and slid down narrow alleyways as if following a secret passageway that only our driver knew of. We passed the old quarter with houses worn down and looking like slums, but still had beautiful glazed tiles in their facÃßade that were used immensely as decoration in the olden days, giving blue, green, turquoise and red patterns to entire buildings, making them stand out from their plain, pastel-coloured neighbours.
As the tram rattled past the main train station, it occurred to me why the architecture looked a little bit like home. Coming from Thailand, I was familiar with the fact that Portuguese culture influenced a lot of Thai culture during the time of King Rama V (in the 19th century), where the King had commissioned Portuguese architects to design many buildings during the time of his reign. One of the locals explained that the king of Thailand indeed came to visit Lisbon once, meeting the King of Portugal in the very same train station that our tram moved past.
We reached a huge open square surrounded by magnificent white columns of the city‚Äôs biggest theatre, the monument of King John of Lisbon atop a horse, as well as the palace walls that ran along the length of the square. The tram stopped long enough for all of us to have a glass of port wine and a Portuguese egg tart (past√©is de nata).
‚ÄúPort was traditionally drank after a meal in Portugal, a habit taken up by the British people, but twisted by the French: they enjoyed their glass of the sweet red port as an aperitif before meals.‚Äù
This Portuguese pastry was also familiar to us Thais ‚Äî creamy egg tart with a consistency similar to that of creÃÄme bruleÃÅe, encased in a crispy, flaked pastry shell sold at the side of the roads. But the Portuguese version has a touch of cinnamon, which gave the tart a special and more complex aroma and flavour. The combination of freshly made, warm egg tart and cool, smooth port is thoroughly enjoyed in Portugal as a breakfast pastry or mid-afternoon snack with coffee.
One of the most famous places to try these gloriously crunchy, buttery tarts in Lisbon is at Past√©is de Bel√©m
A caf√© stood in the corner of the square, where one of the locals pointed out to us that it has been operating there since the 1700s. It was mid-morning, but the caf√© was packed with customers having coffee and a golden, thread-like dessert called Fios de Ovos . Another familiar sight, this dessert is thought by many to originate from Thailand and called Foi-Thong (golden thread), however it was the Portuguese that first made it.
The dessert was another Portuguese delicacy which was shared by many far Eastern cultures when the Portuguese explorer, Vasco da Gama, sailed across the Indian Ocean and created a new trade route in the 15th century.
The tram started up again, winding its way down to a huge moastery that stood close to the harbourside, its walls running 500 metres across the gardens in front, close to the sea. If you came to Lisbon, this was a must-see sight as the monastery was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1983. Inside the dome-like structure which loomed high above us, were altars of Jesus Christ and tombs of the king and queen. The main altar was of European influence, with paintings of the Lord, Mother Mary from the Renaissance period, but the tombs of the long-gone royals were supported by Indian elephants, showing further the fascination with Oriental cultures the king of Portugal at the time had. Inside this church also lay the tomb of the explorer Vasco da Gama.
Lisbon is a big city and half a day of exploring was simply not enough.
