Title: Lisbon, Portugal ‚Äî Heaven on Earth
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Having been woken up by an unpleasant noise I hear every morning Monday through Friday, I peeked at the darkness still reluctant to get up and saw nothing but furniture shapes. This time, I was quite thrilled to kick off the day because in just a few hours I would walk the streets of a city I never thought I‚Äôd visit.
Fast forward a couple of hours, a few airport checks and check-ins and one transit flight and I was finally there. Oh yes, and my arm was sore from carrying a few suitcases (thanks to my girlfriend), with that feeling of exhaustion as if coming home after a whole day‚Äôs work and a mediocre meal and no leg space for a 190-cm guy which caused me to twist and turn in my seat. But that‚Äôs the economy class ticket benefit you don‚Äôt get anywhere else. It is the airport company‚Äôs fault but I do often get ‚Äî ‚ÄúWell, why are you that tall?‚Äù
Other than these minor inconveniences, the flight was good. I was here. Stepping out of the plane and walking for a change was a true remedy. I heard a whispering ‚ÄúThank you‚Äù from my back and knees as I was willowing towards an airport exit.
Outside, palm trees dwarfed every building around it as they stood proudly, defying gravity. Above, the clear sky was chasing away the dark clouds that gathered in the night to water the city. They knew Lisbon was awaiting guests. The air was quite refreshing and it filled my lungs with energy after every breath. Comparing it to the cold Belgrade air, which is best felt with the scarf wrapped around your mouth, was pointless. It was a true marathon to get to the destination, yet I was more than eager to get the tour started. I couldn‚Äôt wait to see what the city had to offer.
The spring sun was shining bright. It is one of those days where you take your jacket with you, but it is warm enough during the day and you don‚Äôt need it. If you sit down, you can feel the wind creeping up your shirt sleeves, giving you goosebumps. So with my jacket on and off and on and off again, I was strolling the old parts of Lisbon.
Each building, house and structure of any kind, whether historical or not was a story for itself thanks to the bright blue, yellowish and white tiles covering it. The tiles, called azulejos, were used as decoration, but also to protect the buildings from the salty river and ocean air. It is the first thing that catches the eye, together with different kinds of tiles laid under your feet. Those painted pictures of ships, seas, winds and other things on the squares, streets, and sidewalks.
Walking through the city street I was faced with the dilemma to look down and up, as vibrant colors were everywhere with tiles reflecting the sun, giving you the warm and cozy feeling of familiarity and admiration.
It took me a while to fight against the hilly terrain to get to what I consider to be the main square ‚Äî Praca do Comercio. It offers a marvelous view of the Tagus river which shows its full power exactly at this place, pushing the coast to the sides, stretching out as much as possible. One might be tricked to consider this to be the sea, partly due to the pleasant breeze coming at you. However, it is just the spot where you can see the full power and potential of nature, as the river narrows down a bit further ‚Äúdown the road‚Äù before it collides with the vastness of the cold and blue Atlantic. Seagulls are flying around, their song mixing with the people murmur and tram‚Äôs racket.
A few tiny white sails were seen on the river, while across, the remaining parts of the city are calling you to explore them, with much more greenery and sparse buildings.
The welcoming atmosphere invites you to sit on the curb, even in one of the surrounding cafes and just soak in everything around you. And that‚Äôs what I did. The sounds, the smells the view. It is all one needs to know about a city to recognize its soul, and it didn‚Äôt take me long to see Lisbon as my own.
As the sun retreats, the tiredness due to miles of walking and exploring caught up with me again, but just like upon the arrival, it was mixed with pleasure and peace.
And the sunsets‚Ä¶true Lisbon colors show up, the ones you cannot see during the day. With the remains of the day, the rush is over and satisfaction is painted on every face you encounter, tourist or local.
Sleep catches with you quickly when you lie down. I cannot remember what happened, but it was morning again. And that awful alarm sound, although it felt better this time. Getting down to the hotel lobby by elevator felt a bit painful due to aching in my legs, yet there was no choice. The city was calling me out to turn every corner, see every tile and smell the air from hills and valleys.
Alfama is a city within a city. I decided to walk across it and it was a mistake from the start. Uphill and downhill terrain made this area specific, with no flat parts. To me, it all seemed uphill, especially after a few hours. Luckily, you can get on the vintage yellow tram which is one of the symbols of the city and ride up, before you get off and walk uphill. Again. Endless elevation. And just like the other areas, Alfama is colorful and vibrant but there‚Äôs something special about it, something mysterious that I couldn‚Äôt define.
My stomach started complaining, which meant that the entire itinerary changed and the first place I wanted to get to was the restaurant. Suddenly, all those historical places became ‚Äúmeh‚Äù as human biology stepped in.
Lisbon is a perfect city for fish lovers. Fish is all over the menus and all I desired at that point was salmon ‚Äî and boy, oh boy, it was terrific. Add a squeeze of lemon on top of it, with a fresh salad as the side dish and it is a perfect combination. No bones to pick just a light yet fulfilling meal.
While all of that was happening, a fado trio was playing the background, a local band, performing here and there, and it was all that was missing. They hit the right note as the sun was setting over Alfama.
The moment I landed at the Belgrade airport, I was happy to be home, yet sadness filled my inner being. The city was grey and colorless, with people rushing all over the place, going in the wrong direction. It was cold outside and the cold reached all the way to my bones. I already missed the sunny hillsides and building tops, the uneven grounds and the atmosphere which seemed to be more welcoming.
I was back in my everyday routine. Yet, on every cloudy and misty day, I remember the Lisbon sun, shining bright!
Until we meet again!

Title: A Meaningful Run ‚Äî How the Lisbon Marathon Made a Difference
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
With the sun beating down on me and a temperature of over 28¬∞C, I see a fellow runner lying on the curb being attended to by first responders. I check my watch and decide to stop once again at the next water station. This is going to be much tougher than I expected‚Ä¶
My journey to the 2017 Lisbon Marathon started in the winter of 2015. I was busy assembling IKEA furniture when I was struck by a burning pain in my knee that refused to go away. For the next few days it continued to get worse and every small stair suddenly became a major challenge. Finally, I decided to see an orthopedist. I never really liked (or had much reason) to see a doctor, but I had just turned 45, my girlfriend Anna was pregnant with our daughter and I figured getting it checked out would be the responsible thing to do.
The visit ended with a referral for an MRI that led to a nasty surprise. The cartilage in my knees was considerably damaged. These injuries had been looming for some time as I continued to ignore the warning signs. The diagnosis was clear. I would now be required to get a sodium hyaluronate injection directly into my knee joints every 6 months just to ease the pain. An injection with a price tag of $750 that isn‚Äôt covered by any health insurance. To add insult to injury, the doctor casually said, ‚ÄúLook, you may be able to go for a 5-kilometer jog, and you should do that regularly, but nothing longer. Take it easy, you will never be able to run a marathon, so don‚Äôt bother trying.‚Äù These comments resonated in me for a long time. I never even considered running a marathon ‚Äî until this very moment.
I have always seen myself as a member of the running community, but frankly, my laps through the park had become less frequent over the years. There was the occasional spring onset of daily runs that lasted for about a month, but they were never farther than 5 to 10k. The longest distance I had ever run was a 25k race but that was only once and it was over 20 years ago. So, I could have been content with injections twice a year and back to a rather normal life. Only that I wasn‚Äôt.
The most urgent issue I wanted to focus on was the pain. I started reading a lot about treatment options and I decided to try something other than getting needles jammed into my knees. After a bit of experimentation, I found that taking a high dose daily (2000 mg) of glucosamine sulphate was starting to help me. Later, I added omega 3 and collagen to the mix. After a couple of weeks the burning sensation went away. I had indeed found an alternative for my battered knees.
Please bear with me, in one of my former lives I was also a lawyer: This is what worked for me, but no medical advice whatsoever is intended.
The following year I wasn‚Äôt really prioritizing my running career. Throughout all of 2016, I covered a total distance of less than 60 km in twelve runs. Yes, I had a lot of other things on my plate, with a newborn baby, being CEO of Berlin‚Äôs Innovation Agency and everything else. At least I was sticking to the doctor‚Äôs advice when it came to the part of ‚Äútaking things easy‚Äù with my knees. But I had a growing sense that I was missing something. I was somehow able to manage getting everything done ‚Äî but I was also realizing that I was losing my edge.
New Year‚Äôs Eve is always a great time for resolutions. In the years past, I must admit (and you can probably relate), these intentions were rather short-lived. But this time I was hell-bent to make a change for real. So I came up with something that seemed utterly beyond reach: For 2017 I resolved to run a marathon. And to make things more interesting, I didn‚Äôt even consider the Berlin Marathon in my hometown. I was looking for a venue with added value. I soon found Lisbon, the Portuguese capital, located at the River Tagus and the Atlantic Ocean, one of the most fascinating cities in Europe. With the race scheduled for October 15th, this would leave me enough time to find out if my knees would keep up with my ambitions.
The first thing I did was to read about marathon training. There are many manuals and programs out there. The takeaway lesson was: Run frequently, consistently including workouts for speed, stamina, and mobility and run a reasonable number of longer runs that should include a 30+ km run in the weeks before the event. This means you must spend a lot of time and you must spend it regularly. Marathon training is an exercise in discipline and commitment, that much I realized. Wait, I only had time for two handfuls of recreational runs in 2016 and (what I thought to be) insufficient sleep due to our baby‚Äôs somewhat erratic sleep patterns, a demanding job and, last but not least, a relationship to cherish. Sounds like something straight from the playbook of Mission Impossible, doesn‚Äôt it?
Nevertheless, I came up with a plan. I set 2 milestones that would serve as my intermediate goals: The 10k City Night race in Berlin on July 29th along the famous Kurf√ºrstendamm Boulevard and the Stadtlauf Berlin half marathon on August 20th. If I could complete both within a reasonable time and my knees would be functional afterwards I would book the flights to Lisbon. After registering for both races, I started running 5 kilometers on January 3rd along the icy shores of Schlachtensee Lake, which would become my favorite route for the next couple of months.
With the marathon still in the ‚Äúdistant‚Äù future, the winter runs that followed were a bit sporadic. Eventually I had to figure out how to fit my training into my daily routine and the only solution I came up with was to get up early. And I mean really early, at 4:30 am.
There has been a lot written about the benefits of starting your day off early and I must say, it‚Äôs totally true! Starting your work day after you have spent some time working out is great. Having a daily sense of achievement after logging 10 or 20 km before you start breakfast is truly awesome. Having the chance to focus on your thoughts while enjoying the sunrise is priceless. So, over the next few months, I was running regularly and enjoying the slow and steady progress I was making.
Both tests I recklessly scheduled quite close to the big day went well, so I booked the flights and a very nice apartment in Lisbon‚Äôs historic Alfama district. Finally, it was going to happen. I would run at the Lisbon Marathon!
In the final week before the race one issue became increasingly pressing ‚Äî the weather forecast. When I had the idea of flying to Portugal for my first ever marathon, I of course checked the weather information. On average you can expect 20¬∞C in the middle of October. But not this year, the forecast was 31¬∞C with clear skies. The 2006 Chicago Marathon had to be shut down with the mercury at 28¬∞C but I expected that in sunny Portugal this wouldn‚Äôt even be considered. So, I frantically worked on adapting my gear. It is a good thing that you reduce your training miles leading up to the race (a.k.a. tapering), so you can take care of these kinds of things.
However, speaking of reduced miles, another question started nagging me. Did I train enough? Even though I ran nearly every day in the weeks prior to Lisbon, I never ran a distance longer than 25 km. But on the other hand, 15 km was one of my regular morning runs, so the additional stretch should be manageable, right? Since there was no chance I could redo my training plan in the next few days, I decided to relax. The race day would prove if my reasoning was right.
I arrived Thursday evening in Lisbon to acclimate myself and focus on the challenge ahead. It was a luxury to have time to think and I enjoyed doing so at the marathon‚Äôs designated finish at Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio. Here, you have a wonderful view over River Tagus‚Äô final passage before joining the Atlantic Ocean. It became my ‚Äúvision quest‚Äù as my girlfriend Anna would call it. She has always been supportive of my aspirations. Although we originally planned to make the trip to Lisbon together, Anna decided to stay at home with our young daughter and this gave me the gift of time alone. I used it well and came up with a list of goals and dreams for my future.
Finally, the day of the race dawned and I was sitting on the train from Lisbon to Cascais jammed with marathoners in various degrees of contemplation. Some were sitting on the floor with an empty look on their face, others were chatting happily away with their running buddies or texting home. I was silently rehearsing my game plan: Stick to the well-trained pace of 5:30, don‚Äôt get carried away by competing with other runners in the first 20 or so km, pick up the pace at 30 km aiming at a negative split, finish sub 4:00 hours.
And I stuck to the plan, at least for the first 20 km. After crossing the starting line in a wave of euphoria I was soon running steadily. I found the waving flag of the 4 hour pacemaker I was going to follow until the half marathon mark and the first misting station was in sight.
Then something unexpected happened. The heart rate display on my watch jumped to an unreal 202 bpm and I forced myself to slow down. Around 175 bpm would have been the ‚Äúnormal‚Äù maximum for a person of my age. Today, looking back at the data, I‚Äôm sure that this reading was erroneous because I have never again gone over a 170 bpm. At the time, I only had the information on my display and it had a tremendous impact. I suddenly realized that I still had another half marathon to go and the sun was beating down mercilessly even though it wasn‚Äôt even 10 a.m. yet. I checked my knees for any signs of pain or weakness. Had I overestimated myself? How could I have believed that with only months of training I would be able to pull this off? I already envisioned myself collapsing at the roundabout near the beach of Carcavelos.
This was the point where I was (to be honest for the first time really) awestruck by the magnitude of the marathon as a test of body and mind. I considered my options. I could stop now and justify it with the parching heat and my staggering heart rate. But in the end, I decided to follow through, no matter what. My goal had changed. Certainly, I still wanted to finish with a time that would be to the best of my abilities, but I mainly focused on not being defeated. I would slow down, I would drink whenever possible, I would even walk any uphill stretches of the course. The reason I started this endeavor in the first place was to prove to myself that it was still possible to accomplish something really demanding and to push my limits. This would become my mantra for the next kilometers to come.
And those kilometers weren‚Äôt easy. In fact, I never experience the famous ‚Äúrunner‚Äôs high‚Äù, at least not while I was running. The last 10 km became an uncomfortable rhythm of moving along an agonizing 2.5 km stretch only to reach the next water station, drinking and cooling myself, and starting all over again, but it worked. After I had passed the 40 km mark the number of cheering spectators increased significantly. That gave me the final boost to give the backup goal I cooked up with while poking along the torrid Avenida Marginal a try: Finishing at 4:30.
With a final sprint I reached the finish line at 4:30:54!
After hitting the stop button on my sports watch I felt exhausted but otherwise amazingly good. No cramps, no sore muscles even in the days following the race. Interestingly enough, the knees that brought me there also carried me throughout the whole distance without any problems. So, on a physiological level, it is safe to say that the stress I put on my body was easily absorbed.
The marathon had both a short and long term impact on my psychology as well. It all started with the continuous effort I put into my training despite all the seemingly ‚Äúgood‚Äù reasons why there wasn‚Äôt enough time. Once I made up my mind and committed myself to the marathon, I magically found ways to make it happen. I was able to build up my knees by training and through supplements with no side effects based on the research I did. I was able to regain my confidence and mental strength on a very fundamental level. And I was able to apply all of this to master the challenge the Lisbon Marathon turned out to be.
After I had taken a cold shower in my apartment and devoured a carb-laden lunch, I immediately went back onto the streets of Lisbon for a walk. I noticed a shift in my perspective that is still present today. A lot of things suddenly felt shallow and dispensable, others became much more significant, like sharpening the focus of my mental map. And I started working towards reaching some of the most important goals that I had identified just days before.
So, it once again proves to be true: Every cloud has a silver lining. When I got the news of my supposedly ruined knees, it seemed to be the end of my running days. But instead, this was just the beginning! It has forced me to make decisions about how I want to live my life. I opted for the challenges and that has allowed me to grow beyond my athletic ambitions. You gain nothing by accepting your fate, you must keep on fighting if you want to win.
--
--
Developer and Lawyer by training. CEO of Technology Foundation Berlin. Proud Dad.

Title: I Went to Lisbon and Was SHOCKED!
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When I was first thinking about moving to Germany, the appeal was pretty clear: Germany is an economic powerhouse, one of the strongest economies in the world. I thought to myself, ‚ÄúOkay, if I move there, I‚Äôm making a smart decision for my career.‚Äù And even though Berlin wasn‚Äôt exactly my first choice, I figured it would work as a starting point.
Fast forward six years, and I‚Äôm feeling stuck both personally and professionally and I‚Äôm starting to question the environment I‚Äôm in.
Feeling stuck? I wrote about why settling in one place can actually be dangerous for your growth. If you‚Äôre curious, check it out here: Why Settling in One Place Can Be Dangerous for Your Growth.
But, let‚Äôs get to the real reason I‚Äôm writing this post: Lisbon.
I recently visited Lisbon for the first time, and let me tell you, I was shocked in the best way possible, I was still taken aback by how much I loved it.
The streets were clean, the infrastructure was solid, and public transportation actually worked well enough to make getting around a breeze. But what really stood out to me was the overall vibe of the city. It just felt‚Ä¶ ordered.
There was this balance of modernity and tradition, Lisbon had this richness that Berlin doesn‚Äôt always capture, at least not in the same way. It‚Äôs not just in the food and the gorgeous architecture, but in the way the city feels. The people were welcoming, the atmosphere felt peaceful and grounded ‚Äî everything just felt a little‚Ä¶ livable.
The streets didn‚Äôt feel unsafe or disorderly, and I didn‚Äôt have to dodge random bottles or step over anything unpleasant. It felt clean‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand not just physically, but in terms of its overall atmosphere. Lisbon felt way more laid-back and balanced‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa place where I could actually imagine calling home.
On my way back to Berlin I find myself wondering‚Ä¶ could Lisbon be the place for me? Maybe it‚Äôs time to seriously think about it. But ‚Ä¶ As much as I‚Äôve dreamt about moving to Lisbon, my hopes have taken a bit of a hit.
Lisbon used to have a reputation for being more affordable than other European capitals, but the reality is, rent prices have been climbing steadily ‚Äî especially in the trendy neighborhoods ‚Äî bringing them in line with cities like Berlin!
On top of that, salaries in Lisbon are still pretty low compared to other European cities, so the cost of living isn‚Äôt as balanced as I once thought. It‚Äôs a bummer, but looks like my dream of settling in Lisbon it didn‚Äôt last too long!
So here I am again, chasing the original plan moving to Munich. Although is one of the most expensive places to live in Germany, at least the salaries are around 30% higher than what I‚Äôve been offered in Berlin!
But even with the potential for a bigger paycheck, I can‚Äôt shake the feeling that I‚Äôm just stuck in this loop of chasing after cities that are becoming increasingly expensive while the job market still feels a bit of a mirage!
The whole ‚ÄúGermany has tons of job opportunities‚Äù narrative is, well, not exactly the truth. Anyone who‚Äôs actually lives here knows how tough it can be to land a job, even if you speak German at a C2 level. The competition is fierce, and sometimes it feels like it doesn‚Äôt matter how qualified you are.
Sure, the western and the southern part of Germany is still financially doing well, but if the job hunt keeps feeling this grim, it might just be time to explore other options. It‚Äôs a tough decision, but I‚Äôm honestly getting a little tired of hitting dead ends. I‚Äôm even starting to entertain the idea of leaving the country altogether.
Sadly, Lisbon will remain in my heart as a city that surprised me and gave me some amazing daydreams of a life where I could see smiles around and feel a sense of calm in the everyday. It‚Äôs the kind of place that makes you think, ‚ÄúThis could be home,‚Äù but sometimes, reality just doesn‚Äôt align with those dreams.
I‚Äôm thinking about where to go next. I‚Äôve got some exciting options on my mind, if you‚Äôre curious, check it out here: I‚Äôm Leaving Berlin. Let me know your thoughts!
--
--
Fluent in sarcasm, not in German. Came for the vibes, stayed for the existential paperwork. Life as an immigrant in Germany.

Title: Lisbon
[Coworker] Meet Shannon Graybill, Lisbon city driver at Le Wagon coding school
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The Coworking magazine by Coworkies. We highlights portraits of extraordinary people who entered the coworking world as owners, managers or members.

--
Listen
Share
Shannon is behind one of Lisbon‚Äôs coolest coding school: Le Wagon. We met at Beta-i and got curious to know more about her story and how you start such a project from scratch without being from the city yourself. Time for some questions!
I moved here four years ago to be with my boyfriend who is from Lisbon. I never imagined at that time that I would still be here four years on, but the city has been changing (for the good) at such an alarming rate in the last few years that I feel like I moved somewhere new.
Rather than why I came to live here, the better question is why I stayed. And to answer that, you can read a blog post I published a few weeks ago on Le Wagon ‚Äî Why would you relocate to Lisbon?
www.lewagon.com
Le Wagon is a code school for non-technical entrepreneurs and creatives. We give people the programming and product development mindset through teaching ruby on rails web development.
My motivation to launch Le Wagon started two years ago while I was working in a local accelerator/ incubator here in Lisbon. I saw a lack of technical talent amongst the founders and also felt that I could benefit myself from understanding on a basic level what is going on behind the scenes of software.
Now, after having gone through the program myself and already running three 9 week batches in Lisbon, I can say I know that and a whole lot more, plus have 60+ Lisbon alumni as a support when it comes to launching my own products and finding cool jobs in the tech market.
Growing very quickly with a very diverse mix of internationals and locals.
We really wanted to be immersed in Lisbon‚Äôs startup ecosystem and Beta-i was a great way to access this community.
We could do a better job of this to be honest. At the moment, we are cross promoting events and of course enjoying some impromptu beers on the roof :)
Learning how to learn (again) ‚Äî their EGOS! As humans, we are conditioned to shy away from challenge. We want all the glory with all the ease. We tend to work in areas and take on tasks that make us feel good. The first three weeks of Le Wagon are an ice cold shower for those that are not accustomed to just not getting something in the beginning. You really have to have faith in yourself and our curriculum when you start the program. The concepts are abstract for most people and they need to time sink in. Le Wagon is like learning to ride a bike. You have to be willing to keep getting on the bike and falling off and trust that eventually if you do that enough times, it will click and you‚Äôll start riding.
To keep the students believing in themselves and their ability. To keep ‚Äúfalling off the bike‚Äù.
In our first batch, we had a student that really struggled. And when I say struggled, there were days he didn‚Äôt finish a challenge. But the guy had a great attitude. He didn‚Äôt give up. He didn‚Äôt compare himself to his classmates. He just kept going. After the bootcamp, he was one of the first to get a job and not even in ruby ‚Äî in Javascript on the backend! He is our mascot here in Lisbon on what it means to give it your all.
Our community is growing locally. We expect in the next year to have our own space with our own cowering for our alumni and ruby on rails developers.
Thanks Shannon for your time and insights!

Content:

By Casey Paxton
Here at Salsify, we can‚Äôt stop talking about our brand spankin‚Äô new office and team in Lisbon, Portugal! We do love Boston, but nothing can top the beautiful sunny weather and gorgeous beaches of Lisbon. I recently got the chance to sit down with our People Operations Specialist in Portugal, Marta Carvalho, to get her take on Lisbon, Boston, and all things Salsify!
Q: So, what exactly does a People Operations Specialist do?
A: As a part of the People Ops team, it‚Äôs my responsibility to promote employee engagement and brand awareness, onboard new hires, support HR processes, team building, and a lot of other fun stuff! Since we are just getting started in Lisbon, my current work is very focused on building and growing the Lisbon team, and ramping up the Salsify employment brand in Lisbon.
Q: How long have you been working for Salsify?
A: A little over one month.
Q: How did you find out about Salsify?
A: I heard about Salsify coming to Lisbon through networking in the Lisbon tech community.
Q: What made you want to work for Salsify?
A: The opportunity to do what I really love in a company with great culture and values. It‚Äôs great to be part of this project since the beginning. Plus, I have the opportunity to be a pioneering person in HR and to think, implement, and see through the best policies and procedures!
Q: What is it like working for Salsify versus working for a Portuguese company?
A: For me, the possibility of traveling and working in collaboration with Boston colleagues on a daily basis is something that I really love. Plus, Portuguese companies tend to have long and inconclusive personal meetings! I‚Äôve been struggling a lot with this in my last years :) I‚Äôm delighted that things at Salsify are done promptly, on time, and focus on specific goals. I feel that people here are very productive and efficient.
Q: What is the biggest cultural difference that you‚Äôve encountered between Portugal and the United States?
A: Well . . . you all seem to have lunch and dinner pretty early :) I‚Äôm used to having dinner by 9 pm for instance while in Boston, it was super common to have dinner by 6 pm. It feels like days and nights in Portugal take longer.
Q: What has been your favorite and least favorite thing about working for Salsify so far?
A: Favorite thing is probably the possibility to work with such a great and friendly team. Least favorite thing is the current temporary office, which is about to change when we move to a new office full of windows and sunshine!
(We actually just moved to our new office! Check it out here.)
Q: Are you someone who can listen to music while you work?
A: Only during some tasks. If I‚Äôm doing some sourcing or replying to some emails, then yes. If I need to think about something more strategic or write down policies and procedures, I can‚Äôt.
Q: Where in the world would you most like to travel?
A: There are so many places I would like to go that it‚Äôs hard to pick out only one. I love sun and beaches, so anything that seems like a paradise are good destinations (Hawaii, Bahamas, Bali‚Ä¶).
Q: Do you have a hidden talent/fact that most people don‚Äôt know about you?
A: Well, I dance a lot of Salsa and Bachata. I‚Äôm not sure if it is a talent, but it‚Äôs something I love to do and I know how to do it.
Q: Tea or coffee?
A: Coffee for sure. Not a fan of tea, only drink it when I‚Äôm sick. Tea does not bring me good memories :)
Q: Reading or watching TV?
A: Both. Love to see a good movie or also to do some binge watching on Netflix. However, also love to take a book to Starbucks (yes, Starbucks is very appreciated in Lisbon!) or a nice coffee shop and read it on a rainy day.
Q: What is your favorite thing about Lisbon?
A: What keeps me in Lisbon is definitely being close to my family. Also, our sunny days, good food, and great sights to see make me love Lisbon. What I like the most is the possibility to go to the beach in fifteen minutes from my home! Even in winter, the sun stills shines here and you can have a good time on a nice terrace on the beach.
Q: Best lunch spot in Lisbon?
A: There are so many. Food in Lisbon is the best. I like to go to Portugalia, in Belem (but more because of the space rather than the food).Q: You recently visited the Boston office! Was this your first time in Boston? How did you like it?
A: Just loved it! It was my first time in the US and I was delighted. The first few days were pretty tough. Never felt so much cold in my entire life! But I loved to see the city with and without the snow. You have a beautiful city and compared to Lisbon, everything is so big. I felt very welcome by the whole team and got really impressed about how big we are in Boston. Looking forward to create something similar in Lisbon.
Q: What are you most excited about moving forward?
A: I love the creation processes of everything. So, very excited about creating the Lisbon Team and to set all things for the creation of our offices as well.
Obrigado, Marta, for letting us get to know you and Portugal a bit better! Check out our careers page for more info about all of our amazing job openings, and be sure to follow us on Instagram, YouTube, and Twitter for all the Salsify updates you could ever want.

Title: Dancing with Chaos: Life Lessons from Lisbon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Let me tell you a story. This one takes us to Lisbon, Portugal, where I went to visit someone who has been my fairy godmother and her amazing husband. To protect her privacy, let‚Äôs call her ‚ÄúBallerina.‚Äù
Now, Lisbon was everything you‚Äôd imagine, great people, great food, and endless opportunities to learn. Between physics, entropy, mountains, ballet, and Portuguese culture, my mind was buzzing. But, as always, the universe had a peculiar surprise in store for me. You see, Ballerina has this friend, Karma, who happens to be a Tibetan Buddhist Kempo monk. Yes, his name is as amazing as his wisdom. One day, we decided to head to the beach for some sun and sea after I met with folks from the World Bank to brainstorm ways to tackle water scarcity. Pretty typical day, right?
Well, here‚Äôs the twist: monks don‚Äôt usually carry swim trunks. So, what do you do when your monk friend wants to dip his toes in the ocean? You go and buy him a pink swimsuit, of course. Armed with this purchase, we made our way to the water, chatting about life, music, and whatever else crossed our minds. Turns out, Karma had spent some time in Mexico and spoke Spanish. This led us down a hilarious rabbit hole of Latin music, culminating in a spontaneous rendition of *Despacito*. There we were, a cosmologist, a Buddhist monk, and a theoretical physics PhD student, on a Portuguese beach, singing and dancing to a reggaeton hit. Life‚Äôs surreal moments, I tell you.
But wait, there‚Äôs more. I‚Äôm not exactly an ocean person. I grew up in the Andes, far from any sea, and I didn‚Äôt realize how quickly the water could chill me. As the sun set, my body temperature dropped fast, too fast. Ballerina, who, by the way, is not just an award-winning cosmologist and a ballerina but also a seasoned mountaineer, immediately noticed something was off. Her mountaineering instincts kicked in, and she got me out of the water before I turned into a human popsicle. After almost giving her a heart attack with my near-hypothermic state, we bundled me up and made it back home safe.
That trip wasn‚Äôt just about beaches, physics, or even *Despacito*. It was about being in the company of some of the most brilliant and fascinating minds I‚Äôve ever met. Karma, in particular, taught me so much about the art of controlling the mind, meditating, and navigating emotions with clarity. It was like a crash course in mastering the internal chaos we all carry.
But more than anything, this trip reminded me of the simple joy in life‚Äôs beautiful chaos. The cliff, the mountains, the black cat, the dreams, the tree, the hedgehogs, the sunset, each a little piece of the puzzle. Between deep conversations, fresh ideas, and hours spent playing with their incredible kids, I felt myself rediscovering the wild, curious, and playful side of me. It‚Äôs the part that often gets buried under all the equations and theories, but it‚Äôs always there, waiting to come alive again.
Life‚Äôs better when it surprises you, isn‚Äôt it?

Content:

Share
It was a nightmare to leave the ‚ÄúEsta√ß√£o Oriente‚Äù in Lisbon.
After spending a delightful few days in Porto, I boarded the AP train, eager to return to Lisbon.
The trip took me 3 good hours that I spent writing and communicating with my laptop. The train wifi was working properly.
However, as I arrived at the Lisbon train station (Aug 5), I found myself in an unexpected predicament.
The bustling station was packed with an ocean of people from all corners of the globe, and a wave of claustrophobia washed over me.
I felt in some ways lost and unsure of how to reach my hotel via the subway train.
Navigating through the sea of travelers proved to be a daunting task.
Each person seemed to be in a hurry, and it felt like the entire world had gathered in Lisbon to witness a momentous event ‚Äî the Pope.
Feeling overwhelmed, I took a moment to compose myself and tried to spot any sign or direction for the subway.
However, it was not easy amidst the crowd. And every escalator was not working.

As my Uber driver approached where my hotel was located, I saw a bridge. A long one! And as we got closer, I was taken aback by its resemblance to the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco.
I was like, wait a minute, where am I?
The Ponte 25 de Abril (the 25th of April Bridge in English), connects the city of Lisbon to the municipality of Almada. I later learned that it was built by an American Bridge Company, and one can see where the inspiration for the design came from. The bridge‚Äôs upper section accommodates cars and the section under is for trains. However, unlike the Golden Gate Bridge, Ponte 25 de Abril doesn‚Äôt allow pedestrians or biking on the bridge.

Title: How to Connect with Others in Lisbon: 10 Great Lisbon Meetups 2022
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
If you‚Äôre reading this article, it means you‚Äôre hoping to meet new people in Lisbon, that‚Äôs awesome! You may be considering moving here permanently, exploring Lisbon as a digital nomad, or you may have lived here for a while and feel like it‚Äôs the time to get out there and make new friendships. Whatever the reason, the answer to ‚ÄúHow do I begin?‚Äù is the same: download the Meetup App.
In case you were wondering why I‚Äôm recommending Meetup instead another app: no, I‚Äôm not affiliated with Meetup in any way. When I first came to Lisbon at the beginning of 2022, I tried out various apps, and Meetup stood out to me as the one with the most significant number of interesting-sounding events that fill up quickly.
So, in this article, I would love to mention a list of Meetups that I found particularly worthy of checking out. If you think that I missed out on any excellent Meetup event, please leave a comment below so that everyone can benefit :)
The list of great 10 Meetups includes:
Curious Monkey
This is a non-profit group and a creative space for sharing knowledge about art and bringing together local and expat communities in Lisbon. They organize various events, including yoga, open mics, and talks with book authors, journalists, and casts of well-known shows such as Cirque Du Soleil. If you‚Äôre looking for some quality conversations, then Curious Monkey will be a great group to join!
www.meetup.com
Drink & Draw
Drink & Draw hosts pop-up drawing sessions in unique locations around Lisbon. For around twenty euros, you can enjoy a mobile-phone-free session with incredible people at a beautiful local winery or a cafe. Each participant is handed a set of drawing materials upon entry and a drink choice, and then the drawing begins! Two or more models pose in the middle of the room, and participants are given tasks such as ‚Äúdraw the model in 30 sec‚Äù or ‚Äúdraw the model in 7 min but with the opposite hand.‚Äù It‚Äôs a lot of fun and an excellent opportunity to explore your drawing technique.
www.meetup.com
Future Founders
I‚Äôm a big fan of this group because I always leave their events feeling inspired and with a sense that I learned something new. The group attracts founders, product people, and venture capitalists. It‚Äôs the perfect place to obtain or give feedback, discuss technology, and get funding! Some of the events take place in a park where participants gather in small groups to discuss challenges and ideas, and then the groups are swapped every 15‚Äì20 min. For those of you who have a business registered in Portugal, this may be an excellent place to learn more about the legal side of things as the group hosts talks dedicated to this topic as well.
www.meetup.com
Lisbon Digital Nomads
Boasting 17K+ members at the time of writing, this group is growing fast and is the best way to connect with other digital nomads and make new like-minded friends. The group organizes recurring running, networking, and board game events. The event spots tend to exceed 100 participants per event, but don‚Äôt be disappointed if you end up on a waiting list. You can still show up to the event and be admitted!
www.meetup.com
Polylogue‚Äôs Lightning Talks
If there were a category for the most thought-provoking event host, Polylogue would win. The idea behind this group is simple yet powerful: whoever shows up can give a 5 min talk about any topic of their choice. The host will provide a projector, a microphone, and snacks. The reason why I love this event so much is that it forces you in a way to learn something new that you would otherwise not look into. Topics range from highly technical concepts to funny talks about delivering packages to the most secluded places in the world to relationship advice. Whatever the case may be, it‚Äôs always fun, and it‚Äôs a great way to meet people who are passionate about what they do in life. Additionally, if you‚Äôre looking for a new coworking space, attending Lightning Talks may help you decide, as the events are hosted across various coworks.
www.meetup.com
Lisbon Supper Club
I first encountered this concept in Lisbon and immediately fell in love with it. This is how it works: you sign up for a themed supper (for example, a ‚ÄúBritish Roast‚Äù or ‚ÄúTruffle Lovers‚Äù), pay around 25 euros, and then attend the supper with up to 20 people who also signed up. The interesting twist is that the supper takes place in the dining room inside the chef‚Äôs apartment which creates an incredible atmosphere encouraging all the strangers to get to know one another by the end of the feast. The food is delicious, the ambiance is magical, and the new friendships last!
www.meetup.com
Passport Comedy
I‚Äôm not going to lie, I had low expectations for this group before going to their first event. And then ‚Äî haha! Little did I know how excellent these events would turn out to be. Passport Comedy has a solid lineup of comedians who will guarantee you an evening filled with tears of laughter. I laughed there more than at the Comedy Cellar in NYC. Grab your spot before these comedians begin doing Netflix Stand-Up Comedy Specials ‚Äî it‚Äôs worth it!
www.meetup.com
Storytelling Lisboa
The concept of this group is quite fascinating. Each event has a specific theme, such as ‚ÄúChaos,‚Äù ‚ÄúBreaks,‚Äù or ‚ÄúLandlords,‚Äù and one thing in common ‚Äî participants can volunteer to spend 10 min telling their story to an audience of 200+ people. Anyone can volunteer to tell a story, but there can be no more than ten speakers per event. The stories range from sad to funny, and the events are hosted in English or Portuguese. I was impressed by how well-structured, emotional, and thought-provoking these stories are. It‚Äôs an event format that is worth checking out at least once.
www.meetup.com
The Block Lisboa
This article wouldn‚Äôt be complete without at least one mention of a crypto-focused group. The Block hosts many crypto, NFT, and developer events. Some of them are more technical and may require prior knowledge, so make sure to read through the event description. I attended an excellent NFT workshop that felt like a whole course on NFTs, met extremely savvy people, and enjoyed great food. Regardless of how familiar you‚Äôre with blockchain, I strongly recommend looking through what The Block offers as long as you‚Äôre curious about how things work.
www.meetup.com
Two Left Feet
And finally, salsa and bachata! This group guarantees a relaxing evening filled with music and dance moves. As long as the weather‚Äôs good, the classes take place outdoors, and the instructor explains each move clearly. While dancing, the participants are asked to switch partners with every new song, so this class is a great way to get better at salsa and bachata and an excellent way to make new friends.
www.meetup.com
That‚Äôs it! I strongly recommend checking out these Meetup groups. I realize there are other great groups out there, so if you feel like I missed any of them, please leave a comment so that every reader can benefit from your recommendation. I am seeing more and more groups being added weekly, so I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if this list grows 10x by the end of 2023!
--
--

Title: Outbound Adventures: 7 top tips for visiting beautiful Lisbon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
This historic city has delicious seafood, unique local music, and stunning views
The gates of old Lisbon can be seen through the colorful houses and streets. (Photo by: Nour Eldin Ebrahim)
I‚Äôve just got back from exploring one of the warmest, most beautiful cities I‚Äôve ever visited: Lisbon
After a week of exploring Portugal‚Äôs capital, I‚Äôve come up with some must-dos for making the most out of your visit.
The beautiful gates of old Lisbon (Photo by: Nour Eldin Ebrahim)
The internal transportation system in Lisbon is easy to use: you go to any metro station and from the machines there buy a Viva Viagem card for 50 cents. You then charge the card as much as you want, in increments of 3, 5, and 10 euros.
Once you‚Äôve charged your card, you can select what kind of ticket you want to use it for. You can ‚Äúzap‚Äù in and out of the metro and some buses by touching the card over a scanner at the beginning and end of each journey. This will automatically deduct the cost of your trip from your card‚Äôs total.
Alternatively, before you begin your day‚Äôs travel you can choose to buy a day pass the ticket on the card for 6 euros, which may work out cheaper.
Pro tip: Get two cards ‚Äî one for zapping, and one to use if you needed a day pass.
Lisbon is famous for its seafood and for its pastries. There is a lot to try, but if I had to recommend just two must-eats, they would be Bacalhau (salted cod) and Pastel de nata (custard tartlets).
Pastel de nata (amazing Portuguese pastry made from custard), is something you can‚Äôt miss when visiting Lisbon
Pastel de nata is one of the most common and well-known Portuguese pastries, and every visitor to Lisbon should try them. Pasteis de Belem makes a great version, by far the best I tried. They were so delicious I managed 12 in one day!
The Bacalhau meanwhile is a very popular ingredient in Portuguese cooking. It‚Äôs delicious and quite different from anything you will have tried elsewhere. And don‚Äôt skimp on the other kinds of seafood, which is such a key part of Portuguese cuisine ‚Äî try the grilled salmon, for example.
Pro tip: Go to Casa Portuguesa do Pastel de Bacalhau in the famous Rua Augusta and try a special twist on Bacalhau. This place mixes the traditional flavors in a cod cake filled with Serra da Estrela cheese ‚Äî a match made in heaven!
Lisbon has its own genre of music, Fado, which is like blues with a touch of folk, and more sadness. If you look online you will find a lot of ‚ÄúFado houses‚Äù recommended by various travel guides to Lisbon, but these are all quite pricey, touristy places.
If you want an authentic experience, just go to Alfama district around 9 to 10 pm, wander through the streets, and check out the small local bars. You will often find places that host non-famous but beautiful Fado singers. Get a drink or a light dinner and enjoy an authentic Portuguese night ‚Äî one of the best experiences I had in Lisbon.
If you open any Lisbon travel guide, you‚Äôll always find this tip: ride tram ‚Ññ28. The reason is that this tram‚Äôs route passes through very interesting, scenic districts of Lisbon, including Baixa, Gra√ßa, Alfama, and Estrela.
And the tram itself is old and historical and looks beautiful to ride. But this has become a very touristic attraction and it‚Äôs literally full of pickpockets.
Tram 12 because the famous Tram 28 is a tourist trap. (Photo by: Nour Eldin Ebrahim)
So be smart and instead ride tram ‚Ññ12, just beside it. It goes to most of the same places and will provide you with a better experience.
Pro tip: Don‚Äôt take the full trip; ride the tram until you arrive at Se Cathedral and hop off. You are now on the top of the hill in the Alfama district. The cathedral is worth seeing and a couple of steps beside it is Santa Luiza Miradouro, a perfect place to watch the sunset, after which you can head to the city center on foot ‚Äî a beautiful and easy walk.
The view from Santa Luiza Miradouro, one of many beautiful viewpoints on top of the hills in Lisbon (Photo: Nour Eldin Ebrahim)
Lisbon is spread over seven hills. The tops of these hills provide a wonderful opportunity to view the city. These panoramic viewpoints are called miradoras in Portuguese and there are many of them. It‚Äôs a free way to view the city‚Äôs beauty. Watch a sunset or a sunrise from a miradouro and I promise you it will be something you will never forget.
Above I mentioned the Santa Luiza Miradouro (a personal favorite). But you can also try the Pra√ßa Alegria Miradouro (reached from Pra√ßa dos Restauradores by the traditional Funicular Gloria), which provides views over Baixa, leading towards the Rio Tejo.
Castelo de Sao Jorge Miradouro is also nice, although don‚Äôt bother with the Castle Sao Jorge next door ‚Äî it‚Äôs a waste of time. But this miradouro is on top of the highest hill in Lisbon, so the view is beautiful.
Shopping is a real pleasure here at Centro Colombo, the most famous shopping mall in Lisbon (Photo: Nour Eldin Ebrahim)
Lisbon is a very good clothes shopping destination in Europe, with seriously good prices!
The best place for a shopping spree is Columbus mall; I got a beautiful coat and a pair of jeans for 33 euros this December (650 EGP!).
Pro tip: One word: PRIMARK
There are a lot of amazing day trips that you can do from Lisbon, taking a train from Rossio train station (which is a beautiful thing to see even if you are not traveling!). But if you will do just one, then without a doubt it should be the beautiful city of Sintra.
The beautiful Sintra, a close-by city and a recommended day trip from Lisbon (Photo by: Nour Eldin Ebrahim)
Sintra is a historic city over the hills, full of old beautiful palaces and a grand Moorish castle that is worth seeing. The city‚Äôs central streets are made of cobblestones and the whole architectural style is colorful and beautiful.
Pro tip: when you arrive by train, exit on the right and wait for the tourist public bus 434 (5 euros); it will take you on a one-way circular ride around the three most important landmarks of Sintra (the town, the Moorish castle on the hill, and the Pena Palace). You can ride and hop on/off any bus until you make a full circle back to the train station. The castle is highly recommended!
The narrow but very colorful streets of Lisbon (Photo by: Nour Eldin Ebrahim)

Title: Lisbon ‚Äî a civilization on the edge of Europe
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
This story is about how a one encounter can change everything and how Lisbon can tell you everything if you can listen
Recently we were walking around the city with my friend and he asked me,
‚Äî Does the city respond to you? It got me thinking.
If you think of a city as a separate civilization, any city responds to me. Perhaps because I am a historian and I love life, comfortable shoes, walking at least 10 thousand steps a day and have endless curiosity. For me, a city is about life. Some look at a city as a geographical object, others as an investment, a source of income, beauty, history or just a backdrop. I look at the city as a separate civilization. On the other hand, there is a city and there is a village. In the village, life is organized differently. In the village, in my opinion, not much happens. All life is concentrated in the city ‚Äî championships, concerts, forums, summits, museums, galleries, meetings, marches, etc. Open any news and all the news is about city life. The city is about life. And who is interested in other people‚Äôs life? A person is either not interested in it, or he looks at it from the outside, half-heartedly. He‚Äôs busy with his own life. For example, can you describe the street where you go to work every day and tell another person about it in such a way that he wants to live on this street? Can you convey your interest in life to another person? Apparently, when we say that this city responds or doesn‚Äôt respond to me, we don‚Äôt mean the facades of the houses. We‚Äôre talking about how the life of the city coincides with our own idea of life. Or it doesn‚Äôt. And then it seems like a foreign city.
Cities like people.
First encounter with Lisbon
It wasn‚Äôt love at first sight. But it was love. For Lisbon or for Bruno or for Lisbon through love for Bruno. It doesn‚Äôt matter anymore. It‚Äôs love. I think of Bruno so often that I sometimes think I made him up. Maybe I did. No there really is a guy named Bruno, who showed up at a moment when I felt like there was no way we matched up with Lisbon. He showed up and opened my eyes to this city. No, he wasn‚Äôt my city guide, but he looked and kissed me in a way that made me want to live in this city. No, Bruno and I aren‚Äôt a couple, he‚Äôs still in my memories, and what‚Äôs more, I don‚Äôt think he even realizes the Important role he played in my life. But my story with Lisbon will always begin with that encounter.
Lisbon responded to me
The day after meeting Bruno, I went for a walk with a completely different mood and found myself in Rossio Square. I took a 360 degree look around and realized that from this point I could see all of Portugal‚Äôs history.
Did you know that you can see the history of the country by standing in this very square and you don‚Äôt even have to move anywhere? Don‚Äôt believe me? Now you will üòä
Medieval Ages
Look up the hill to the east to see St. George‚Äôs Castle, one of the oldest buildings in Lisbon. This is where Portugal‚Äôs history as a kingdom begins. Having survived the Romans and Visigoths, the Iberian Peninsula was subjected to a new invasion. In 711 Muslims came to its territory ‚Äî they were called Moors. The beginning of Portugal‚Äôs own independent history is associated with the name of Afonso I Henriques, nicknamed the Conqueror. Personality has significance in history. Thanks to Afonso I the territory of the country increased many times. But the most valuable trophy of Afonso I was undoubtedly Lisbon, which after cruel battles in 1147 became part of Portugal and turned into one of the largest centers of the country, and in 1255 the capital from Coimbra was moved to Lisbon.
Not far from Rossio Square there is Martin Muniz Square, who fought bravely during the siege of Lisbon, he alone attacked the gates of the fortress and defended them without letting them close, sacrificing his life. Thanks to Martin Muniz‚Äôs feat, the attacking Christian soldiers were able to approach the open gate and capture the fortress.
It is on this square that the famous 28th tram stops, which will take you to St. George‚Äôs Castle. Of course, you can also climb the hill on foot and get confused in the maze of streets of Alfama. It is from here that the city began to grow, descending down the hill to the banks of the Tagus River.
If you turn to the west, you will see the Gothic arches of the ruins of the Karmu Monastery. It was once one of the largest churches in the city. The history of the monastery began in 1385, when before the decisive battle of Aljubarrota, King Jo√£o I of Avis and his magnificent commander-in-chief of the Portuguese army, 25-year-old Nuno Alvares Pereira, made a vow: in the event of victory over the Castilians, each would build a monastery in honor of Our Lady. To commemorate the victory and in fulfillment of the vow made before the battle, Jo√£o I founded the monastery of Batalha, and Nuno Alvares Pereira in 1389 founded a monastery of the Carmelite order in Lisbon, known as the ‚ÄúChurch of Carmo‚Äù. Where he later donated all his considerable fortune, and then took monastic tonsure. Pious Nuno lived in the monastery until the end of his days. The hero of the battle Nuno Alvares Pereira deservedly got his place on the arch in the main square Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio.
The Carmelite Monastery was to become one of the most beautiful monuments of the National Gothic, but a tragic fate awaited it. On November 1, 1755, the vaults of the church could not withstand the strong earth tremors and collapsed, burying the townspeople who came to mass under them and losing forever the tomb of Connetabile Nuno, whom the Vatican canonized recently in 2009. The Battle of Aljubarrota, in which Portuguese troops defeated the Castilian army, laid the foundations for the Age of Discovery.
The Age of the Great Discovery was a golden age for Portugal, the XV-XVI centuries
Take a look at the square beneath your feet: the wave-shaped mosaic is no accident. It is a symbol of the ocean, of the sea voyages that made Portugal a great empire. Portugal opened the world to the world and discovered itself. The age of the Great Discovery was a golden age for Portugal, the XV-XVI centuries were a time of unprecedented Portuguese greatness, it was a wonderful time of selfless and courageous navigators heroes.
Breathe in the air. Can you smell it?
The most incredible smell I‚Äôve ever smelled is the smell of jacaranda. Lisbon‚Äôs lilac tree, Jacaranda mimosifolia, is truly worthy of the royal court. Jacaranda came from Brazil, bringing with it the scent of honey, grapes and the Atlantic Ocean. Brazil was a colony of Portugal, and Rio de Janeiro even served as the capital of the empire for 13 years, because of the invasion of Napoleon‚Äôs army under the command of General Junot the royal house had to move to Brazil in 1807. It is a unique fact in history that the capital of an empire becomes its overseas colony.
In fact, the official name of the square is Pedro IV Square. In the center of the square you can see a monument to the King of Portugal and the first emperor of Brazil.
Rossio Square now looks smart and peaceful. And once the fires of the Inquisition were burning here, heretics and witches were burned on the place of today‚Äôs national theater of Queen Mary stood the palace of the Inquisition and people always gathered to watch this spectacle. The first autodafa took place here in 1540.
Slowly, the former greatness of the Portuguese Empire fades away and in 1580. Portgugal fell under Spanish rule for 60 years. In 1640 there is a rebellion in Lisbon, as a result of which the independence of Portugal was restored. And if we walk a little from Rossio Square past the magnificent train station, we will see the Monumento dos Restauradores.
In 1755 Lisbon was destroyed by a terrible earthquake.
Take a look around ‚Äî this is Lisbon Pombal. Lisbon rebuilt after the earthquake. a great city reborn after a great catastrophe. At least, that was the original intention of Marquis Sebasti√£o Jos√© Pombalho, who was appointed by King Jos√© I to lead the rebuilding of Lisbon after the devastating earthquake of 1755 and who created the so-called Pombaline style. One of the most characteristic features of the Pombalino style is its desire for order and will to live, which can be traced back to people‚Äôs desire to protect themselves from the destructive elements. If in Alfama it is very easy to get lost in its chaotic winding streets, then in the lower new Lisbon it is impossible to do so ‚Äî the city is built on a plan, clearly on a line. The task before the architects was difficult ‚Äî it was necessary not only to rebuild a part of the country, but also to make the buildings stronger and more resistant to seismic activity. Pombalino style is very visible on the streets of the city ‚Äî strict rectangular shapes of buildings, the exterior of buildings is simple, standard and laconic.
Breathe in again. What do you smell this time?
It‚Äôs the smell of coffee and the roaring 1920s. I was sitting in Caf√© Nicola, where the bohemians of Lisbon drank coffee. Did you know that Portugal is a coffee fanatic country. According to the Potrugal Coffee Association (Associa√ß√£o Industrial e Comercial do Caf√© https://aicc.pt/) 80% of Portuguese people can‚Äôt imagine their lives without coffee, while the rest don‚Äôt drink it. Remember the phrase: ‚ÄúUm caf√© e um pastel de nata, por favor‚Äù and you won‚Äôt be lost. A vida s√≥ come√ßa depois de um caf√© ‚Äî life begins only after coffee. I don‚Äôt know who this phrase belongs to, but I‚Äôm sure he was Portuguese. By the way, definitely those 20% are lying.
The 20th century is a turbulent time.
As I stood in Rossio Square I remembered that it was here in 1974 that thousands of people gathered to celebrate the fall of the dictatorship. On April 25, 1974, a bloodless military revolution took place in Portugal. Soldiers, tired of colonial wars and censorship, overthrew the authoritarian regime. In the streets, women and children came up to them, put carnations in the barrels of their rifles ‚Äî and they did not shoot. Red carnations became a symbol of freedom and in Portugal you look at them in a special way. This event has become a symbol of hope for all of Europe.
Here in Lisbon, in Rossio Square, on Avenida da Liberdade, at the walls of Carmo, the dreams of freedom have become a reality. And I want to remember that revolutions are not always accompanied by weapons. Sometimes it‚Äôs just flowers and music. And that‚Äôs the lesson of Lisbon.
And that‚Äôs not all that Rossio Square has to tell us.
The city responded to me. It was in this city that I first experienced how deeply a place can speak if you know how to listen to it. Here, in Rossio Square, another Portugal opened up before me.
If you have walked around Rossio Square too, tell what you felt. Maybe this place opened up an unexpected side of Portugal for you?
I want to work in Lisbon as a tour guide. I want to tell the guests of the city about the history of the country, which has given the world so many wonderful discoveries and not only geographical discoveries and many lessons.
That‚Äôs my dream.And dreams are supposed to come true.

I want to live in Portugal because I am delighted. Historian and traveler, author of articles on the history of the EU. I want to share my impressions with you

Posted: 6/26/2003 | June 23rd, 2023
Lisbon is one of my favorite cities in the world. It‚Äôs home to impressive museums, historic buildings, picturesque plazas, chilled-out cafes, and a lively mix of clubs and candlelit music venues where people go to listen to traditional fado music. I fell in love with the city as soon as I arrived ‚Äî and it was even better the second time!
Today, Lisbon is one of the most popular cities on the continent. From cruisers to digital nomads, everyone loves this sunny city. I‚Äôve visited a few times over the years and always look forward to going back. The warm weather, inviting colors, and laid-back vibe really make people feel welcome.
The best way to see the city, though (especially if it‚Äôs your first time) is to take a walking tour. It‚Äôs the first thing I do when I visit a new city as it‚Äôs the best way to connect with a local guide, get insider info, and see the main sights.
These days, there are a ton of walking tours available to ensure you make the most of your visit. Here‚Äôs a list of my favorites ‚Äî from free tours to food tours to pub crawls ‚Äî to help you sort through it all so you just end up with the best!
Best Overall Tour
Learn More
I‚Äôve taken Walks tours all over Europe and it is, by far, my favorite tour company. They always manage to go above and beyond with tours that are both fun and educational.
In Lisbon, they offer a few tours (including food tours) but for a good primer on the city I recommend their Lisbon in a Day tour. It includes a river cruise, early access to Jeronimos Monastery, and lunch. It lasts a full day too!
Best Free Tour
Learn More
This informative three-hour free tour takes you through five of Lisbon‚Äôs most popular neighborhoods ‚Äî Gra√ßa, Alfama, Baixa, Chiado, and Bairro Alto ‚Äî offering up an entertaining and enlightening dose of history and culture along the way.
The tours also focus on a more local side of Lisbon. If you‚Äôre on a budget and want an introduction to the city, this is the tour for you. Just remember to tip the guide!
Here are a few more walking tour options to help you make the most of your time in Lisbon:
Devour started in Spain and quickly began doing tours in Lisbon. They offer a food and fado tour, mixing two cultural highlights of Lisbon on one tour. I personally like the Tastes & Traditions food tour they do: you stop at seven small businesses in Lisbon, eating up to nine samples and sipping three different types of beverages. Devour is one of the best food tour companies in Europe and their Lisbon tours are no exception.
Tours start at 95 EUR.
Book here!
This tour company offers a whole range of tours but their Best of Lisbon introductory tour is perfect for both first-time Lisbon visitors and budget travelers. The three-hour tour starts at 9:30am and takes you through some of the city‚Äôs main neighborhoods, making a stop for wine and a bite of the famous pastry, pastel de nata (an egg custard tart). The group tours max out at 14 people.
Tours start at 18 EUR.
Book here!
Street art has taken over the world‚Äôs big cities, including Lisbon. On this three-hour tour, you‚Äôll see some of the best works in the city and learn about the social and political motives behind them. Tours are led by a local street artist too, so you‚Äôll really get an insider‚Äôs look at the scene and visit murals most other tours skip.
Tours start at 35 EUR.
Book here!
Pancho does tours all over the Iberian Peninsula, using local guides and crafting itineraries that focus on street art, tapas and wine, and day trips to places like Sintra. Personally, I like their fado music tour. During the 2.5-hour tour, you‚Äôll learn everything there is about this melancholic music that‚Äôs endemic to Portugal. You‚Äôll get a front-row seat at a fado show in the center of Lisbon at the end.
Tours start at around 40 EUR.
Book here!
Overtourism is a problem in many cities, particularly in Europe, with crowds of people ping-ponging from one attraction to the next. Hence, the idea behind We Hate Tourism Tours: the 3.5-hour walking tour takes you to some way off-the-radar neighborhoods to show you how the people of Lisbon really live. There are only about six people per tour, which keeps things intimate. It also means you should book in advance as tours sell out fast. I love how they are getting people out of the main touristy areas and showing you a real look at Lisbon life. I can‚Äôt recommend this tour enough.
Tours start at 40 EUR.
Book here!
Lisbon has a very lively nightlife these days and, if you‚Äôre looking for a way to see it while also meeting other travelers, the classic pub crawl is a good way to go. This tour takes you to three spots, with a free shot at the first and the third stop. Plus, there‚Äôs a one-hour period of all-you-can-drink cider or sangria. It‚Äôs a great option for solo travelers looking to meet other people. It‚Äôs not a real ‚Äúlocal‚Äù thing but it‚Äôs fun!
Tours start at 20 EUR.
Book here!
***
Lisbon has walking tours for just about every interest and budget, which is one of the many reasons I love the city. Whenever I visit, I always take a tour or two because the city just has so much to see and do, and the local guides always add a ton of value to my trip. These tours allow you to get an inside perspective on life here and ask locals questions on where to go, what to do, and how to act. Be sure to take at least one of these tours while you are in the city.

You‚Äôll find suggested itineraries, budgets, ways to save money, on and off the beaten path things to see and do, non-touristy restaurants, markets, and bars, and more! Book Your Accommodation You can book your hostel with Hostelworld as they have the biggest inventory and best deals. If you want to stay somewhere other than a hostel, use Booking.com as they consistently return the cheapest rates for guesthouses and cheap hotels. Two of my favorite places to stay are:
If you‚Äôre looking for more places to stay, here is a complete list of my favorite hostels in Lisbon.

I never go on a trip without it as I‚Äôve had to use it many times in the past. My favorite companies that offer the best service and value are:

Title: The Most Peaceful Place in Lisbon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We are a group of ordinary yet extraordinary travel lovers sharing our experiences of exploring the world with the world.

--
9
Listen
Share
I love the bustle of Lisbon: the up-and-down streets, the beauty of the multicolored azulejos fa√ßades on the buildings, the decorated cobblestone streets and sidewalks, and even the grittiness of the poorer neighbourhoods. But sometimes you want a break, a place without busy-ness, without touristy-ness. A place where you can feel calm and reflective for few hours. I discovered such a place in Estrela Park, a few blocks from the gleaming and grand Portuguese Parliament Buildings, and just opposite the Basilica da Estrela.
In contrast to these grand and gleaming buildings, Estrela Park feels intimate and a bit wild. Its main features are the exotic plants and trees from around the world that grow tall and lush within its gates. The park was designed in 1842 as a place for the working classes of Lisbon to relax and forget the toil and the stress of city living. Ironically, funding for construction dried up due to political instability, and the park was not completed until thirty years later. This was a tumultuous time for Portugal, as the nation veered precariously and at times violently between monarchists and republicans.
The tranquil green spaces are punctuated by several beautiful stone statues. It occurred to me that this juxtaposition between art and nature, white and green, would be worth a photo essay, showing the statues at a distance, half-hidden by the foliage, and then up close, where the depth of their expressiveness is unconcealed. But then, as I learned the stories behind these statues they revealed themselves to be much more than decorative. I‚Äôm presenting them in the order I came across them as I explored the park (and with gratitude to this Wordpress article, which helped me fill in the blanks about their origins):
The King‚Äôs Daughter, Guardian of the Ducks
She stands amid the rushes in the center of a pond, carrying a bundle of straw or something; a gaggle of stone ducks flocks around her feet. Up close, the naturalistic Art Nouveau style of the sculpture shows her in motion, walking along, yet looking down with care and affection at the ducks she guards. But wait: why would anyone guard ducks?
I discovered online that the statue was inspired by the Norwegian fairy tale of the same name, which I had never before heard of. The ducks, it turns out, are actually the 12 brothers of the princess. They had been enchanted by an evil witch. The princess risked her own life to break the spell, which could only be done by weaving each brother a shirt from thistledown (that‚Äôs what she carries in her arms). The down had to be harvested by moonlight in the moor of the trolls. It‚Äôs a harrowing tale of courage and deception, well worth reading.
Statue of Jo√£o de Deus
Jo√£o de Deus was a famous Portuguese poet, educator and politician of the 19th century, known for his personal rigor and political independence ‚Äî he never joined a political party. I first spied him behind the wrought-iron fence of the bandstand, beneath a flowering jacaranda tree. I was struck by the upright posture of this diminutive man, whose large head makes his body seem quite short. He seems both humble and strangely dignified. The school just next to the park bears his name.
Wikipedia says this about him: Next to Cam√µes and perhaps Almeida Garrett, no Portuguese poet has been more widely read, more profoundly admired than Jo√£o de Deus; yet no poet in any country has been more indifferent to public opinion and more deliberately careless of personal fame‚Ä¶
Oh my! He sounds like a man with the heart of a flan√™ur!
The Digger
This statue of a farmer tilling the soil with a hoe was erected in 1913 ‚Äî the first statue added to the garden after the monarchy was abolished and Portugal became a republic in 1910. Framed behind a spreading banyan tree, the sculpture seems a fitting public expression to mark the political transition. Notice how clearly the man‚Äôs rough clothing and strong arms are depicted.
But that look in his eyes ‚Äî it‚Äôs not that of a victorious peasant embracing his nation‚Äôs freedom, is it? To me, he is looking up anxiously, almost fearfully. Perhaps he symbolizes the entire nation, still working hard just to survive, gazing towards an uncertain future of the 20th Century. Would the eyes of a similar statue created in Portugal in 2022 look much different?
The Awakening, or Laziness
This 1915 statue of a naked young woman arising in the morning is said to be the most popular in the park. It‚Äôs easy to see why. From a distance, under an umbrella tree, her white figure is eye-catchingly sensuous.
Up close, though, it is the expression on her face that makes her so utterly beguiling ‚Äî that satisfied, languorous smile, those half-opened eyes! Though one of her arms is missing, the other is clearly in the middle of a stretch. I love the two very different words the woman supposedly embodies: Awakening and Laziness. Is she rising to meet the day, awakening to the possibilities and hopes of her future ‚Äî much as the young republic was awakening? Or has she already risen too late to do anything productive with her youthful energy? It‚Äôs hard not to think about her fellow statue, the Digger, not 50 meters away, who has been toiling away, probably since dawn.
Statue of Antero de Quental
Antero de Quental was a 19th Century realist poet and political philosopher, but his statue is the last edition to the park. It was installed in this private grove of ivy-covered trees in 1951. It makes me laugh to see a ‚Äúrealist‚Äù poet dressed in the robes of an ancient Roman! I hope he has a good sense of humor in whatever immortal realm of the poets he resides.
As a young poet, de Quental declared the role of poets, in an era of great transformation, was to be messengers of the day‚Äôs great ideological questions. He emerged as a socialist, advocate of the proletariat, and eventually an anarchist. To me it‚Äôs surprising his defiant-seeming statue was installed in the midst of Portugal‚Äôs repressive Salazar dictatorship.
Wikipedia has this to say about the great poet, and the sad ending of his life: Throughout his life, de Quental oscillated between pessimism and depression; afflicted with what might have been bipolar disorder‚Ä¶he committed suicide by two gunshots to the stomach while seated on a bench in a local garden park. He died approximately an hour later. ‚ÄúOf all things, the worst is having been born,‚Äù he wrote in a poem.
Allegory (Man with a Dog)
This final statue I encountered reclines at the edge of another little lake in the park, and has an ‚Äúunknown provenance.‚Äù Seen below, shrouded behind palm trees, it features a man in a robe with wild curly hair and a long beard that appears blown back as he leans slightly into an invisible strong wind. His large, powerful hands hold protectively onto his little dog. Its lips form a wide ‚ÄúO‚Äù because its mouth is also the spout of a fountain.
There is something loveable about this sculpture. I suppose it is the forcefulness of the man juxtaposed with the gentle way he holds his companion. It made me smile and think of all the old men and women I‚Äôve seen in Lisbon, even in Estrela Park, out walking their little dogs.
The future might be wild and uncertain, but we can do the best we can to take care of the ones we love, whether dogs or ducks or a whole nation, even a continent, once again in the midst of turbulent times and perhaps a great transformation.
