Title: Lisbon: The Most Over-Hyped, Over-Priced ‚ÄúHidden Gem‚Äù in Europe
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Ah, Lisbon. The ‚Äúit‚Äù destination of every travel influencer who‚Äôs already exhausted Paris, Rome, and Barcelona. You know, that hidden gem where everyone and their grandmother is flocking to for its authentic charm? Yeah, that place.
Let me paint you a picture: sun-drenched streets, vibrant azulejos, and Fado music echoing from every corner. It all sounds like a dream, right? Until you‚Äôre elbow-to-elbow with a herd of selfie-stick-wielding tourists, paying ‚Ç¨15 for a pastel de nata while being told it‚Äôs a steal. Lisbon is that friend who showed up late to the party, acts like they invented the party, and then charges you an entry fee to stay.
Remember when people said Lisbon was Europe‚Äôs best-kept secret, a cheap alternative to all those other overpriced cities? Ah yes, those were the days‚Ä¶ like three years ago. Fast forward to today, and you‚Äôre casually dropping ‚Ç¨200 a night for an Airbnb with a rustic view of the neighbor‚Äôs laundry hanging out to dry. Authentic, right? At least the Tuk-Tuksare cheap. Oh wait, no they‚Äôre not ‚Äî get ready to sell a kidney for a 10-minute ride that smells like exhaust fumes and regret.
Oh, and about those locals everyone raves about meeting ‚Äî good luck finding any. Lisbon is now a foreigner‚Äôs paradise, with expats and digital nomads who‚Äôve all set up camp. You won‚Äôt meet many born-and-bred Lisboetas because they‚Äôve been priced out of their own city and forced to the suburbs. It‚Äôs basically Lisbon: The International Edition. But sure, tell your friends you really connected with the local culture while chatting with other tourists over overpriced sangria.
What could make this urban utopia even better? How about a healthy dose of soul-crushing traffic. Lisbon has turned into a slow-moving parking lot. It‚Äôs ironic because for a city with hills so steep they should come with a life insurance policy, you‚Äôd think driving would be a breeze. Nope. It‚Äôs gridlock central, with honking horns, frustrated drivers, and narrow streets that could fit maybe one-and-a-half cars from the 1980s. So be prepared to sit back, relax, and enjoy the sounds of motorbikes revving while you take in the sights and smells of the city.
Speaking of smells‚Ä¶
If you‚Äôre looking for that special olfactory experience, Lisbon‚Äôs got you covered. Nothing says European sophisticationquite like walking down a street and being hit with the sweet perfume of sewage mixed with leftover sardines and an occasional whiff of diesel fumes. Add in the occasional garbage strike, and you‚Äôve got a delightful sensory overload that really enhances the ambiance. Ah, the authenticity.
‚ÄúLisbon has the best seafood in the world!‚Äù they say, and sure, it‚Äôs great. If by ‚Äúgreat‚Äù you mean paying ‚Ç¨30 for a plate of sardines served with a side of Instagrammable lighting. Maybe you can hunt for one of those hidden, local tasquinhas, but here‚Äôs the reality: the moment you find one, congratulations! So has the rest of the internet. Prepare to pay tourist prices for what used to be a grandma‚Äôs Sunday lunch.
And speaking of pastel de nata (because everyone has to mention it, right?), after you‚Äôve waited 45 minutes in line for the world‚Äôs best custard tart at Past√©is de Bel√©m, you‚Äôll realize something groundbreaking: it‚Äôs a tart. A good tart, but in the end, it‚Äôs 3 bites of egg custard. Revolutionary.
Love walking? Great, because you‚Äôll be doing a lot of it. Lisbon is famous for its seven hills, which should really come with a fitness warning. Your calves will either be rock solid after day one or you‚Äôll be crawling up to the nearest overpriced cafe to gasp for air and reconsider your life choices. Who needs a gym when you‚Äôve got uneven cobblestone streets and inclines that rival the Tour de France?
Oh, and don‚Äôt think about wearing anything stylish. Those charming stone sidewalks will have you slipping and sliding into oblivion. Practical shoes or death ‚Äî your call.
Lisbon is the land of boutique hotels and chic rooftop bars now. Need a cocktail with a view? You‚Äôre in luck ‚Äî if you‚Äôve got ‚Ç¨15 to spare for something served in a mason jar with an edible flower garnish. Nothing screams ‚Äúauthentic Portuguese culture‚Äù quite like a trendy rooftop overlooking the real Lisbon down below, where locals used to afford rent.
Speaking of rent, just try talking to someone who‚Äôs lived in Lisbon for more than five years. They‚Äôll tell you about the days when you could get a two-bedroom apartment for the price of a plate of Bacalhau √† Br√°s. Now? Good luck finding anything that‚Äôs not being Airbnb-ed by some guy named Chad who‚Äôs ‚Äúliving his best life‚Äù while making a killing off your holiday budget.
Fado music is the soul of Lisbon, a haunting, melancholic soundtrack to the city‚Äôs history. That is, until you realize you‚Äôre paying ‚Ç¨50 for a dinner-and-Fado experience where the servers sing in between handing you a glass of overpriced house wine. It‚Äôs like dinner theater but with extra saudade and a hefty bill.
If you love being part of a crowd of people who are all convinced they‚Äôve discovered something new and edgy, Lisbon is for you. Sure, it‚Äôs beautiful, but so is that postcard of the Eiffel Tower you could‚Äôve bought instead of spending ‚Ç¨500 on a long weekend here. Between the hills, the prices, the awful traffic, the expat invasion, and the stench, Lisbon is Europe‚Äôs most over-hyped, over-exposed city. But hey, at least you‚Äôll get a great Instagram post out of it. #LisbonGoals #LivingTheDream #SendHelp

This final statue I encountered reclines at the edge of another little lake in the park, and has an ‚Äúunknown provenance.‚Äù Seen below, shrouded behind palm trees, it features a man in a robe with wild curly hair and a long beard that appears blown back as he leans slightly into an invisible strong wind. His large, powerful hands hold protectively onto his little dog. Its lips form a wide ‚ÄúO‚Äù because its mouth is also the spout of a fountain.
There is something loveable about this sculpture. I suppose it is the forcefulness of the man juxtaposed with the gentle way he holds his companion. It made me smile and think of all the old men and women I‚Äôve seen in Lisbon, even in Estrela Park, out walking their little dogs.
The future might be wild and uncertain, but we can do the best we can to take care of the ones we love, whether dogs or ducks or a whole nation, even a continent, once again in the midst of turbulent times and perhaps a great transformation.
--
--
9
We are a group of ordinary yet extraordinary travel lovers sharing our experiences of exploring the world with the world.
Author, communications expert and publisher of Changemakers Books, Tim is now a full time Mature Flaneur, wandering Europe with Teresa, his beloved wife.

Title: Discovering Portugal: The 10-Day trip to Lisbon and Azores
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Hello readers!
I‚Äôve always dreamt of being the traveler who writes her blog from a cozy coffee shop in the visiting town. That dream comes true as I bring you this post live from Lisbon, Portugal.
Sid and I couldn‚Äôt be happier since we touched down in Portugal. Visiting this vibrant country has been a long-standing wish, and we‚Äôre thrilled to be here finally. We are spending ten days exploring two incredible destinations: the vibrant capital city of Lisbon and the stunning volcanic island of Sao Miguel in the Azores.
In this blog post, I will share my experience in Lisbon.
I had doubts when Sid insisted on coming to Lisbon instead of Porto or Faro, as in my research, most travel blogs raved about these two as more popular and cultural cities to visit. But oh boy, how Lisbon grew on me.
I mean it is difficult not to fall in love with Lisbon. In addition to its energy, charm, and laid-back vibe, the city has so much to offer:
What more can a girl want? Well, Lisbon had a secret surprise for me.
By lucky happenstance, we visited Lisbon in the week of St Anthony‚Äôs Day, the biggest festival of the year for the city. This catapulted our experience 10x. Not only did we get to enjoy the festivities of June 12, but also we got to see the city in its full charm, bustling with street parties, food stalls, on-the-go cocktails, & colorful decorations throughout the five days.
The festival was undoubtedly a highlight, and I feel incredibly fortunate to have experienced such cultural immersion. Here are some special moments from our time joining the local festivities:
If you can, I will highly recommend planning your trip to the capital city of Portugal in June. But no sweat if you are unable to. Lisbon is a family-friendly and an all-year destination, so visit whenever you visit, you will have a great time.
Let me share more about what else made our Lisbon experience unforgettable.
Belem was our first stop in Lisbon. It‚Äôs full of attractions, so we purchased a 24-hour Lisboa card to avoid having to buy individual tickets at each site. This also helped us avoid queues which is a life savior as this location is frequented by many tourists. Almost everywhere there was a 30‚Äì45-minute queue to get tickets, so I will highly recommend buying yours in advance!
We started with the Belem Tower. It had beautiful stone architecture and was very picturesque thanks to being right by the water.
Besides that though, there wasn't much to do inside despite the hype. So if you are pressed for time, instead of waiting in line to go up the tower, I will recommend walking along the water to the Monument of the Discoveries, I enjoyed this walk much more than exploring Belem Tower from inside.
The Monument of Discoveries was a captivating work of art. It showcases 33 significant figures who played pivotal roles in Portugal‚Äôs overseas expansion. On this trip, I was fascinated to discover how much the Portuguese pride their international conquests in South America and Asia.
What truly captivated me about this monument were the intricate carvings of these figures. As someone who dabbles in pottery and finds it challenging to carve even in the forgiving medium of clay, I can only imagine the skill and precision required to achieve such detailed work in stone.
Speaking of carving, the real treasure was the Jer√≥nimos Monastery ‚Äî our next stop! While I was standing in the line to go in, I had many moments when I wanted to ditch it and move on to the next site as even Lisboa card didn't allow us to skip-the-queue here. But THANK GOD I did not.
The architecture inside the Monastery is breathtaking. I was constantly reaching for my phone, and even though the lighting was challenging, we managed a few great clicks.
There was also a church adjacent to the monastery, which was equally beautiful. I had a little deja vu of history class when I crossed Vasco Dd Gamma‚Äôs tomb, remembering reading about him as the man who found the sea route from Europe to India, ultimately leading to the Portuguese colonizing the Indian state of Goa.
Belem also has the iconic Past√©is de Bel√©m, a popular bakery where the iconic custard tarts of Portugal are believed to have originated. It was so conveniently located next to the monastery, that we weren't even surprised that there was a long wait to get a table. It didn't matter as the weather was pleasant, we just grabbed our bites and enjoyed them in the nearby park ‚Äî in true London fashion! üòâ
After Belem, we returned to the city center. We decided to hike up to the Castle Sao Jorge via Alfama.
Alfama is Lisbon‚Äôs oldest and most enchanting neighborhood. And wandering through its narrow, winding streets here is one of my favorite memories from the trip. üòç
Second favorite memory is the pitstop at Portas do Sol. This viewpoint offers a much-needed breather after climbing the steep steps of Alfama. And the panoramic view is breathtaking! Another spot where I couldn't stop reaching for my phone and managed to get a few good clicks despite challenging lighting.
I came back to this multiple times during the trip and it was never enough time to soak in the beauty.
As we made our way to the castle, the views were even more spectacular from up there. The castle‚Äôs interior doesn‚Äôt hold much as most of it was destroyed in an earthquake, which was never reinstated. Fun fact: under the dictator's rule, this castle‚Äôs walls were restored to create a postcard-perfect image of Lisbon, leaving the insides in complete ruins.
I, however, thoroughly enjoyed exploring the interiors too. The battlements, the scenic staircase, peacocks strutting the castle grounds, and remains of the pottery used many years ago, made for a charming evening.
We also watched the sunset from the cozy little restaurant they had inside the castle walls. It was the perfect place to end the day and savor some summer drinks after a long fulfilling day.
Lisbon provides easy accessibility to the neighboring towns such as Sintra and Cascais. Both of which are less than an hour's train ride and cost under 10 euros back and forth.
For Sintra, we took the train from Rossio Station. Trains also run from Oriente station at a higher frequency but we opted for Rossio as that was within walking distance from our apartment and we wanted to get there as soon as possible to beat the crowd (which we couldn‚Äôt because yours truly likes her sleepüòõ).
The town was quite hilly, so while I was taking my time to hike around in my flowy dress, Sid, who grew up in the foothills of the Himalayas aka pahadi ladka, was feeling right at home and leading the way enthusiastically.
And for once, instead of Sid, I was remembering my childhood vacations in the hills ‚Äî to Shimla and Mussoorie ‚Äî the famous hill stations in India.
Our first stop was Quinta da Regaleira. This site is a mysterious estate with Gothic architecture, hidden tunnels, and lush gardens. Everything was so beautiful and well-maintained, that one can easily spend hours in this place.
The highlight was undoubtedly the famous Initiation Well, a spiral staircase that descends into the earth.
We enjoyed the experience of going down the stairs and it was also fun to explore the network of underground passages and caves it led to.
Our day was jam-packed as there were two more sites we wanted to see in Sintra. So we decided to have a quick lunch at the caf√© within the estate. The soup at the cafe was one of the best soups I have had ‚Äî 100% recommended.
We decided to make our way to Moors Cattle ‚Äî our next destination ‚Äî via a hike through Villa Sassetti. Now, here are some learnings:
It took us about 45 minutes to the Moorish Castle. Even though I was feeling tired, this site took my breath away. It was an ancient fortress that extended on two sides with long stone-walled towers on each. It was a complete contrast to Quinta da Regaleira but no less breathtaking. I had never seen anything like this before, so I was in awe. And despite my fear of heights, I climbed to the highest point of the castle and was rewarded with stunning views.
Can you tell from my photo that I was getting tired? Well, by the time we reached the iconic Pena Palace ‚Äî I was in a mood ü•±
Sintra is often referred to as the magical town owing to this palace because it allegedly inspired Walt Disney to create the castle in Disney stories. Sadly, I wasn‚Äôt as impressed by the palace as I had hoped. Maybe it was the mix of exhaustion and crowds that turned me off. Because goes without saying that the palace was stunning. The intricate tile work and the rich contrast of deep red and yellow with the green-manicured gardens were truly impressive.
And roaming around the rooms gave an insight into how living in the bygone era of royalty and romance must have felt.
Kudos to Sid for keeping me going and capturing beautiful memories of lifetime despite my exhaustion.
After two days of intense exploring, Sid decided to catch up on work for the remaining days. It was a perfect excuse for me to start the morning slow.
The shot above is from our apartment in Lisbon. We stayed at the Sao Nicolau Townhouse by Ando Living. Ando Living is a collection of lifestyle-serviced apartments in Lisbon, Porto, and Istanbul. The apartment was spacious and beautifully decorated and we were welcomed with complimentary snacks and wine, which was a pleasant surprise and fun to relish on this balcony after a tiring day of city exploring.
We liked staying in the Baixa-Chidao area, it was a little touristy but the vibes and connectivity were excellent.
With easier access to Europe, Sid and I are embracing the concept of slow travel. This means staying longer at places we are visiting to truly soak in the local culture. Sid is splitting his time between exploring and working remotely. I am using the extra days to engage in local activities that otherwise I wouldn‚Äôt have the time for.
I was fortunate to try a few of these in Lisbon, and I will recommend these three:
After that, I decided to take a baking class for Past√©is de Nata. I am not a big chef, but I like to learn new skills, and cooking delicacies from different cuisines has always fascinated me. When we decided to move to London, I remember thinking this would be a good opportunity to build this skill. After all:
There are multiple baking classes available, but I decided to do the one with Homecooking Lisbon. It was highly rated and better priced. I think that‚Äôs because it was a little out of the touristy areas, but not too far, as I walked to LX Factory from there. I also saw a tram right outside so its pretty well connected.
The baking class turned out to be an incredible experience. Having never baked pastries before, I was nervous. But our instructor was so skilled and walked us through each step patiently. Honestly, I thought the tarts are pretty easy to bake at home, and I will definitely try.
I made a new friend in the class‚Äî a sweet girl from Australia with whom I was teamed up. I had a blast baking together and we couldnt stop giggling after she pointed to me that she found our instructor rather charming ü•∞
I also met a lovely couple from New Zealand who had been saving for years to make this trip happen and were midway in their three-month-long Europe exploration, having covered South France and Spain before Portugal, and were headed to Greece and Italy after.
There was also this fun family from California. Both parents were proud chemical engineers, much to the embarrassment of their daughter, who had to keep reminding them that ‚ÄúThis is a cooking class, not a science class!‚Äù üòÑ
And the best part was that we not only had a plate full of warm custards to try as a group, but was enough for everyone to take home ‚Äî I was so excited for Sid to try!
2. Free Walking tour
Last but not least, I can‚Äôt not talk about the free walking tout I took on my last day in Lisbon. It was a fantastic way to meet a local guide and learn fun facts about the city that I had so thoroughly enjoyed.
Our tour guide was fantastic ‚Äî she was fun, laid-back, and full of captivating stories about Portugal ‚Äî good, bad or ugly ‚Äî she narrated her anecdotes in an endearing way.
Did you know that Lisbon is older than Rome? Yep, it is the second oldest capital city in Europe, right after Athens. Despite being so ancient, it was ruled by numerous powers, including the Romans, Germans, Spanish, Greeks, and even the Moors. The Moors, in particular, left a lasting legacy with their beautiful tiles that adorn the city today.
Did you know the Portuguese are very proud of the overseas expansion? I mean, they did put up the Monument of Discoveries in Belem to celebrate that. I knew the Portuguese had invaded India and Brazil, but I didn‚Äôt know they had invaded China as well. In fact, I learned an interesting fun fact that oranges in the Mediterranean used to be bitter and green until the Portuguese found the sweet and reddish oranges in China, which they brought back to Europe for trade. They were such a hit that countries started naming the fruit after Portugal ‚Äî Romania‚Äôs ‚Äòportocale,‚Äô Bulgaria and Turkey‚Äôs ‚Äòportakal,‚Äô and Greece‚Äôs ‚Äòportokali‚Äô all mean orange.
Our tour guide also shared about the time when Portugal crowned a bastard son as king of Portugal instead of making the daughter queen because she was married to the King of Spain. I mean, that makes sense, given the history of colonization. Interestingly though, the story has a Game of Thrones twist. The city‚Äôs bishop was against this coronation and in protest, he didn‚Äôt ring the bells of the famous Lisbon cathedral. Fatal mistake, as soon after he was thrown out of the top window (yes, the window you see in this picture) in front of the entire city and it was still considered an honest ‚Äúbattle mistake.‚Äù
‚ÄúWell, that's a Portuguese sense of humor and easy-going vibe for all of you‚Äù ‚Äî concluded our tour guide.
Well, she didn't just leave us there. She also took us to this special street called Rua De Saudade to familiarise us with ‚ÄúSaudade‚Äù, a unique Portuguese term that doesn‚Äôt translate into any other language, and encompasses a feeling of longing, melancholy, and nostalgia.
This is the other layer to the Portuguese soul she said ‚Äî an undercurrent of melancholy.
3. Fado Live Music Show
This is also what their traditional Fado music beautifully encapsulates. We were fortunate to find a nice show to enoy this music. We had such a great time experiencing this despite the language barrier, it was a perfect way to end our stay in Lisbon.
On day 4, the sky cleared. Until now we had decent weather too, but it was slightly chilly for me, especially in the evening. Staying indoors would have been a shame on a perfect sunny day like that, so since Sid was busy , I hopped on a quick 40-minute train ride to explore the beach town of Cascais by myself.
It turned out to be the best decision! As soon as the train left the Lisbon station, I was welcomed by the sparkling blue waters of the Atlantic Ocean. I wasn‚Äôt expecting the entire train ride to be this coastal. And when I reached, right off the bat I could feel the beach air. The city was bustling with people, but in a relaxing and rejuvenating way. And the vibe was lively and infectious.
Before I retired to the beach, I did a short walk around the town to check out some places I read about in the self-guided walking tour I found online. You see, Cascais is that kind of town where there are beaches plus a lot of other things to see as well.
Cascais was also great for retail therapy. I mean, leave me alone and I don‚Äôt come back with shopping bags ‚Äî ask Sid if that has ever happened üòõ
No, but seriously, I found both quality and price better here in Cascais than in Lisbon. And if those beautiful colorful cork products don‚Äôt attract you ‚Äî nothing will. I was so excited to taking these beautiful pieces home and remember my sweet trip by.
==============================================================
I‚Äôll come back to Portugal for more history in Porto, more culture in Algrave, and more commerce in Alentejo. But for now ‚Äî it is island time and up next is Sao Miguel, Azores. Stay tuned, the next post coming soon!

Title: Lisbon (Portugal) is not paradise, and nowhere else is either
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
If you look on Instagram, living abroad seems to be such an exciting, colourful, perfect experience. But more often than not, being an ‚Äúimmigrant‚Äù is much harder than it seems.
[Clarification, to me, you are not an ‚Äúexpat‚Äù until your company sends you to work abroad. If you choose to move in another country, you are an ‚Äúimmigrant‚Äù. Using the word ‚Äúexpat‚Äù only for temporary, rich and privileged (often Western) countries seems like a post-colonial term to me. We are all immigrants if we decide to live abroad.]
At the beginning everything is exciting and overwhelming at the same time. Then, you start feeling alone. You don‚Äôt speak the language. You‚Äôve lost all the things that used to make you ‚Äúyou‚Äù before. Your little habits. It‚Äôs super hard to integrate.
There‚Äôs this saying that goes something like ‚Äúthe grass is greener in the neighbours‚Äô garden‚Äù. Well, until you haven‚Äôt experienced it, I don‚Äôt think you can understand what it actually means.
After having lived in 5 different countries (France, Belgium, Hungary, Romania, Portugal), in 8 different cities, I can confidently say that there‚Äôs no such thing as one, perfect place that has it all. In the end it comes down to what you are looking for at a certain point in your life.
For example, some on the internet will have you believe that living in sunny Lisbon, Portugal is wonderful. It is, but few talk about the (very) low salaries locals have here and the struggle it is to make a living. How high the taxes are. The horror of bureaucracy. Or how expensive housing has become (same prices as in Paris!). How uncomfortable winters can be here, without central heating, proper isolation and as a result, mold infestation in the walls. How hard it is to make friends if you don‚Äôt speak the language. The list goes on.
I used to think that people in my home country (France) were all very negative. But then I met people who challenged my conception and I realised that you find negative people or even jerks, everywhere. Human beings tend to do this very funny thing called ‚Äúprojection‚Äù which is when someone projects his or her own perception onto something or someone else.
Generalising an experience is a dangerous exercise because in the end all experiences are very subjective and personal. Some will like living in ‚ÄúX‚Äù place, some will hate it. Don‚Äôt take everything you see or hear for the absolute truth. Challenge it. Ask yourself, would it make sense to me?
Also, the place you might hate could be paradise for someone else. Let‚Äôs keep an open mind about the reality of what life is actually like. Not in those ‚Äúexpats‚Äù bubbles or what ‚ÄúInstagram lifestyle gurus‚Äù preach.
Living abroad is fantastic, it‚Äôs also very hard. You grow a lot. You have to reinvent yourself, leave your comfort zone. It can also be very rewarding. You learn about yourself, about life, about letting go and adapting, about surviving. You might even start to appreciate some things you had ‚Äúat home‚Äù.
Everyone should experience living abroad once in their life, if they have the opportunity to do so. Maybe if we did, we would be more tolerant and understanding of each other, more open, warm, welcoming‚Ä¶ Maybe communities would actually flourish again. And the world would be a better place.
--
--
Survivor, seeker, storyteller. Writing to heal from maternal narcissistic abuse and CPTSD. A journey of resilience, truth and rebirth as I find my voice.

Title: Lisbon Land Ownership Mapping: Unpacking Regulatory Mechanisms Behind Lisbon‚Äôs Spatial (In)justice
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

This blog series presents the results of the common investigation of Dark Matter Labs and the Institute of Human Rights and Business which seeks to explore the opportunities and barriers to just transition in the built environment through perspectives of urban land ownership.

--
Listen
Share
This blog post is the 4th article in the series. The collaboration between Dark Matter Labs and the Institute of Human Rights and Business (IHRB) has previously resulted in mapping of Copenhagen and Prague, and aims to continue its investigation further in Athens.
Through findings in this blog, we aim to flag the role of the state and city councils as active agents ‚Äî alongside many others ‚Äî shaping neoliberal development as opposed to the prevailing belief that solely the market forces may jeopardize spatial justice. The example of Lisbon shows that whereas transparent and accessible land ownership information is an important enabler for public oversight and policy, it is not the only key factor shaping a city‚Äôs ability to safeguard local livelihoods and affordability. This blog post expands on the thesis that land ownership patterns are foundational to spatial (in)justice, broadening the definition by encompassing the state- and city council-led regulatory mechanisms that govern property markets.
Lisbon is currently the 3rd most expensive city in Europe for rental accommodation. Given Portugal‚Äôs lower salary levels compared to other European member states, the recent penetration of vast amounts of foreign capital into the housing market has made everyday life increasingly unmanageable for its citizens.
Lisbon can be considered as a flagship example of the dynamics where the public debt of the European ‚Äúsemi-periphery‚Äù to the financial European and global market ‚Äúcore‚Äù (see: Lima, 2023) creditors turns the city into space for capital accumulation and its repayment. The public assets, municipal land, cultural heritage, housing, service sector and public space all become tools for economic growth often measured solely by abstract metrics such as real estate value appreciation.
Financialization means that even greater amounts of capital decoupled from the real economy and local realities (livelihoods, salaries etc.) flow into the city‚Äôs square meters turning them into financial assets that demand continuous returns on investments. In a context where finance is linked to space, new waves of capital need to continue finding physical room to act, with major impacts on people‚Äôs lives. The true debtors of this logic are not only the state or the municipality balance sheets, but the displaced citizens whose apartments needed to be freed for urban rehabilitation, struggling middle-class families facing soaring housing costs, the 22,812 families on the waiting list for social housing, and the young; future generations who might never afford a home, forced to live with their parents.
In Lisbon, state-aided deregulation of the rental market, commodification of the existing housing stock, land and new housing developments speculation are the forces that have shaped this condition. Based on existing research, this blog aims to explain these forces.
Due to a lack of data transparency, it is difficult to precisely assess and depict who owns land and properties in the city, as well as what are the historical transactions which could bring actors in power into the public eye. What is known, however, through qualitative interviews with leading housing justice researchers, is that the main factors that have been shaping the catastrophic housing affordability crisis in Lisbon are those known to many other cities in Europe.
The structure of the blog aims to guide the reader through the dynamics which led Lisbon to its current condition.
1. Role of the state ‚Äî making ground for new capital
2. Large institutional investors & land ownership patterns
3. Data transparency review
4. Conclusion and recent developments
Neoliberalism involves preference for the extension of spontaneous (freed from state interference) competitiveness, market powers, and the belief in their ability to regulate economies efficiently. As it aims for a world where the state‚Äôs role is diminished, it paints a false picture of its passive role in the neoliberalisation of the economies. However, it‚Äôs precisely the state which, through a deliberate set of policies and regulations, provides the means through which the free market forces can spread their wings.
The case of Lisbon is exemplary, demonstrating that, in the context of property markets, instead of merely conforming to the free market doctrine, the state, and the municipal government chose to regulate in favour of the private sector to stimulate economic growth.
Against the backdrop of the 2008 financial crisis, the EU, Portuguese state, and Lisbon city government implemented, on the one hand, austerity measures resulting in the lowest public investment in housing in Europe, and on the other, multiple incentive mechanisms to attract foreign investment capital, aiming to repay the ‚ÄúTroika‚Äù loan, and re-stabilise the economy.
Neoliberalist logic moved Portugal away from its previous, more welfare-oriented system, creating a new state-craft infrastructure for market-oriented economic growth. Rather than being passive agents, the governing institutions actively retreated, creating room for the private market to rule.
To understand the reasons why Lisbon became so unaffordable, one needs to understand the set of historical events that turned the city, from being from a ‚Äúhigh-risk‚Äù location, to a top investment destination in 2018 (the Emerging Trends in Real Estate European ranking, PwC & Urban Land Institute, 2018).
The developments which took place over two decades can be summarised as major trends of:
2. 1. Further financialisation of the housing stock through engagement of large- scale institutional investors
The first trend can be broken down further into three state-led and deliberate shaping mechanisms including:
Financing ‚Äî Urban rehabilitation funding programmes that provided efficient financing infrastructure for renovations of the historical core
Deregulation ‚Äî Simplification of urban rehabilitation rules
Liberalisation ‚Äî Special tax incentives based on a desired economic turn towards commercial and tourist functions
Low taxation for EU citizens willing to relocate and invest
Incentives for wealthy transnationals willing to invest in the property market
o Liberalisation of the rental market through, among others,
The set of events shows that multiple incentives and deregulation rather than demand and supply issues led to the current unaffordability (see: Untaxed, Investigate Europe 2022).
The measures that led to the commodification of the historical core proved to be successful in terms of real estate investment returns. Following this first wave of investments, the perceived oversupply of luxury housing and scarcity of land for new large-scale investments in the central areas led institutional investors to bet on the peripheral plots of Lisbon‚Äôs metropolitan area.
A significant surge of almost 90% in building permits between 2017 and 2018 indicates this surge in large-scale investments, where substantial capital could be deployed. The adoption of a build-to-sell strategy ensured a secure exit option for institutional investors, who then facilitated the acquisition of ostensibly ‚Äúaffordable‚Äù housing from non-premium segments by smaller investors keen on subletting.
As highlighted by Lima, 2013, the narratives of the large investors shifted towards ‚Äúlong-term‚Äù investments targeting ‚Äúthe middle class‚Äù. Further narrative tools which the author points towards are:
Against the backdrop of liberalised rental laws, institutional investors drove the creation of a ‚Äúnew supply‚Äù of speculative rental apartment units extending beyond the historical core. This perpetuates the financialisation of housing, allowing the trend to proliferate and persist beyond the city centre.
The following illustration aims to capture the dynamics that led to Lisbon‚Äôs persisting unaffordability:
By complementing the great research of Lima, 2023 with our own investigations regarding land sizes, the following table shows the largest projects led by institutional investors in the Lisbon metropolitan area:
Link to the TABLE
Additionally the Map by Lima, 2023 shows locations of the projects.
Further research, including Lisbon‚Äôs Municipal Housing Charter‚Äôs, clearly indicates that the Municipality of Lisbon and State & Public Companies remain large landowners in the city (see maps).
We have created a map that combines this data.
Link to INTERACTIVE MAP
Interestingly, the Lisbon Land Registry function resides under the Ministry of Justice. The permanent certificate of land registry provides, online, all the data regarding a property, even the pending requests. It is always updated and available for consultation. The WEBSITE (INSTRUCTION (in Portuguese) of the Registo Predial Online offers the possibility of creating a ticket based on Town, parish (however, outdated taxonomy) and building number. The building number however can only be known if the interested party knows it (e.g. from a legal document such as a property sales contract) or applies for it in a physical office in Lisbon.
Application based on the property number (not land plot) is possible but costs 1 euro per entry (each apartment is one entry). For for purposes of this project, obtaining the scale of data would be simply beyond budget, and it may not even give much information on land. No data has therefore been purchased from this source.
As a test, a random search for buildings in the area of Santa Catarina (which is now part of the Miseric√≥rdia parish) revealed 650 possible buildings, several of which may contain multiple housing units. One could reduce the cost of the purchase by filtering out some buildings (for example, those known to be owned by the municipality), but this is not an option, as the cadaster building number is decoupled from its address.
Interviews with researchers conducting similar investigations (Cocola-Gant, A; Gago A.; Lima, R, and Silva R.) confirmed that large-scale land ownership investigations are an impossible or very costly task. Applications for buildings by their address costs 14 euro, need to be submitted via a physical office in Lisbon and are limited to 10 inquiries per day. According to some researchers, even the municipality‚Äôs own planning department may not have a clear overview on the municipal assets.
Lisbon serves as a prime illustration of how gentrification processes, initially disconnected from land ownership, originate in the city core and radiate outwards. Initially, urban rehabilitation efforts and incentives for transnational individuals and corporate investors attract foreign capital, which primarily targets properties such as apartments and housing units, and are not necessarily land focused. In the second instance, however, as the market matures, land plays an important role as the large-scale investors attracted by promising returns seek space for large-scale developments. Thus, as the property market in the central areas gets saturated, the new wave of large-scale investments provides a new supply of housing units, inflating the market further.
Amid rising cost of living, Lisbon city council has recently introduced measures to mitigate the effects of increased financialisation of the housing sector.
This February (2024) the municipality approved the new ‚ÄúCooperativas 1¬™ Habita√ß√£o Lisboa‚Äù programme which involves making municipal assets available to housing cooperatives for 90 years. This includes small plots of land for construction of affordable housing by the cooperatives. Furthermore, Lisbon‚Äôs Municipal Housing Charter just went through a 3-month long public consultation process (see also Civic Assembly‚Äôs website, the Report, and Maps). The Charter defines a strategy for the implementation of municipal housing policies between 2023 and 2033, representing an investment of 918 million euros. Its future is yet to be seen.
Special thanks to Agust√≠n Cocola-Gant, Ana Gago, Rita Silva, Rafaella Lima for your valuable research and time sharing insights that enabled the writing of this blog post. In depth research, action and activism on the ground are the true powers able to change the trajectories of spatial injustice.
This research and blog post is conducted and written by Aleksander Nowak aleks@darkmatterlabs.org
Giulio Ferrini (IHRB) giulio.ferrini@ihrb.orgAnnabel Short (IHRB) annabel.short@ihrb.org

Title: Why Are People From Lisbon Called ‚ÄúLittle Lettuces‚Äù?
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Stories from Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking lands and cultures

Member-only story
Featured
--
30

There is a certain pride in affirming the statement, ‚Äúsou alfacinha‚Äù (I‚Äôm a little lettuce) when inquired by other Portuguese people about where in Portugal I am from.
Not that it isn‚Äôt already obvious from my bland accent. The one that, us Lisboners, call the ‚Äònormal‚Äô or ‚Äòneutral‚Äô Portuguese accent, but really is more of a muffled series of mumblings and swallowed word endings. Something resembling Spanish with a Russian accent, or so I‚Äôve been told.
‚ÄúSou alfacinha‚Äù, I confirm, with a smile on my face. I smile, and then curl the sides of my mouth into an expression of confusion. Why on earth am I calling myself a lettuce? And a small one at that?
The expressions we provide on-demand, like automatized motions learned as toddlers, are often a complete mystery to us. We use them, seldom realizing what they actually mean.
Like a baton passed in an intergenerational rally race.
It‚Äôs a crisp morning. The kind that flaunts itself through the window as the day breaks. The sun is beaming through its seams and reflecting off the Atlantic coast, into the vast sky that paints the day blue.

Title: Lisbon Beyond the Hype
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Luxury travel, redefined. Changing the way you discover the world, one immersive experience at a time.

--
Listen
Share
Carried by the river Tagus is the mix of food, architecture, spices, and cultures that have blended together over the course of centuries to create present-day Lisbon. With the lure of vibrant yellow trams, delicious custard tarts, and promises of charming nearby towns, the rest of the world is turning up to discover one of Europe‚Äôs oldest (and most beautiful) capital cities.
Kelsey Lash is our intrepid travel writer who recently deepened her love of the Portuguese capital during an incredible stay at the Four Seasons Hotel. Kelsey tapped into the expertise of Lisbon native and local guru, Jo√£o Santana Domingos, to take you on an immersive journey through the vibrant streets, profound history and captivating culture of the City of Seven Hills.
Lisbon‚Äôs history, which shines through modernity, is best experienced through taste ‚Äî and there‚Äôs no better way to sample that diversity than with petiscos. These small portions of diverse and adventurous dishes can be washed down with a glass of vinho verde, a young wine with a distinctive fresh and fruity palette, cultivated by small growers in the country‚Äôs historic Minho province. Taverns and trendy bars alike present the perfect opportunity to experience Portuguese cuisine and lifestyle in one atmospheric sitting. Head to Bairro do Avillez where seafood and fish are always on the menu and sample the specialty red giant shrimp and razor clams.
With an undulating cityscape of peaks and urban valleys, Lisbon, like Rome, has seven hills, each with its own breathtaking view. Hop aboard the Tram 28 and let it carry you to to Miradouro das Portas do Sol, where the views of the Alfama neighborhood are without comparison or set off for the Miradouro da Senhora do Monte with an elevated vantage point and a wide scope view of the city. Take a sunset stroll up to the sloping, verdant lawns of Parque Eduardo VII, a 62-acre public park with vistas of the Tagus and beyond. Salute yourself for a day‚Äôs worth of climbing at one of our favorite wine bar‚Äôs, By The Wine, found in the heart of the elegant Chiado neighborhood.
Portugal is blessed with over 1,000 kilometers of beaches, and Lisbon has some of the best. Protected from Portugal‚Äôs infamous swells, Cascais enjoys sandy beaches, a busy marina, and scenic seaside cliffs with the dramatic Boca do Inferno (Hell‚Äôs Mouth) rock formation. Ride the waves at Guincho, an ideal beach for surfing and other water sports. Stretching for miles, Costa de Caparica has fantastic facilities and is ideal for families. Explore the pristine beach of Portinho da Arr√°bida, complete with rolling terrain and white, sandy shores. Whether you get your kicks from riding the waves, hiking the shore or burying your toes in the sand, there is no limit to the city‚Äôs coastal offerings.
See Lisbon the way locals do through barrios that have stood the test of time. Home to a vibrant community of locals, a legion of cafes and shops, and a lively small-town atmosphere, Alvalade and Avenidas Novas neighborhoods entice residents and travelers alike. Another in-vogue neighborhood, Marvila, has transformed abandoned warehouses into workspaces, artisan breweries, and art galleries. Have a beer at Dois Corvos, where they created the first artisan beer ever produced in Lisbon.
At the center of Campo de Ourique is the eponymous market, Mercado de Campo de Ourique. Dating back to 1934, the former farmer‚Äôs market has been painstakingly refurbished, yet retains the authenticity of its heyday. Packed with gourmet food stands offering options for all manner of tastes and moods, the lively hangout spot is bursting with colors, flavors and locals at lunch.
Reflecting the metamorphosis of Lisbon, the LX Factory has breathed new life into a former manufacturing complex in the Alc√¢ntara neighborhood. Combining arts and an entrepreneurial spirit, the sprawling, multifaceted mall has become one of the city‚Äôs coolest hangouts, with bookstores, hip fashion boutiques, interior design outlets alongside artists‚Äô ateliers ‚Äî all under one urban-industrial roof.
Discover the beating heart of Lisbon in Fado music, a Portuguese folk song of melancholic character usually accompanied by guitar and a traditional Portuguese meal. Since the early 19th century, Fado (literally: ‚Äúfate‚Äù or ‚Äúdestiny‚Äù) has been an important fixture in everyday life of the Portuguese working class, where fadistas draw locals into dark taverns to be serenaded. Themes of resignation command the performances, but hopefulness is weaved throughout, a reminder that each ending is also the start of a new beginning.
Painted tiles, known as azulejos, made their way to the Iberian Peninsula in the 14th century and have since become synonymous with Portuguese culture. Examples are omnipresent in Lisbon, from the exquisite facade of Fronteira Palace to the cartoon-style murals inside Oriente Station to huge openair artworks gracing walls across the city. For an immersive, interactive exploration of the aesthetic tradition, take an exclusive tile-making workshop with artisans at a family-owned factory in the Arrabida National Park area.
A fairytale of palaces and castles, Sintra has charmed travelers for centuries. Protected by UNESCO as a World Heritage Site, European Romantic architecture reigns, yet beneath the colorful exterior the region holds dark secrets from its past: The well of the Quinta da Regaleira estate hides a concealed network of tunnels once used in obscure masonic rituals. Back on the sunny side, there are ancient ruins, hiking trails, and sand beaches to be discovered. Take a tour in a 1940s replica sidecar, beginning on the coast in Roca Cape and weaving through the Estoril Coast and Cascais Bay, before reaching the village.
Nature reserves often conjure images of inland oases, but Arr√°bida Natural Park is different. The area comprises a stunning section of wild coastline backed by fertile lands yielding Moscatel and Periquita grape varieties; follow the Costa Azul wine route to sample the region‚Äôs terroir and locally produced cheeses. Located just an hour‚Äôs transfer from Lisbon, this piece of paradise is accessed via the iconic Ponte de 25 de Abril bridge, redolent of the globally renowned Golden Gate in San Francisco. After an adventurous arrival, relax on secluded white sand beaches, go dolphin watching, and dine on freshly caught fish. Distinguished views, lush hills, and limestone cliffs constitute numerous hiking trails, and your expert guide will lead you to the footprints of dinosaurs dating to the Jurassic era.

Explore the world with a depth beyond your imagination ‚Äî and totally tailored to you.

Title: Lisbon ‚Äî City at the edge of Europe
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
My very first impression of Lisbon was of a public parking lot taken over by gypsies. One guy, with the biggest tin of sausages I‚Äôve ever seen, sidled up to the window of the campervan I was in with friends, & asked for a single euro, we handed it over without question. If there‚Äôs something everyone should know, it‚Äôs don‚Äôt mess with gypsies. When we came back at the end of the day the giant tin of sausages had been thrown, still 3/4 full, near one of the tyres, but the campervan was intact & as we left it. We considered that euro as the best value of the trip. I really regret not getting a photo of the sausages.
My lasting impression is that a visit to this city is a ticket to many beautiful experiences. The city has an energy, diversity, organised chaos & creativity that reflects a true metropolis.
¬ª Triple bottom line, sustainability, (Socio-cultural, Economic & Environmental)I have now been to Lisbon 3 times, seeing 3 very different parts of the city & 3 very different experiences. Each visit building a picture of the city that I enjoy more each time. I think the public transport is one of the best I‚Äôve seen. But, the major problem the city faces is that it seems like there‚Äôs a massive difference between the haves & the have-nots. If you catch a train or bus to Esta√ß√£o do Oriente you will see this fairly clearly. The only upside being that at least there is a sheltered place for people experiencing homelessness, a luxury not often afforded by people in the same situation in other cities, Vancouver comes to mind.
As a city that heavily relies on tourism, a blessing & curse for beautiful cities round the world, it has been subject to the highs & pitfalls of an industry that is never quite secure. The Portuguese were smart enough to create a digital nomad visa to attract location independent people from all over the world, which is adding a different layer to the economy & social mix. The only problem being that this causes impacts on living costs for residents.
Despite this, life is fairly cheap, food is exceptional & so is the wine. I walked through a shopping centre near Esta√ß√£o do Oriente while I waited for my bus & the place was completely packed with people loaded with shopping bags. But global labels selling well doesn‚Äôt mean much for the have nots.
Lisbon economic is the engine of the country, along with Porto, which is even moreso tourism focused. Lisbon has a focus of people, the city centre is only 100sqm with estimated 533,920 people but the outlying metropolitan area has over 3M people (worldpopulationreivew.com) & is the largest urban area in the EU.
To me Lisbon is a centre of creativity, artistry combined with technical proficiency. A great combination for design thinking. I can see that the people are open to social evolution, are connected to the global consciousness. I can see in the future this could really grow, expand & exported (as it already is).
¬ª Tree canopy cover & evidence of biodiversityThis really depends where you are, apparently ‚Äúapproximately 8% of Lisbon is covered directly by canopy‚Äù(Franco & McDonald, 2018) & the feel on the ground is that there‚Äôs parts that are really green, but more parts that are not. I feel like I experienced therange of the spectrum with my last 2 visits, I stayed in complete opposite places. This is always good to do for a holistic view of a place, I like a little visit to a lower socio-economic place to bring me down to earth.
As far as biodiversity goes, I believe there is some left, I could hear birds & there was evidence of fauna in some of the parks. There are some really large parks which have wild parts to them, the below satelite map shows that there is large areas of greenspace, which you feel on the ground. There are breaks from the dense suburbs, which is an approach I actually really like, to densify housing & consolidate green space into large areas. A few small fish in the water, yes I did bring my snorkel mask like a total nerd.
Next time I go I want to spend a whole day walking around the large green space in the lower right hand corner of the below pic, Parque Florestal de Monsanto. I‚Äôve been to the outskirts but in the middle, you can see the clearing about the road running through, this is a prison, it‚Äôs blurred out in Google maps, which always tickles the armpit of my curiosity. Even the prison in Wacol near Brisbane isn‚Äôt blurred out. I‚Äôm also interested in what Skycity is going to be like, which is in the middle of the greenspace closer to the middle of the image. Also indicated is Cascais for reference.
¬ª Pedestrian, cyclists & motorcyclist friendlyI had so much fun cycling through Cascais when I was there. Cascais is a little out of Lisbon near the coast, but I think it still feels like an extension of the city out on the corner of the Tagus river & the Atlantic. In other parts of the city cycling is impossible because of the hills, but tuk-tuks are regulars now. In other parts it is normal to see confident cyclists getting about on the street & despite the heavy car traffic, they seem to be respected & allowed to take up space. I think partly because they‚Äôre also generally moving faster than said cars stuck in traffic. I think also partly because the Portuguese people seem very level headed & pragmatic, this said I would love to see more bike lanes painted in.
Yes, there are plenty of motorcycles getting about, there‚Äôs even a chapter of the Litas (a worldwide womxn only riding club) that exists there. It is the perfect place for getting around the skinny streets or getting out on the weekend.
¬ª Public transport system effectiveness
I love a good short wait for a train & easy transfer to another line, & the system here delivers the goods. Ahhh :) Those accustomed to the shitshow of the Brisbane heavy rail system will also be enamoured with this one. I also like when a place has good people watching, which Lisbon provides, it‚Äôs not the veritable freak show in NYC, but you definitely want to be wearing sunglasses to check people out (in a non creepy way pls).
I also like how clean & comfortable the trains are. There are buses too, which I still haven‚Äôt been on, but from the maps it looks like a good amount of the city is well connected. Another good thing is that the transport card, which is cheap to buy, will get you everywhere in the greater metropolitan area, even to Cintra, the most magical fairy castle place I‚Äôve ever seen.
¬ª Residents experiencesI really think in this case it depends on where you live, thus why I was so glad to experience both sides of the proverbial tracks. I think that both sides have a good life, there‚Äôs all the opulence & luxury you can afford, at the same time there‚Äôs plenty of social, low cost housing, if you can get it. I think city possibly does the tired old dance of focusing funds to the streetscapes of the tourist & wealthy areas, but at the same time if you‚Äôre not wealthy there‚Äôs a lot of little stalls & hustles going on which can keep unskilled people going. I don‚Äôt doubt that the have-nots have it tough though.
I think I‚Äôd be interested to know how accessible university education is in Lisbon, I think this is going to be key to the future as the city‚Äôs population is aging. I think a well educated workforce has the potential to do better during the rough times ahead (for most cities) as retirees outweigh working adults. Some of the most intelligent, multilingual & interesting people I‚Äôve ever met were Portuguese (shout out to Claudia Taborda, one of my lecturers at QUT), so I get the impression education is at a high level here.
‚Ä¢ Now to the weirder things I care about
¬ª Can I drink alone at a bar & not feel judged?For me yes, I have done this every time I‚Äôve visited & loved the whole experience. I felt sexy & mysterious & was not subject to a single judgy face. As with Paris, I would drink or eat alone there any day. In fact I had one of the best Thai curries of my life at an Indian restaurant in Cascais watching motorcycle racing on the big screen at a table next to a guy doing the same. Couldn‚Äôt have felt more acceptable. I have a friend who lives there who often sends me photos of cocktails he‚Äôs drinking alone at the beachfront, sometimes he takes his cat, it all sounds like a dream. Also, I once went to a Fado restaurant, without booking, like a dummy, but managed to snag a seat opposite a truly interesting woman from Dubai, also getting about alone, we shared a plate of snacks, the enchanting music and single woman traveller stories, truly one of my most favourite nights, made possibly because I was solo.
¬ª Are the plants realYes, lots of real plants in restaurants, can‚Äôt say I recall seeing many plastic plants getting about. But I haven‚Äôt been through the whole city yet so maybe next time I‚Äôll notice it & need to do a retraction. There is so much bougainvillea doing really well, which just adds to the ambiance.
¬ª Is it safe to walk alone at night?Yes, for me anyway. The last 2 times I was there I walked back to my accommodation alone late at night, in 2 very different areas, passing all sorts of characters, but felt safe. I may have made another woman feel unsafe as I followed her back to the guesthouse we were both staying at, she did not want to chat. Still useful to be street smart.
¬ª Do people dance? (self consciousness rating)Yesss! Ah it‚Äôs very nice to see, people dancing at clubs, even in an afternoon, or on the beach next to the volleyball courts. There is a bit of an athletic vibe, especially with the younger adults, so I think dance ability comes with that.
¬ª Is there cool old shit with cool stories, other than churches or cathedrals?So much! Books shops, bars, castles, just the cobbled streets are super interesting, the trams are great, this is a city for all senses, visual & taste especially. This is like the epicentre of non-religious cool old shit (plenty of old religious shit for those that way inclined).
¬ª Pet trends, dogs in bars & dog parksI didn‚Äôt notice that many dogs to be honest with you, I think this speaks to the transitionary lifestyle people have here, but I did see some at the beachside cafes & they looked very welcome there, I wouldn‚Äôt think twice about having a dog in this city. Plenty of walkabouts to get up to, plenty of parks too.
¬ª Do people stare at my tattoos? Are there alt folk about?I feel like this is the least starey place I‚Äôve been, no one gives a shit, plenty of other tattooed people about, you can be whoever you want to be. I think this all goes with the general progressive & globally connected vibes. There is a continuation of tradition, but there‚Äôs also a tolerance & acceptance that I really like.
¬ª General vibe notesIt‚Äôs just a cool city, not squeaky clean, has a certain amount of grit. But I think it‚Äôs a good place to get fat & happy ‚Äî or fit & hippy. Up to you on that journey. All the food I had there was incredible. The people are lovely, & mostly speak English so it‚Äôs real easy for a dumb monolinguist like me (hot tip, more people speak English than Spanish, so don‚Äôt gracias, instead stick to either obrigada/o or thanks).
Not yet mentioned is the Pastel de Nata ‚Äîthis is very important! If you do one thing it‚Äôs visit Pastel de Belem, wait for as long as necessary, order an espresso & 2 pastels, don‚Äôt make the mistake of thinking 1 is sufficient, I think 6 is actually the correct amount.
I think one thing that could be a critique, is how it sprawls, even though there are places closer that could be renewed with some creativity & investment. This is the problem with older cities, there‚Äôs places that have been around for centuries, sometimes millennia, but who‚Äôs going to make a decision on removing the remains when they become useless. It‚Äôs a decision I don‚Äôt know the answer for, since I am from Brisbane which has a fairly rigorous demo & rebuild policy for anything over 15‚Äì40yrs old.
Not sure if anyone can tell this, but I would jump at the chance to live in Lisbon.
--
--

Title: Lisbon Chronicles: From Ancient Roots to Modern Marvels
Content:

Lisbon, the capital city of Portugal, is a captivating blend of rich history, vibrant culture, and breathtaking landscapes. Nestled on the western coast of the Iberian Peninsula, Lisbon has long been a hub of exploration, trade, and cultural exchange. This article delves into the fascinating history of Lisbon, highlights its must-visit places, and provides insights on the best time to explore this enchanting city.
Lisbon‚Äôs history is a tapestry woven with diverse influences and remarkable events. The city‚Äôs origins can be traced back to the Phoenicians around 1200 BCE, who established a settlement called ‚ÄúAlis Ubbo.‚Äù Over the centuries, Lisbon was inhabited by various civilizations, including the Romans, Visigoths, and Moors, each leaving an indelible mark on the city‚Äôs culture and architecture.
Roman and Moorish Eras
During the Roman era, Lisbon, known as Olissipo, flourished as a significant trading post. The Romans constructed roads, bridges, and aqueducts, some of which still stand today. The fall of the Roman Empire saw Lisbon transition into the hands of the Visigoths and later the Moors. The Moors, who ruled from the 8th to the 12th century, infused the city with Islamic culture, architecture, and advancements in agriculture and science. The Alfama district, with its narrow winding streets and Moorish influences, remains a testament to this period.
The Age of Discovery
The 15th and 16th centuries marked Lisbon‚Äôs golden age during the Age of Discovery. Under the leadership of Prince Henry the Navigator, Portuguese explorers set sail from Lisbon, embarking on voyages that would change the world. Vasco da Gama‚Äôs discovery of the sea route to India in 1498 and subsequent expeditions established Lisbon as a global maritime power. The wealth and knowledge brought back by these explorers fueled the Renaissance in Portugal, leading to significant advancements in art, science, and architecture.
Earthquake and Reconstruction
The devastating earthquake of 1755, followed by a tsunami and fires, razed much of Lisbon to the ground. The Marquis of Pombal spearheaded the city‚Äôs reconstruction, implementing innovative urban planning and architectural techniques. The Baixa district, with its grid-like streets and neoclassical buildings, emerged from this reconstruction, symbolizing Lisbon‚Äôs resilience and rebirth.
Lisbon is a city that begs to be explored, with its historic neighborhoods, iconic landmarks, and cultural gems offering a rich tapestry of experiences for visitors.
Alfama: The Alfama district is the oldest neighborhood in Lisbon, characterized by its labyrinthine streets, traditional Fado music, and stunning viewpoints. Visitors can wander through its narrow alleys, visit the S√£o Jorge Castle, and enjoy the panoramic views from Miradouro da Gra√ßa.
Bel√©m: Bel√©m is synonymous with Portugal‚Äôs Age of Discovery. This district is home to the iconic Bel√©m Tower, a UNESCO World Heritage site, and the Jer√≥nimos Monastery, a masterpiece of Manueline architecture. The Monument to the Discoveries, located along the Tagus River, pays tribute to the explorers who set sail from Lisbon.
Baixa and Chiado: Baixa and Chiado are bustling districts in the heart of Lisbon. Baixa is known for its elegant squares, such as Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio and Rossio Square, as well as the Elevador de Santa Justa, a stunning neo-Gothic elevator offering panoramic views of the city. Chiado, on the other hand, is a cultural and commercial hub, with its theaters, bookstores, and vibrant caf√©s.
Bairro Alto: Bairro Alto is Lisbon‚Äôs bohemian quarter, famous for its lively nightlife and artistic atmosphere. As the sun sets, the neighborhood comes alive with Fado music, trendy bars, and restaurants serving traditional Portuguese cuisine. During the day, visitors can explore its unique shops and historic buildings.
LX Factory: LX Factory, a former industrial complex, has been transformed into a creative and cultural hub. Located in the Alc√¢ntara district, it features trendy shops, art galleries, restaurants, and a lively atmosphere. The iconic Ler Devagar bookstore, with its towering bookshelves and whimsical d√©cor, is a must-visit.
Lisbon‚Äôs Mediterranean climate makes it an attractive destination year-round, but the best time to visit depends on your preferences and interests.
Spring (March to May): Spring is one of the best times to visit Lisbon, as the weather is mild and the city is in full bloom. The temperatures range from 15¬∞C to 20¬∞C (59¬∞F to 68¬∞F), making it perfect for exploring the city‚Äôs outdoor attractions. Additionally, the spring months see fewer tourists compared to the summer, providing a more relaxed experience.
Summer (June to August): Summer in Lisbon is warm and bustling with activity. Temperatures can soar to 30¬∞C (86¬∞F) or higher, making it ideal for enjoying the city‚Äôs beaches and outdoor festivals. However, this is also the peak tourist season, so expect larger crowds and higher prices for accommodation and attractions.
Autumn (September to November): Autumn is another excellent time to visit Lisbon, with pleasant temperatures ranging from 15¬∞C to 25¬∞C (59¬∞F to 77¬∞F). The summer crowds begin to thin out, and the city‚Äôs parks and gardens are adorned with vibrant fall colors. September, in particular, is a great month to experience the city‚Äôs cultural events and festivals.
Winter (December to February): Winter in Lisbon is mild compared to other European cities, with temperatures rarely dropping below 8¬∞C (46¬∞F). While there may be occasional rain, the city remains lively with Christmas markets, festive lights, and cultural events. Winter is also the off-peak season, offering more affordable accommodation options.
Lisbon is a city that seamlessly blends its rich historical heritage with contemporary culture and vibrant energy. From its ancient neighborhoods and iconic landmarks to its creative hubs and lively districts, Lisbon offers a diverse range of experiences for every traveler. Whether you‚Äôre exploring the narrow streets of Alfama, marveling at the architectural wonders of Bel√©m, or enjoying the nightlife in Bairro Alto, Lisbon promises a journey filled with discovery and enchantment. Additionally, check holidays in Portugal prior to travel to improve your overall tour experience. So, pack your bags and set out to explore this captivating city, where the past and present converge in a harmonious symphony of culture, history, and adventure.

The capital of Portugal is a beautiful city, no doubt, but it is also predictably touristy and, as such, immensely avoidable after a mandatory trip, or two. Having said that, it doesn‚Äôt always happen as per your wish.
During a recent trip to Lisbon, I made an earnest attempt to camouflage my prejudice, ensured the person accompanying me got to enjoy the best of everything Portugal‚Äôs capital city has to offer, and eventually didn‚Äôt regret making yet another visit to a city I have honestly got bored with. Football fans will be aware that the domestic season in Portugal got over recently, and I believe there is no better time to discuss my predicament. I arrived at the cafe/bakery and thought about getting a number to be served. Before I could do it, a nice man gave me his number. This is a Portuguese way of living. They are always helpful.
It was so relaxing to sit in the bakery and have coffee with a croissant. I could stay there all day just writing and drawing, or people-watching.
And or walking on the banks of the river on Parque das Na√ß√µes.
Today I had codfish with spinach and chickpea puree. And then again, in a different way, as a snack with apple juice and strawberry. You can find all kinds of fish everywhere you go here.
On the banks of the Tagus River, I was surprised and happy to hear a Brazilian song.
I recently had the opportunity to visit Lisbon, the capital of Portugal again. I immediately felt at home with the city‚Äôs beauty, its rich history, and its vibrant culture. There is art everywhere.
The Beauty of Lisbon

Beyond here, there‚Äôs nothing. Ne plus ultra, the Romans carved on the Pillars of Hercules at the narrow neck where Spain almost, almost touches Africa.
They were talking about the wild, tempest-tossed Atlantic, of course. A swelling, storming, steel-grey wilderness that devoured their ships the way killer whales now devour the rudders of billionaire‚Äôs yachts.
Ignore the warning. You can sail out between the pillars of Hercules. The Romans knew that.
The wild Atlantic swallowed Ulysses, but more modest men of cunning made their way tortuously along the coast to Lisbon. In Alfama, the ancient fishing district with an Arabic name that survived the 1755 earthquake that reshaped the city entirely, you can still see the ruins of the Roman empire‚Äôs last settlement before the sea.
Lisbon is the westernmost city in Europe. And after visiting every capital city in Western Europe, after traveling from Sicily to Stockholm and from Warsaw to Wrexham, Lisbon, and Portugal as a whole, remained a barely explicable gap in our charted territory.
We liked it right away.

Blink and you will miss the tiny little pride flags stuck in the windows of shops and cafes in Lisbon. Blink and you might miss its queer culture entirely.
When I first visited Lisbon‚Äôs unofficial ‚Äúgay village‚Äù it was a culture shock in comparison to the vibrant gay village of my city, Montreal. Title: Less conventional things to do in Lisbon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up

Lisbon may not be the first city that comes to mind for most people wanting to visit a European capital. However, don‚Äôt let this be a reflection on what the city has to offer. On the contrary, having been asked for pointers quite a few times over the years, I‚Äôve decided to compile a list of 7 things that are off the beaten path, absolutely worth doing should you visit or live there. These should give you a small taste of the potential that this three thousand year old city hides.
Lisbon has a 4km long aqueduct built in the 18th century. Many people know of the large arch that cuts across the Alc√¢ntara valley:
However, far less well known is the fact that it cuts deep into the city centre, and that you can walk inside it, and see some beautiful monuments on the way. This path is part of the City-wide ‚ÄúWater Museum‚Äù that is currently being developed and begins at the ‚ÄúM√£e d‚Äô√Ågua‚Äù, the largest water reservoir of the structure.
This gorgeous monument offers some great views of the city which I shall not spoil for you here. The next step is to head to nearby Pr√≠ncipe Real and head underneath the park into another reservoir, the Patriarcal.
This is where you can take a really pleasant guided tour along 4oom of tunnels that pass underneath the streets of the city.
At the time of writing, the tunnels lead all the way to the S√£o Pedro de Alc√¢ntara view point, where you can join other tourists. However, the city is currently expanding the length of tunnels accessible by foot.
Portugal does not have a rich history of beer. The Portuguese are well known for their love of wine, having some of the best bottles in the world produced there, and the Portuguese culture is built much more around wine that it is around beer. It is quite ordinary to see people drinking wine at lunch and dinner rather than beer, as is more common in Northern and Eastern Europe. Having said that, Lisbon and Oporto have jumped on the craft beer bandwagon with roaring success, and these local delicacies can be enjoyed at a variety of places throughout the capital. There is a great list of places here which I will summarise:
Update: Check out Musa in Marvila.
The reason Lisbon was built in its current location, and one of the main factors of its historical prominence, is the Tagus river delta. The Tagus is the longest river in the Iberian peninsula and its enormous reverse-delta is home to dolphins, flamingos and amazing views over the city. One of the best things to do in the city is to hop on a sail-boat and do a 2 hour cruise of the delta at sunset.
Lisbon is quite unique in comparison to the other European capitals when it comes to museums. You won‚Äôt find a Louvre, National Gallery, or Prado here. What you will find however, is a large amount of excellent small to mid-sized museums all over the city, catering to every taste. I‚Äôll spare the reader another long list and link to this blog which has a comprehensive one. To that list I‚Äôll add a couple more that should be at the top of your list:
2. Under-dogs Gallery ‚Äî Lisbon‚Äôs best street art gallery. It doesn‚Äôt limit itself to just street art, however:
Lisbon‚Äôs music scene is UGE as some might say. The city offers a regular serving of all types of genres, scenes and festivals all year round. The centuries-old multicultural environment has always been a fertile ground for original music output, and you can hear European, Brazilian, African, Indian and SE Asian music scenes come together in a setting unmatched anywhere else in the world.
A few highlights:
Venues:
Labels:
Events:
Special mention to this wine bar located inside one of the watering holes that used to quench the city‚Äôs thirst. Incidentally, it‚Äôs one of the end points of the aforementioned aqueduct, although this stretch isn‚Äôt accessible to the public (maybe try asking the owners of the wine bar).
With the largest amount of sunlight hours per year of any European capital, it‚Äôs only natural that Lisbon‚Äôs sunsets would live up to the city‚Äô sunny reputation. Great spots to enjoy these are:
Equally stunning are the sunrises from some of the nightclubs like Lux.
‚Äî
I hope this brief list gives you some idea of the huge amount of things to do there. If you have any more tips or have specific questions, feel free to leave them in the comments!

Content:

Lisbon is full of surprises. It doesn‚Äôt matter if you have visited it a thousand times, there will always be another little street, corner or ‚Äúbeco‚Äù that will lead you to a new square or to a colorful building that you have never seen before. Here is a guide that will lead you to those beautiful not-that-well-known neighborhoods!
If you have been in Lisbon, it is likely that you have seen the Assembleia da Rep√∫blica (Portugal‚Äôs chamber of Congress) or the Bas√≠lica da Estrela. Well, not that far from those places, there is a little neighborhood that has survived the last waves of tourism. It‚Äôs called Madragoa, and it‚Äôs one of the most authentic and beautiful places in Lisbon!
Jos√© Saramago, a portuguese writer and Nobel prize winner, lived in Madragoa. About it, he wrote: ‚Äúin one of the hillsides of Lapa, it‚Äôs Madragoa, named that way after the people of the sea (or ‚Äúmar‚Äù, in portuguese) came to live here after the XVI century‚Äù.
You can walk through the Rua da Esperan√ßa (the same street where Saramago lived) and see some cozy little coffee shops and traditional Tascas, or go uphill to Rua das Madres and be amazed with the colours of typical Lisbon‚Äôs houses.
2. Penha da Franca
Penha da Fran√ßa it‚Äôs located above Arroios neighborhood, and right next to Gra√ßa. And even though it‚Äôs centrally located, not that many tourists knows about it. A main reason why many young locals have chosen this area to live.
Penha da Fran√ßa features two amazing view points: the Miradouro do Monte Agudo and the Miradouro da Penha da Fran√ßa. Also, you‚Äôll find delicious nepalese restaurants, proper portuguese‚Äôs tascas and interesting antique shops. You can even go to the Alto de S√£o Jo√£o cemetery, which has unique monuments and amazing river views.
And because of it‚Äôs location, you can walk right into it! From OnJ S. L√°zaro hotel, you‚Äôll only have to walk through Avenida Almirante Reis, and the go uphill taking one of the many stairs, like the one in Rua Cidade de Manchester or Rua Cidade de Cardiff.
3. Bica
To be fair, it is likely that the Bica elevator will appear on your travel guide, or at least that your tour guide will recommend it to you. Not of that matters: we still think that the Bica neighborhood is wildly underrated.
First, as you can see from the main photography of this article (made by notorious @francisco_crocco), Bica is huge, colorful and hilly. Second: in the past years, it has become one of the coolest neighborhoods in Lisbon, and a lot of new restaurants have opened there, mainly in the Rua de Sao Paulo.
The stairs, the little squares or ‚Äúlargos‚Äù, and the notorious Miradouro de Santa Catarina definitely need a longer visit.
4. Obvioulsy, you can‚Äôt miss the rest of Lisbon!
By highlighting these neighborhoods of Lisbon, we don‚Äôt mean for you to skip the beautiful Alfama, Gra√ßa, Baixa or Bairro Alto.
As we said before, if you come to Lisbon, you‚Äôll never stop to discover new corners to fall in love with.
Check out the rest of our posts, and see waht they have to offer!

Title: Best Neighborhoods in Lisbon: Where to Stay During Your Visit
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
