Title: London to Lisbon with a 3-month-old baby
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

All those little bits of me compiled in my happy tidy kingdom. Let‚Äôs travel, eat and organise together.

--
Listen
Share
One of the things that everyone tells you when you talk about having babies is ‚Äúno more travelling!‚Äù. I‚Äôve always challenged this assumption and thought (and said) ‚ÄúWhy? It must be slightly more challenging, but some people do it‚Äù. ‚ÄúOh, you have no idea‚Äù.
I would then kind of give up and wouldn‚Äôt challenge it too much as I didn‚Äôt have babies, so if this was true, I would only understand it once I had them.
And then I had a baby. As we are Portuguese we had to plan our first holidays to visit the family in Portugal, and that meant travelling.
So we planned our first trip to Portugal. By car. From London to Lisbon. With a 3 months old.
Our friends with babies said ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre crazy! You have no idea what you‚Äôre getting into!‚Äù. And once again we thought ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the big deal?‚Äù. But we had never travelled with Dinis so if it was that hard, we would only understand it once we travelled. And so we did.
Our first and most difficult trip was on August 2018 when Dinis was 3 months old. Because we wanted to spend a month in Portugal and we have Mia (our black Labrador) we decided to drive, so she could come with us (I know #crazy).
Was it cheaper than flights and leaving Mia with a dogsitter? Not really. But it was more about having her with us for all that time to be honest. A month is a long time to leave her behind. Was it easy? Nop. Did we survive? Yes. Both on the way to Lisbon and back.
Driving to Portugal from London nonstop takes 21h26 min (according to Google Maps).
We had already done it when we went to Portugal to get married and we took two days (about 12h drive each day). But with Dinis we left London, drove down to France, through to Spain and arrived in Portugal 5 days later (one of the days was a stay-over at my brother‚Äôs in France). So a 4 day drive. Double the time we had done before. And why? Well, let me explain.
There‚Äôs a few challenges when travelling with a baby in a car.
First, you need to stop every two hours. Babies shouldn‚Äôt stay in the car seat for longer than that until they‚Äôre 6 months due to risks of suffocation. So Jo√£o planned a 6 hour of drive per day, with a stop every two hours. So ideally, we would spend about 8 hours a day travelling to a new destination with minimum stops included.
But our drives took about 12 hours each day. And why? Because you should only stop every 2 hours for safety purposes, but a baby has a mind of their own. They‚Äôre hungry, they pee, they poop and most of all they get bored and cry about it. Especially when they‚Äôre not used to being in a car that often (which is our case, we don‚Äôt own a car in London).
So that‚Äôs the hardest bit, you need to stop often and irregularly. You also need to be patient and either teach your baby to self soothe to sleep before you travel, during your travel or stop every single time your baby is upset or needs to sleep.
I‚Äôm not going to lie, he did get very upset a few times during our travels and at times where we couldn‚Äôt stop straight away as we‚Äôd miss the exit for a resting area. But the truth is they are not hurting, so you just need to try and calm them down with other distractions until you‚Äôre able to make the stop.
With the following travels (by plane), one thing I‚Äôve noticed, is that breastfeeding is great for airplanes but not that great for cars. In a moving car, it‚Äôs not safe to take the baby out of the seat and hold them in the car. Should an accident happen (as we all know, these are unpredictable) and the chances of survival drop drastically.
For breastfeeding to work we, we need to feed the babies on demand. So sometimes they might sleep for 2 hours nonstop and have to be waken up, sometimes they feed every 30 min.
That‚Äôs when formula (or expressing if you‚Äôre good at it and have the patience for it) is a great help. You just need fresh boiled water in a flask, some prepared formula doses, bottles and you‚Äôre good to go!
This depends on the babies. Some babies are extremely sensitive to dirty nappies in the first months and will complain about it straight away. Dinis was like that. I understand! It must be just slightly uncomfortable to be sitting in your own pee or poop. Most rest stops will have toilets with changing tables for you to change your baby.
But when they don‚Äôt you quickly learn to improvise. I changed Dinis on grass, on a table and a lot of times on my lap whilst sitting in the car. It‚Äôs not very easy, and it depends on the size of your baby (I struggled more on the way back to London as he had grown during that month), but it‚Äôs doable.
Naps are a bliss. When they happen. I‚Äôm sooo glad decided to try and fix Dinis‚Äô sleep before we travelled.
I believe a baby that doesn‚Äôt know how to, needs to be taught to sleep. Is it easier said than done? Hell yeah! Can it be done? Hell yeah.
From week 3, Dinis stopped sleeping properly during the day, giving me good nights, but terrible days. I couldn‚Äôt do anything. He wouldn‚Äôt even like being in the sling for too long as it was a very hot summer in London last year. So, two weeks before travelling and after 2 months of sleep struggle, we had enough and had to do something about it.
I don‚Äôt like the Ferber method (leaving your kid to cry on his own), I find it too harsh and I honestly think it wouldn‚Äôt work on Dinis (he‚Äôs a stubborn one), so I used the Tracy Hogg method (her book is on my Approved tab under the ‚ÄúMum Books tab‚Äù) and we fixed Dinis‚Äô naps during the day whilst his sleep pattern remained unchanged. From barely any sleep during the day, only sleeping on my chest we got to 3 naps a day (one of them a 2 hours nap). And him being able to get to sleep with no ‚Äúboob aid‚Äù was what helped soooo much during our trip. Not that I didn‚Äôt breastfed him to sleep a few times. But at least half the time he would go to sleep on his own whilst we were on route with minimal fuss.
Should you have no time to read anything else past this (I know how motherhood works) my top tip for travelling with a baby is the following: Just go.
As with a lot of things in life, the thought of travelling with our baby is scarier and way more difficult than actually travelling with our baby. Because once you‚Äôre on route, it‚Äôs actually fine. So just grab your baby, and go. Well, prepare a little of course. But don‚Äôt let the thought of it stop you from going.
Because we‚Äôre two Portuguese living in London, if we want to see our family we need to travel. And since Dinis was born, we made 3 trips to Portugal and went to Prague on holidays. So that ‚Äúimpossible to travel once you have a baby‚Äù is nonsense to me. You‚Äôre a bit more limited money wise, you need to plan a bit more, but otherwise it‚Äôs all good. You just need to be a bit more flexible about your normal routine and not worry about how that will permanently affect your baby: it will not. Babies are sponges, they absorb what‚Äôs around them and they will change quickly and more effectively than we adults do. They just go with the flow.
Was this an easy trip? Not really. But would we do this again? Yes, we would. If anything it made us feel brave and made us not fear any other trip we will do with him.
So that‚Äôs it. Do it. You and your baby will be fine. And he might not remember much of it, but he will love it and you will have the best memories of it.
Hug, Millia

Title: Lisbon: A rising star for American property buyers
Content:

The ultimate guide to discover Portugal¬¥s hidden gems

--
Listen
Share
Portugal‚Äôs capital is having a moment and Americans are taking notice. Lisbon has planted itself on the radar of wealthy U.S. property buyers, drawn in by the city‚Äôs charm, affordability, and a rental market that‚Äôs too good to pass up. This year alone, at Goldcrest Buyers Agency we had a surge of over 15% on enquiries from US citizens ‚Äî and I will explain why Lisbon is such an attractive destination for real estate investors.
Particularly for American investors, Lisbon offers the best of both worlds, a charming, laidback lifestyle at a fraction of the living costs as back home, and a favorable property investment scene.
Recently ranked as the sixth most profitable European city for property rentals by Global Property Guide, it‚Äôs outshining traditionally popular spots like Paris, Berlin and London. Rental yields in Lisbon averaged 5.65% by mid-2024, a number that‚Äôs been steadily climbing thanks to a strong demand from tenants and comparatively lower property prices.
For Americans, especially those used to high costs of cities like New York or San Francisco, Lisbon feels more attainable. High demand, fewer regulatory headaches than other European cities, and a booming tourism industry mean landlords can see real profits. Compared to places like Berlin or Paris, where acquisition costs are steep and rental rules are tight, Lisbon feels more accessible.
Why are Americans moving to Portugal?
Portugal has been quietly climbing the ranks as a destination for Americans looking to relocate, and the momentum is unmistakable. Google searches about ‚Äúhow to move to Portugal‚Äù increased by +1100% since 5 November 2024, with more Americans considering relocation than ever before.
This isn‚Äôt just a fad. Between January and June of this year, over a million U.S. tourists visited Portugal ‚Äî a 15% jump from 2023. Meanwhile, the number of Americans living in Portugal grew by 44% last year, reaching over 14,000 by mid-2024. Many are drawn by the promise of a more affordable, slower-paced life.
And for Californians in particular, Portugal feels familiar. The weather is sunny, the coastline is stunning, and the lifestyle is relaxed. But unlike California, Portugal‚Äôs cost of living doesn‚Äôt break the bank.
Lisbon‚Äôs appeal for property investors
Lisbon is more than just a great place to live; it‚Äôs a smart place to invest. Tourism is booming, and short-term rental platforms have made it easy for property owners to turn their homes into income-generating assets. That said, this growth hasn‚Äôt come without challenges. The demand for rentals has pushed up prices, inciting debate about housing affordability for locals.
Despite this, property experts predict that Lisbon will remain a favorite for investors. Its location, climate, and quality of life make it instant draws for those looking to move abroad. The key for the future will be finding a balance between attracting investors and ensuring affordable housing for everyone.

This isn‚Äôt exactly a restaurant review. There are a few reasons why it would never qualify. First, I never knew the name of the restaurant in question. The trip was crazy, I was in Lisbon for three days, Madrid for three days, Barcelona for Three days, and Paris for three days. This was day two in Lisbon, after spending a day in Sintra exploring castles.
Lisbon was a new experience for me. I‚Äôd travelled a fair bit before, but never to somewhere with that kind of history. Canada doesn‚Äôt have a lot of historical buildings. Nothing that goes back more than a few hundred years and even that tends to be historical sites, important buildings, that sort of thing. The other places I‚Äôd travelled had, up until that point, been the US, South America, and the South Pacific. None of them have really old buildings that are still in use. Lisbon had houses in the city older than the oldest buildings in Canada and they were still in use. The Airbnb I was staying in was in a courtyard that predates confederation in Canada. The whole neighbourhood was like that.

Title: The Untold Downsides of Living in Lisbon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
It‚Äôs easy to make it seem like everything in Lisbon is perfect, but like anywhere else on earth, Portugal has its ups and downs. On the eve of my first full calendar year here, I wanted to share some negatives about life in Lisbon that don‚Äôt often get brought up by freshly-minted immigrants.
Perhaps the biggest disappointment for me was learning that it‚Äôs very difficult to reach the rest of Europe‚Äôs rail network from Portugal. It‚Äôs not impossible, but it involves switching trains several times and the entire journey takes almost twice as long as it would take by car. Within Portugal, most of the line is on slow-rolling commuter trains, and you only hit high-speed rail once you reach the Spanish city of Badajoz. As an American, I sort of took for granted that everywhere in Europe was well-connected by train, so I did very little research in this area only to be disappointed by Portugal‚Äôs lack of integration into the rest of the continent‚Äôs high speed rail networks.
Even getting to Spain‚Äôs capital, Madrid, is no easy feat. It used to be possible to go to sleep in Lisbon and wake up refreshed in Madrid on a sleeper train. Prior to the pandemic there was an overnight sleeper train that regularly ran between Lisbon and Madrid but it hasn‚Äôt been in operation since 2021. Thankfully, there is now talk of bringing it back. There is also talk of increasing the speed of the lines between Lisbon and Madrid by refurbishing a section of the line on the Portuguese side that‚Äôs not currently suited to high speed travel. But it‚Äôs hard to imagine a rejuvenation and refurbishment of train lines being very quick, so it‚Äôs anyone‚Äôs guess as to when we might expect it.
Once you reach a major Spanish city you can fairly easily get to Paris and from Paris on to the rest of Europe, but getting to Madrid or Barcelona as a primary objective is the difficult part. Hopefully within the next few years we will have both faster, and overnight, routes between the peninsula‚Äôs major cities.
Lisbon is famous for its white and black cobblestone pathways. In the tourist areas of the city ‚Äî like Chiado-Baixo ‚Äî these pathways are wide and pedestrian traffic is prioritized. Elsewhere in the city, though, sidewalks can be very narrow and impossible for two people to walk abreast. This is expected in a city as old as Lisbon where it would take moving entire city blocks to widen sidewalks.
The center of my neighborhood has plenty of wide sidewalks for walking, but in the area where I live the sidewalks are narrow. Couple this with a 7-year old and cars that are frequently driving way too fast and it‚Äôs a recipe for anxiety. Even where the sidewalks are wide, it‚Äôs not unusual to see people pull their vehicles completely up on the sidewalk. While I can normally walk around them, it is almost certainly a huge challenge for the elderly and disabled.
I‚Äôve even seen people park perpendicular to a street corner, with the ass-end of their car out in an intersection while they run into a store. This seems pretty common with the over 60 crowd, but it‚Äôs usually disregarded and nobody says anything. This seems to just be normal life in Lisbon.
And if you do own a car here, you can expect to pay out the ass for parking. People in large American cities will be familiar with this, but those of us from the burbs are accustomed to free parking everywhere. Street parking does exist, but it seems to require a lot of effort to find a spot. Personally, I‚Äôm a fan of Lisbon‚Äôs attempts to reclaim streets for pedestrians and reduce the amount of cars on its congested streets.
And here‚Äôs one final thing you should know ‚Äî the highways throughout Portugal are full of toll roads and automated speed traps. We rented a car for a recent trip to Fund√£o and I racked up about ‚Ç¨60 in speeding fines while going about 8km over the posted speed limit. I knew we should have taken the train!
When I was told that winters in Lisbon were wet and cold I sort of glossed over that detail. How cold could it really be?
The answer is that it gets pretty fucking cold and wet in Lisbon. The rain begins in October and doesn‚Äôt stop until late November. After a brief pause for the holidays, it begins again in the spring. Of course, climate change is creating some variations in this pattern based on what I hear from folks who have spent their entire lives here, but this winter has certainly met expectations. This is not the kind of cold like, say, Toronto or Cleveland or even Atlanta. Temperatures this winter haven't dipped below 37F so far, and most days are much more mild coming in somewhere between 45F-55F. But the combination of cold and wet creates this ongoing chilliness in the house that we use central heating systems to eliminate in the United States.
I‚Äôve only lived in a single apartment since we moved here, so my experience with housing is pretty limited. I think we managed to lease a pretty nice apartment with modern amenities. But it seems that most buildings‚Äô walls are concrete, which doesn‚Äôt provide very good insulation. And of course central heating is unheard of outside of newly-constructed homes in suburban developments. If you get good sun, as our apartment does, things warm up during the day in exterior rooms, but nights and mornings can be downright chilly.
You also need to open windows periodically to air the house out, otherwise it becomes stuffy and stale. In winter this is challenging because of the cold and rain. Cross-breezes are great in the summer but bone-chilling in winter and the dampness permeates your house, keeping clothes from drying and creating excellent conditions for mold. So you wind up with this twofold problem in the fall and winter: you need to open the windows, but it lets the cold and dampness in.
Last year due to the problem with drying clothes, we bought a dryer. This year, due to the presence of mold in our bathroom, we bought a dehumidifier. Take people at their word when they say Lisbon gets cold.
Speaking of airing out the house, the air quality outside is not always great and is worsened by passing cars. Occasionally, it‚Äôs even worse off when there is a wildfire near Lisbon, which happens a lot now during the dry summers.
We‚Äôre among other US families and friends that have noticed an uptick in respiratory infections and I was told by a friend from the US that has lived in Lisbon a few years longer than us that respiratory illnesses are common in Lisbon, especially among kids. Lisbon is a port city, a major tourist destination, and as a very old city, suffers from lots of dust and mold which find their way into the air when disturbed.
We're on the first floor (which is what we'd refer to as the 2nd floor in the US) and with our windows open we get kind of dirty air from outside passing through the house if we don't have the cross-breeze going in the opposite direction. A good breeze can help keep the combination of dust, mold, and car exhaust moving, but if the air is still it wafts into the house. Cigarette smoke is common too, and definitely factors into the equation if you spend any amount of time at quiosques or patios.
We have a 7 year old and so we're not always sure what's normal during cold season for kids her age. Not to mention that she came of age during the peak of the pandemic where masking was common and we have now largely abandoned that practice unless we ourselves are sick and going out in public. My grandmother would have said "she's got the crud," and I think that's mostly it. But during our first year in Lisbon we had "the crud" frequently, though so far this year it has been noticeably better.
We are also regularly among crowds of other people: on the metro, the bus, or just walking through the mercado. These situations obviously present opportunities to transmit airborne illnesses, whereas in the United States prior to the pandemic it was very rare that we were in crowded spaces with other people. This doesn't really seem like a coincidence.
There's a lot going on here, including the fact that I have had asthma since I was about my daughter's age. Unfortunately, maybe that's going to be true of her as well. If there is a positive spin I can put on this issue, it's that Ventolin inhalers can be acquired here without a prescription (I read this somewhere online, tried it for myself, and found it to be true!) and the cost of my daily asthma medication is something like ‚Ç¨30 a month (compared to closer to $120 a month back home).
We‚Äôre still happy here, and we think the drawbacks of living in Lisbon are outweighed by the benefits to our life, which I talk about in other articles. There are other minor challenges and things we don‚Äôt like, which would be true of anywhere we lived. Things like:
These things don‚Äôt amount to a hill of beans, however, when we think about how happy we are to be here and about all the other things we love about being in Lisbon. And if we‚Äôd known about these things before moving here, we still would have come. A big part of our relocation to Portugal was to consciously become more adaptable and make changes in our lives in order to thrive in a new community. And while we knew things like climate control would be challenging, we have already started to acclimate to the changes. We have dealt with both heat and cold better than we did during our first year, and we anticipate that this will only improve the longer we‚Äôre here.
I know we‚Äôll find more things that rub us the wrong way the longer we stay here, but our first year and a half here has also taught us that we are adaptable ‚Äî that we can still change and reinvent ourselves, and that there are also new and exciting things to love spread out around this small-but-beautiful country.
--
--
I write about cybersecurity and technology, history, travel, and life as an immigrant. I live in Lisbon, Portugal, where I drink beer and eat pork.

When I left Paris ‚Äî after visiting a few cities in France, I headed to Lisbon, Portugal. After all, I was already in Europe. So, why not explore more than just France ‚Äî thus killing two or three birds with one stone? (No birds were harmed during this trip).
As my Uber driver approached where my hotel was located, I saw a bridge. A long one! And as we got closer, I was taken aback by its resemblance to the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco.

The Ponte 25 de Abril (the 25th of April Bridge in English), connects the city of Lisbon to the municipality of Almada. The bridge‚Äôs upper section accommodates cars and the section under is for trains. However, unlike the Golden Gate Bridge, Ponte 25 de Abril doesn‚Äôt allow pedestrians or biking on the bridge.

Title: How to Connect with Others in Lisbon: 10 Great Lisbon Meetups 2022
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
If you‚Äôre reading this article, it means you‚Äôre hoping to meet new people in Lisbon, that‚Äôs awesome! You may be considering moving here permanently, exploring Lisbon as a digital nomad, or you may have lived here for a while and feel like it‚Äôs the time to get out there and make new friendships. Whatever the reason, the answer to ‚ÄúHow do I begin?‚Äù is the same: download the Meetup App.
In case you were wondering why I‚Äôm recommending Meetup instead another app: no, I‚Äôm not affiliated with Meetup in any way. When I first came to Lisbon at the beginning of 2022, I tried out various apps, and Meetup stood out to me as the one with the most significant number of interesting-sounding events that fill up quickly.
So, in this article, I would love to mention a list of Meetups that I found particularly worthy of checking out. If you think that I missed out on any excellent Meetup event, please leave a comment below so that everyone can benefit :)
The list of great 10 Meetups includes:
Curious Monkey
This is a non-profit group and a creative space for sharing knowledge about art and bringing together local and expat communities in Lisbon. They organize various events, including yoga, open mics, and talks with book authors, journalists, and casts of well-known shows such as Cirque Du Soleil. If you‚Äôre looking for some quality conversations, then Curious Monkey will be a great group to join!
www.meetup.com
Drink & Draw
Drink & Draw hosts pop-up drawing sessions in unique locations around Lisbon. For around twenty euros, you can enjoy a mobile-phone-free session with incredible people at a beautiful local winery or a cafe. Each participant is handed a set of drawing materials upon entry and a drink choice, and then the drawing begins! Two or more models pose in the middle of the room, and participants are given tasks such as ‚Äúdraw the model in 30 sec‚Äù or ‚Äúdraw the model in 7 min but with the opposite hand.‚Äù It‚Äôs a lot of fun and an excellent opportunity to explore your drawing technique.
www.meetup.com
Future Founders
I‚Äôm a big fan of this group because I always leave their events feeling inspired and with a sense that I learned something new. The group attracts founders, product people, and venture capitalists. It‚Äôs the perfect place to obtain or give feedback, discuss technology, and get funding! Some of the events take place in a park where participants gather in small groups to discuss challenges and ideas, and then the groups are swapped every 15‚Äì20 min. For those of you who have a business registered in Portugal, this may be an excellent place to learn more about the legal side of things as the group hosts talks dedicated to this topic as well.
www.meetup.com
Lisbon Digital Nomads
Boasting 17K+ members at the time of writing, this group is growing fast and is the best way to connect with other digital nomads and make new like-minded friends. The group organizes recurring running, networking, and board game events. The event spots tend to exceed 100 participants per event, but don‚Äôt be disappointed if you end up on a waiting list. You can still show up to the event and be admitted!
www.meetup.com
Polylogue‚Äôs Lightning Talks
If there were a category for the most thought-provoking event host, Polylogue would win. The idea behind this group is simple yet powerful: whoever shows up can give a 5 min talk about any topic of their choice. The host will provide a projector, a microphone, and snacks. The reason why I love this event so much is that it forces you in a way to learn something new that you would otherwise not look into. Topics range from highly technical concepts to funny talks about delivering packages to the most secluded places in the world to relationship advice. Whatever the case may be, it‚Äôs always fun, and it‚Äôs a great way to meet people who are passionate about what they do in life. Additionally, if you‚Äôre looking for a new coworking space, attending Lightning Talks may help you decide, as the events are hosted across various coworks.
www.meetup.com
Lisbon Supper Club
I first encountered this concept in Lisbon and immediately fell in love with it. This is how it works: you sign up for a themed supper (for example, a ‚ÄúBritish Roast‚Äù or ‚ÄúTruffle Lovers‚Äù), pay around 25 euros, and then attend the supper with up to 20 people who also signed up. The interesting twist is that the supper takes place in the dining room inside the chef‚Äôs apartment which creates an incredible atmosphere encouraging all the strangers to get to know one another by the end of the feast. The food is delicious, the ambiance is magical, and the new friendships last!
www.meetup.com
Passport Comedy
I‚Äôm not going to lie, I had low expectations for this group before going to their first event. And then ‚Äî haha! Little did I know how excellent these events would turn out to be. Passport Comedy has a solid lineup of comedians who will guarantee you an evening filled with tears of laughter. I laughed there more than at the Comedy Cellar in NYC. Grab your spot before these comedians begin doing Netflix Stand-Up Comedy Specials ‚Äî it‚Äôs worth it!
www.meetup.com
Storytelling Lisboa
The concept of this group is quite fascinating. Each event has a specific theme, such as ‚ÄúChaos,‚Äù ‚ÄúBreaks,‚Äù or ‚ÄúLandlords,‚Äù and one thing in common ‚Äî participants can volunteer to spend 10 min telling their story to an audience of 200+ people. Anyone can volunteer to tell a story, but there can be no more than ten speakers per event. The stories range from sad to funny, and the events are hosted in English or Portuguese. I was impressed by how well-structured, emotional, and thought-provoking these stories are. It‚Äôs an event format that is worth checking out at least once.
www.meetup.com
The Block Lisboa
This article wouldn‚Äôt be complete without at least one mention of a crypto-focused group. The Block hosts many crypto, NFT, and developer events. Some of them are more technical and may require prior knowledge, so make sure to read through the event description. I attended an excellent NFT workshop that felt like a whole course on NFTs, met extremely savvy people, and enjoyed great food. Regardless of how familiar you‚Äôre with blockchain, I strongly recommend looking through what The Block offers as long as you‚Äôre curious about how things work.
www.meetup.com
Two Left Feet
And finally, salsa and bachata! This group guarantees a relaxing evening filled with music and dance moves. As long as the weather‚Äôs good, the classes take place outdoors, and the instructor explains each move clearly. While dancing, the participants are asked to switch partners with every new song, so this class is a great way to get better at salsa and bachata and an excellent way to make new friends.
www.meetup.com
That‚Äôs it! I strongly recommend checking out these Meetup groups. I realize there are other great groups out there, so if you feel like I missed any of them, please leave a comment so that every reader can benefit from your recommendation. I am seeing more and more groups being added weekly, so I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if this list grows 10x by the end of 2023!
--

Title: Outbound Adventures: 7 top tips for visiting beautiful Lisbon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
This historic city has delicious seafood, unique local music, and stunning views
The gates of old Lisbon can be seen through the colorful houses and streets. (Photo by: Nour Eldin Ebrahim)
I‚Äôve just got back from exploring one of the warmest, most beautiful cities I‚Äôve ever visited: Lisbon
After a week of exploring Portugal‚Äôs capital, I‚Äôve come up with some must-dos for making the most out of your visit.
The beautiful gates of old Lisbon (Photo by: Nour Eldin Ebrahim)
The internal transportation system in Lisbon is easy to use: you go to any metro station and from the machines there buy a Viva Viagem card for 50 cents. You then charge the card as much as you want, in increments of 3, 5, and 10 euros.
Once you‚Äôve charged your card, you can select what kind of ticket you want to use it for. You can ‚Äúzap‚Äù in and out of the metro and some buses by touching the card over a scanner at the beginning and end of each journey. This will automatically deduct the cost of your trip from your card‚Äôs total.
Alternatively, before you begin your day‚Äôs travel you can choose to buy a day pass the ticket on the card for 6 euros, which may work out cheaper.
Pro tip: Get two cards ‚Äî one for zapping, and one to use if you needed a day pass.
Lisbon is famous for its seafood and for its pastries. There is a lot to try, but if I had to recommend just two must-eats, they would be Bacalhau (salted cod) and Pastel de nata (custard tartlets).
Pastel de nata (amazing Portuguese pastry made from custard), is something you can‚Äôt miss when visiting Lisbon
Pastel de nata is one of the most common and well-known Portuguese pastries, and every visitor to Lisbon should try them. Pasteis de Belem makes a great version, by far the best I tried. They were so delicious I managed 12 in one day!
The Bacalhau meanwhile is a very popular ingredient in Portuguese cooking. It‚Äôs delicious and quite different from anything you will have tried elsewhere. And don‚Äôt skimp on the other kinds of seafood, which is such a key part of Portuguese cuisine ‚Äî try the grilled salmon, for example.
Pro tip: Go to Casa Portuguesa do Pastel de Bacalhau in the famous Rua Augusta and try a special twist on Bacalhau. This place mixes the traditional flavors in a cod cake filled with Serra da Estrela cheese ‚Äî a match made in heaven!
Lisbon has its own genre of music, Fado, which is like blues with a touch of folk, and more sadness. If you look online you will find a lot of ‚ÄúFado houses‚Äù recommended by various travel guides to Lisbon, but these are all quite pricey, touristy places.
If you want an authentic experience, just go to Alfama district around 9 to 10 pm, wander through the streets, and check out the small local bars. You will often find places that host non-famous but beautiful Fado singers. Get a drink or a light dinner and enjoy an authentic Portuguese night ‚Äî one of the best experiences I had in Lisbon.
If you open any Lisbon travel guide, you‚Äôll always find this tip: ride tram ‚Ññ28. The reason is that this tram‚Äôs route passes through very interesting, scenic districts of Lisbon, including Baixa, Gra√ßa, Alfama, and Estrela.
And the tram itself is old and historical and looks beautiful to ride. But this has become a very touristic attraction and it‚Äôs literally full of pickpockets.
Tram 12 because the famous Tram 28 is a tourist trap. (Photo by: Nour Eldin Ebrahim)
So be smart and instead ride tram ‚Ññ12, just beside it. It goes to most of the same places and will provide you with a better experience.
Pro tip: Don‚Äôt take the full trip; ride the tram until you arrive at Se Cathedral and hop off. You are now on the top of the hill in the Alfama district. The cathedral is worth seeing and a couple of steps beside it is Santa Luiza Miradouro, a perfect place to watch the sunset, after which you can head to the city center on foot ‚Äî a beautiful and easy walk.
The view from Santa Luiza Miradouro, one of many beautiful viewpoints on top of the hills in Lisbon (Photo: Nour Eldin Ebrahim)
Lisbon is spread over seven hills. The tops of these hills provide a wonderful opportunity to view the city. These panoramic viewpoints are called miradoras in Portuguese and there are many of them. It‚Äôs a free way to view the city‚Äôs beauty. Watch a sunset or a sunrise from a miradouro and I promise you it will be something you will never forget.
Above I mentioned the Santa Luiza Miradouro (a personal favorite). But you can also try the Pra√ßa Alegria Miradouro (reached from Pra√ßa dos Restauradores by the traditional Funicular Gloria), which provides views over Baixa, leading towards the Rio Tejo.
Castelo de Sao Jorge Miradouro is also nice, although don‚Äôt bother with the Castle Sao Jorge next door ‚Äî it‚Äôs a waste of time. But this miradouro is on top of the highest hill in Lisbon, so the view is beautiful.
Shopping is a real pleasure here at Centro Colombo, the most famous shopping mall in Lisbon (Photo: Nour Eldin Ebrahim)
Lisbon is a very good clothes shopping destination in Europe, with seriously good prices!
The best place for a shopping spree is Columbus mall; I got a beautiful coat and a pair of jeans for 33 euros this December (650 EGP!).
Pro tip: One word: PRIMARK
There are a lot of amazing day trips that you can do from Lisbon, taking a train from Rossio train station (which is a beautiful thing to see even if you are not traveling!). But if you will do just one, then without a doubt it should be the beautiful city of Sintra.
The beautiful Sintra, a close-by city and a recommended day trip from Lisbon (Photo by: Nour Eldin Ebrahim)
Sintra is a historic city over the hills, full of old beautiful palaces and a grand Moorish castle that is worth seeing. The city‚Äôs central streets are made of cobblestones and the whole architectural style is colorful and beautiful.
Pro tip: when you arrive by train, exit on the right and wait for the tourist public bus 434 (5 euros); it will take you on a one-way circular ride around the three most important landmarks of Sintra (the town, the Moorish castle on the hill, and the Pena Palace). You can ride and hop on/off any bus until you make a full circle back to the train station. The castle is highly recommended!
The narrow but very colorful streets of Lisbon (Photo by: Nour Eldin Ebrahim)

Title: Lisbon ‚Äî a civilization on the edge of Europe
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
This story is about how a one encounter can change everything and how Lisbon can tell you everything if you can listen
Recently we were walking around the city with my friend and he asked me,
‚Äî Does the city respond to you? It got me thinking.
If you think of a city as a separate civilization, any city responds to me. Perhaps because I am a historian and I love life, comfortable shoes, walking at least 10 thousand steps a day and have endless curiosity. For me, a city is about life. Some look at a city as a geographical object, others as an investment, a source of income, beauty, history or just a backdrop. I look at the city as a separate civilization. On the other hand, there is a city and there is a village. In the village, life is organized differently. In the village, in my opinion, not much happens. All life is concentrated in the city ‚Äî championships, concerts, forums, summits, museums, galleries, meetings, marches, etc. Open any news and all the news is about city life. The city is about life. And who is interested in other people‚Äôs life? A person is either not interested in it, or he looks at it from the outside, half-heartedly. He‚Äôs busy with his own life. For example, can you describe the street where you go to work every day and tell another person about it in such a way that he wants to live on this street? Can you convey your interest in life to another person? Apparently, when we say that this city responds or doesn‚Äôt respond to me, we don‚Äôt mean the facades of the houses. We‚Äôre talking about how the life of the city coincides with our own idea of life. Or it doesn‚Äôt. And then it seems like a foreign city.
Cities like people.
First encounter with Lisbon
It wasn‚Äôt love at first sight. But it was love. For Lisbon or for Bruno or for Lisbon through love for Bruno. It doesn‚Äôt matter anymore. It‚Äôs love. I think of Bruno so often that I sometimes think I made him up. Maybe I did. No there really is a guy named Bruno, who showed up at a moment when I felt like there was no way we matched up with Lisbon. He showed up and opened my eyes to this city. No, he wasn‚Äôt my city guide, but he looked and kissed me in a way that made me want to live in this city. No, Bruno and I aren‚Äôt a couple, he‚Äôs still in my memories, and what‚Äôs more, I don‚Äôt think he even realizes the Important role he played in my life. But my story with Lisbon will always begin with that encounter.
Lisbon responded to me
The day after meeting Bruno, I went for a walk with a completely different mood and found myself in Rossio Square. I took a 360 degree look around and realized that from this point I could see all of Portugal‚Äôs history.
Did you know that you can see the history of the country by standing in this very square and you don‚Äôt even have to move anywhere? Don‚Äôt believe me? Now you will üòä
Medieval Ages
Look up the hill to the east to see St. George‚Äôs Castle, one of the oldest buildings in Lisbon. This is where Portugal‚Äôs history as a kingdom begins. Having survived the Romans and Visigoths, the Iberian Peninsula was subjected to a new invasion. In 711 Muslims came to its territory ‚Äî they were called Moors. The beginning of Portugal‚Äôs own independent history is associated with the name of Afonso I Henriques, nicknamed the Conqueror. Personality has significance in history. Thanks to Afonso I the territory of the country increased many times. But the most valuable trophy of Afonso I was undoubtedly Lisbon, which after cruel battles in 1147 became part of Portugal and turned into one of the largest centers of the country, and in 1255 the capital from Coimbra was moved to Lisbon.
Not far from Rossio Square there is Martin Muniz Square, who fought bravely during the siege of Lisbon, he alone attacked the gates of the fortress and defended them without letting them close, sacrificing his life. Thanks to Martin Muniz‚Äôs feat, the attacking Christian soldiers were able to approach the open gate and capture the fortress.
It is on this square that the famous 28th tram stops, which will take you to St. George‚Äôs Castle. Of course, you can also climb the hill on foot and get confused in the maze of streets of Alfama. It is from here that the city began to grow, descending down the hill to the banks of the Tagus River.
If you turn to the west, you will see the Gothic arches of the ruins of the Karmu Monastery. It was once one of the largest churches in the city. The history of the monastery began in 1385, when before the decisive battle of Aljubarrota, King Jo√£o I of Avis and his magnificent commander-in-chief of the Portuguese army, 25-year-old Nuno Alvares Pereira, made a vow: in the event of victory over the Castilians, each would build a monastery in honor of Our Lady. To commemorate the victory and in fulfillment of the vow made before the battle, Jo√£o I founded the monastery of Batalha, and Nuno Alvares Pereira in 1389 founded a monastery of the Carmelite order in Lisbon, known as the ‚ÄúChurch of Carmo‚Äù. Where he later donated all his considerable fortune, and then took monastic tonsure. Pious Nuno lived in the monastery until the end of his days. The hero of the battle Nuno Alvares Pereira deservedly got his place on the arch in the main square Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio.
The Carmelite Monastery was to become one of the most beautiful monuments of the National Gothic, but a tragic fate awaited it. On November 1, 1755, the vaults of the church could not withstand the strong earth tremors and collapsed, burying the townspeople who came to mass under them and losing forever the tomb of Connetabile Nuno, whom the Vatican canonized recently in 2009. The Battle of Aljubarrota, in which Portuguese troops defeated the Castilian army, laid the foundations for the Age of Discovery.
The Age of the Great Discovery was a golden age for Portugal, the XV-XVI centuries
Take a look at the square beneath your feet: the wave-shaped mosaic is no accident. It is a symbol of the ocean, of the sea voyages that made Portugal a great empire. Portugal opened the world to the world and discovered itself. The age of the Great Discovery was a golden age for Portugal, the XV-XVI centuries were a time of unprecedented Portuguese greatness, it was a wonderful time of selfless and courageous navigators heroes.
Breathe in the air. Can you smell it?
The most incredible smell I‚Äôve ever smelled is the smell of jacaranda. Lisbon‚Äôs lilac tree, Jacaranda mimosifolia, is truly worthy of the royal court. Jacaranda came from Brazil, bringing with it the scent of honey, grapes and the Atlantic Ocean. Brazil was a colony of Portugal, and Rio de Janeiro even served as the capital of the empire for 13 years, because of the invasion of Napoleon‚Äôs army under the command of General Junot the royal house had to move to Brazil in 1807. It is a unique fact in history that the capital of an empire becomes its overseas colony.
In fact, the official name of the square is Pedro IV Square. In the center of the square you can see a monument to the King of Portugal and the first emperor of Brazil.
Rossio Square now looks smart and peaceful. And once the fires of the Inquisition were burning here, heretics and witches were burned on the place of today‚Äôs national theater of Queen Mary stood the palace of the Inquisition and people always gathered to watch this spectacle. The first autodafa took place here in 1540.
Slowly, the former greatness of the Portuguese Empire fades away and in 1580. Portgugal fell under Spanish rule for 60 years. In 1640 there is a rebellion in Lisbon, as a result of which the independence of Portugal was restored. And if we walk a little from Rossio Square past the magnificent train station, we will see the Monumento dos Restauradores.
In 1755 Lisbon was destroyed by a terrible earthquake.
Take a look around ‚Äî this is Lisbon Pombal. Lisbon rebuilt after the earthquake. a great city reborn after a great catastrophe. At least, that was the original intention of Marquis Sebasti√£o Jos√© Pombalho, who was appointed by King Jos√© I to lead the rebuilding of Lisbon after the devastating earthquake of 1755 and who created the so-called Pombaline style. One of the most characteristic features of the Pombalino style is its desire for order and will to live, which can be traced back to people‚Äôs desire to protect themselves from the destructive elements. If in Alfama it is very easy to get lost in its chaotic winding streets, then in the lower new Lisbon it is impossible to do so ‚Äî the city is built on a plan, clearly on a line. The task before the architects was difficult ‚Äî it was necessary not only to rebuild a part of the country, but also to make the buildings stronger and more resistant to seismic activity. Pombalino style is very visible on the streets of the city ‚Äî strict rectangular shapes of buildings, the exterior of buildings is simple, standard and laconic.
Breathe in again. What do you smell this time?
It‚Äôs the smell of coffee and the roaring 1920s. I was sitting in Caf√© Nicola, where the bohemians of Lisbon drank coffee. Did you know that Portugal is a coffee fanatic country. According to the Potrugal Coffee Association (Associa√ß√£o Industrial e Comercial do Caf√© https://aicc.pt/) 80% of Portuguese people can‚Äôt imagine their lives without coffee, while the rest don‚Äôt drink it. Remember the phrase: ‚ÄúUm caf√© e um pastel de nata, por favor‚Äù and you won‚Äôt be lost. A vida s√≥ come√ßa depois de um caf√© ‚Äî life begins only after coffee. I don‚Äôt know who this phrase belongs to, but I‚Äôm sure he was Portuguese. By the way, definitely those 20% are lying.
The 20th century is a turbulent time.
As I stood in Rossio Square I remembered that it was here in 1974 that thousands of people gathered to celebrate the fall of the dictatorship. On April 25, 1974, a bloodless military revolution took place in Portugal. Soldiers, tired of colonial wars and censorship, overthrew the authoritarian regime. In the streets, women and children came up to them, put carnations in the barrels of their rifles ‚Äî and they did not shoot. Red carnations became a symbol of freedom and in Portugal you look at them in a special way. This event has become a symbol of hope for all of Europe.
Here in Lisbon, in Rossio Square, on Avenida da Liberdade, at the walls of Carmo, the dreams of freedom have become a reality. And I want to remember that revolutions are not always accompanied by weapons. Sometimes it‚Äôs just flowers and music. And that‚Äôs the lesson of Lisbon.
And that‚Äôs not all that Rossio Square has to tell us.
The city responded to me. It was in this city that I first experienced how deeply a place can speak if you know how to listen to it. Here, in Rossio Square, another Portugal opened up before me.
If you have walked around Rossio Square too, tell what you felt. Maybe this place opened up an unexpected side of Portugal for you?
I want to work in Lisbon as a tour guide. I want to tell the guests of the city about the history of the country, which has given the world so many wonderful discoveries and not only geographical discoveries and many lessons.
That‚Äôs my dream.And dreams are supposed to come true.

Title: The Best Walking Tours in Lisbon
Content:

Posted: 6/26/2003 | June 23rd, 2023
Lisbon is one of my favorite cities in the world. It‚Äôs home to impressive museums, historic buildings, picturesque plazas, chilled-out cafes, and a lively mix of clubs and candlelit music venues where people go to listen to traditional fado music. I fell in love with the city as soon as I arrived ‚Äî and it was even better the second time!
Today, Lisbon is one of the most popular cities on the continent. From cruisers to digital nomads, everyone loves this sunny city. I‚Äôve visited a few times over the years and always look forward to going back. The warm weather, inviting colors, and laid-back vibe really make people feel welcome.
The best way to see the city, though (especially if it‚Äôs your first time) is to take a walking tour. It‚Äôs the first thing I do when I visit a new city as it‚Äôs the best way to connect with a local guide, get insider info, and see the main sights.
These days, there are a ton of walking tours available to ensure you make the most of your visit. Here‚Äôs a list of my favorites ‚Äî from free tours to food tours to pub crawls ‚Äî to help you sort through it all so you just end up with the best!
Best Overall Tour
Learn More
I‚Äôve taken Walks tours all over Europe and it is, by far, my favorite tour company. They always manage to go above and beyond with tours that are both fun and educational.
In Lisbon, they offer a few tours (including food tours) but for a good primer on the city I recommend their Lisbon in a Day tour. It includes a river cruise, early access to Jeronimos Monastery, and lunch. It lasts a full day too!
Best Free Tour
Learn More
This informative three-hour free tour takes you through five of Lisbon‚Äôs most popular neighborhoods ‚Äî Gra√ßa, Alfama, Baixa, Chiado, and Bairro Alto ‚Äî offering up an entertaining and enlightening dose of history and culture along the way.
The tours also focus on a more local side of Lisbon. If you‚Äôre on a budget and want an introduction to the city, this is the tour for you. Just remember to tip the guide!
Here are a few more walking tour options to help you make the most of your time in Lisbon:
Devour started in Spain and quickly began doing tours in Lisbon. They offer a food and fado tour, mixing two cultural highlights of Lisbon on one tour. I personally like the Tastes & Traditions food tour they do: you stop at seven small businesses in Lisbon, eating up to nine samples and sipping three different types of beverages. Devour is one of the best food tour companies in Europe and their Lisbon tours are no exception.
Tours start at 95 EUR.
Book here!
This tour company offers a whole range of tours but their Best of Lisbon introductory tour is perfect for both first-time Lisbon visitors and budget travelers. The three-hour tour starts at 9:30am and takes you through some of the city‚Äôs main neighborhoods, making a stop for wine and a bite of the famous pastry, pastel de nata (an egg custard tart). The group tours max out at 14 people.
Tours start at 18 EUR.
Book here!
Street art has taken over the world‚Äôs big cities, including Lisbon. On this three-hour tour, you‚Äôll see some of the best works in the city and learn about the social and political motives behind them. Tours are led by a local street artist too, so you‚Äôll really get an insider‚Äôs look at the scene and visit murals most other tours skip.
Tours start at 35 EUR.
Book here!
Pancho does tours all over the Iberian Peninsula, using local guides and crafting itineraries that focus on street art, tapas and wine, and day trips to places like Sintra. Personally, I like their fado music tour. During the 2.5-hour tour, you‚Äôll learn everything there is about this melancholic music that‚Äôs endemic to Portugal. You‚Äôll get a front-row seat at a fado show in the center of Lisbon at the end.
Tours start at around 40 EUR.
Book here!
Overtourism is a problem in many cities, particularly in Europe, with crowds of people ping-ponging from one attraction to the next. Hence, the idea behind We Hate Tourism Tours: the 3.5-hour walking tour takes you to some way off-the-radar neighborhoods to show you how the people of Lisbon really live. There are only about six people per tour, which keeps things intimate. It also means you should book in advance as tours sell out fast. I love how they are getting people out of the main touristy areas and showing you a real look at Lisbon life. I can‚Äôt recommend this tour enough.
Tours start at 40 EUR.
Book here!
Lisbon has a very lively nightlife these days and, if you‚Äôre looking for a way to see it while also meeting other travelers, the classic pub crawl is a good way to go. This tour takes you to three spots, with a free shot at the first and the third stop. Plus, there‚Äôs a one-hour period of all-you-can-drink cider or sangria. It‚Äôs a great option for solo travelers looking to meet other people. It‚Äôs not a real ‚Äúlocal‚Äù thing but it‚Äôs fun!
Tours start at 20 EUR.
Book here!
***
Lisbon has walking tours for just about every interest and budget, which is one of the many reasons I love the city. Whenever I visit, I always take a tour or two because the city just has so much to see and do, and the local guides always add a ton of value to my trip. These tours allow you to get an inside perspective on life here and ask locals questions on where to go, what to do, and how to act. Be sure to take at least one of these tours while you are in the city.

You‚Äôll find suggested itineraries, budgets, ways to save money, on and off the beaten path things to see and do, non-touristy restaurants, markets, and bars, and more! Title: The Most Peaceful Place in Lisbon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We are a group of ordinary yet extraordinary travel lovers sharing our experiences of exploring the world with the world.

--
9
Listen
Share
I love the bustle of Lisbon: the up-and-down streets, the beauty of the multicolored azulejos fa√ßades on the buildings, the decorated cobblestone streets and sidewalks, and even the grittiness of the poorer neighbourhoods. But sometimes you want a break, a place without busy-ness, without touristy-ness. A place where you can feel calm and reflective for few hours. I discovered such a place in Estrela Park, a few blocks from the gleaming and grand Portuguese Parliament Buildings, and just opposite the Basilica da Estrela.
In contrast to these grand and gleaming buildings, Estrela Park feels intimate and a bit wild. Its main features are the exotic plants and trees from around the world that grow tall and lush within its gates. The park was designed in 1842 as a place for the working classes of Lisbon to relax and forget the toil and the stress of city living. Ironically, funding for construction dried up due to political instability, and the park was not completed until thirty years later. This was a tumultuous time for Portugal, as the nation veered precariously and at times violently between monarchists and republicans.
The tranquil green spaces are punctuated by several beautiful stone statues. It occurred to me that this juxtaposition between art and nature, white and green, would be worth a photo essay, showing the statues at a distance, half-hidden by the foliage, and then up close, where the depth of their expressiveness is unconcealed. But then, as I learned the stories behind these statues they revealed themselves to be much more than decorative. I‚Äôm presenting them in the order I came across them as I explored the park (and with gratitude to this Wordpress article, which helped me fill in the blanks about their origins):
The King‚Äôs Daughter, Guardian of the Ducks
She stands amid the rushes in the center of a pond, carrying a bundle of straw or something; a gaggle of stone ducks flocks around her feet. Up close, the naturalistic Art Nouveau style of the sculpture shows her in motion, walking along, yet looking down with care and affection at the ducks she guards. But wait: why would anyone guard ducks?
I discovered online that the statue was inspired by the Norwegian fairy tale of the same name, which I had never before heard of. The ducks, it turns out, are actually the 12 brothers of the princess. They had been enchanted by an evil witch. The princess risked her own life to break the spell, which could only be done by weaving each brother a shirt from thistledown (that‚Äôs what she carries in her arms). The down had to be harvested by moonlight in the moor of the trolls. It‚Äôs a harrowing tale of courage and deception, well worth reading.
Statue of Jo√£o de Deus
Jo√£o de Deus was a famous Portuguese poet, educator and politician of the 19th century, known for his personal rigor and political independence ‚Äî he never joined a political party. I first spied him behind the wrought-iron fence of the bandstand, beneath a flowering jacaranda tree. I was struck by the upright posture of this diminutive man, whose large head makes his body seem quite short. He seems both humble and strangely dignified. The school just next to the park bears his name.
Wikipedia says this about him: Next to Cam√µes and perhaps Almeida Garrett, no Portuguese poet has been more widely read, more profoundly admired than Jo√£o de Deus; yet no poet in any country has been more indifferent to public opinion and more deliberately careless of personal fame‚Ä¶
Oh my! He sounds like a man with the heart of a flan√™ur!
The Digger
This statue of a farmer tilling the soil with a hoe was erected in 1913 ‚Äî the first statue added to the garden after the monarchy was abolished and Portugal became a republic in 1910. Framed behind a spreading banyan tree, the sculpture seems a fitting public expression to mark the political transition. Notice how clearly the man‚Äôs rough clothing and strong arms are depicted.
But that look in his eyes ‚Äî it‚Äôs not that of a victorious peasant embracing his nation‚Äôs freedom, is it? To me, he is looking up anxiously, almost fearfully. Perhaps he symbolizes the entire nation, still working hard just to survive, gazing towards an uncertain future of the 20th Century. Would the eyes of a similar statue created in Portugal in 2022 look much different?
The Awakening, or Laziness
This 1915 statue of a naked young woman arising in the morning is said to be the most popular in the park. It‚Äôs easy to see why. From a distance, under an umbrella tree, her white figure is eye-catchingly sensuous.
Up close, though, it is the expression on her face that makes her so utterly beguiling ‚Äî that satisfied, languorous smile, those half-opened eyes! Though one of her arms is missing, the other is clearly in the middle of a stretch. I love the two very different words the woman supposedly embodies: Awakening and Laziness. Is she rising to meet the day, awakening to the possibilities and hopes of her future ‚Äî much as the young republic was awakening? Or has she already risen too late to do anything productive with her youthful energy? It‚Äôs hard not to think about her fellow statue, the Digger, not 50 meters away, who has been toiling away, probably since dawn.
Statue of Antero de Quental
Antero de Quental was a 19th Century realist poet and political philosopher, but his statue is the last edition to the park. It was installed in this private grove of ivy-covered trees in 1951. It makes me laugh to see a ‚Äúrealist‚Äù poet dressed in the robes of an ancient Roman! I hope he has a good sense of humor in whatever immortal realm of the poets he resides.
As a young poet, de Quental declared the role of poets, in an era of great transformation, was to be messengers of the day‚Äôs great ideological questions. He emerged as a socialist, advocate of the proletariat, and eventually an anarchist. To me it‚Äôs surprising his defiant-seeming statue was installed in the midst of Portugal‚Äôs repressive Salazar dictatorship.
Wikipedia has this to say about the great poet, and the sad ending of his life: Throughout his life, de Quental oscillated between pessimism and depression; afflicted with what might have been bipolar disorder‚Ä¶he committed suicide by two gunshots to the stomach while seated on a bench in a local garden park. He died approximately an hour later. ‚ÄúOf all things, the worst is having been born,‚Äù he wrote in a poem.
Allegory (Man with a Dog)
This final statue I encountered reclines at the edge of another little lake in the park, and has an ‚Äúunknown provenance.‚Äù Seen below, shrouded behind palm trees, it features a man in a robe with wild curly hair and a long beard that appears blown back as he leans slightly into an invisible strong wind. His large, powerful hands hold protectively onto his little dog. Its lips form a wide ‚ÄúO‚Äù because its mouth is also the spout of a fountain.
There is something loveable about this sculpture. I suppose it is the forcefulness of the man juxtaposed with the gentle way he holds his companion. It made me smile and think of all the old men and women I‚Äôve seen in Lisbon, even in Estrela Park, out walking their little dogs.
The future might be wild and uncertain, but we can do the best we can to take care of the ones we love, whether dogs or ducks or a whole nation, even a continent, once again in the midst of turbulent times and perhaps a great transformation.
--

Title: Getting Lost in the Historic Labyrinth of Lisbon‚Äôs Alfama District
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When you think of finding your way around in places that are unknown, you rely on GPS and your phone to help you get there. Back in 2016, when I was exploring Lisboa (Lisbon), Portugal, I found myself in the Alfama district. It‚Äôs one of the oldest neighborhoods in the city and possibly one of the most confusing places you could be in.
As I walked through the neighborhood, I found myself lost in a seemingly endless maze of narrow, winding staircases and hidden alleys. Without the help of GPS or the internet, I had to rely on my sense of direction to find my way around. Turns out, that sense was non-existent.
Despite feeling completely disoriented, exploring Alfama was an adventure in itself. Around every turn, I found unexpected surprises: charming courtyards, hidden plazas, and laundry drying in the sun. It was like I had stepped back in time, and I was happy to be lost in this labyrinth.
Eventually, I managed to find my way back to civilization, but I wouldn‚Äôt have regretted getting lost in Alfama. Navigating through the district‚Äôs twisting streets turned out to be a memorable experience.
Exploring Alfama district is an unforgettable experience of getting lost in a labyrinthine of narrow streets and it‚Äôs one of the most interesting neighborhood designs I‚Äôve ever seen. After all, getting lost in such an ancient area is not a bad thing, but a chance to explore its wonders one inch at a time.

Share
When we began planning to relocate to Portugal in 2022, I was excited for the opportunity to ditch my car and use public transit ‚Äî especially trains ‚Äî to get around.
And for the most part that's what we've done: we don't own a car, and we get around the center of Lisbon by public transit, with the occasional bit of frustration when a bus arrives late or a metro carriage is packed to the brim with commuters.
Comboio Portugal's trains can get you around most of Portugal without too much difficulty, but we were disappointed to discover that there were no easy routes out of Portugal and into Spain ‚Äî much less into the greater continental system of trains that crisscross Europe.
But what do I mean by an "easy route?"
The main issue is that ‚Äî due to a limited number of train schedules ‚Äî it is not possible to travel from one end of the peninsula to the other without an overnight stay somewhere near the middle. The limited number of departures ‚Äî and indeed the speed of the route itself ‚Äî mean that it's not possible to do even if you catch the first train out of Lisbon or Barcelona early in the morning.
Badajoz is a Spanish city in the ancient and contested border region of Extremadura (Estremoz in Portuguese). It‚Äôs a medium-sized city that seems to be well-accommodated, with historical relevance dating back to pre-Roman times.
But key to our attention is the fact that Badajoz is the current nexus of Portugal's train service, Comboio Portugal, and Spain's primary rail carrier, Renfe. Here the two services join at a small but functional station.
But your problems originating from Lisbon actually begin before you reach Badajoz, at a small city in Santar√©m called Entroncamento.
Entroncamento is where the relatively-fast Intercidades train service from Lisboa Oriente switches to the slow, frequently-stopping Regional service from Comboio Portugal. There are no direct trains from Lisbon to Badajoz, and you must switch at Entroncamento, with the same being true going the other direction.
The Regional service from Entroncamento is on a small, two-carriage train that makes 16 stops along the way and takes almost 3 hours to make the journey between Entroncamento and Badajoz. It's not entirely uncomfortable, but it is not fast, and the stops are frequent. But they are also some of the most charming stops along the route, and they offer some of the most beautiful vistas of Portugal's interior.
The leg from Badajoz to Madrid is likewise beautiful. It's accomplished on Renfe's Alvia service, and is much more comfortable than the journey between Badajoz and Entroncamento. The Alvia has comfortable, assigned seats, air conditioning, and a cafeteria car. It's much more like the Comboio Portugal Intercidades service, and it offers gorgeous views of Spain's snow-capped Sierra de Gredos mountains.
Gazing out the window of either the Renfe or CP trains, it's easy to imagine the Iberian countryside of Hemingway's cock and bull stories ‚Äî gentle brooks that wind past the ruins of old stone fences, among low-slung green hills dotted with the outlines of black bulls and cork trees. This scene blends uninterrupted on either side of the border for a 100km stretch, making it impossible to know which country you're in.
On the Portuguese side of the line, I saw a farmer with a plow yoked to a mule, manually plowing the soil with equipment that Iberian farmers have used for a thousand years. I could barely believe my eyes.
Our goal is to reach Barcelona, and we don't mind leaving on the earliest train out of Lisboa Oriente. And in all of our scenarios we will select the fastest services available.
That will be the 07:39 AM Intercidades (IC) departing from Lisboa's Oriente station. Oriente is a lovely station that's easy to navigate and can be reached from the Lisbon Metro's red line. The IC ride from Oriente to Entroncamento is the shortest leg of the entire journey, clocking in at a little under an hour and placing you there by 08:30 AM assuming everything goes right (it often does not on Comboio Portugal).
Here you have a few moments to top off snacks and water and locate your train to Badajoz. The Entroncamento station is pretty spartan and has limited facilities, so it's really best to get anything you'll need for the entire stretch to Badajoz before you leave Oriente.
In Entroncamento, you switch trains onto the slow-rolling and frequently-stopping Regional service departing at 09:06 AM. This train has two cars and unassigned bench seating. It's far from comfortable and at 3 hours it can be a test of patience.
By the time you roll into Badajoz at 12:54 PM you will have lost an hour crossing the Spanish border.
You will also need to find some way to occupy several hours, as the next train departing for Madrid is at 05:43 PM on Renfe's Alvia service.
Here is where a key decision emerges on your trip from Lisbon to Barcelona ‚Äî spend a long evening and night in Badajoz, waking the next morning to catch the first train to Madrid at 08:16 AM, or continue on to Madrid, arriving at 10:39 PM, where you will spend the night and have many options for reaching Barcelona the following day. Your choice basically comes down to: where would I rather sleep?
The good news, I suppose, is that 10:39 PM is a perfectly acceptable time to find a meal in Spain, where dinners often do not begin until 9:00 PM or later. But if you are already tired, Badajoz seems to have plenty to offer and ‚Äî at least as far as I can tell ‚Äî would not be a bad place to spend the night. And spending the night here would certainly allow you to eventually roll into Barcelona a little earlier in the day.
The leg from Badajoz to Madrid is a little under 5 hours whether you take the 08:16 AM or the 05:43 PM, but it is comfortable, with the Alvia offering assigned seats and both 1st and 2nd class carriages. There is a well-equipped cafeteria car and frequent trips up and down the aisles by the food cart.
Assuming that you decided to spend the night in Badajoz and take the 08:16 AM Alvia the following morning, you would arrive in Madrid a little past noon, and would then have many options for traveling on to Barcelona. All of them can be on Renfe's AVE high speed rail service, which was slightly nicer than the Alvia service and comparable to Comboio Portugal's Alfa Pendular high speed service.
This is the route I actually took a few weeks back. It was long ‚Äî and I made the trip hung over from a night of drinking with colleagues in Barcelona ‚Äî but it got me home.
As with the trip originating in Lisbon, we want to get as far as possible in a given day, so we don't mind leaving early. During my trip a few weeks ago, I intentionally chose a later train as I knew the earliest train out ‚Äî at 5:50 AM ‚Äî would be too early for me, and as we'll see in a moment, sacrificing sleep to get out as early as possible is not going to do anything for getting home faster when going west.
The AVE service is nice and fast, with comfortable seats that you can select in first and second class. I bought a first class seat because I wanted to be as comfortable as possible with a belly full of last night's cocktails ‚Äî not that it helped much as the train jostled from side-to-side as it chugged slowly out of the ancient Catalonian principality.
The countryside here looks a lot different than it does coming from the west, but during this time of the year it was beautiful. Fruit orchards (I couldn't tell if they were cherries, plums, peaches, or some other variety of stone fruit blossoms) were in full bloom, creating rows of pink and white blossoms that striped the countryside all the way to Madrid.
The AVE service should drop you in Madrid at a very respectable 9:10 AM. But the problem is that on most days, there are only two trains departing Madrid for Badajoz: 8:30 AM and 4:17PM. And you've already missed one of them.
So you must again ask yourself where you'd prefer to spend the night.
Even though it feels like you haven't made it very far, there's a strong case to be made for spending an evening in Madrid vs. Badajoz. Madrid is a major city with many restaurants and attractions that can be used to blow your time. It's almost worth it just to exit the train station here so you can see the beautiful edificio of Madrid's Puerta de Atocha railway station. But there are also museums, parks, the botanical gardens, and more just a short distance from the station.
I chose to spend the night in Madrid and got a small room near the train station so that I could pull out on the first train to Badajoz the next morning. Given the hangover, I did not do any sightseeing. But you're smarter than me and won't have that particular problem. Right? I did eat some of the worst croquettes I've ever had that night.
Sorry Spain ‚Äî Portugal's are just better.
That first train leaves at 8:30 AM, and at least for me, navigating the train station was a little confusing, so I suggest leaving yourself enough time to figure out how to get to the right train. The arrival and departure terminals are in separate buildings, so make sure you go to the right one.
The Alvia train to Badajoz is fine, with all of the amenities you need to be comfortable, but with slightly less-comfortable seats than the AVE even in first class. It speeds along just south of Spain's Sierra de Gredos mountains. With their snow-capped peaks, they make for a gorgeous backdrop to the aforementioned cow pastures and cork trees. It's a little like Texas hill country, but with some very serious hills.
By the time you reach Badajoz at 1:34 PM in the afternoon you will have made a 5 hour haul across the Iberian peninsula, but it places you in Badajoz with enough time to catch the trains on to Lisbon, where you will pick up an hour as you cross the border.
The first train to Portugal departs at 2:09 PM in the afternoon, so you have a bit of time to get snacks and water before moving on. If you miss it, there's another train to Lisboa Oriente station at 7:41 PM, but it obviously puts you in Lisbon much later at night (after 10:00 PM). This may not matter as much for a tourist, but as I was eager to get home to my family, my calculations were always focused on getting home as early in the day as possible.
Both services require taking the slow moving Regional service to Entroncamento ‚Äî the reverse of what I described in the first westward-bound trip ‚Äî and switch to an Intercidades service for the final leg of the journey to Lisbon's Oriente Station.
The Regional service to Entroncamento sits on an inconspicuous track that's on the perimeter of the main platforms. It's clearly labeled as a Comboio Portugal train, and when we arrived I assumed it was the train I needed to board. But we were made to enter the terminal anyway, and not permitted to re-enter the platform until its scheduled departure.
The Regional service to Entroncamento also departed late, but the conductor mostly made up the time during the trip. It was interesting to observe the people getting on and off along this route. Many of its stops were extremely rural, and I saw a mixture of different commuters: cyclists fully-decked in their cycling gear who brought bicycles aboard and got off after a few stops, grannies with grocery bags in either hands who rode the train for just one stop, and younger folks who looked like they were taking the full ride for a weekend of partying in Lisbon. Sometimes the conductor stepped out to help the older passengers on or off the train with their grocery bags or boxes, and it was easy to imagine that this cast of regulars were people he knew well and saw multiple times a week.
We arrived about 10 minutes late and discovered that CP had held the outbound train to Lisbon, allowing us to board and make the 4:52 PM arrival time in Lisbon.
This was much to the current passengers' consternation, but much to my relief and gratitude.
While I'm glad I made the cross-peninsular trip by train, it's not something I would want to do regularly. Nor, perhaps, would I want to do it with a large family and lots of luggage in tow.
But if you have a few days to burn and nowhere better to be, and you don't mind a slow moving tour of the Iberian countryside, this is an excellent option.
I should point out that overall the cost of the trip was actually comparable to a round-trip airline ticket. The Portuguese leg of the trip comes out to about ‚Ç¨25 one way. The leg between Portugal and Madrid is another ‚Ç¨45. And a first class ticket on the AVE between Madrid and Barcelona, in either direction, comes out to about ‚Ç¨119. This is all in one direction.
If cost is your limiting factor ‚Äî and especially travel time ‚Äî air travel makes more sense.
But there are plenty of good reasons to take the train if you can: reduced environmental impact, the ability to get up and walk around to stretch your legs and take in views, choices for food and drink in the cafeteria cars, and beautiful views of the countryside are all compelling reasons to consider travel-by-train. And while the trains (at least in Spain) require you to run your bags through a screening process, it was nothing compared to the headache that is air travel in the year 2025.
I'd like to see more options for getting places by rail, so I try to take the trains whenever it's feasible. My hope is that the more we use trains, the more countries see the demand for expanded routes and increased optimization in existing routes.
While I might not take this route frequently, I'm at least comfortable in the implications that it brings and can pack and plan accordingly. And if you believe the hype, plans are in the works to bring high speed service between Lisbon and Madrid. If accomplished, this would result in something like 3 hours of travel time between the peninsula's capitals and would make getting on to Barcelona in a day an easy feat.
But I'm afraid the Portuguese cynicism for major works like this has already worn me down, and I'm not expecting this to be the case any time soon.
Even if I don't plan on going from coast to coast, I know I can make it from capital to capital in a single day, and that's a thing I might try to do more often now that I've done it once.
And maybe at some point, I'll make the cross-peninsula trek and just keep going ‚Äî into France and the heart of Europe. But that's a feat for someone with way more time on their hands than me right now.
