Title: What You Need to Know About Lisbon‚Äôs Culture of Illegal Chinese Restaurants
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Discover new and exciting places from all around the world.

--
1
Listen
Share
Lisbon is one of the most beautiful cities in Europe and Portugal‚Äôs main centre of education, economy and culture. Its picturesque alleys of Bairro Alto and the fancy boulevards from Rossio to Tejo are just a fraction of places to go and see during the day. And by night, you‚Äôll hear traditional Fado tunes coming out of every bar, inviting you to join the vibrant nightlife. Lisbon‚Äôs atmosphere is overall an exciting mix of fast-paced city life and Mediterranean flair that provides the needed balance between work and life.
But when you go off the usual streets and places full of tourists, you may experience a whole different side of Lisbon, one that isn‚Äôt mentioned in any common guide and for outsiders quite difficult to access. Without knowing the right places beforehand, it‚Äôs practically invisible. I talk about Lisbon‚Äôs rising underground scene of secret Chinese restaurants.
‚ÄúYou probably mean the ‚Äûillegal‚Äú Chinese. There are three of them close to Martim Moniz. One at the end of the street Beco da Oliveira and two are in a building in street Rua do Terreirinho (number 40 if I remember correctly).‚Äù ‚Äî Henning, Erasmus Student from Lisbon on Hubble
The most prominent spot for such restaurants is around the metro station Martim Moniz in the neighborhood of Mouraria. They are often hidden in apartment buildings and back alleys, and the more you proceed into the side streets of Mouraria, the creepier it gets.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not pretty sure about the name of the restaurant but I think it is Chin√™s Clandestino. As the name says, it is a clandestine restaurant, so it‚Äôs like a secret spot to have a nice meal. Here you have the address: Mouraria ‚Äî Rua da Guia, 9, 2 Dto, Mouraria, Lisboa. Have fun!‚Äù ‚Äî Daniela, World Citizen on Hubble
The friendly and colorful Lisbon you once knew (well, a few minutes ago) is gone. Streets are plastered with garbage instead of the azure blue Azulejo tiles. Now, heated discussions in all kinds of languages come in place of the relaxing, traditional melodies from the Old Town. You would love nothing more than to turn around, hop onto the metro back to Bairro Alto and quickly forget about your unsuccessful adventure, but the goal is already within your reach. You can‚Äôt go back now, can you?
‚ÄúThere are two in Rua do Benformoso 59. Just knock on the door on the 1st floor or try the one on the 2nd floor.‚Äù ‚Äî Nanxi, Foodie on Hubble
You wind up standing in front of a slightly rundown house. The door is open most of the time and leads to a dark hallway. It feels like you‚Äôre in a movie‚Ä¶No, not the one‚Äôs with a happy ending. You dare to go upstairs. The smell of food fills your nose but the fear of getting kidnapped and waking up tomorrow without a kidney is the only thing you can think of.
Nervously, you read the number of the apartment where you have to go from a little, crumpled-up piece of paper which you got from your Airbnb host. It‚Äôs the right place. You gather all your courage and knock on the door. You regret it, why did you even come here, you should have gone to McDonal ‚Äî ‚Ä¶ Suddenly, an old, Asian lady opens the door and invites you warmly in. Although you don‚Äôt understand a word, it feels like everyone is very kind to you. Maybe this isn‚Äôt so bad at all. At least your organs are safe.
In the restaurant, it‚Äôs a completely different world. A bit modest, but clean, traditional and cozy. A few people are having dinner, others play ancient board games. The old lady sits down and continues to watch a TV show while you proceed to one of the 8 tables in total. There‚Äôs no pressure. You sit down, choose a meal and after all the stress you get rewarded with incredible amounts of tasty food at a good price. Regular restaurants have nothing on the unmatched dishes and familiar vibe. It‚Äôs like you would eat at your grandparent‚Äôs home, well if your grandparents should be from Asia and‚Ä¶ I mean you get it.
I can‚Äôt recommend those places enough. Instead of going to the same locations over and over again, you should try one of these secret restaurants. It‚Äôs an exciting part of everyday life in Lisbon and when you want to see its true nature while having a cheap night-out, this is it!
If you want to receive more recommendations on exciting places and events in your area, sign up here to join our weekly newsletter at Hubble and connect with other like-minded people to spread and discover the world‚Äôs experiences.

Title: Lisbon‚Äôs Quiosques Helped Me Rediscover Backgammon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Portugal  Calling is a new publication on Medium managed by a Portuguese editorial team featuring a wide range of topics about life, language, and Portuguese culture.

--
3
Listen
Share
Like most children, when I was very little, there were things in our house that I was not allowed to touch. Things like the grandfather clock in our living room, which I was told would fall over on me. Or the record player, which I actually did touch, and did break the stylus on, and which never worked again. And of course common dangerous kitchen things like the stove, oven, or kitchen knives.
But of all the things I was not allowed to touch, the weirdest and seemingly most harmless one was a small, gray, leather-bound case that my mom kept in her room. It was about the same size as one of our encyclopedias, but thinner, and had a handle for carrying. The brass latches kept both sides of the case firmly closed. At the time, it felt like the perfect child-sized suitcase for pretending I was going on a trip somewhere. ‚ÄúAloha! I‚Äôm off to Hawaii with my cool little suitcase!‚Äù, I might‚Äôve pretended. Except that I definitely was not allowed to use this little case as a prop.
But within this tantalizing little case was something special to my mom. Something she worried I would either damage, or lose the pieces to, or spill something on, or maybe she just thought I‚Äôd swallow a piece. It was a backgammon board; a game my mom would later reveal to me in the hopes of having a partner for playing. But she would be disappointed, as it turned out, because backgammon is kind of confusing for a kid.
While we tried to play a few times, most of our games ended in mutual frustration, and for the time being I decided backgammon was boring and not something I wanted to learn to play.
The trajectory of gaming for me was not a straight line from my first encounter with backgammon to rediscovering it decades later. As a kid I played a lot of the basic Milton Bradley and Parker Bros. stuff ‚Äî Monopoly, Trouble, Guess Who, Clue ‚Äî and as I entered my junior high years I began playing tabletop role playing games. During weekends in high school, I would go to a tennis meet, then head to a friend‚Äôs house at Fort Polk where half of our team would engage in UNO or Risk and the occasional groan-inducing session of Axis and Allies.
It wasn‚Äôt until I was in early college, and I met my friend Lyle, that I got into what were then called ‚ÄúEuropean-style board games‚Äù: Ticket to Ride, Puerto Rico, Game of Thrones, and more. The vast world of tabletop gaming ‚Äî with its myriad choices of engines, strategies, settings, and pleasant little game pieces ‚Äî opened up to me and hooked me. It was revelatory.
After I got married in 2010, I introduced my wife to the world of adult board games, and she got into them as well. By 2012, we were hosting weekly game nights at our house in Atlanta. My wife would prepare a delicious meal for everyone, and we‚Äôd kick things off with a warmup game like Citadels, Epic Spell Wars of the Battle Wizards (we lovingly call this game Wizards of Skullfuck Mountain because none of us could be bothered to remember the name), or something else that played quickly. Then we‚Äôd eat, and get into the real main course ‚Äî a good multiplayer board game‚Äî which might last for 2‚Äì3 hours.
This went on for many years until the complications of life finally intruded on everyone, and we had a kid.
Around the same time in 2012, I was being introduced to the ancient Asian strategy game of Go by a coworker. I was fascinated by the simplicity of the game, but continuously challenged by its complex strategies. At this point I was mostly dabbling ‚Äî we‚Äôd play a few games on a mobile app each week, but eventually I changed jobs, we lost touch, and I didn‚Äôt think about Go for a while.
Then in 2014, I got an itch to play Go again, and got a physical Go board and pieces and brought them to work. I sat it on my desk and friends and I would take turns playing throughout the day. One day an outside consultant I had hired walked by my desk and noticed our Go board and revealed that he was deeply into Shogi and Go. This let to a renewed interest in Go for myself, and an introduction to the intricacies and deep strategies of Go for some of my coworkers. While some of them got deeply into it (one of them is now the head of Atlanta‚Äôs Go Club and a highly-ranked player), I played occasionally but did not invest a lot of time in practicing. Consequently, I am not very good at Go but I still love the game.
Fast forward to 2024. I still love games. And our daughter does too. Among her favorites are Splendor, Azul, Ghost Blitz, and chess. A lot of my free time in Lisbon is spent sitting at the park quiosque reading, writing, and drinking a cold beer on a nice day. While the kid runs circles around the quiosque with her friends climbing trees and playing tag, my wife and I sit at the quiosque‚Äôs small tables making small talk, looking at our phones, or planning out the week‚Äôs activities. Sometimes friends join us, and when they do there is plenty of good conversation to keep our brains occupied. But when it's just us, it's nice to have something to do beyond just chatting.
This got me thinking about small games to occupy ourselves. It's not unusual to see people playing cards, but I don't love the way cards occupy your hands, and I honestly don't really enjoy most of the two-player card games. I thought about Go, but I have consistently failed to get my wife interested in Go, and with its hundreds of small pieces, it could make for a real mess if the kit came open accidentally or a pigeon decided that one of the pieces looked particularly tasty. Then I thought about dice, but I don't know any simple games involving dice.
But then a thought entered my mind: what about backgammon?
Backgammon has its own portable case and is available in very small form-factors.
Backgammon is for two players.
Backgammon has limited pieces to lose.
Backgammon has a relaxed pace, and allows your hands to be free to smoke or drink.
But what I couldn't remember is anything about playing it, so I started doing some reading and watching some videos and realized that backgammon was actually pretty easy to learn, but that there was ample room for strategy. Things clicked and finally fell into place for me, and I thought that I'd like to order a small backgammon set to try.
I found what appeared to be a nice, travel-sized set on Amazon Espanha: a travel set from Yellow Mountain. As we had a trip coming up to Alcaide for the Festa de Cogumelos, I knew my wife and I would have an opportunity to play for a few days: during our time relaxing at the hotel.
For two people on the move wanting to learn to play, it was a good set. The Yellow Mountain set is probably overpriced, but it‚Äôs nice for anyone looking for a travel-sized board. When fully opened it lays flat on a table, has a felt game board, and the checkers are magnetized, making it easier to keep up with them. It comes with a set of backgammon rules. My only real complaint is that the miniature dice feel cheap, and that the magnetized checkers sometimes make them hard to stack.
After our arrival at the hotel, we sat in the lounge and played for several hours while we had drinks and snacks. I explained the basics of the game to my wife and she quickly caught on.
Since then, we‚Äôve played hours of backgammon while we're at the quiosque, but we have also started playing more at home. We are having a great time challenging each other and figuring things out for ourselves. It‚Äôs so nice to have an interesting, casual game to play while we hang out at the quiosque. I‚Äôm looking forward to having it this coming spring and summer.
And there's a lot of strategy that we have yet to discover. We didn't begin using the doubling cube ‚Äî a dice that effectively lets both players bet on the outcome of the game in order to win more points ‚Äî though we eventually added it into play and have slowly started to increase the number of points needed to win a game (we're up to 9 points now). But the doubling cube absolutely adds another element of strategy to the game.
Neither of us has yet to score a gammon or backgammon, which occurs when one player manages to "bear off" all of their pieces out of their home board before the other player has a single piece in. Most of our games wind up being very close, and I'm confident there are strategies we are overlooking for blocking each other from scoring. The defining moment of each game is always when one of us gets our last piece past the last opponent on the board, at which time it becomes a race to bear off all of our pieces.
For Christmas, my wife bought me a nice, handmade home board from a Greek company called Manopoulos ‚Äî it's gorgeous and the pieces and game board are so satisfying to hold and touch! It's too big for the quiosque, but that's okay. It's a wonderful board to use at home and we look for any opportunity to pull it out and play a few rounds. It‚Äôs something that will be in our family for years.
And you know what? I‚Äôll probably let my daughter touch it, though thus far she has shown little interest in backgammon after watching us play many rounds.
I‚Äôm glad I remembered that little suitcase from my childhood, and that my mom at least tried teaching me a game that ‚Äî although I didn‚Äôt find interesting at the time ‚Äî I would remember later in life. It at least made backgammon a possibility in my mind and made it an option to consider when I was looking for a casual, portable, strategic, two-player boardgame.
I think my mom would be happy to know that I rediscovered backgammon and learned how to play. And I'm glad I did! The gameplay is the perfect pace for nice days at the quiosque.
And when she eventually returns to Lisbon for a visit, I look forward to surprising her with my knowledge of backgammon, and playing a few games with her at the quiosque over a cold beer.

21st August 2013 Lisbon, Portugal
The ship‚Äôs engine whirled, shook and rattled to a stop as outside, the crew scuttled about to pull thick ropes around the metal structures on Lisbon‚Äôs port to hold the cruise ship in place for the day. The sun‚Äôs rays enveloped the entire city from the top of the mountains, over brightly-coloured houses all in pastel, before reaching over one magnificent church standing tall at sea level.
‚ÄúLisbon was a city full of history and culture. Many buildings and markets were kept as it was a hundred years before, portraying the old ways of life.‚Äù
We went ashore after having breakfasted on the ship and rode a century-old tram around different city quarters, with assurance from the driver that this tram line was used as regular transportation in the city.
The tram climbed up steep hills and slid down narrow alleyways as if following a secret passageway that only our driver knew of. We passed the old quarter with houses worn down and looking like slums, but still had beautiful glazed tiles in their facÃßade that were used immensely as decoration in the olden days, giving blue, green, turquoise and red patterns to entire buildings, making them stand out from their plain, pastel-coloured neighbours.
As the tram rattled past the main train station, it occurred to me why the architecture looked a little bit like home. Coming from Thailand, I was familiar with the fact that Portuguese culture influenced a lot of Thai culture during the time of King Rama V (in the 19th century), where the King had commissioned Portuguese architects to design many buildings during the time of his reign. One of the locals explained that the king of Thailand indeed came to visit Lisbon once, meeting the King of Portugal in the very same train station that our tram moved past.
We reached a huge open square surrounded by magnificent white columns of the city‚Äôs biggest theatre, the monument of King John of Lisbon atop a horse, as well as the palace walls that ran along the length of the square. The tram stopped long enough for all of us to have a glass of port wine and a Portuguese egg tart (past√©is de nata).
‚ÄúPort was traditionally drank after a meal in Portugal, a habit taken up by the British people, but twisted by the French: they enjoyed their glass of the sweet red port as an aperitif before meals.‚Äù
This Portuguese pastry was also familiar to us Thais ‚Äî creamy egg tart with a consistency similar to that of creÃÄme bruleÃÅe, encased in a crispy, flaked pastry shell sold at the side of the roads. But the Portuguese version has a touch of cinnamon, which gave the tart a special and more complex aroma and flavour. The combination of freshly made, warm egg tart and cool, smooth port is thoroughly enjoyed in Portugal as a breakfast pastry or mid-afternoon snack with coffee.
One of the most famous places to try these gloriously crunchy, buttery tarts in Lisbon is at Past√©is de Bel√©m
A caf√© stood in the corner of the square, where one of the locals pointed out to us that it has been operating there since the 1700s. It was mid-morning, but the caf√© was packed with customers having coffee and a golden, thread-like dessert called Fios de Ovos . Another familiar sight, this dessert is thought by many to originate from Thailand and called Foi-Thong (golden thread), however it was the Portuguese that first made it.
The dessert was another Portuguese delicacy which was shared by many far Eastern cultures when the Portuguese explorer, Vasco da Gama, sailed across the Indian Ocean and created a new trade route in the 15th century.
The tram started up again, winding its way down to a huge moastery that stood close to the harbourside, its walls running 500 metres across the gardens in front, close to the sea. If you came to Lisbon, this was a must-see sight as the monastery was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1983. Inside the dome-like structure which loomed high above us, were altars of Jesus Christ and tombs of the king and queen. The main altar was of European influence, with paintings of the Lord, Mother Mary from the Renaissance period, but the tombs of the long-gone royals were supported by Indian elephants, showing further the fascination with Oriental cultures the king of Portugal at the time had. Inside this church also lay the tomb of the explorer Vasco da Gama.
Lisbon is a big city and half a day of exploring was simply not enough.

Title: The Triumphal Arch of Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio, Its Sculptures and Their Meaning
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Situated in one of the most beautiful squares of the world, the Triumphal Arch of Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio, most commonly known as Rua Augusta Arch, is the monumental gate that connects Lisbon to Tagus river.
The construction process of this Triumphal Arch, the emblematic finishing element of the buildings that constitute the former Terreiro do Pa√ßo, was long and certainly not controversy-free.
Supported by grandiose columns it is topped by a set of sculptures that carries a lot of meaning.
Today it is one of the tourist attractions of the city and a must-visit place for the Portuguese as well as for foreigners, as it provides a stunning 360-degree view over the river and the Pombaline Downtown.
After the devastating earthquake of 1755, it was necessary to rebuild the entire downtown area of the city. For that a team of engineers and architects was formed and was led by minister Marquis of Pombal that under the rules of the Reformist Enlightenment movement created a new modern, rational city with a classic and simple style, the Pombaline Style.
The monumental Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio was built over the former Terreiro do Pa√ßo. The royal palace that used to exist there since the 16th century and that collapsed was solely symbolically replaced by the equestrian statue of King Jos√© I.
The square, composed by buildings with arcades, is perfectly symmetric and has two towers both on the east and west sides, while the south side faces the river and the north side faces the new city. The Triumphal Arch of Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio, the noble entrance of Lisbon, was projected for the north end since the beginning.
The first project, by Eug√©nio dos Santos, was classic and simple and was approved in 1758. It was a round arch sided by statues in niches, with a triangular pediment and topped by a sculpture set.
In 1762 the architect passed away and was substituted by Carlos Mardel who presented a new proposal. More connected to a baroque model, this proposal replaces the pediment with a tall bell tower and a clock, decorated with pinnacles and flame-shaped sculptural ornaments.
Just like the previous one, this project long awaited its execution, seeing that the economic resources of the kingdom were being destined to more important works.
With time passing by, the political context as well as people‚Äôs tastes changed and new ideas arose, which triggered a heated discussion among the people of Lisbon.
Thus, the execution of the Triumphal Arch of Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio was successively delayed. First due to the withdrawal of Marquis of Pombal from the government in 1777 and later due to the political and economical instability that resulted from the civil war in the early 1800s.
However, in 1815 the support columns were built and only in 1873 was finally inaugurated the monument projected by Ver√≠ssimo Jos√© da Costa, a solution that merges the best of the two previous proposals.
From Eug√©nios dos Santos he chose to include the sculpture sets, as well as the classic lines and balanced proportions; from Carlos Mardel he included the clock and placed it facing north, while the south side features the coat of arms of Portugal. Plus, he added a baroque style with the rococo decoration that surrounds them.
Ver√≠ssimo Jos√© da Costa kept the already built base but discarded the triangular pediment from the two previous projects, replacing it with a rectangular structure that corresponds to a wide hall, where we can see the clock mechanism, as well as a superb view from both the large lateral windows.
The sculptures present in the Triumphal Arch of Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio resulted from an iconographic programme from the French artist C√©lestin Anatole Calmels (1822‚Äì1906). This artist executed, among others, the emblematic works of the Allegories on the sides of the portal of Palmela Palace and the sculpture set of the pediment of the City Council of Lisbon.
On the south side of the arch, the artwork on the top level was executed by the Portuguese romantic sculptor Victor Bastos (1830‚Äì1894), author of, among other pieces, the monument of tribute to the poet Lu√≠s de Cam√µes, situated in the Square named after him.
They are the colossal allegories of the rivers Tagus (west side) and Douro (east side) on the sides of the building; and two pairs of statues that represent four important figures of the History of Portugal.
While the representations of these same rivers in the statues of Liberdade Avenue are harder to distinguish, here they‚Äôre more clearly identified. The statue on the east side features a bunch of grapes, which we immediately associate to the Demarcated Region of Douro, instituted in 1756 during the governance of Pombal. On the opposite side the Tagus seems to have had an object on its hand, but whatever it was is now broken.
When it comes to the statues, from left to right we can find: on the west side, Viriathus (181 BC-139 BC), the mythical leader of Lusitanian people, followed by Vasco da Gama (1469‚Äì1524), the navigator and explorer that discovered the sea route from Europe to the East.
On the east side, from left to right we can see Marquis of Pombal (1699‚Äì1782), who was responsible for the development of the country and for the reconstruction of the capital. A figure that certainly wouldn‚Äôt have had a place here if the arch hadn‚Äôt been built so belatedly. Finally we see Constable Nuno √Ålvares Pereira (1360‚Äì1431), an equally important personality of the History of Portugal and Lisbon and founder of the Carmo Convent.
Four personalities from different times and of distinct qualities but all certainly related to the allegories on the top of the arch: Valour and Genius crowned by Glory.
This last stone sculpture set presents us three figures: the middle one is standing and represents Glory, who is holding two bronze bay crowns on top of the head of two seated figures next to her.
Below them we can see the inscription: ‚ÄúVIRTVTIBVS MAIORUM VT SIT OMNIBVS DOCMENTO. P.(ECVNIA) P.(VBLICA) D.(ATVM)‚Äù, which means: By virtue of the Greatest, so that it may serve everyone as a teaching. Dedicated to public expenditure. ‚Äù
On the west side we can see the female figure of the goddess Minerva wearing a plume helmet and holding a sword, with a lion resting by her side. On the two sides of the helmet are presented two small winged dragons, which remind us of the symbol of the House of Aviz.
The roman goddess Minerva, associated with the greek Athena, is the goddess of wisdom, strategic warfare and the sponsor of arts, hence being connected to Valour.
Genius is here represented on the east side by the god Apollo with books and a lyre. In this case the beardless young figure has wings, which connects it to the Christian figure of the Archangel Michael.
On top of one of its wings there‚Äôs a discreet small figure of a philosopher that we hypothetically associate to the roman writer of the 1st century BC Virgil.
The symbology of the Triumphal Arch of Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio, the Equestrian Statue of King Jos√© I, the Cais das Colunas and even the dimensions and proportion of the Square and of the buildings that constitute it, have been targets of interpretations that tend to emphasise its masonic and esoteric character. We leave these reflections to the specialists.
To finish off, we must suggest you visit the Triumphal Arch of Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio that has been open to the public since 2013. You can access it in Rua Augusta by going on an elevator and then going up a few stairs. You‚Äôll have access to a terrace where you can admire the stunning view.

You know what they say, right? It is very easy to come to Lisboa, but to leave this city is very hard. In the next few months, you will spend in this ‚Äò ‚Äò, you will find out that this could not be more true. To get familiar with the place you can call home for your Erasmus semester, Cidade Linda here are some of the highlights you can ‚Äî and should ‚Äî not miss.
You probably noticed them in your new neighbourhood: These small restaurants or local caf√©s can be found throughout the city. Start your day by ordering a strong ‚Äò bica‚Äô and a pastel de nata. You cannot leave Lisboa without trying this combination out and, chances are high it will even become your daily routine!
Besides supporting your local pastelaria, check out Manteigaria as well. There are two: one in Rua do Loreto and one in Lisboa‚Äôs Time Out Market. This food market is also great for getting a bite or a drink during the day or evening.
When you are done exploring the city and head out to Bel√©m, the place not to miss for the best past√©is de Nata (this is plural of ‚Äò pastel de nata ‚Äò by the way, which is good to know in case you want to order more than one) is Past√©is de Bel√©m. Easy to recognise because people line up in the street, but it‚Äôs worth the wait. Trust me!
On a Tuesday or Saturday, take a stroll through. Feira da Ladra is a secondhand market, up in the area between the Gra√ßa and Alfama neighbourhoods and is a must-see as well. It is a great place to go treasure hunting and find a truly special souvenir to bring home: uniquely illustrated postcards, plates with a 70‚Äôs design, but also vintage shoes or old leather bags. Enjoy a walk back to the city centre from here, and you will notice why they say Lisboa is built on seven hills right away.
One of the best places in town to get a drink with a view is Park Rooftop. When you haven‚Äôt been there before, it can seem a bit strange to enter a random parking garage for a drink. But, just take the elevator all the way up and you are at the rooftop bar. It can be hard to get a table but try going during the day and enjoy the view on the Ponte 25 de Abril. This place is also nicest views over the city must be highly recommended when the sun sets or for parties at night.
There is a lot to see and do in the city of course, but when the temperatures rise ‚Äî and believe me, they will ‚Äî check out the beaches nearby. Easy to reach by train are those of Carcavelos, Estoril and Cascais. Another great one is Costa da Caparica, on the other side of the Tejo river. Take the bus from Pra√ßa da Espanha and you can be in the ocean just forty minutes later. Perfect, right? And, since you are there, you might as well try a surf lesson.
A night out in Lisboa starts here. Meet your friends at the nearby Pra√ßa Lu√≠s de Cam√µes and head into one of the small streets to buy a cheap drink at one of the bars. From here, you can easily walk down, towards the river, to the Cais do Sodr√© area later that night. Here, the bars and clubs can be found in Pink Street. Not the official name, but the asphalt is actually painted pink. Try some of the streets around it as well, just follow the crowd and enjoy your drink out on the streets!
Another thing not to miss is LxFactory. Try to go on a Saturday and have a look at the market at this former threads and fabrics factory, but any other day is nice as well to go here for a drink, lunch, brunch and do some shopping. Oh, and you should definitely check out Livraria Ler Devagar, an amazing there. Hundreds of books cover the walls ‚Äî both, new and second-hand ‚Äî which make space not only nice to see in real life but definitely Instagram-worthy as well.
Check out the concerts and other festivals that LX Factory organises, there‚Äôs always something going on. they organise at LX Factory too, there are some cool events going on.
Just follow these six tips, and you will slowly become more of a local in your new city. In the next few months, you will undoubtedly have tons of tips to add to the list and understand even more why you can never really leave Lisboa.

Content:

I‚Äôve learned that big cities are a hassle no matter where in the world you travel. If you have a rental car, driving in European urban centers is incredibly stressful. That‚Äôs why I chose to ride the bus into Lisbon and let someone else deal with traffic.
My base in √ìbidos offered a simple solution. A comfortable bus picked me up less than a five minute walk from my Airbnb and dropped me off in Lisbon city center one hour later for $8. Best deal of the trip I‚Äôd say.
One of the first things you learn about Lisbon is that the city you see today is relatively new (by European standards). On November 1, 1755, a powerful earthquake leveled much of Portugal‚Äôs capital. An ensuing tsunami and fire increased the devastation. More than 35,000 people died. At the time, Lisbon was one of the largest cities in Europe.
Ruins of the Carmo Convent in central Lisbon were preserved as a memorial to the earthquake. Today the site appropriately serves as an archaeological museum. Stone arches inside rose to an open sky, providing silent testaments to the day Lisbon crumbled.
Legend has it that Lisbon, similar to Rome, was founded on seven hills. There were incredible views out over the city from the top of each hill but you had a workout hiking up and down each one.
I found that Lisbon was an interesting mix of modern and an almost whimsical past. Rickety trams clicked and clacked their way up the hills as electric cars whirred by.
It was a great city to just wander rather than trying to hit a list of major sights. You were bound to get lost anyway in the winding streets of the old town. Rare for Europe, the city‚Äôs commercial center actually had a grid-like street plan built after the earthquake.
I‚Äôd compare Lisbon to San Francisco in the States. Both cities are on the ocean, have hills and trams. Both suffered devastating earthquakes. Lisbon even had a suspension bridge spanning its bay that resembled the Golden Gate.
I peeked inside this store for Portugal‚Äôs national football (not soccer) team. Led by star Cristiano Ronaldo, Portugal is still alive in the current World Cup. When the team is playing, life pretty much comes to a standstill here, with everyone gathering around their TVs. Portugal‚Äôs historical rivals include Brazil, Spain and France.
I jumped on a local train to go a few minutes down the coast for a visit to the Bel√©m neighborhood in western Lisbon. A massive monument to Portuguese explorers was built there as a nod to its place as the point where ships departed Lisbon.
Bel√©m also housed Jer√≥nimos Monastery, erected in the early 1500s near the launch point of Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama‚Äôs first journey. Da Gama became the first European to reach India by sea after he sailed around the south of Africa at the Cape of Good Hope. His remains were interred in a prominent carved tomb in the nave of the monastery‚Äôs church.
Da Gama‚Äôs discovery and the subsequent Portuguese armadas that sailed to India for spices helped build the small country into a serious world power in the 1500s.
So much of Portugal‚Äôs history and culture, its national identity really, stem from the Age of Discovery.

Unveiling the Charms of Portugal‚Äôs Capital City
Are you ready to embark on a journey to one of Europe‚Äôs most enchanting destinations? Get ready to explore the vibrant streets, taste the delectable cuisine, and immerse yourself in the rich culture of Lisbon, Portugal. From historic landmarks to breathtaking views, Lisbon has something to offer for every traveler.
Lisbon, the capital city of Portugal, is a treasure trove of history, art, and natural beauty. Nestled along the Atlantic coast, this charming metropolis boasts a unique blend of old-world charm and modern sophistication. With its winding cobblestone streets, pastel-colored buildings, and picturesque vistas, Lisbon is a destination that beckons to be explored. Whether you‚Äôre a history buff, a food enthusiast, or an avid adventurer, Lisbon promises an unforgettable experience that will leave you longing for more.
As we delve into the heart of Lisbon, prepare to be captivated by its timeless allure and dynamic energy. From the moment you arrive, you‚Äôll be greeted by the warm hospitality of the locals and the irresistible aroma of freshly baked pastries wafting through the air. As you wander through the city‚Äôs diverse neighborhoods, each with its own distinct character, you‚Äôll discover a tapestry of experiences that will leave an indelible mark on your soul.Now, let‚Äôs embark on a virtual journey through Lisbon, where we‚Äôll uncover its hidden treasures, unravel its rich tapestry of culture and tradition, and savor the flavors of its culinary delights. Get ready to be transported to a world where history comes alive, and every cobblestone has a story to tell.
Curiosities:
Did you know that Lisbon is one of the oldest cities in Western Europe, predating other European capitals such as Paris and Rome? Its history dates back over 3,000 years, making it a living testament to the passage of time and the resilience of its people.
Climate and Best Time to Visit:
Lisbon enjoys a Mediterranean climate, with mild winters and warm summers. The best time to visit is during the spring (April to June) and autumn (September to October) when the weather is pleasantly mild, and the city is adorned with blooming flowers and lush greenery. Summer (July to August) is also a popular time to visit, despite the warmer temperatures, as it coincides with festive events and lively street celebrations.
Places to Visit:
Lisbon is brimming with iconic landmarks and hidden gems waiting to be discovered. From the historic Alfama district with its narrow alleys and stunning viewpoints to the grandeur of Belem Tower overlooking the Tagus River, every corner of Lisbon has a story to tell. Don‚Äôt miss the chance to visit the majestic S√£o Jorge Castle, which offers panoramic views of the city, or explore the vibrant cultural hub of LX Factory, where art, design, and creativity converge.
Myths and Legends:
Legend has it that Lisbon was founded by the ancient Greek hero Odysseus during his epic journey home from Troy. According to myth, Odysseus was so captivated by the beauty of Lisbon‚Äôs natural harbor that he decided to establish a city on its shores. While the origins of Lisbon may be shrouded in myth and folklore, one thing is certain ‚Äî the city‚Äôs allure is as timeless as the stories that have been woven into its fabric.
Typical Phrases:
As you wander through the streets of Lisbon, you‚Äôll often hear locals greeting each other with ‚ÄúBom dia‚Äù (Good morning), ‚ÄúBoa tarde‚Äù (Good afternoon), or ‚ÄúBoa noite‚Äù (Good evening). These simple phrases reflect the warmth and friendliness of the Portuguese people, who take pride in extending a warm welcome to visitors from near and far.
Cuisine and Culture:
No visit to Lisbon would be complete without indulging in its delectable cuisine. From savory bacalhau (salted cod) dishes to sweet past√©is de nata (custard tarts), Lisbon‚Äôs culinary scene is a feast for the senses. Be sure to sample traditional Portuguese dishes such as grilled sardines, caldo verde (kale soup), and arroz de marisco (seafood rice) at local eateries and family-owned restaurants. As you savor each bite, you‚Äôll gain a deeper appreciation for the rich culinary heritage that defines Lisbon‚Äôs gastronomic identity.
The people of Lisbon are known for their warmth, hospitality, and love for music and dance. Fado, Portugal‚Äôs soulful musical genre, holds a special place in the hearts of Lisboetas (residents of Lisbon) and is often performed in intimate venues known as fado houses. The haunting melodies and heartfelt lyrics of fado songs capture the essence of Portuguese culture and evoke a deep sense of emotion that resonates with locals and visitors alike.
In conclusion, Lisbon is a city that invites you to embrace its history, savor its flavors, and immerse yourself in its vibrant culture. Whether you‚Äôre strolling along the cobblestone streets of the old town, admiring the intricate azulejos (ceramic tiles) that adorn buildings, or simply sipping a glass of port wine while gazing at the sunset over the river, Lisbon will leave an indelible impression on your heart. So pack your bags, set out on an adventure, and get ready to fall in love with the timeless allure of Lisbon, where every moment is a celebration of life, beauty, and the art of living.

Title: Lisbon: How Geography Shapes a Culture
Content:

Traveling abroad can seem daunting, overwhelming, and complex on the surface, with so much to worry about what can go wrong. But traveling embraces our commonality with other people, and traveling can be simple and fun. This publication answers the question of: What can go right?

Member-only story
--
Share
Long before cities like Paris, Munich, and London began to emerge, one Western European city stood above the rest. Known for its culture, elegance, and community, this city was developed on seven hills surrounding the beautiful blue-teal waters of its harbor and beyond. Known for Fado music, melancholic and soulful melodies through song illustrating histories of social marginality and transgression. And known for their Past√©is de Bel√©m, delicious custard tarts in which the original recipe is still a mystery. Combining the benefits of sharing the same climate as San Diego while also remaining as low cost as Midwest America, this complicated, picturesque, and attitude-changing city of Lisbon, Portugal, exemplifies how geography shapes a society. Modern geologists and sociologists have fiery arguments on whether geology shapes society or whether the societies we create affect which type of geology we settle in. And while a combination of both seems to be the truth, Lisbon highlights how not only geography shapes a city but how geological events change the philosophy, community, and culture of a city and its surrounding society.
HOW GEOGRAPHY SHAPES SOCIETY

The last time I was in Europe was in 2019 when I went to Web Summit Lisbon: the world‚Äôs largest tech conference.
I have the chance to be back in Europe this summer, funnily enough, in Lisbon again.
Turns out I really like coming back to places. I‚Äôve got to reflect on the (massive) personality changes I‚Äôve had since 2019‚Ä¶ as well as the things that really haven‚Äôt changed (spoiler: I still get really loud when I am enthusiastic. And I have a very low bar for things that make me enthusiastic‚Ä¶ things within life are just SO worth raving about).
My recollection of Lisbon in 2019 was entirely fantastical. I didn‚Äôt have one bad thing in my memory‚Ä¶ I even forgot about all those stairs. Youthful bliss.
Adulthood comes with new features: some are good (wine at lunch) and some are not so good (an adult culture of complaining). This second time in Lisbon has me reflecting on my sense of adventure and open-mindedness from before. While places do have their downsides, overall, I think the big picture of life is generally quite positive; it‚Äôs something that adults lose track of among the millions of opportunities to be negative.
For example, Lisbon has many (many!) stairs/hills, but it‚Äôs also filled with stunning view points. I could complain about the stairs or I could appreciate the sheer fact that you can see the ocean, castles and millions of portuguese roofs from the centre of Lisbon.
Anyway, this is the start to yet another ramble about how great it is to be an optimist: to see the world for all its amazingness. While this is not a complex sentiment, it can be overruled with our primitive software (i.e., our brains looking out for danger) or the primitive software of other adults looking out for danger.
Let‚Äôs remember that the commodities of the 21st century are things the wealthiest of the 19th century couldn‚Äôt even dream of buying.
I‚Äôve used the phrase zest for life over the last few years to ground my optimism for the world. I‚Äôll attempt to inject this zest within the 5 lessons I learned (or re-learned) after my recent last 9 days in Lisbon.
While I was walking up a huge hill towards Jardim do Torel I noticed a very peaceful grandma sitting on a bench with her feet dangling and her hands doodling. The skies were perfectly blue and she was all cozy on the cobblestone road tilted 45 degrees.
There‚Äôs something so pleasurable about watching someone pursue their life for themselves, despite other expectations or limitations from terrain.
Similarly, my friend Jake writes a great and intense newsletter about golf, and while I am the furthest thing from a golf fanatic, I love reading his newsletter. He is so passionate and unapologetically a golf nerd that it‚Äôs just refreshing. It‚Äôs cementing to see someone else pursue their interests so boldly.
I like spotting the bullet-journaling grandmas and Jakes in the world.
It‚Äôs an art to pay attention and find these gems. But, if you look close enough, you‚Äôll see many happy people and their passions flowing through their veins.
Our brains get easily flagged down by negative, ugly or scary things. I think the world is more kind than it is mean (re: Factfulness) but our minds have a huge distortion to notice the few mean things rather than the many kind ones. But with the art of attention, you can see beyond this distortion.
I‚Äôm a big fan of spotting cute things. Cute puppies in strollers, cute families with grown children‚Ä¶ all wearing matching bucket hats, cute cartoons on fancy menus, cute babies with fat cheeks. It‚Äôs like a renewable resource of serotonin.
I even feel happy running around Lisbon in circles. Recognising spots from last time and places I‚Äôve walked around a bunch this time.
Attentiveness allows me to log a street I‚Äôve walked on such that when I walk on it again, it gives me a dose of familiarity: a very popular neutron-firing-pattern for the human brain.
I try to be attentive to all the Portuguese words, to recognise sounds and phrases, let them become familiar tunes instead of being drowned by the foreignness and communication barriers.
Essentially, there‚Äôs always a positive twist on my surroundings if I‚Äôm attentive enough. I derive a lot of happiness from hunting.
I‚Äôve noticed a lot of people phrase their wishes in the past-tense:
These ‚Äúwishes‚Äù are just regrets rebranded. I think the utility of regret is its ability to learn for or reframe the future. Why not reflect on regrets briefly, and then make wishes for the future?
Have wishes that aren‚Äôt regrets but plausible ideas:
Better yet, make these wishes more specific so that they‚Äôre not just theoretical.
Other than reflection, I see no reason to wish from the past. I see no reason to hold grudges. I‚Äôd like to learn from the past & pay it forward without dwelling.
One of my lowest points during this trip was when I was really tired and made a snap judgement about someone else. It‚Äôs inexcusable and not something I do often (thankfully), but also not something I‚Äôm immune to. It was a low point because I was really disappointed in myself.
I reflected and realised that I have my snap judgments in moments of desperation or insecurity. It‚Äôs not a them problem, it‚Äôs a me problem.
eople live lives with different compasses. They might achieve things in their lives I wish I could emulate or have, but instead of looking within myself for why I don‚Äôt achieve those things, I judge them to compensate for their gains with a loss. Basically, I will lower one element of themselves to feel less jealous.
I think this is a really rotten mentality. Lessening someone else to feel more secure yourself.
I believe I should appreciate subjectivity, i.e., respecting other people‚Äôs lives to co-exist with mine. Realising my beliefs are not objective and binarily correct, enjoying my life but not at the expense of how others want to live theirs and supporting other humans without being too pushy on my agenda.
Part of this journey has been internalizing that every human has something I can learn from. Everyone. They may lead vastly different lives than me but surely I do not have it all figured out.
Philosophically, my higher mind agrees with the notion of subjectivity and respect. But my monkey-mind can uncontrollably judge when it feels in danger.
I‚Äôve been reading Tim Urban‚Äôs book ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs our problem‚Äù and it‚Äôs undoubtedly inspiring these reflections of higher and primitive minds. The architecture of our brain is soooo ancient while the world is sooooo new; having a deep understanding of both is vital to co-existing in them sustainably.
Ancient = hunter-gatherers running from lions. New = can use a device built in 40+ countries to connect to the world wide web to click a button to borrow a bike for 10 minutes. These are very different scenarios!
The monkey inside my brain can mistake good, kind, different people with a lion trying to eat me. It will panic, judge, run, scream and desire a banana for extra running energy. And when it turns out that the person is in fact uninterested in having me for lunch, the monkey will be embarrassed it was wrong so it will use cognitive dissonance to rationalise how the perfectly fine human was actually a lion 10 seconds ago through the magic of animal-morphing technology that obviously the monkey catalyzed to relieve the threat.
I hope that‚Äôs enough of a vivid scenario to illustrate how silly our minds can be. Hence, I am working on a three-pronged approach to combat monkey-mind judgement:
During a conversation at Bahr Bairro Alto with Ula and Jo√£o, we chatted about a random person pursuing a wealthy life in the more ‚Äòtraditional‚Äô route. We‚Äôre a group of people who thrive on the unconventional route, so it was interesting to discuss someone with similar ambition but a different approach.
I just assumed this person was pursuing wall-street‚Ä¶ because that‚Äôs what most people I know who want to make a lot of money do. But then they were both like no: think bigger.
I didn‚Äôt know there was something bigger than wall street? Turns out there‚Äôs a category well beyond wall-street that takes more insider information. Wall Street just has a good brand. Like Gucci (known luxury) vs Zegna (less known, but more luxury) or Rolex (known luxury) vs Patek Philip (less known, but more luxury)‚Ä¶. It‚Äôs a luxury so luxury that it‚Äôs off the market.
I liked learning this a lot since I get such a high off of learning about less-mainstream paths and more rare experiences.
This concept of thinking beyond the ceiling is so appealing. Our conversation added a new anchor within my pursuit for an interesting and status-quo-challenging life.
I have a very Serbian dad which means after his obedient medium-sized dog comes his stick-shift 2010 car with nearly 300,000 km logged. He taught me how to drive a manual car.
However, it turns out that driving on flatland & wide Canadian roads is VERY different from hilly, 1800s cobble-stone, windy, tiny Portuguese roads!
But you know‚Ä¶ I did it and learned a lot.
There were many miracles along the way. Like how our Peugeot managed to go 120 km/h in 5th gear without falling apart, only getting a handful of honks and successfully avoiding all instances of parallel parking (big miracle, you have no idea).
We also had not 1, not 2, not 3 but 4 Portuguese people actively get in the car, demonstrate some of their manual car life lessons & help with hill-starts or parking. 3/4 were complete strangers who stopped everything to get in the driver seat, not kidnap us, and share their wisdom. Their helpfulness was such an asset and is one of the things I‚Äôll really remember about this trip. It‚Äôs an energy I‚Äôd like to share more in life too.
Another thing I‚Äôve noticed in Portugal that parallels my Serbian culture is how much people like to feed each other! Contrast to Asia, portions are VERY generous. It never feels like someone is optimising their margin. While this isn‚Äôt the most business-forward, life-wise, I really enjoy the vibes of the anti-stinginess. Essentially, I don‚Äôt want to make my wealth by selling the least amount of salmon for the highest possible price.
It‚Äôs been a really beautiful time‚Ä¶ and in what feels like another full circle, I‚Äôm off to London, the place I was supposed to go in April 2020‚Ä¶ :)
I‚Äôm grateful for the strings of the world and for your attention‚Ä¶ now go enjoy something around you :)
Isabella Grandic
PS. I have been watching some great optimistic takes on AI. I really liked this video and this one.
--
--
Chems banker, lover of the world, always dreaming up ideas for societal infrastructure!

Title: Book Review: ‚ÄúTwo Nights in Lisbon‚Äù by Chris Pavone
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When Chris Pavone‚Äôs Two Nights in Lisbon was initially published in hardcover last May, there was a great deal of pre-release hype behind it. I got a print galley, a digital galley, and then a finished copy of the novel ‚Äî which all came to me by the publisher without much prompting on my part if I‚Äôm recalling things correctly. Thus, it seemed like the publisher was particularly interested in promoting this one quite heavily from my perspective. But that‚Äôs not all. The book was generously blurbed, and quite gushingly, by several A-list American authors, including John Grisham, Stephen King, and Megan Abbott. Grisham and King, in particular, trumpeted the fact that this was a novel that you couldn‚Äôt put down. Indeed, this is a bit of a page-turner ‚Äî if you don‚Äôt mind thinking about taking a nice hot shower as you read this. The thing with Two Nights in Lisbon is that it is more than just an effective thriller: it has something important to say and the ultimate subject matter of this novel is quite unsavory as it might be topical. I don‚Äôt want to reveal too much for those who have yet to wade into this book, but, suffice to say, I found myself putting it aside at certain moments because the real crime presented within it is so repellant and distasteful, if not violent, that I needed to take a break from the mechanization of this tome‚Äôs harrowing plot.
The novel is about a newlywed couple who are vacationing, sort of, in Lisbon, Portugal. I say sort of because it is also something of a business trip for the groom, John. However, he goes missing one morning and his wife Ariel immediately goes to both the police and the American embassy to get them on the case. Neither, of course, is of very much help to her. Then, she receives a phone call: it turns out that John has been kidnapped and Ariel has 48 hours to pull together three million euros in ransom to have him returned to her alive. Ariel, of course, doesn‚Äôt have that kind of money, but she happens to know people in her social circles who might. That is, of course, if they want to help her out ‚Äî and they might have their reasons for not wanting to. And thus begins a bit of a cat-and-mouse game of double-crosses and requisite plot twists, and, naturally, the CIA winds up getting involved ‚Äî which shouldn‚Äôt be saying too much as this is something mentioned near the beginning of this book.
Does that sound like a good premise for a thriller? It does to me, too. However, Two Nights in Lisbon veers off into unpredictable territory even though you can kind of figure out what‚Äôs likely to happen before it happens. This doesn‚Äôt make the book a less-than-stellar read; quite the contrary. This is a well-done slow burn, and the novel does go into important territory that has been covered by many thrillers being released these days: those that detail violence that is implicit against women. To that end, Pavone does a masterful job of creating a believable female protagonist who is quite vulnerable, but who does her fair share of fighting back against all sorts of injustices that are done to her. That‚Äôs probably the big selling point of this novel and what makes it so immensely readable. Having said that, though, this is also a challenging read because the book‚Äôs subject matter is bound to make readers quite uncomfortable. Thus, Two Nights in Lisbon is not an easy book to take. While it is a relatively quick to flip through even at being more than 400 pages in length (and it is a quick read because of its semi-predictability, which is a pleasure of its own and keeps the narrative moving), it could have been trimmed just a little bit. It feels a little overlong, with an epilogue that feels a bit tacked on to give this book a mercifully happy ending. (Or as happy of an ending as you could expect from a book such as this. This is not to say that I‚Äôm not happy it ends the way it does, but these characters really go through the wringer and there could have been, perhaps, a little less of that in the lead-up to the end.)
In the end, I‚Äôm not sure how far I would go in recommending Two Nights in Lisbon as a must-read novel. It is very well done, but it made me squirm. The writing is top drawer for being genre fiction‚Äî flaws are damned. And the book does have them: you can‚Äôt think of the twists and turns too hard, or the plot kind of comes undone. Without meaning to spoil anything, it turns out that the kidnappers go to an awful lot of trouble just to achieve their ends ‚Äî though, at the same time, they must go to the lengths they go to. (For this reason, I guess I‚Äôm of two minds about this book.) In any event, perfection is always hard to come by, so we should be very satisfied with the care and craft that Pavone has put into this novel about the ugliness of American society and how women tend to get treated within it. Overall, Two Nights in Lisbon is going to appeal to readers who like their thrillers to thrill, but perhaps not too much. Me? I liked this, but didn‚Äôt love it ‚Äî and the reason is that I now feel as though I have to have that hot shower to rinse away the griminess of the major crime that is ultimately revealed here. Two Nights in Lisbon is worth a look, but just be prepared to go against what those A-list writers were raving about. This is a novel you‚Äôll want to put down now and then. You‚Äôll need to just get through the repulsiveness of the female protagonist‚Äôs unfavorable experiences throughout this troubling yet searing work of genre fiction.
Chris Pavone‚Äôs Two Nights in Lisbon was published by Farrar, Straus and Giroux / MCD on May 24, 2022.

Content:

I was traveling in Lisbon. That day, I went to an old restaurant listed in the Lonely Planet guidebook. A guitarist was playing traditional Portuguese music. Tourists from all over the world were drinking wine and talking, their faces bright with laughter. I had a few glasses of wine.
I began to feel the buzz. I grew tired of the place and left.
I kept walking. Not along the routes tourists take, but deeper into the old city. There were no pretty buildings. The walls were faded, and the windows sat still in the dark. The road wasn‚Äôt smooth ‚Äî just an uneven path of small stones and rough cobbles. Every step caught my toes. I kept losing balance.
As night deepened, dim streetlamps flickered on, one by one.
Women stood along the roadside.
Drunk, I approached them. I stopped in front of one captivating woman. I wanted to say something. She didn‚Äôt understand me ‚Äî but she named a price in English. ‚ÄúWant to fuck,‚Äù she said. I couldn‚Äôt understand anything else she said.
I couldn‚Äôt afford the full price. I handed her a bit of money, then turned and walked away.
I approached another woman. Did the same ‚Äî gave her money, then left. I just wanted to talk to someone.
I kept stumbling forward. The streetlamps swayed.
After midnight passed, fog began to settle.At first it hung loose, then thickened. It sank heavy into the pitch-black streets. Every shop was dark, shutters pulled tight. My sight blurred, then slowly vanished. I couldn‚Äôt tell street from wall. I walked with my eyes on the ground.
There was no one around. Once in a while, a car passed. Its headlights flared into the fog ‚Äî then faded without a trace. The dampness clung to my skin. I kept walking, aimless. I didn‚Äôt want to stop.
Around dawn, the fog began to lift.A narrow alley appeared. Beer cans. Torn snack wrappers. Soggy paper cups. Traces of someone who had been there through the night. But no one remained. No women. No cars. No sound. No people‚Ää‚Äî just what was left behind.
I was tired. I headed back to my room.
Morning was coming. The street had changed. Taxis and buses passed in steady rhythm. The green leaves of roadside trees glimmered in the morning sun.
At an Indian restaurant, the shutter rolled up with a loud clatter. Workers carried boxes inside, turned on the lights, and scrubbed the floor. The scent of spices filled the air. Metal pots clanged, hoses sprayed water, voices echoed. Everything was waking up again.
People walked. Shops opened. The day had begun.
And in the middle of it all, with sunken eyes from a night spent in the street, I quietly walked back to my room.
--
--
Every moment in life is part of the journey. I'm still new to writing, but I hope to share something about life through it.

I‚Äôm going to go ahead and assume that 2 Chainz was visiting Lisbon when he made that song. Ok‚Ä¶..maybe that‚Äôs a stretch, but seriously this city is literally vibrating with some of the best energy I‚Äôve EVER been around. And I‚Äôm one of those hippy-dippy, ‚ÄúI need to feel the aura, the mojo, the vibe‚Äù‚Ä¶ whatever you call it, to get a sense of whether I‚Äôll like something. AND THIS PLACE GIVES ME ALLLL THE FEELS.
The best way for me to describe it is to actually borrow from my home office, Havas Chicago. We have 3 major tenants of what it means to be a Chi-town Havaser, they are: All In. Clever. Heart.
You can tell that every single person in the Lisbon Village is beaming with pride for their agency, clients and country. They proudly represent some of the biggest companies in Portugal.. a leading grocery store, a major bank and even the train system. I‚Äôm helping out on NOS, one of the leading telecom accounts in Portugal. About a year ago, NOS came to Havas and said they wanted to completely re-invent the brand. Havas answered in the most ALL IN way ever‚Ä¶‚Ä¶creating Havas Different, a culturally relevant, hyper-village focused model designed to service NOS. The team re-invented the way they work, so that NOS and Havas can fulfill the collective vision and grow together. WOW!
As a strategist, I know that clever insights are both hard to come by, but also imperative to doing good work. My mentor, Joao (The Head of Strategy), and the other strategists in Lisbon have it down pat. The insights they bring to the table are simple, yet poignant and surprising, yet delivered in a way that makes you feel like you knew it all along. For example, when NOS tasked Havas to create a campaign for the Christmas season, the team came to the table with most clever insight around the most prominent fixture of the season, Santa. They asked themselves: if we live in 2018, where technology rules our lives‚Ä¶.why are we still writing letters to Santa? So, they created a campaign all around the idea that Santa MUST have a phone number and NOS was going to bring it to you. Again, WOW! (smart insight jealousy rushes all over).
Upon arrival at the office, I was immediately greeted by Maria Jos√© (a beloved receptionist). She and the others taking a smoke break immediately flashed me smiles, grabbed me for a typical Portuguese double cheek kiss and proceeded to start teaching me Portuguese phrases I needed to know. After that, my mentor Joao took me around the office and introduced me to everyone‚Ä¶.againüëèüèΩ every üëèüèΩsingle üëèüèΩperson got up from their desks, gave me a double cheek kiss and was ready to teach me about their agency and culture. Before the day was up, I was invited to take a walk all around downtown, view the amazing sunset from the River and try a shot of Ginginha, a trademark drink in Portugal. They welcomed possibly the most stereotypical American, midwestern girl with open arms and big smiles. Again, WOW (tear of happiness streams down cheeks).
So, like I said, it‚Äôs truly a vibe here. It‚Äôs hard to put into words. I can‚Äôt even do it justice, but I‚Äôm OBSESSED and I can‚Äôt wait to see where it takes me.

Content:

It‚Äôs a question I‚Äôve been asked countless times since moving to Lisbon from Lagos. Sometimes it‚Äôs asked with genuine curiosity. Other times, it feels more like a challenge ‚Äî a polite way of saying, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt look like you belong here.‚Äù
But the truth is, I‚Äôve been asking myself the same thing, too.
When you leave home ‚Äî really leave it ‚Äî you don‚Äôt just pack a suitcase. You carry your culture, your accent, your rituals, and your invisible expectations. You try to wear them lightly, but they cling to you in moments you least expect, like when no one laughs at your jokes, or when your food smells ‚Äútoo much‚Äù in a shared kitchen.
What I didn‚Äôt expect was that losing my cultural footing in Portugal would help me discover who I am.
Growing up in Lagos, everything felt loud and alive. The streets were full of stories. There was always a neighbor knocking, a generator buzzing, a market woman shouting the price of tomatoes like it was breaking news.
I loved it. And I also wanted out.

I fell in love with Lisbon probably on the day I was born, even though I never got it until I started to travel through the world.
When I started traveling, I began to look at my city with the eyes of a tourist, and that's the best way to find some hidden secrets or to look at places where you normally just pass through without even looking.
I‚Äôll just share with you some 5 places not to miss in Lisbon and help you get as enamored with my city as I am.
Lisbon is such an old city that one of my favorite neighborhoods is older than Portugal, being over 100 years old.
It‚Äôs one of those more typical neighborhoods in Lisbon where you can Fado houses and still see a bit of an old times type of life, with a thigh community in the middle of a big city.
It had become a very touristy place in the last couple of years, but it‚Äôs still possible to get lost and find some old stores, where you can find fun trinkets.
Fado is part of the tradition not only in Lisbon but specifically in this neighborhood, where you can find a ‚ÄúCasa de Fado‚Äù almost in every corner.

Content:

MeetnGreetMe together with our amazing travel blogger would like to share memories and some tips with you in case you have been thinking about visiting Portugal for a long time, or just decided to go there an hour ago! Today we will explore the best of Lisbon, Porto and Sintra. Together with Anastasia.
‚ÄúAt the beginning I will give you some general information about Portugal. Portugal shares borders with Spain and it‚Äôs the most western country in Europe ‚Äî sounds interesting, am I right? If you want to have a condensed view of European landscapes, culture and the way of life, Portugal might be one of the best options for you. I have been there twice and I am sure I will go there again. My both visits were in February (Yes, it sounds cold but believe me, even in February it‚Äôs +18 and sunny‚Ä¶and nothing can spoil your time there).
I have visited only Lisbon and Porto and some small villages nearby (for me it is better to visit fewer cities but to feel them, rather than explore the whole ‚ÄúEurope on two feet a day‚Äù. That is why today I will tell you about these 2 cities.
How to get there?
As it was a planned trip, I booked flight tickets in advance (Warsaw-Lisbon-Warsaw) and it was only 80 euros (which is very cheap I think). From Lisbon to Porto I travelled by bus ‚Äî 4 hours and 20 euros- may be you will find a cheaper way to get there, but I didn‚Äôt have enough time for it and used a simple intercity bus.
Lisbon is the capital and the largest city of Portugal. Lisbon is one of the oldest cities in the world, and the oldest in Western Europe. There are a lot of tourists all year long and you have to be prepared for much attention (especially if you are a woman), tasty food, good wine and hospitality‚Ä¶.let‚Äôs go!
I will tell you about places I have visited and advice YOU to visit!
Rossio Square (Pedro IV Square)
Lisbon‚Äôs most famous square. There‚Äôs no better place in Lisbon to soak up the local atmosphere than at Pedro IV Square. It has been the city‚Äôs main gathering place since the Middle Ages. Today, it‚Äôs the place where friends meet up and as a result it‚Äôs always crowded ‚Äî you will not miss it.
Monument to the Discoveries
It is the mammoth white-stone Monument to the Discoveries. Do you all remember Vasco da Gama- the first European to reach India by sea‚Ä¶.Yes-yes, he was from Portugal. Now you understand why they have this monument and so proud of it. You can ride an elevator to enjoy the view from the top of this Lisbon landmark.
Alfama
The oldest quarter in historic Lisbon, the Alfama district is dotted with architectural landmarks and it‚Äôs the charm of the neighborhood‚Äôs meandering streets, tasty food and wine, clubs with Fado (amazing music) that make the Alfama a can‚Äôt-miss destination.
And one more life-hack ‚Äî Tram line #28
The historic ‚Äútram‚Äù takes you through the city‚Äôs oldest sectors past some of Lisbon‚Äôs most popular sights and attractions. You don‚Äôt have to pay extra money (the ticket costs like a normal one ‚Äî 3 euro).
Belem Tower
Belem Tower, also known as the Tower of St. Vincent, this statue was designed to protect sailors on their voyages, faces the river and makes an incredible impression on you.

If there is one thing we understand, it‚Äôs the importance of your student accommodation towards your general student experience. What‚Äôs more, we know a huge factor is your student home‚Äôs location. You want to live in one of the best neighborhoods, one that‚Äôs just as perfect for you as your residence. If this is you, let us guide you through Lisbon‚Äôs best neighborhoods for students!
Definitely one of the best neighborhoods for students, it‚Äôs very, very popular with international students. Marqu√™s de Pombal is known among the locals as the central business district of the city and also as a major transportation hub. With two metro lines crossing here, and something like 20 different bus lines to catch, you‚Äôre always just a shot away from any place in the city. During the day, catch the sun up in the Eduardo VII gardens and after nightfall head down to the Kiosk-bars of Av. da Liberdade for drinks with your friends. There are many student residences nearby, including several that are Erasmus exclusive. Check out our student accommodation in Marqu√™s de Pombal.
An Erasmus favorite! If you don‚Äôt want to have to go to parties, but prefer the parties to come to you, rent a room in the Bairro Alto. From Thursday to Saturday, the crowds fill up every one of the tiny bars here and spill out onto the streets. Thankfully, it‚Äôs quiet enough during the day, so you can party as much as you want throughout the night and then spend your mornings taking it easy inside. Friendly warning, you guys: Bairro is for party-animals only. Check out our student apartments and studios in Bairro Alto.
The large avenue (Alameda d. Afonso Henriques) that gives this area its name has a very wide garden with plenty of places for taking in Lisbon‚Äôs great weather and a kiosk-bar where you can have one of the coldest ‚Äî and cheapest ‚Äî glasses of beer to cool off. The streets to the sides of Alameda have plenty of student flat shares that are popular with Portuguese students, especially students of Instituto Superior T√©cnico (- called IST, or T√©cnico, for short). Click the link if you want to check out some student shared apartments in Alameda.
The neighbourhoods of S√£o Sebati√£o and Saldanha are between three of the main universities of Lisbon: Universidade Nova de Lisboa (Nova), Universidade Cat√≥lica de Portugal (Cat√≥lica) and T√©cnico. It is not surprising, then, that you will find a student in nearly every building of the area. Some places like Bairro Azul are almost entirely occupied by students. It has great transportation options, the Gulbenkian Foundation with its museum, library and gardens (useful whether you feel like art, a stroll or some study time) and El Corte Ingl√©s, the huge department store that also has over 12 cinema rooms. Click the links if you want to browse for student apartments in Saldanha or to rent student accommodation in S√£o Sebasti√£o.
Alfama is not only the historical quarters of Lisbon, it‚Äôs the city‚Äôs heart and soul. This is a personal favourite of mine ‚Äî the neighbourhood where I have always lived. You‚Äôll find there is nothing more charming than Alfama‚Äôs crazy, maze-like streets, and there is no better way of taking in the city‚Äôs culture than getting lost here. At night, you can hear Lisbon‚Äôs traditional music, Fado, being sung from a hundred little restaurants. Houses and apartments are traditionally rather small and hundreds of years old, but some studios and apartments have been recently refurbished and make the perfect student homes to live in. Interested? Click the link to see student accommodation in Alfama.

Title: How I Launched the Product Management Society in Lisbon: Building a Thriving Community for PMs

As a product manager who has navigated through various roles and experiences, I know how important it is to connect with others in the same field. But what happens when there‚Äôs no ready-made community for product managers in your city? You build one.
That‚Äôs precisely what I did when I launched the Product Management Society in Lisbon. The goal was simple: create a space where product managers could share knowledge, network, and help each other grow. But the impact has been far more significant than I ever anticipated.
The Product Management Society began as a small meetup group. We gathered product managers to discuss challenges, solutions, and industry trends. What I didn‚Äôt expect was how quickly the community would grow. To date, we‚Äôve hosted 50+ events and built a community of 1,100+ members from multiple countries, all passionate about product management.
Our community is more than just a group of people ‚Äî it‚Äôs a vibrant network of professionals supporting each other‚Äôs career growth. We connect through our Slack group, where discussions around best practices, job opportunities, and product management challenges take place. We also have a WhatsApp group (invite-only), providing a more immediate and casual way for members to stay in touch, share opportunities, and engage in real-time conversations.
We host regular events on Meetup, from casual networking to in-depth workshops and talks by seasoned professionals.
At the heart of our society is the belief that product management is better when we learn together. From our events and workshops to our blog, we are committed to delivering valuable content and experiences for PMs at every stage of their careers.
Some of the highlights include:
We‚Äôre not just about talk ‚Äî we‚Äôre about action. The Product Management Society has already made valuable connections with companies and other organizations. One of the major highlights was our hiring event with Altar.io, which allowed our members to connect directly with a top product-focused company and potentially land roles in their teams.
We‚Äôve also collaborated with Productized for multiple events, including where our members had the chance to meet industry leaders, expand their networks, and gain insights into the latest product management trends. Additionally, we partnered with Product Weekend for another collaboration that helped our members further their careers and expand their skills.
Furthermore, we have an ongoing collaboration with Radhika Dutt, the author of Radically Rethinking OKRs, as she works on her new book. This collaboration brings exclusive insights into how product managers can rethink their approach to goal-setting and OKRs, providing even more value to our members.
These collaborations are a testament to the growing influence of our society and the opportunities we can provide for product managers looking to advance in their careers.
If you‚Äôre a product manager based in Lisbon ‚Äî or anywhere else in the world ‚Äî we invite you to join us. The Product Management Society isn‚Äôt just about attending events, it‚Äôs about building relationships and fostering a sense of community. By joining our Slack group, you can start contributing to discussions and sharing your experiences. You‚Äôll also find job postings, helpful resources, and answers to your burning questions. Our WhatsApp group (invite-only) takes the conversation to the next level, offering a more immediate space for feedback and quick interactions with fellow PMs.
Our Meetup page is regularly updated with upcoming events, where you can sign up to attend. Whether you‚Äôre looking to connect with peers, gain new insights, or find your next opportunity, there‚Äôs something for everyone.
The Product Management Society also runs a blog where members share their thoughts on the latest trends, challenges, and innovations in the field. Whether you‚Äôre a senior PM or just starting out, you‚Äôll find valuable insights that can help shape your career and approach to product management.
You can check out the blog at blog.productmanagementsociety.com, where we post articles covering everything from product strategy to career advice. Our goal is to make this an ever-growing resource that PMs can turn to for practical advice and thought leadership.
Whether you‚Äôre looking to network, learn, or grow your career, joining the Product Management Society is an opportunity you don‚Äôt want to miss. We‚Äôve created a space that fosters growth, collaboration, and professional development.
The Product Management Society has proven time and again to be a valuable resource for product managers. From hosting multiple events to building a community that supports one another, we‚Äôve created something truly special in Lisbon ‚Äî and we want you to be part of it.
So, come join us! Sign up for our events, join our Slack and WhatsApp groups, and start connecting with other like-minded professionals. Whether you‚Äôre looking to gain new insights, find your next job, or simply connect with others in the industry, we‚Äôve got you covered.
Also, don‚Äôt forget to follow us on our LinkedIn page for updates and more!
Together, we can make the Product Management Society a place where we all grow, learn, and thrive!
