Title: Lisbon ‚Äî Day Two
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Going down for breakfast we were able to get what looked to be the last two free seats in the restaurant. I‚Äôm looking down the room thinking it is rammed and being surprised as it wouldn‚Äôt appear the hotel is that big. But there is a mirror across the back of the room, so it looks twice the size with twice the people in it, and it was only my third wander around the room before I nearly walked into myself coming the other way and realised what was going on. (Have I said I‚Äôm not a morning person?)
I suppose it could be said I‚Äôm the weather jinx. The previous afternoon had been warm, so this morning I leave the hotel in shorts, t-shirt, and wearing sunglasses. So of course by the time we got on the first of the tour buses it was overcast and threatening to rain. If I said it was a little changeable during the day it might just about cover the number of times we changed seats, got undercover, back into the open, back undercover, in the open, downstairs, upstairs, downstairs, on and off.
When the sun did break through it was lovely and warm, but on the second of the three bus tour routes the spit spots turned into a torrential downpour, which coincided with exactly where we had planned to get off the bus and explore on foot.
As with many larger cities there are more than one route of HOHO buses in Lisbon. There are lots of places of interest to see, but they are spread out over a wide area, putting them all on one route would mean an exceedingly long bus tour.
We had decided on the blue route first which was more to the east and north of the city. Besides the grand municipal buildings and old churches it is interesting as to what catches the eye when on the tours. Such as the sex shop in a building with an Art Deco female fresco on the wall.
Or the Lisbon Business Centre being in a low rent run down block with ideas above its station.
The name of an ice cream store.
Or even the former gas storage frames.
The route goes through the part of the city which had regeneration for when Lisbon hosted Expo 1998. And there are some very interesting structures to see.
There is always too much to try and take in and with the speed of travel, or the angle you are at on the bus means that I spend a lot of time when back at home wondering what the hell I was trying to take a photo of.
What is not in any doubt is just how steeply undulating the city is. There are a lot of roads the buses go up which I‚Äôd not want to attempt driving a car, especially the angle of some of the red light induced hill starts which would be needed.
After a lap of the blue route, we change to the red route, getting part of the way around before the rain forced us downstairs for cover, fortunately picking seats which weren‚Äôt still getting leaked on down there. The viewpoint behind raindrop splattered windows is totally different and the opportunity to take photographs is limited. To zero.
We got off where we had planned to at the Jeronimos Monastery, supposedly where the first Pastel de Natas were ever made. It is in a traffic free zone (apart from the tour buses), and it is surrounded by museums. (And parts of the monastery buildings have been converted into museums.)
It is properly tipping it down and so we head into a packed Maritime Museum caf√© for lunch. There are map related items to buy in the gift shop, without having to go into the museum, so always good. And whilst we had been lunching the rain had stopped and the sun was trying to escape the cloud cover.
Only for the rain to come back the moment we step outside. But we are used to rain, and we carry on and have a mooch about, through gardens, under the road and railway and to the riverbank and the immense Monument to the Discoveries on it.
In front of it in the square is a map of the world and on it are places highlighted with dates of when the Portuguese empire arrived there during the late fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries following the footsteps of its famed explorers Vasco de Gama and Ferdinand Magellan.
We are heading back under the road and rail when Helen feels someone close up behind her. There is a woman pawing at her backpack and saying, ‚Äòsorry it was open.‚Äô It most definitely wasn‚Äôt the woman was blatantly trying to rob Helen. Fortunately, the front pocket was only full of tissues, and her phone and purse were at the bottom of the main compartment buried under lots of other stuff like a jumper and scarf. But whilst checking there was nothing missing the woman and her sidekick had scuttled off as fast as they could and were nowhere to be seen when we were back up at street level. The would-be thief may have got fuck all, but it did shake Helen up and meant she was reluctant to use the backpack as a backpack for the rest of the day and was ultra wary about anyone being close behind her at all.
It began to brighten as we continued to wander around Belem, but we didn‚Äôt stop and pick the bus back up at the same point, instead we ended up walking back towards the large suspension bridge.
This meant a detour over a footbridge spanning the road and railway and out onto the roof of one of the MAAT buildings, giving a good view of the other older one.
And of the suspension bridge, built to look like the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco, it is painted in the same plum colour paint (which is the best colour to be seen in the fog), but is a bit shorter.
Behind it on the hill on the south of the river is the statue Christ the King, like a smaller version of Christ the Redeemer in Rio, more like Christ the Reduced. They do like a copy.
The bridge is called the April 25th Bridge, a nod to the 1974 revolution. It had been shrouded in mist when we had come past it on the bus earlier.
We walked back to under the bridge before reacquainting ourselves with the HOHO bus tours, retracing part of the route we had done before (downstairs in the dry at the time), and past the Belem tower.
Another shower forced us back undercover, and moving back out from the cover just happened to coincide with passing the Basilica, one of the more spectacular churches of the city, and I missed the chance to get a photo of it completely.
Before the loop was complete, we jumped off to change to the green route for a couple of stops to get us up the steep narrow winding streets to the castle. It is easy to see why this route uses a minibus. The route certainly makes me want to reiterate my reluctance to ever want to drive on these streets in a car.
The plan is to get to the castle so that we can catch the 5pm walking tour included with the HOHO tickets. Which we just about manage.
The tour guide in Guilherme, and he is from Brazil, and is doing the tour in English and Spanish, which just blows my mind as I can only just about manage the one language, and even that needs to be carried around in a bucket most of the time.
From the high point next to the castle entrance we have a slow meander down to the river stopping at key points to have things pointed out and for little pieces of the history of the city imparted to us.
One is at the statue of St Vincent (patron saint of the city),
And the viewpoint down from the plaza there, over the terracotta roofs to the river, and across to the church of St Vincent on another hill,
And the dome of the National Pantheon housed in a former church.
We pass a tree which looks like it roots have escaped from the soil and are on an acid trip induced adventure.
There is a quick poke inside the cathedral (which we are likely to return to later in the week).
And then it is down to the river side, stopping at the spiky house.
And finally into the Commerce Square in front of the grand arch, which we had passed through on our little stroll the evening before.
It was a good tour, lasting a lot longer than the advertised hour, and there was even a recommendation of a post tour restaurant for dinner. Which had massive portions of lovely food at reasonable prices. Such sized portions it was probably a good idea there was a walk back up to the hotel involved afterwards.
Those twelve hours had flown by. Time for rest and to get ready to do it all again tomorrow. More buses and a boat tour to come.

Title: A Rainy (but Wonderful Weekend) in Lisbon: Pastries, Proposals & One Very Soggy Pair of Trainers
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
There are few things more iconic than leaving rainy London in search of sunnier skies ‚Äî only to land in Portugal to find‚Ä¶ more rain.
Welcome to Lisbon, land of seven hills, centuries of charm, and one of the soggiest weekends I‚Äôve ever had. And somehow, it was still magical.
We arrived bright-eyed, hopeful, and wildly underdressed. The UK, of course, had decided to be 22¬∞C and sunny that weekend, while Lisbon greeted us with a torrential downpour.
After squelching to our hotel, Portobay Liberdade, we regrouped and, now lightly towel-dried, swam our way to a nearby Italian spot (Il Basilico, I think?) for a bite. My travel companion‚Äôs trainers were instantly soaked, turning a casual stroll into a mission: Operation Waterproof Shoe Hunt.
Easier said than done. Lisbon‚Äôs got many things ‚Äî views, wine, vintage tiles, but trainers shops? Not in a monsoon.
That first day? Honestly, a washout. But then, we stumbled into dinner. And let me tell you, it was a revelation.
After drying off from our soggy adventures, we chose to dine in our hotel that night at Bistro 6, and it was one of the most fantastic choices we made. The duck was remarkable: Crispy on the outside, tender and rich on the inside, with a wonderful depth of flavour present in every bite. It was so good that even in a city as full of culinary gems as Lisbon, we couldn‚Äôt resist going back for round two. I‚Äôm pretty sure I‚Äôll be daydreaming about that plate for years to come.
By morning, we gave in to our fate. Lisbon was going to soak us, and we were going to like it. Jackets on, umbrellas up (luckily supplied by the hotel), optimism renewed.
First stop: the Mercado da Ribeira (aka Time Out Market Lisbon). Our first-ever Time Out Market and it set the bar high. It wasn‚Äôt your typical chaotic food court, instead, it felt like a well-curated space with an incredible variety of options. From fresh seafood and gourmet croquettes to decadent handmade chocolates, there was something for every craving. The place was organised yet vibrant, buzzing with energy.
If you‚Äôre new in town, it‚Äôs the perfect place to meet people: everyone sits together, it‚Äôs lively, communal, and thriving.
We grabbed a doughnut (incredible!!), a couple of coffees, then wandered through the traditional market tucked behind the main hall. Fishmongers shouting, locals shopping, fruit stacked high, there was a real sense of the city coming to life. We were completely captivated.
Next, we set off to see Lisbon Cathedral (S√©) and try our luck with Tram 28, Lisbon‚Äôs charmingly vintage and famously packed transit option. While we waited in the drizzle, we were approached by a charismatic Parisian tour guide, offering a covered tuk-tuk ride through the city.
Usually, we‚Äôd run from that kind of pitch, but he had a roof, plastic sides, and an irresistible charm. Reader, we climbed aboard.Best decision of the trip.
He took us through the seven hills of Lisbon, shared history with passion, pointed out hidden spots we‚Äôd never have found on our own, and gave us time to really enjoy the views, not just tick them off a list.
Oh, and at our very first miradouro (viewpoint), someone proposed right next to us. Cue tears. Lisbon, suddenly, wasn‚Äôt just rainy ‚Äî it was romantic.
We ended the day at Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio, where the weather finally gave us a break. Picture this: three grand golden-yellow fa√ßades on three sides‚Ä¶and then, nothing. Just open sky and the wide, rolling Tagus River, looking more like a calm ocean than a river. It was one of the most unexpectedly stunning squares I‚Äôve ever stood in.
With a glass of wine in hand and the wind finally drying our coats, we toasted to Lisbon‚Äôs stubborn beauty.
Sunday morning brought us to Bel√©m ‚Äî land of custard tarts and monumental queues. Our attempt to visit Jer√≥nimos Monastery failed (read: misunderstood the queue and were politely turned away), but fate had better plans: we headed early to Past√©is de Bel√©m instead.And thank everything holy we did.
This place is a Lisbon legend. From the outside, it looks like a pleasant caf√©. But inside? It‚Äôs a labyrinth of awning-covered rooms, waiters by the dozen, and pastries by the thousands. Somehow, we snagged a table.
Between the two of us, we ordered at least six pastries ‚Äî custards, almond cakes, an orange thing I can‚Äôt explain ‚Äî and two coffees. The bill? ‚Ç¨10 total. I don‚Äôt know how. I don‚Äôt care. I would‚Äôve paid triple.
We even brought some back to the UK with us. That‚Äôs how good they were.
We wandered through Alfama and Old Town Lisbon on our last day, taking in the steep streets, the tiled walls, the laundry flapping above us. If I can give you one travel tip for Lisbon, it‚Äôs this:
Do not come with a new hip. Or bad knees. Or any aversion to steep climbs.Lisbon is beautifully vertical. Like, mountain goat vertical. My poor mum (fresh from hip surgery) was a trooper, but fair warning: this city is cardio with a capital C.
So, was it the sun-soaked European weekend I imagined? No.Was it a glorious, rain-drenched, pastry-fueled, unexpectedly beguiling adventure? Absolutely.
Lisbon is a city that sneaks up on you. It‚Äôs tiled facades and rooftop views, ghost stories in ancient cathedrals, and secret tarts tucked in glass counters. It‚Äôs fascinating markets and quiet moments, and unexpected friendships with French tuk-tuk drivers.
It‚Äôs a city I‚Äôll absolutely come back to, preferably with better footwear, a lighter raincoat, and the same appetite for surprises.
--
--
I love reading fiction, writing when the mood strikes, and pottering outside when the sun comes out. Love art, travel, and catching a West End show when I can.

Title: A Meaningful Run ‚Äî How the Lisbon Marathon Made a Difference
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
With the sun beating down on me and a temperature of over 28¬∞C, I see a fellow runner lying on the curb being attended to by first responders. I check my watch and decide to stop once again at the next water station. This is going to be much tougher than I expected‚Ä¶
My journey to the 2017 Lisbon Marathon started in the winter of 2015. I was busy assembling IKEA furniture when I was struck by a burning pain in my knee that refused to go away. For the next few days it continued to get worse and every small stair suddenly became a major challenge. Finally, I decided to see an orthopedist. I never really liked (or had much reason) to see a doctor, but I had just turned 45, my girlfriend Anna was pregnant with our daughter and I figured getting it checked out would be the responsible thing to do.
The visit ended with a referral for an MRI that led to a nasty surprise. The cartilage in my knees was considerably damaged. These injuries had been looming for some time as I continued to ignore the warning signs. The diagnosis was clear. I would now be required to get a sodium hyaluronate injection directly into my knee joints every 6 months just to ease the pain. An injection with a price tag of $750 that isn‚Äôt covered by any health insurance. To add insult to injury, the doctor casually said, ‚ÄúLook, you may be able to go for a 5-kilometer jog, and you should do that regularly, but nothing longer. Take it easy, you will never be able to run a marathon, so don‚Äôt bother trying.‚Äù These comments resonated in me for a long time. I never even considered running a marathon ‚Äî until this very moment.
I have always seen myself as a member of the running community, but frankly, my laps through the park had become less frequent over the years. There was the occasional spring onset of daily runs that lasted for about a month, but they were never farther than 5 to 10k. The longest distance I had ever run was a 25k race but that was only once and it was over 20 years ago. So, I could have been content with injections twice a year and back to a rather normal life. Only that I wasn‚Äôt.
The most urgent issue I wanted to focus on was the pain. I started reading a lot about treatment options and I decided to try something other than getting needles jammed into my knees. After a bit of experimentation, I found that taking a high dose daily (2000 mg) of glucosamine sulphate was starting to help me. Later, I added omega 3 and collagen to the mix. After a couple of weeks the burning sensation went away. I had indeed found an alternative for my battered knees.
Please bear with me, in one of my former lives I was also a lawyer: This is what worked for me, but no medical advice whatsoever is intended.
The following year I wasn‚Äôt really prioritizing my running career. Throughout all of 2016, I covered a total distance of less than 60 km in twelve runs. Yes, I had a lot of other things on my plate, with a newborn baby, being CEO of Berlin‚Äôs Innovation Agency and everything else. At least I was sticking to the doctor‚Äôs advice when it came to the part of ‚Äútaking things easy‚Äù with my knees. But I had a growing sense that I was missing something. I was somehow able to manage getting everything done ‚Äî but I was also realizing that I was losing my edge.
New Year‚Äôs Eve is always a great time for resolutions. In the years past, I must admit (and you can probably relate), these intentions were rather short-lived. But this time I was hell-bent to make a change for real. So I came up with something that seemed utterly beyond reach: For 2017 I resolved to run a marathon. And to make things more interesting, I didn‚Äôt even consider the Berlin Marathon in my hometown. I was looking for a venue with added value. I soon found Lisbon, the Portuguese capital, located at the River Tagus and the Atlantic Ocean, one of the most fascinating cities in Europe. With the race scheduled for October 15th, this would leave me enough time to find out if my knees would keep up with my ambitions.
The first thing I did was to read about marathon training. There are many manuals and programs out there. The takeaway lesson was: Run frequently, consistently including workouts for speed, stamina, and mobility and run a reasonable number of longer runs that should include a 30+ km run in the weeks before the event. This means you must spend a lot of time and you must spend it regularly. Marathon training is an exercise in discipline and commitment, that much I realized. Wait, I only had time for two handfuls of recreational runs in 2016 and (what I thought to be) insufficient sleep due to our baby‚Äôs somewhat erratic sleep patterns, a demanding job and, last but not least, a relationship to cherish. Sounds like something straight from the playbook of Mission Impossible, doesn‚Äôt it?
Nevertheless, I came up with a plan. I set 2 milestones that would serve as my intermediate goals: The 10k City Night race in Berlin on July 29th along the famous Kurf√ºrstendamm Boulevard and the Stadtlauf Berlin half marathon on August 20th. If I could complete both within a reasonable time and my knees would be functional afterwards I would book the flights to Lisbon. After registering for both races, I started running 5 kilometers on January 3rd along the icy shores of Schlachtensee Lake, which would become my favorite route for the next couple of months.
With the marathon still in the ‚Äúdistant‚Äù future, the winter runs that followed were a bit sporadic. Eventually I had to figure out how to fit my training into my daily routine and the only solution I came up with was to get up early. And I mean really early, at 4:30 am.
There has been a lot written about the benefits of starting your day off early and I must say, it‚Äôs totally true! Starting your work day after you have spent some time working out is great. Having a daily sense of achievement after logging 10 or 20 km before you start breakfast is truly awesome. Having the chance to focus on your thoughts while enjoying the sunrise is priceless. So, over the next few months, I was running regularly and enjoying the slow and steady progress I was making.
Both tests I recklessly scheduled quite close to the big day went well, so I booked the flights and a very nice apartment in Lisbon‚Äôs historic Alfama district. Finally, it was going to happen. I would run at the Lisbon Marathon!
In the final week before the race one issue became increasingly pressing ‚Äî the weather forecast. When I had the idea of flying to Portugal for my first ever marathon, I of course checked the weather information. On average you can expect 20¬∞C in the middle of October. But not this year, the forecast was 31¬∞C with clear skies. The 2006 Chicago Marathon had to be shut down with the mercury at 28¬∞C but I expected that in sunny Portugal this wouldn‚Äôt even be considered. So, I frantically worked on adapting my gear. It is a good thing that you reduce your training miles leading up to the race (a.k.a. tapering), so you can take care of these kinds of things.
However, speaking of reduced miles, another question started nagging me. Did I train enough? Even though I ran nearly every day in the weeks prior to Lisbon, I never ran a distance longer than 25 km. But on the other hand, 15 km was one of my regular morning runs, so the additional stretch should be manageable, right? Since there was no chance I could redo my training plan in the next few days, I decided to relax. The race day would prove if my reasoning was right.
I arrived Thursday evening in Lisbon to acclimate myself and focus on the challenge ahead. It was a luxury to have time to think and I enjoyed doing so at the marathon‚Äôs designated finish at Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio. Here, you have a wonderful view over River Tagus‚Äô final passage before joining the Atlantic Ocean. It became my ‚Äúvision quest‚Äù as my girlfriend Anna would call it. She has always been supportive of my aspirations. Although we originally planned to make the trip to Lisbon together, Anna decided to stay at home with our young daughter and this gave me the gift of time alone. I used it well and came up with a list of goals and dreams for my future.
Finally, the day of the race dawned and I was sitting on the train from Lisbon to Cascais jammed with marathoners in various degrees of contemplation. Some were sitting on the floor with an empty look on their face, others were chatting happily away with their running buddies or texting home. I was silently rehearsing my game plan: Stick to the well-trained pace of 5:30, don‚Äôt get carried away by competing with other runners in the first 20 or so km, pick up the pace at 30 km aiming at a negative split, finish sub 4:00 hours.
And I stuck to the plan, at least for the first 20 km. After crossing the starting line in a wave of euphoria I was soon running steadily. I found the waving flag of the 4 hour pacemaker I was going to follow until the half marathon mark and the first misting station was in sight.
Then something unexpected happened. The heart rate display on my watch jumped to an unreal 202 bpm and I forced myself to slow down. Around 175 bpm would have been the ‚Äúnormal‚Äù maximum for a person of my age. Today, looking back at the data, I‚Äôm sure that this reading was erroneous because I have never again gone over a 170 bpm. At the time, I only had the information on my display and it had a tremendous impact. I suddenly realized that I still had another half marathon to go and the sun was beating down mercilessly even though it wasn‚Äôt even 10 a.m. yet. I checked my knees for any signs of pain or weakness. Had I overestimated myself? How could I have believed that with only months of training I would be able to pull this off? I already envisioned myself collapsing at the roundabout near the beach of Carcavelos.
This was the point where I was (to be honest for the first time really) awestruck by the magnitude of the marathon as a test of body and mind. I considered my options. I could stop now and justify it with the parching heat and my staggering heart rate. But in the end, I decided to follow through, no matter what. My goal had changed. Certainly, I still wanted to finish with a time that would be to the best of my abilities, but I mainly focused on not being defeated. I would slow down, I would drink whenever possible, I would even walk any uphill stretches of the course. The reason I started this endeavor in the first place was to prove to myself that it was still possible to accomplish something really demanding and to push my limits. This would become my mantra for the next kilometers to come.
And those kilometers weren‚Äôt easy. In fact, I never experience the famous ‚Äúrunner‚Äôs high‚Äù, at least not while I was running. The last 10 km became an uncomfortable rhythm of moving along an agonizing 2.5 km stretch only to reach the next water station, drinking and cooling myself, and starting all over again, but it worked. After I had passed the 40 km mark the number of cheering spectators increased significantly. That gave me the final boost to give the backup goal I cooked up with while poking along the torrid Avenida Marginal a try: Finishing at 4:30.
With a final sprint I reached the finish line at 4:30:54!
After hitting the stop button on my sports watch I felt exhausted but otherwise amazingly good. No cramps, no sore muscles even in the days following the race. Interestingly enough, the knees that brought me there also carried me throughout the whole distance without any problems. So, on a physiological level, it is safe to say that the stress I put on my body was easily absorbed.
The marathon had both a short and long term impact on my psychology as well. It all started with the continuous effort I put into my training despite all the seemingly ‚Äúgood‚Äù reasons why there wasn‚Äôt enough time. Once I made up my mind and committed myself to the marathon, I magically found ways to make it happen. I was able to build up my knees by training and through supplements with no side effects based on the research I did. I was able to regain my confidence and mental strength on a very fundamental level. And I was able to apply all of this to master the challenge the Lisbon Marathon turned out to be.
After I had taken a cold shower in my apartment and devoured a carb-laden lunch, I immediately went back onto the streets of Lisbon for a walk. I noticed a shift in my perspective that is still present today. A lot of things suddenly felt shallow and dispensable, others became much more significant, like sharpening the focus of my mental map. And I started working towards reaching some of the most important goals that I had identified just days before.
So, it once again proves to be true: Every cloud has a silver lining. When I got the news of my supposedly ruined knees, it seemed to be the end of my running days. But instead, this was just the beginning! It has forced me to make decisions about how I want to live my life. I opted for the challenges and that has allowed me to grow beyond my athletic ambitions. You gain nothing by accepting your fate, you must keep on fighting if you want to win.
--
--
Developer and Lawyer by training. CEO of Technology Foundation Berlin. Proud Dad.

Title: I Went to Lisbon and Was SHOCKED!
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When I was first thinking about moving to Germany, the appeal was pretty clear: Germany is an economic powerhouse, one of the strongest economies in the world. I thought to myself, ‚ÄúOkay, if I move there, I‚Äôm making a smart decision for my career.‚Äù And even though Berlin wasn‚Äôt exactly my first choice, I figured it would work as a starting point.
Fast forward six years, and I‚Äôm feeling stuck both personally and professionally and I‚Äôm starting to question the environment I‚Äôm in.
Feeling stuck? I wrote about why settling in one place can actually be dangerous for your growth. If you‚Äôre curious, check it out here: Why Settling in One Place Can Be Dangerous for Your Growth.
But, let‚Äôs get to the real reason I‚Äôm writing this post: Lisbon.
I recently visited Lisbon for the first time, and let me tell you, I was shocked in the best way possible, I was still taken aback by how much I loved it.
The streets were clean, the infrastructure was solid, and public transportation actually worked well enough to make getting around a breeze. But what really stood out to me was the overall vibe of the city. It just felt‚Ä¶ ordered.
There was this balance of modernity and tradition, Lisbon had this richness that Berlin doesn‚Äôt always capture, at least not in the same way. It‚Äôs not just in the food and the gorgeous architecture, but in the way the city feels. The people were welcoming, the atmosphere felt peaceful and grounded ‚Äî everything just felt a little‚Ä¶ livable.
The streets didn‚Äôt feel unsafe or disorderly, and I didn‚Äôt have to dodge random bottles or step over anything unpleasant. It felt clean‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand not just physically, but in terms of its overall atmosphere. Lisbon felt way more laid-back and balanced‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa place where I could actually imagine calling home.
On my way back to Berlin I find myself wondering‚Ä¶ could Lisbon be the place for me? Maybe it‚Äôs time to seriously think about it. But ‚Ä¶ As much as I‚Äôve dreamt about moving to Lisbon, my hopes have taken a bit of a hit.
Lisbon used to have a reputation for being more affordable than other European capitals, but the reality is, rent prices have been climbing steadily ‚Äî especially in the trendy neighborhoods ‚Äî bringing them in line with cities like Berlin!
On top of that, salaries in Lisbon are still pretty low compared to other European cities, so the cost of living isn‚Äôt as balanced as I once thought. It‚Äôs a bummer, but looks like my dream of settling in Lisbon it didn‚Äôt last too long!
So here I am again, chasing the original plan moving to Munich. Although is one of the most expensive places to live in Germany, at least the salaries are around 30% higher than what I‚Äôve been offered in Berlin!
But even with the potential for a bigger paycheck, I can‚Äôt shake the feeling that I‚Äôm just stuck in this loop of chasing after cities that are becoming increasingly expensive while the job market still feels a bit of a mirage!
The whole ‚ÄúGermany has tons of job opportunities‚Äù narrative is, well, not exactly the truth. Anyone who‚Äôs actually lives here knows how tough it can be to land a job, even if you speak German at a C2 level. The competition is fierce, and sometimes it feels like it doesn‚Äôt matter how qualified you are.
Sure, the western and the southern part of Germany is still financially doing well, but if the job hunt keeps feeling this grim, it might just be time to explore other options. It‚Äôs a tough decision, but I‚Äôm honestly getting a little tired of hitting dead ends. I‚Äôm even starting to entertain the idea of leaving the country altogether.
Sadly, Lisbon will remain in my heart as a city that surprised me and gave me some amazing daydreams of a life where I could see smiles around and feel a sense of calm in the everyday. It‚Äôs the kind of place that makes you think, ‚ÄúThis could be home,‚Äù but sometimes, reality just doesn‚Äôt align with those dreams.
I‚Äôm thinking about where to go next. I‚Äôve got some exciting options on my mind, if you‚Äôre curious, check it out here: I‚Äôm Leaving Berlin. Let me know your thoughts!
--
--
Fluent in sarcasm, not in German. Came for the vibes, stayed for the existential paperwork. Life as an immigrant in Germany.

Title: Lisbon
[Coworker] Meet Shannon Graybill, Lisbon city driver at Le Wagon coding school
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

The Coworking magazine by Coworkies. We highlights portraits of extraordinary people who entered the coworking world as owners, managers or members.

--
Listen
Share
Shannon is behind one of Lisbon‚Äôs coolest coding school: Le Wagon. We met at Beta-i and got curious to know more about her story and how you start such a project from scratch without being from the city yourself. Time for some questions!
I moved here four years ago to be with my boyfriend who is from Lisbon. I never imagined at that time that I would still be here four years on, but the city has been changing (for the good) at such an alarming rate in the last few years that I feel like I moved somewhere new.
Rather than why I came to live here, the better question is why I stayed. And to answer that, you can read a blog post I published a few weeks ago on Le Wagon ‚Äî Why would you relocate to Lisbon?
www.lewagon.com
Le Wagon is a code school for non-technical entrepreneurs and creatives. We give people the programming and product development mindset through teaching ruby on rails web development.
My motivation to launch Le Wagon started two years ago while I was working in a local accelerator/ incubator here in Lisbon. I saw a lack of technical talent amongst the founders and also felt that I could benefit myself from understanding on a basic level what is going on behind the scenes of software.
Now, after having gone through the program myself and already running three 9 week batches in Lisbon, I can say I know that and a whole lot more, plus have 60+ Lisbon alumni as a support when it comes to launching my own products and finding cool jobs in the tech market.
Growing very quickly with a very diverse mix of internationals and locals.
We really wanted to be immersed in Lisbon‚Äôs startup ecosystem and Beta-i was a great way to access this community.
We could do a better job of this to be honest. At the moment, we are cross promoting events and of course enjoying some impromptu beers on the roof :)
Learning how to learn (again) ‚Äî their EGOS! As humans, we are conditioned to shy away from challenge. We want all the glory with all the ease. We tend to work in areas and take on tasks that make us feel good. The first three weeks of Le Wagon are an ice cold shower for those that are not accustomed to just not getting something in the beginning. You really have to have faith in yourself and our curriculum when you start the program. The concepts are abstract for most people and they need to time sink in. Le Wagon is like learning to ride a bike. You have to be willing to keep getting on the bike and falling off and trust that eventually if you do that enough times, it will click and you‚Äôll start riding.
To keep the students believing in themselves and their ability. To keep ‚Äúfalling off the bike‚Äù.
In our first batch, we had a student that really struggled. And when I say struggled, there were days he didn‚Äôt finish a challenge. But the guy had a great attitude. He didn‚Äôt give up. He didn‚Äôt compare himself to his classmates. He just kept going. After the bootcamp, he was one of the first to get a job and not even in ruby ‚Äî in Javascript on the backend! He is our mascot here in Lisbon on what it means to give it your all.
Our community is growing locally. We expect in the next year to have our own space with our own cowering for our alumni and ruby on rails developers.
Thanks Shannon for your time and insights!

Content:

By Casey Paxton
Here at Salsify, we can‚Äôt stop talking about our brand spankin‚Äô new office and team in Lisbon, Portugal! We do love Boston, but nothing can top the beautiful sunny weather and gorgeous beaches of Lisbon. I recently got the chance to sit down with our People Operations Specialist in Portugal, Marta Carvalho, to get her take on Lisbon, Boston, and all things Salsify!
Q: So, what exactly does a People Operations Specialist do?
A: As a part of the People Ops team, it‚Äôs my responsibility to promote employee engagement and brand awareness, onboard new hires, support HR processes, team building, and a lot of other fun stuff! Since we are just getting started in Lisbon, my current work is very focused on building and growing the Lisbon team, and ramping up the Salsify employment brand in Lisbon.
Q: How long have you been working for Salsify?
A: A little over one month.
Q: How did you find out about Salsify?
A: I heard about Salsify coming to Lisbon through networking in the Lisbon tech community.
Q: What made you want to work for Salsify?
A: The opportunity to do what I really love in a company with great culture and values. It‚Äôs great to be part of this project since the beginning. Plus, I have the opportunity to be a pioneering person in HR and to think, implement, and see through the best policies and procedures!
Q: What is it like working for Salsify versus working for a Portuguese company?
A: For me, the possibility of traveling and working in collaboration with Boston colleagues on a daily basis is something that I really love. Plus, Portuguese companies tend to have long and inconclusive personal meetings! I‚Äôve been struggling a lot with this in my last years :) I‚Äôm delighted that things at Salsify are done promptly, on time, and focus on specific goals. I feel that people here are very productive and efficient.
Q: What is the biggest cultural difference that you‚Äôve encountered between Portugal and the United States?
A: Well . . . you all seem to have lunch and dinner pretty early :) I‚Äôm used to having dinner by 9 pm for instance while in Boston, it was super common to have dinner by 6 pm. It feels like days and nights in Portugal take longer.
Q: What has been your favorite and least favorite thing about working for Salsify so far?
A: Favorite thing is probably the possibility to work with such a great and friendly team. Least favorite thing is the current temporary office, which is about to change when we move to a new office full of windows and sunshine!
(We actually just moved to our new office! Check it out here.)
Q: Are you someone who can listen to music while you work?
A: Only during some tasks. If I‚Äôm doing some sourcing or replying to some emails, then yes. If I need to think about something more strategic or write down policies and procedures, I can‚Äôt.
Q: Where in the world would you most like to travel?
A: There are so many places I would like to go that it‚Äôs hard to pick out only one. I love sun and beaches, so anything that seems like a paradise are good destinations (Hawaii, Bahamas, Bali‚Ä¶).
Q: Do you have a hidden talent/fact that most people don‚Äôt know about you?
A: Well, I dance a lot of Salsa and Bachata. I‚Äôm not sure if it is a talent, but it‚Äôs something I love to do and I know how to do it.
Q: Tea or coffee?
A: Coffee for sure. Not a fan of tea, only drink it when I‚Äôm sick. Tea does not bring me good memories :)
Q: Reading or watching TV?
A: Both. Love to see a good movie or also to do some binge watching on Netflix. However, also love to take a book to Starbucks (yes, Starbucks is very appreciated in Lisbon!) or a nice coffee shop and read it on a rainy day.
Q: What is your favorite thing about Lisbon?
A: What keeps me in Lisbon is definitely being close to my family. Also, our sunny days, good food, and great sights to see make me love Lisbon. What I like the most is the possibility to go to the beach in fifteen minutes from my home! Even in winter, the sun stills shines here and you can have a good time on a nice terrace on the beach.
Q: Best lunch spot in Lisbon?
A: There are so many. Food in Lisbon is the best. I like to go to Portugalia, in Belem (but more because of the space rather than the food).Q: You recently visited the Boston office! Was this your first time in Boston? How did you like it?
A: Just loved it! It was my first time in the US and I was delighted. The first few days were pretty tough. Never felt so much cold in my entire life! But I loved to see the city with and without the snow. You have a beautiful city and compared to Lisbon, everything is so big. I felt very welcome by the whole team and got really impressed about how big we are in Boston. Looking forward to create something similar in Lisbon.
Q: What are you most excited about moving forward?
A: I love the creation processes of everything. So, very excited about creating the Lisbon Team and to set all things for the creation of our offices as well.
Obrigado, Marta, for letting us get to know you and Portugal a bit better! Check out our careers page for more info about all of our amazing job openings, and be sure to follow us on Instagram, YouTube, and Twitter for all the Salsify updates you could ever want.

Let me tell you a story. This one takes us to Lisbon, Portugal, where I went to visit someone who has been my fairy godmother and her amazing husband. To protect her privacy, let‚Äôs call her ‚ÄúBallerina.‚Äù
Now, Lisbon was everything you‚Äôd imagine, great people, great food, and endless opportunities to learn. Between physics, entropy, mountains, ballet, and Portuguese culture, my mind was buzzing. But, as always, the universe had a peculiar surprise in store for me. You see, Ballerina has this friend, Karma, who happens to be a Tibetan Buddhist Kempo monk. Yes, his name is as amazing as his wisdom. One day, we decided to head to the beach for some sun and sea after I met with folks from the World Bank to brainstorm ways to tackle water scarcity. Pretty typical day, right?
Well, here‚Äôs the twist: monks don‚Äôt usually carry swim trunks. So, what do you do when your monk friend wants to dip his toes in the ocean? You go and buy him a pink swimsuit, of course. Armed with this purchase, we made our way to the water, chatting about life, music, and whatever else crossed our minds. Turns out, Karma had spent some time in Mexico and spoke Spanish. This led us down a hilarious rabbit hole of Latin music, culminating in a spontaneous rendition of *Despacito*. There we were, a cosmologist, a Buddhist monk, and a theoretical physics PhD student, on a Portuguese beach, singing and dancing to a reggaeton hit. Life‚Äôs surreal moments, I tell you.
But wait, there‚Äôs more. I‚Äôm not exactly an ocean person. I grew up in the Andes, far from any sea, and I didn‚Äôt realize how quickly the water could chill me. As the sun set, my body temperature dropped fast, too fast. Ballerina, who, by the way, is not just an award-winning cosmologist and a ballerina but also a seasoned mountaineer, immediately noticed something was off. Her mountaineering instincts kicked in, and she got me out of the water before I turned into a human popsicle. After almost giving her a heart attack with my near-hypothermic state, we bundled me up and made it back home safe.
That trip wasn‚Äôt just about beaches, physics, or even *Despacito*. It was about being in the company of some of the most brilliant and fascinating minds I‚Äôve ever met. Karma, in particular, taught me so much about the art of controlling the mind, meditating, and navigating emotions with clarity. It was like a crash course in mastering the internal chaos we all carry.
But more than anything, this trip reminded me of the simple joy in life‚Äôs beautiful chaos. The cliff, the mountains, the black cat, the dreams, the tree, the hedgehogs, the sunset, each a little piece of the puzzle. Between deep conversations, fresh ideas, and hours spent playing with their incredible kids, I felt myself rediscovering the wild, curious, and playful side of me. It‚Äôs the part that often gets buried under all the equations and theories, but it‚Äôs always there, waiting to come alive again.
Life‚Äôs better when it surprises you, isn‚Äôt it?

Two black socks hang from plastic clips above the Travessa da Cruz do Torel, an alleyway in Lisbon. I cut through the Jardim do Torel on the way to my favorite park. Yet I‚Äôve never been this way, turning right instead of left when exiting the garden.
I lean upon the golden wall, taking in the details of the surroundings. Slanting shadows carry shade and slice the buildings into softer, darker tones.
High above the buildings, above the wire and the socks, sits the pale, subdued moon. I can‚Äôt fathom what it is ‚Äî what it physically is ‚Äî dust, rock, an assortment of matter. What I see, perhaps, isn‚Äôt dust drifting into darkness; I see something like a stone, patiently waiting to shine.
I can conceptualize a stone. When I look into the sky, it‚Äôs like a rock beneath a moving river; is that not what it is?
Later it‚Äôll change, morph into a sphere of light, glistening from afar.
Its emergence means that night is falling, and that feels good. I feel the change of weather, the chilling of the breeze.

Title: Lisbon, Portugal ‚Äî Heaven on Earth
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Having been woken up by an unpleasant noise I hear every morning Monday through Friday, I peeked at the darkness still reluctant to get up and saw nothing but furniture shapes. This time, I was quite thrilled to kick off the day because in just a few hours I would walk the streets of a city I never thought I‚Äôd visit.
Fast forward a couple of hours, a few airport checks and check-ins and one transit flight and I was finally there. Oh yes, and my arm was sore from carrying a few suitcases (thanks to my girlfriend), with that feeling of exhaustion as if coming home after a whole day‚Äôs work and a mediocre meal and no leg space for a 190-cm guy which caused me to twist and turn in my seat. But that‚Äôs the economy class ticket benefit you don‚Äôt get anywhere else. It is the airport company‚Äôs fault but I do often get ‚Äî ‚ÄúWell, why are you that tall?‚Äù
Other than these minor inconveniences, the flight was good. I was here. Stepping out of the plane and walking for a change was a true remedy. I heard a whispering ‚ÄúThank you‚Äù from my back and knees as I was willowing towards an airport exit.
Outside, palm trees dwarfed every building around it as they stood proudly, defying gravity. Above, the clear sky was chasing away the dark clouds that gathered in the night to water the city. They knew Lisbon was awaiting guests. The air was quite refreshing and it filled my lungs with energy after every breath. Comparing it to the cold Belgrade air, which is best felt with the scarf wrapped around your mouth, was pointless. It was a true marathon to get to the destination, yet I was more than eager to get the tour started. I couldn‚Äôt wait to see what the city had to offer.
The spring sun was shining bright. It is one of those days where you take your jacket with you, but it is warm enough during the day and you don‚Äôt need it. If you sit down, you can feel the wind creeping up your shirt sleeves, giving you goosebumps. So with my jacket on and off and on and off again, I was strolling the old parts of Lisbon.
Each building, house and structure of any kind, whether historical or not was a story for itself thanks to the bright blue, yellowish and white tiles covering it. The tiles, called azulejos, were used as decoration, but also to protect the buildings from the salty river and ocean air. It is the first thing that catches the eye, together with different kinds of tiles laid under your feet. Those painted pictures of ships, seas, winds and other things on the squares, streets, and sidewalks.
Walking through the city street I was faced with the dilemma to look down and up, as vibrant colors were everywhere with tiles reflecting the sun, giving you the warm and cozy feeling of familiarity and admiration.
It took me a while to fight against the hilly terrain to get to what I consider to be the main square ‚Äî Praca do Comercio. It offers a marvelous view of the Tagus river which shows its full power exactly at this place, pushing the coast to the sides, stretching out as much as possible. One might be tricked to consider this to be the sea, partly due to the pleasant breeze coming at you. However, it is just the spot where you can see the full power and potential of nature, as the river narrows down a bit further ‚Äúdown the road‚Äù before it collides with the vastness of the cold and blue Atlantic. Seagulls are flying around, their song mixing with the people murmur and tram‚Äôs racket.
A few tiny white sails were seen on the river, while across, the remaining parts of the city are calling you to explore them, with much more greenery and sparse buildings.
The welcoming atmosphere invites you to sit on the curb, even in one of the surrounding cafes and just soak in everything around you. And that‚Äôs what I did. The sounds, the smells the view. It is all one needs to know about a city to recognize its soul, and it didn‚Äôt take me long to see Lisbon as my own.
As the sun retreats, the tiredness due to miles of walking and exploring caught up with me again, but just like upon the arrival, it was mixed with pleasure and peace.
And the sunsets‚Ä¶true Lisbon colors show up, the ones you cannot see during the day. With the remains of the day, the rush is over and satisfaction is painted on every face you encounter, tourist or local.
Sleep catches with you quickly when you lie down. I cannot remember what happened, but it was morning again. And that awful alarm sound, although it felt better this time. Getting down to the hotel lobby by elevator felt a bit painful due to aching in my legs, yet there was no choice. The city was calling me out to turn every corner, see every tile and smell the air from hills and valleys.
Alfama is a city within a city. I decided to walk across it and it was a mistake from the start. Uphill and downhill terrain made this area specific, with no flat parts. To me, it all seemed uphill, especially after a few hours. Luckily, you can get on the vintage yellow tram which is one of the symbols of the city and ride up, before you get off and walk uphill. Again. Endless elevation. And just like the other areas, Alfama is colorful and vibrant but there‚Äôs something special about it, something mysterious that I couldn‚Äôt define.
My stomach started complaining, which meant that the entire itinerary changed and the first place I wanted to get to was the restaurant. Suddenly, all those historical places became ‚Äúmeh‚Äù as human biology stepped in.
Lisbon is a perfect city for fish lovers. Fish is all over the menus and all I desired at that point was salmon ‚Äî and boy, oh boy, it was terrific. Add a squeeze of lemon on top of it, with a fresh salad as the side dish and it is a perfect combination. No bones to pick just a light yet fulfilling meal.
While all of that was happening, a fado trio was playing the background, a local band, performing here and there, and it was all that was missing. They hit the right note as the sun was setting over Alfama.
The moment I landed at the Belgrade airport, I was happy to be home, yet sadness filled my inner being. The city was grey and colorless, with people rushing all over the place, going in the wrong direction. It was cold outside and the cold reached all the way to my bones. I already missed the sunny hillsides and building tops, the uneven grounds and the atmosphere which seemed to be more welcoming.
I was back in my everyday routine. Yet, on every cloudy and misty day, I remember the Lisbon sun, shining bright!
Until we meet again!

Title: Exploring the Vasco da Gama Tower: Lisbon‚Äôs Modern Marvel
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We are exploring Lisbon. One street at a time.

Member-only story
--
Share
Nestled along the banks of the Tagus River in Lisbon‚Äôs vibrant Parque das Na√ß√µes district is the Vasco da Gama Tower, an architectural gem that marries Portugal‚Äôs rich maritime heritage with contemporary design.
Rising to 145 meters (476 feet), it is the tallest structure in Portugal and a symbol of the city‚Äôs forward-looking spirit.
Named after the famed Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama, the first European to reach India by sea, the tower embodies the adventurous spirit that propelled Portugal to the forefront of the Age of Discoveries.
Its design is inspired by the billowing sails of a caravel, the iconic ship that carried explorers like da Gama to uncharted territories. This homage is not just in name but in the tower's silhouette against Lisbon‚Äôs skyline.
Designed by architects Leonor Janeiro and Nick Jacobs in collaboration with the engineering firm SOM (Skidmore, Owings & Merrill), the Vasco da Gama Tower was originally constructed for Expo ‚Äô98, the World‚Äôs Fair hosted by Lisbon in 1998.
The event commemorated the 500th anniversary of Vasco da Gama‚Äôs voyage to India and spurred significant urban development‚Ä¶

A new chapter. A new adventure.
Lisbon has slowly but surely won me over. It‚Äôs a city where I‚Äôve decided to pause and settle for a while, despite the numerous considerations that influenced this decision. Now, I‚Äôm excited to share my journey in Lisbon, including my discoveries of its food, cafes, and various other delights.
This isn‚Äôt my first experience living abroad. Before Lisbon, I spent six years in Izmir, T√ºrkiye, which was no small stint, especially since I moved there when I was just 18. Now, I‚Äôve chosen to continue my journey in Lisbon, though the future might see me moving elsewhere or perhaps returning to my home country, Indonesia. For now, Lisbon is my home, and I can‚Äôt wait to explore and share its wonders.
Visiting Lisbon as a tourist, I found the city to be incredibly charming and lovely. However, by moving here made me realise how hill-y this city is! I arrived in September, at that time it was still pretty warm ‚Äî maybe around 30+C, I was sweating all the time!
Surprisingly, I‚Äôve adapted! I‚Äôve learned to control my breathing, maintain a steady walking pace, and navigate the public transportation system, which has helped me avoid excessive walking and sweating ‚Äî obviously ü§£. Now, I can truly appreciate all that Lisbon has to offer, both its beauty and its challenges.
Coming to Lisbon without knowing Portuguese has been surprisingly manageable, as most people here speak English. However, this convenience has made me a bit ‚Äúlazy‚Äù about learning the language ‚Äî I think I took it for granted somehow. Despite this, I‚Äôm starting to learn Portuguese, albeit slowly, and I‚Äôm doing my best to speak it as much as possible. Even though people in restaurants, cafes, and other places often ask me to speak in English instead, I appreciate their understanding of my struggle to even form a single sentence ü•π
Like many European countries, I don‚Äôt have particularly problems on finding Asian foods in Lisbon. There are some restaurants which are pretty good, however I am still in the mission finding the best ones here. Beside Asian cuisines, there are other lots of foods choices. I have my favourite bagel place, coffee (even the overpriced one ü§£‚òïÔ∏è), and local food like Francesinha (I like this a lot!). I will make different writings about it ‚Äî Lisbon food review!
Surprisingly, there is a big Asian supermarket here, quite close with the airport and decent pricing. Mostly products from China, but they have quite variable options from Indonesian, Korean, Thai, Vietnamese, and Japanese. As I am Asian myself, having this HUGE supermarket is a blessing! üòá
There are foods that I am quite familiar here in Portugal which is pretty similar like in Indonesia, they have different fillings ‚Äî like Risoles, Croquete, and some biscuits (like cat-tongue, etc).
So, food culture in Portugal is quite rich. I don‚Äôt think I ever have food shock here in extreme ways! Don‚Äôt worry if want to move or live here, your stomach will be fine and full too üçΩÔ∏è
Diversity is a thing here in Lisbon, I think it is nice to have such a diverse community. People are surprisingly warm and friendly tho. According to the European Commission‚Äôs survey about Quality of life in European cities in 2023, 94% population agreed that the city is a good place to live in general. For me in general, Lisbon is a safe city. Obviously like another cities in the world, there are sketchy neighbourhoods and crimes, but I found in general is pretty safe. So far, I don‚Äôt have negative experiences here.
I think I‚Äôve written quite a bit here, so I‚Äôll wrap it up for now. There‚Äôs much more to share about Lisbon, so stay in touch! More stories to come. See you soon!

Title: Working for a US company from Lisbon as an offshore team
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Follow publication
Your startup‚Äôs next digital product development team.
Follow publication
--
Listen
Share
In February of 2016, I started a new experience in my life. I was cast as the leader of a team (a team of two, at the time, including myself, though having grown a lot more since then‚Ä¶) that would work with a US company.
Almost two years have passed since and now it‚Äôs time for a new challenge. It‚Äôs also time to reevaluate the time and experiences taken from it.
First things first. For the first few months, I will try to minimize any disruption as best as I can. In the beginning, I‚Äôm all about understanding everything that‚Äôs in and around the company. How they work, who the people are, and how they get along together. Understanding how they think helps me to adjust my discourse to something that would be more familiar to them, more inline with what they‚Äôve come to expect so far.
I‚Äôm always careful with my first interactions. I have seen many times in my life people coming along and, in attempting to be helpful, start right away trying to fix any issues that may come their way. In my view, this approach, while sometimes needed, is rarely successful. People will usually see it as a source of disruption. You won‚Äôt have a full understanding of the problems or how they came about, and how they have tried to solve them in the past.
So I start by listening. I listen to interactions, I try to understand inside jokes, understand what worries they might have ( big or small ) on a personal and professional level. I usually try to avoid making any major decisions without understand all of the problematic.
Before this, I only had the experience of working with people that mostly were beside me or at least within the same city. When presented with this challenge I immediately identified two important issues ‚Äî Not sharing the same space and different timezones. I started to read a lot about remote working, and even though most of it referred to individuals rather than a team setting, the underlying principles still apply, so I could already see some issues that we were bound to face.
So how do you connect and work with people taking into account these possible issues? You communicate! You over communicate! You spend a lot of time talking to be on the same page.
Communication will also help when different cultures are in play. I spend some time understanding not only how they are as individuals, but also the cultural traces in their personalities. And whatever I didn‚Äôt understand I would ask. An expression, a feeling, some sarcastic remark, or jokes that I didn‚Äôt get‚Ä¶ I much prefer to ask than sit there guessing.
I found a great team with awesome individuals on the client side. When we came onboard, with us being an offshore team, it is easy to start setting up a divide between people. Us and them. Them and us. Fortunately, the client is amazing and they had the same way of thinking as I did!
They gave us company emails. We had access to the same communications channels as them. We got access to staging and production servers. We got t-shirts! They treated us, and expected from us, the same as any person in their company.
No one gains from one side being treated differently. For me, the only way for this to work as best as possible is through letting the offshore team be completely integrated with the process/spirit of the client. Of course, there‚Äôs a large component of trust involved, but with this kind of attitude, they‚Äôll gain people eager to help since they share the client goals and view them as their own.
It is important to note that this is something that needs to be addressed on both sides and is a never ending story, a continuous and ongoing effort. It can happen naturally, but you also have to create and nurture an environment where people can continue to grow and feel valued.
Sometimes you will make mistakes‚Ä¶ I believe it‚Äôs not a matter of if but when. You will have an unexpected behaviour, or you will introduce a bug in the system. At some point in time, you will do something that‚Äôs not in the greater plan of things.
What are the next steps? Tell the truth! Admit your mistake.
Maybe they will understand, maybe they won‚Äôt. One thing is for sure though, you will grow and strengthen the bonds that everyone shares. I see no harm in making mistakes, the problem is when people don‚Äôt admit to them.
From the first day, I try to remove any dependency on us that the client might have. If I see something that might create a dependency I try to plan how to remove it. Are we the only ones with knowledge on some part of the platform? Let‚Äôs pass that knowledge on to someone on the client‚Äôs side. For some clients we‚Äôre the only source of technology on their team. When that happens we have to be extra careful and try to complement that with a better knowledge base on the tech side of things.
I do the same on a team level ( I‚Äôve written about that subject in a different blog post ), so I apply the same principle. ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt it great for business if I create dependency?‚Äù ‚Äî I hear you ask. Of course it is, but that isn‚Äôt the way we work. We want people to work with us because we are great at what we do; not because they are shackled to us due to an over-reliance on what we know.
This was a great experience! The things I‚Äôve learned from working with a different country and timezone; for a different culture, with different views, is something that has helped me to grow immensely! Sharing knowledge and views and understanding the culture was an awesome experience.
If you have any comments or feedback on this subject, I‚Äôd love to hear from you!
Nowadays I‚Äôm working in my own company trying to bring some products ( like https://isdown.app ) to life. Besides product development, I love to build and scale engineering teams. If you have any questions, feel free to ping me on Twitter or LinkedIn or just leave a comment.
Also, check out Runtime Revolution. It‚Äôs an awesome product development agency with a proven track record helping clients scaling their engineering teams with an offshore team.

By sheer luck, we arrived in Lisbon during Festa de Santiago Antonio (The Feast of Saint Anthony). This month-long celebration of Anthony of Padua (who is actually not the patron saint of Lisbon but is preferred by the locals) sees the city transform into a spectacular carnival. The streets are decorated with colorful ribbons, street food stalls are packed into every open corner, cold beer flows from the taps, and the air smells of grilled anchovies.
Saint Anthony is also referred to as the holy matchmaker. During each festival, 16 lucky couples get to wed in a lavish ceremony!
We spent most of our days in Lisbon walking and eating, eating and walking. Since Lisbon is known as ‚Äúthe city of seven hills,‚Äù it was easy to work up an appetite. Even coming from San Francisco (which is quite hilly) we were impressed by the steepness of several streets. To address the challenges of getting from point A to B in the city, many of the steeper streets have funicular trains ready to ferry people up and down the hills.
We treated ourselves to the street food stalls on many many occasions‚Ä¶
Our host also shared his cooking with us!
On our third day, we took the ferry across Tagus Bay to the city of Cacilhas and followed an abandoned road along the water. This road eventually led to a statue of Christ the Redeemer, a monument inspired by the one in Rio de Janeiro in Brazil. This statue (inaugurated in 1959) was created to express gratitude that the Portuguese were spared the worst effects of World War II. It also looks over the April 25 bridge‚Ä¶which looks awfully familiar to the one we just left behind.
In 1775, one of Europe‚Äôs most powerful earthquakes hit Lisbon (estimated to be between 8.0 and 9.0). The earthquake struck during a holiday morning and did catastrophic damage, killing an estimated 60,000 people and destroying 85% of the city. Subsequent fires then burned in Lisbon for over 6 days and a tsunami with waves over 20 feet hit the shore.
The pic below is from the Alfama neighborhood. This neighborhood is one of the oldest in the city having been spared the worst of the earthquake damage.
Sadly, 5 days weren‚Äôt near enough for Lisbon (or Portugal obviously)! Hoping we will return!
Ol√°- hello
Obrigad(a/o) ‚Äî thanks (the o or a depends on the gender of the SPEAKER‚Ä¶ confusing for my Spanish-oriented brain)

Content:

Kristina, I am glad to meet you and am simply enchanted by your artworks ‚Äî I cannot find a better name to describe what you do. Let‚Äôs start from the very beginning. Your passion for photography and your first creative steps took place‚Ä¶ Where and when?
I was born and raised in the southern part of Ukraine. Since I was a very artistic child, my parents used the opportunity ‚Äî they introduced me to all kinds of creative expression: painting, music, dancing. I was fond of seeing the beauty of the moment and at some point, ‚Äî around age 7‚Äì8 years old ‚Äî when my grandparents bought one of those first digital cameras, I started taking photos. Just shooting everything I saw around ‚Äî mostly nature. Of course, not all of the shots, but some, made my grandpa admit ‚ÄúOh, she‚Äôs a good eye!‚Äù.It was the very beginning of my photography path. Hence, shooting nature still attracts me ‚Äî it is a way of meditation and a source of inspiration for me.Another way of expressing my mood and showcasing creativity was artistic shooting with a good friend from my school. We used to dress up and invent themed photoshoots, crafting all the details from scratch with our own hands ‚Äî they were important ‚Äî and incorporating a touch of aesthetics to each picture.Finally, I kept forgetting and belittling one important point ‚Äî my photos were displayed in a town hall exhibition in my hometown. It was literally the whole exhibition of my photographs. Talking about it now, I feel goosebumps.
So nature was your primary shooting experience. What about developing your eye and style? What kind of photography mostly attracts you now? What would you call your favorite style and does it allow experimenting?
Since humans are a part of nature, I love shooting portraits and body portraits. Now I will explain myself better. When I take a photo, I try to capture the expression so that the dialogue between the person and their sensations is seen in the picture. There is much more than face and body when it comes to seeing body language. I find gestures, movement, shapes, and sights even more important than the primary image, clothing sets, and surroundings. I like minimalistic photos, which speak to people‚Äôs hearts more than to their brains and eyes. However, aesthetics are very important to me ‚Äî I always see it in details and (people say) am good at showcasing it.
Is there anything really special for you during the photoshoot? Something you can never omit.
My point is using the photoshoot as a therapy. It is an intimate process which I can really compare to a confession. The camera sees a lot. However, I have 3 main rules for any shooting to take place smoothly. Before we shoot , we need to meet and have a talk over a coffee or tea, or whatever. It helps the person to open up and feel more comfortable.And the second thing is that the person should understand what they feel like during the process. It is essential, as the sensations and feelings cannot be hidden once snapped with a camera. That‚Äôs why I need the first step of meeting before the shoot ‚Äî so there is no intimidation, but freedom and comfort.Rule number 3 is putting myself into the model‚Äôs shoes from time to time ‚Äî it makes me understand how a person in front of the camera feels in different situations. In case I realize there are some points making me uncomfortable as a model, I avoid them in my own shoots.
Are there any taboos for you? What would you never shoot?
My principle goes far beyond any taboos ‚Äî I try everything at least once. Otherwise, how would I know if there is something I like or I don‚Äôt like? Every kind of art is unique and it might make you come up with some deep ideas ‚Äî it will make you broaden your skills or knowledge.I am pretty much philosophical in this aspect. Everything can take place, unless it is your own experience telling you that you don‚Äôt like it.
An idea as your motto during your lifetime? Or a couple of them‚Ä¶
In my opinion , there is always something going on in life which can change our perception, our opinion , and our principles. So there is no constant definition of what guides me in life other than changes. I guess there is a saying that the only permanent thing in life is change. And this is what I totally agree with. The strategy can change according to your goals, your values , and your sensations ‚Äî and it would be a very poor decision to follow only one rule for the whole of your life.

Title: A Shrine to the Other Maria
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

A fl√¢neur is someone who wanders around with no other purpose than to be an acute observer of life: the man (or woman) of leisure, the idler, the urban explorer, the connoisseur of the street. This is what we want to embody in our year in Europe. Come wander with us!

--
2
Listen
Share
In Lisbon‚Äôs Mouraria, the birthplace of a legend.
Fado (‚ÄúFate‚Äù) is Portuguese ‚ÄúBlues‚Äù music born in the slums of Lisbon in the 1820s‚Ä¶Well, that‚Äôs the kind of intro you might expect to read in an article about Fado. To our surprise, flaneuring through the winding streets of the Mouraria in the oldest part of Lisbon, Teresa and I discovered the actual birthplace of the woman whose music marked the emergence of Fado from the shadows into the light.
The plan for the day, in as much as there was one, was to start at the Chapel of Our Lady of Health, at the bottom of the Mouraria, wander through the backways until we got hungry, and then find our way to Z√© da Mourari, a traditional Portuguese restaurant that Teresa particularly wanted to try.
The chapel was built as an appeal to the Virgin Mary for her to intercede with God and save the city from the plague, which ravaged Lisbon during the 16th Century. The crowned statue of Mary at the front of the chapel is still paraded around the neighborhood once each year in thanks for her deliverance.
Just behind the church, the roads zigzag up and along the hillside towards Sao Jorge Castle, through the Mouraria, one of the few parts of the city that survived the earthquake of 1755. The name means ‚ÄúMoor-area.‚Äù It‚Äôs the old quarter of the city where the muslims were confined after the Christian reconquest of Lisbon in 1147. Because of its narrow winding alleyways and crooked streets, The Mouraria remained a magnet for outcasts. It attracted a rougher crowd of immigrants, sailors and sex-workers. Now it‚Äôs just starting to emerge as a rather hip part of Lisbon, while still keeping its authentic character.
Strangely enough, as we soon discovered, many of the immigrant in this neighborhood today are from Bangladesh ‚Äî the new muslims who are welcomed to Portugal. It‚Äôs obvious not only from the restaurants and stores with Bengali signs, but also from the colorful men‚Äôs sarongs hanging out the windows to dry with the laundry. Even the graffiti and street art has a Bengali flair.
We wandered around until our feet got sore, then headed in the general direction of the restaurant. The road narrowed, then widened into a tiny square with two trees loaded with oranges in the center. The houses here were old, not more than two stories, with some of the doors laughably tiny. The artwork on the walls was playful yet beautifully done. We were captivated.
The walls contained some clever visual jokes, like this woman blowing miniature ballerinas towards a cat‚Ä¶
And this door with a poem scrawled next to it that reads: ‚ÄúI want my love/There is no other/I want my love/There goes another!‚Äù
We noticed at the far end of the little square a gleaming white building that seemed almost out of place in the scruffy but well-decorated little square. A sign on the building explained that this square was named in honor of Fado legend Maria Severa, who was born in this house in 1820 and lived in this neighborhood.
Her father was a gypsy, her mother owned a tavern and was a sex-worker known as ‚Äú Barbuda‚Äù ‚Äî the bearded one. Maria, however, was great beauty by all accounts, and perhaps unavoidably fell into her mother‚Äôs profession. She sang early Fado songs in the taverns and brothels of the Mouraria. According to one source (Lisboa, a Love Affair), she was the first person to sing fados in the street, accompanying herself on guitar and composing her own lyrics. She sang about her life and her problems: love and heartbreak, betrayal, jealousy, revenge, tragedy; the same problems as the people she lived among. Her style of Fado became wildly popular. Indeed, one has to wonder if strands of this acceptance of hardship that will break the soul might have gone all the way back to the moors left to fend for themselves on this hill.
There are no portraits of Maria, but here are some descriptions written by various writers who met her: (with thanks to my source Atlas Lisboa):
Writer Luis Augusto Palmeirim: When I entered Severa‚Äôs house, a modest dwelling of the vulgar type her unlucky peers inhabit, there she was, smoking, leaning back on a straw couch, wearing polishing slippers dotted with red twine, a silk flowery kerchief on her head and the sleeves of her dress rolled up to the elbows. She was a rather swarthy, thin, nervous woman, remarkable for her magnificent peninsular eyes. On the gaming table laid a guitar, the inseparable companion to her triumphs.
Poet Bulh√£o Pato: It will be difficult for another Severa to appear, haughty and impetuous, so generous as ready to punch the face of whoever would act rogue on her! Brave, full of affection for the ones she cared for, as well as rough to her enemies, She was no ordinary woman, you can be sure of that.
One of her lovers was the Count of Vimioso, a ‚Äúbohemian‚Äù aristocrat who used to take Maria out to bullfights. This gave her exposure beyond the Mouraria. She was hired to sing at parties in high society, and her reputation grew. Tragically, Maria died of tubuculosis at the age of twenty six. However according to Lisboa, a Love Affair, what she really died of was a broken heart, because the social difference between her and the count was never going to allow a marriage between them: ‚ÄúShe actually died poor and abandoned, of tuberculosis, in a miserable brothel on Rua do Capel√£o, on November 30, 1846‚Ä¶Her last words are said to have been: ‚ÄòI die without ever having lived‚Äô ‚Äî She was 26 years old.‚Äù
Something in her music had quickened the heart of Lisbon. Fado had changed because of her; it became this powerful expression of desire crushed by fate. Because of Maria, Fado moved from the shadows into popular culture. Her life became a legend, then the subject of a novel, then a play, which in 1933 was turned into the first Portugese movie ever made with sound.
As Teresa and I strolled from the little square that bore the legend‚Äôs name, I thought about the shrines to these two Marias, just a few short blocks from one another. The people of Lisbon loved the Virgin Mary because she saved them from their fate. They loved Maria Severa because she sang about their fate. She transformed their sorrow into more than simply suffering. She made it into something beautiful and holy.

Author, communications expert and publisher of Changemakers Books, Tim is now a full time Mature Flaneur, wandering Europe with Teresa, his beloved wife.
