I arrived in Lisbon a little over one month ago to start my Erasmus semester abroad. I had previously not visited Lisbon but had heard incredible things, so when I arrived, I wanted to see it all for myself. I couldn‚Äôt wait to get out and get active making use of the last summer days in September/October. I found myself immersed by a city full of beautiful old buildings, cobbled streets (old streets of Alfama), viewpoints (Miradouro Santa Catarina, Nossa Senhora de Monte are two favourites) and rooftop bars at sunset (Park, Topo, LX), great contemporary art (Museu Cole√ß√£o Berardo) not to mention the surfing (Costa de Caparica) and most importantly the incredible nightlife here (cheap drinks in Bairro, great electronic music at Lux and a festival called Brunch). But hands down the best aspect of Erasmus is the exposure to new people, new cultures, new languages and most importantly new food!
But, me being me‚Ä¶I just can‚Äôt seem to ignore my keen interest in startup‚Äôs and Lisbon‚Äôs thriving ecosystems makes it even harder to ignore. Once I got confirmation of my place here at NOVA , I quickly added Web Summit to the list of ‚Äòmust-dos‚Äô whilst here. Building on my past work at Leade.rs and VivaTech earlier this year (check out my medium profile). I am very much looking forward to being part of their Live team covering social media for this momentous event ‚Äî boy do we have a task. Previously based in Dublin ‚Äî 2016 was the first year Lisbon hosted the event and what an event it was‚Ä¶attracting 53,000 people, 15,000 companies, 7,000 CEOs and 700 investors it became Europe‚Äôs largest tech conference, and it‚Äôs poised to grow in 2017. This all demonstrates that Lisbon is not only capable but eager and yearning to establish itself on the world stage as a leader in creativity, technology, and innovation.
Paddy Cosgrove Web Summit founder put it well‚Ä¶‚ÄòLisbon is like Berlin five years ago, but with a southern European climate.‚Äô
Currently Lisbon is a rising star and an underdog ‚Äî ranked by Allianz as the fifth-best-performing startup community in Europe, ahead of front-runners like Stockholm and Dublin. In fact, according to Preqin, the number of VC deals closed in Lisbon 2016 jumped sixfold from 2015, delivering it‚Äôs best year yet $18.5 million spread across 9 deals. But that is just the tip of the iceberg ‚Äî the Portuguese have had to make do without swaths of international investment which countries like the UK and Germany have received and that has translated into making Lisbon one of the best locations to bootstrap a startup.
One of Portugal‚Äôs main attractions is the combination of low-cost of living and high quality of life, two things that are very rarely found in one of Europe‚Äôs capital cities. On top of that, the OECD considered it the 3rd easiest country to start a company. This makes it makes it cheaper and easier to build great products utilising their highly skilled and ubiquitous talent. Fun fact: Lisbon has the highest percentage of founders with Masters or Ph.D. a whopping 82%.
Their rich history also plays its part, their Age of Discovery inspires a sense of exploration and due to Portugal‚Äôs small size; it fosters an outwardly focused mindset. It‚Äôs this very mindset which makes startups here think ‚Äòinternational from day one‚Äô giving them access to a larger addressable market, vital to startup scalability. According to the 2017 Startup Genome Report, Portuguese startups have high proportion of customers from outside Europe. A great example being F*ck Marry Kill, the gamified dating app, was founded in Lisbon but also enjoys popularity in German markets too. Furthermore, another advantage is how widespread and well spoken English is here, EF reports English proficiency at 59.68%.
Picture yourself ‚Äì considering all of the above whilst relaxing in the hot summer sun after a surf on a stunning beach; sipping a caipirinha and eating some freshly caught and perfectly cooked seafood ‚Äîthen you know how it feels to live in Portugal.
It‚Äôs international accessibility, low cost of living and enriching lifestyle is catching ever more attention of global talent and press. All of these factors coalesce to accelerate the momentum it has recently accumulated ‚Äî but to become sustainable, the ecosystem needs founders to nurture the next generation of entrepreneurs by spreading their knowledge and expertise through mentorship and re-investment.
A vital channel for mentorship, funding and networking is incubators such as, Beta-i producing 40 startups and raising more than $166million. They have worked with over 500 startups and run various acceleration programs, including Beta-start and Lisbon Challenge which attract applicants from 60 countries.
Canopy City a social impact-focused coworking space and incubator.
Impact Hub part innovation lab, part business incubator, and part community center.
BET Ventures an events company aimed at empowering entrepreneur‚Äôs.
StartUP Lisboa a government body focused on scale-up innovation. Check out their #ThisisPortugal campaign below.
Talkdesk, joined 500 startups ‚Äî received 21 million dollars of investment from Salesforce.Uniplaces, a disruptive force in the student accommodation industry that started in Lisbon and has spread to 30+ European cities ‚Äî raised $24 million Series A last NovemberCLICK HERE for more.
In many ways Lisbon feels like Europe‚Äôs version of San Francisco ‚Äî not to mention the look-a-like Golden Gate Bridge, tanned surfers, streetcars and hills (lucky no sharks though).
Sheffield‚Äôs Universities Portuguese partner and my host university, Nova School of Business and Economics is in the unique position of having a great interface with the Lisbon startup community due to their newly opened NOVA Venture Lab, running its flagship Zero Gravity incubator/accelerator programme designed to invest in and develop innovative startups both nationally and internationally.
This innovative mindset filters into their teaching here too. In particular one of the main driving forces behind this renewed perspective and practice is Miguel Mun√±oz Duarte my Entrepreneurship professor and CEO of iMatch an innovation, marketing and sales focused collaborative consultancy. He has great connections to the vibrant ecosystem here and often arranges guest speakers to shine some light on the practical workings of the methodologies and techniques that we learn. A great example of this was our first guest Christian Vismara ‚Äî a product manager at Build-Up Labs who came to talk to our class about his role there and specifically his work on F*ck Marry Kill.
First off, Build Up Labs is a Lisbon based Startup Studio also known as a Venture Builder ‚Äî they create startups from start to finish (wherever that may be). A Venture builder is an all in one ideation, building/development, and growth house. They leverage a lean process and a cross-disciplinary team using shared resources to grow successful businesses. Think of it as the diametric opposite of ‚Äòall your eggs in one basket‚Äô ‚Äî instead their approach is ‚Äòput lots of eggs in different basket and nurture them until they either fly or die.‚Äô
Recently parent Startup birdie (Build Up Labs) celebrated it‚Äôs first successful hatch and fly- in other words, their first exit with NVY.LIFE to L‚ÄôOreal, it‚Äôs a beauty and lifestyle club via blog/news/app ‚Äî they help readers to realise the best versions of themselves. Check it out HERE.
Christian however, talked a little more about F*ck Marry Kill (FMK) ‚Äî dubbed ‚ÄúTinder of the university students‚Äù by Jornal de Not√≠cias and as the name suggests, it‚Äôs not your standard dating service it‚Äôs a game that is designed not to be taking seriously and is best at making it more fun to meet new people. They are now attracting a growing and addicted user base in Portugal and Germany too. In total, they have 72,600 users and has already registered 1.2 million hits and more than 550,000 messages sent.
tapmyback ‚Äî a peer-to-peer motivation and feedback tool for teams. ToyToy a kids toy product discovery app.CLICK HERE to check out their Portfolio.
‚ÄúThe only thing worse than starting something and failing‚Ä¶is not starting.‚Äù ‚Äî Seth Godin
Startup is a game of failure and if you fail, you learn and if you learn, you succeed. At Build Up Labs they strongly head the words above. Un-afraid to talk about their past mistakes they view their failures as a portfolio of experience and after all, their motto is‚Ä¶
‚ÄúGrow fast or kill fast‚Äù
The venture building model was new and interesting to me, so after the great talk Christian gave; I approached him to find out more‚Ä¶I was invited to visit their office in the up-and-coming industrial end of town, Marvilla which is located in a co-working space called The Hood ‚Äî I was introduced to all the members of the team; Rui Gouveia CEO, Jo√£o Duarte data scientist, Jo√£o Pereira and Salvador Barros, I am really excited to help develop their social profile and produce an effective strategy.
CLICK HERE to find out more about the venture building model.
Finally, I have to say that I have never felt such a strong affinity to a city, let alone the one I luckily chose to study in. There is so much to do and see and it‚Äôs impossible to tire of it. A trip to Oporto is next on the agenda.
If you are reading this and you are;
A. interested in startup/tech/innovation
B. going to web summit C. need a social media helping hand.
Then reach out to me via email: t.dwyer193@gmail.com

Content:

Welcome to a new edition of the Tales of Ink and Light. In this one, i flip through the pages of a classic photobook and find echoes of the poetry that attracted me to Lisbon.
A decisive factor in my decision to move to Lisboa was the poetic atmosphere that i had felt while walking up and down its streets during a few short-ish stays. Often when i leave the house, i am unexpectedly reminded of that impalpable yet intensely real thing that exudes from the city.
I find it hard to define (and there is also the fact that i‚Äôd be reluctant to name it with precision, even if it were possible). It may be the colours of the walls, it may be the light, it may be a smell, it may be certain clothes people wear, it may be the sounds, it may be attitudes or certain sentences, and the river is certainly a part of it. It is these small things that suddenly appear to incarnate the soul of the place and make you think ‚Äî oh, yes, indeed, i‚Äôm here, this is it. It is the sort of inescapable feeling that seems impossible to describe and that you can only understand if you‚Äôve experienced it personally time and time again.
‚ÄòLisbon, you know‚Ä¶‚Äô is a sentence i read in a poem that appears in Lisboa, cidade triste e alegre (‚ÄòLisbon, sad and joyful city‚Äô), a photobook that started as a series of booklets sent to subscribers by post (at the time, it was a way to circumvent the censorship of the dictatorial regime) and later rose to fame after being prominently featured in Martin Parr and Gerry Badger‚Äôs History of the Photobook. A modern facsimile edition‚Ä¶

Title: The WebSummit & Happy Trails on Sintra, Lisbon with WERIDE.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Follow publication
I ride. I drink craftbeer. Sometimes I invest.
Follow publication
--
Listen
Share
I‚Äôm just back from the WebSummit in Lisbon. I had never been to Lisbon before but I‚Äôve heard that they have great trails. As much as I‚Äôm a technerd and the WebSummit is an massive tech party with endless happenings, there was no way they were going to keep me off the trails all the week! I‚Äôve heard the call of the trails! I contacted WERIDE and booked a full day guided ride including rental bike, at the Sintra-Cascais Natural Park, approximately 25km north-west of Lisbon. I knew that I was pushing it doing a full day Enduro ride after three days of late nights and many drinks..But,
to bike or not to bike ‚Äî was not even the question..
I was picked up by Hugo, the owner of WERIDE who took me to Miguel, my guide for the day. My trail monster for the day was a YT Capra with an amazing √ñhlins rear shock. A Swedish rear shock for a rare Swedish guy, now that‚Äôs how you roll!
After an espresso and a Pastel de nata at the little town of Arneiro, we started the fifty minute non-stop climb up to the trailhead. It was raining and humid but the air was fresh and the surrounding forrest was green and lush. I had asked for Enduro, and enduro is what I got. No Enduro without the obligatory climbs before the fun..
The trailhead, and actually all trails in Sintra all starts next to ‚ÄúTholos do Monge‚Äù, a mass grave built in the Chalcolithic period (2300 BC / 2000 BC) at the top of one of the highest elevations of the Sierra de Sintra. From the top you have a network of 25 different Enduro/HD style trails all decending down the mountains in different directions.
It is very hard to describe the Sintra forrest. It is something like a cross-over between a jungle and a Mediterranean forrest. This coupled with a misty carpet hovering a few meters above your heads turns the whole ride into a mystical-magical journey.
After a fantastic descent on the trails filled with fun obstacles, drops and flow trails, we climbed back up again to connect to another fun DH trail. I stopped counting the climbs up and down the mountain but the fantastic descents was the reward for the long climbs.
After a well deserved freshly grilled mackerel lunch at ‚Äúthe Bikers Refugee‚Äù in the small city of Penedo, we started the devilish climb back up to the top for our final long descent.
The Donkey trail starts at the top on Peninha, a very remote and isolated chapel overlooking the Atlantic with stunning views.
Words cannot justify the stunning views around Peninha. But best of all is the amazing descent.
After all the climbs I was ready for the long, breath taking descent to the towards the sea.
What goes up must come down. And that is a good thing!
We finished off the ride with a cold beer where we had parked. It could not have been better.
I‚Äôm glad that I took a day off the WebSummit craziness for a ride in Sintra despite being very tired from the outset. It was an amazing experience. Magical forrest, endless cool trails and a fantastic guide. I can definitely recommend to anybody who wants to ride in Portugal to contact WERIDE. These guys are pure Pros, attentive, fun and can adapt to any rider style from beginners to Pro-riders. XC, DH or Enduro, whatever makes you tick. They also know how to spice up the ride with espresso, lunch and a beer just at the right time when you really need it. They have top level, state-of-the art well serviced bikes and are very affordable, so it makes absolutely no sense to bring your own bike.
They do: half-day, full-day rides and also organize multiple days or week long rides all over Portugal. They even have their on RVs for maximum comfort for the longer rides. Enduro Magazine just came back from a couple of days with them and published this great piece.
I will definitely come back and I recommend mountain bikers who are searching for their next adventure to go and discover Portugal. You will not regret it.
--
--
I ride. I drink craftbeer. Sometimes I invest.
Investor & Entrepreneur. Former Facebook Exec. Passionate Mountain Biker. Lover of craft beers. Father of 5.

Title: Short-term Trip to Lisbon: what you need to know for the first visit
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
We just returned from a short business trip to Lisbon with my husband. It was our first time visiting the city, and I can‚Äôt help but share this story.
We visited Lisbon right after our relocation to The Azores, San Miguel Island. It‚Äôs also Portugal but far from the mainland and is located in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean but it‚Äôs another story‚Ä¶ Since we had not visited this country before it was interesting to compare both locations, and got to know the capital of Portugal and the mentality of the locals.
The airport is right in the city, 30 minutes from the center, which is very handy and saves you time.
The old part of the city is pretty compact and no need to use transportation. It‚Äôs very nice to walk around. By the way, did you know Lisbon is one of the oldest cities in the world? And it‚Äôs worth the stroll, but most of the main sights in Lisbon could be seen in 2 days.
Lisbon is a relatively compact city, but it‚Äôs still a good idea to stay as centrally as possible!
Chiado and once again Chiado, and the area surrounding it!!!
It has a really wonderful, relaxed vibe. Everything is extremely close here. We were staying at 9 Hotel Mercy and were completely satisfied with the location and hotel.
If you want to save some money you can choose areas a little farther from the center such as Avenidas Novas and Alcantara ‚Äî they are also good for long-term living. But in this case, you will need to use transportation.
The first thing I recommend after you leave the hotel is to have a glass of Vinho Verde ‚Äî ‚ÄúGreen wine‚Äù ‚Äî which is a traditional Portuguese wine produced exclusively in the northwest of the country. It is lightly sparkling and low in alcohol. It‚Äôs really good!
Ginjinha. Trying ginjinha in Lisbon is a travel must. Actually, it‚Äôs a cherry liqueur that originated in Lisbon. A lot of bars serve ginjinha in small cups made of dark chocolate. Drinking can be fun.
Below I‚Äôll share a list of dishes I‚Äôve tried, of course, it could be longer, but I was only there for a few days. Plus, we had excellent breakfasts at the hotel.
Perhaps I would have started listing famous tourist attractions in the past, but it‚Äôs not so important to me now. I don‚Äôt like the fuss about it. Besides, such places are always so crowded!
Instead of visiting the famous Elevador de Santa Justa, standing in an endless line, and then in the small and stuffy elevator car (I googled and saw pictures of tourists), I‚Äôll choose to sit in a nearby rooftop bar with a panoramic view of the same elevator and enjoy the wonderful view!!!
It‚Äôs good to read a few articles or watch a video before the trip to manage your expectations. Make a few marks on the map of places you want to visit.
I really couldn‚Äôt imagine traveling without a long list of must-see sights. But now I open up a google map with my marks on it and choose on the spot what place I want to visit depending on the mood. And that‚Äôs fine.
If I want to learn more about the city and its history, the best way to do it is to book a city tour for a few hours with a private guide who lives in this city and can share some personal stories from life.
From the beginning, it became clear that there was no point in comparing mainland Portugal and San Miguel Island. Yes, it is one country, but so different in so many ways!Generally, I like that Lisbon is lively enough and full of locals even in the city center. But a few things that were a little embarrassing to me are the tourists‚Äô and emigrants' way of behaving, and it wasn‚Äôt just downtown. I would describe it as unbridled and disrespectful which makes the atmosphere around a little bit cold and not friendly. These are my personal remarks you might not even notice it, but my empathy didn‚Äôt allow me to ignore such things.
This city is a really nice place for tourists, but I would think twice about long-term living.

Hello World! ‚Äî Excited to share with you how my first week in Lisbon with Remote Year went.
The City: Two words: Hills and Festivals. There are hills everywhere. Lisbon is the stairmaster city incarnate ‚Äî I swear, we are all going to have nice butts at the end of this month. June is also a great month to visit because of all the festivals! All the charming little districts (Alfama, Bica, Bairro Alto, Castelo & Mouraria) bring the party to the streets to celebrate St. Anthony. Grilled sardines, bread with sausage, red wine, music and entertainment fill the streets for the entiremonth.
The Workspace: It‚Äôs a 10 minute walk from my apartment and folks shuffle in and out depending on their schedules.
The Gym: Fitness Hut: a 3 minute walk from the workspace and 55 Euros for 5 weeks. The biggest adjustment for me (other than not having my trainer Cheyne to keep an eye on me) is having to ration your water because there are no water fountains! You‚Äôd think they‚Äôd want to make sure you stay hydrated‚Ä¶
The Routine: Currently non-existent. When I wake up, go to sleep, eat, work out, code, and study vary at different hours of the day every single day. I guess my routine is: Do what you want when you want ‚Äî I can‚Äôt lie, it‚Äôs fucking great.
The Work Situation: The UpWork profile is up but I‚Äôm having trouble even finding work to submit bids/proposals for. Most of the jobs require the freelancer to be physically located in the U.S and anything remotely related to Finance requires a lot of Strategy and Business Development experience, none of which I really have. I wallowed a bit for a few days: I realized that my resume was top-notch for a Corporate Finance job but unfortunately only that. Smaller and more nimble firms want someone that can not only manage Budget, Pacings, Close from an Operational side but also someone that can do Strategy, Business Dev and even some sales; coding experience would be a huge plus. It‚Äôs been a humbling experience for sure‚Ä¶
The Coding: The plan is to go through the free version of CodeAcademy (current progress at 35%) before I commit to the paid version. PluralSight was recommended as well so we‚Äôll see. Luckily, I‚Äôve got a team of software engineers on this program who are all so willing to help throughout this process.
Last but not least, the People: Remote Year Denali is a group of 40 amazing individuals, lead by our fearless leader and positivity unicorn, Erica. (She‚Äôs the one wearing the grey jacket on the bottom right of me in the photo below). Everyone is so incredibly talented, driven and passionate about making the most of both their careers and life ‚Äî it‚Äôs impossible to not feel inspired to do the same every single day. Back home, I‚Äôve always felt like the odd one out at work, always questioning things and always pushing the envelope because I wanted more: I wanted more to my career than what people decided for me and I wanted more to life than what I knew. I can‚Äôt tell you how incredible it feels to meet 39 other individuals who feel EXACTLY the same way.
Originally published at https://allthingslil.net on June 5, 2018.

Title: My Favorite Restaurants in Lisbon, Portugal (2022)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Lisbon is an incredible energetic place. And since I moved here, in 2016, the city has developed a lot and, fortunately, it continues to innovate.
One of the best parts of living in the capital is being able to closely follow the growth of the gastronomic scene, which is varied and full of good representative chefs.
It wasn‚Äôt an easy task, but I selected my all-time favorite restaurants, from the finest to the tradicional ones ‚Äî for all tastes and budgets.
Belcanto is one of the main references in the Portuguese gastronomy ‚Äî with 2 Michelin stars and in 42nd place on ‚ÄúThe World‚Äôs 50 Best Restaurants‚Äù list. If you are looking for an unforgettable experience, this is the place.
Of√≠cio is one of those restaurants that we want to take everyone to visit. They have a menu of sharable dishes and finger food that are absolutely delicious. My favorites: Spider Crab, Sea Vegetable Taco, Old-fashioned Oven Rice and, of course, the best dessert ever, the Cheese Tart by chef Hugo Candeias.
This Viennese coffee house makes me feel at home. They serve traditional Austrian dishes, like Wiener Schnitzel, and my favorite pastries, Apfelstrudel and the Sachertorte. On weekends, they also serve brunch.
Bairro do Avillez is divided into two main areas: Taberna (a more relaxed space, with small dishes, charcuterie and finger food) and P√°teo (a sea-food restaurant organized in two floors). My favorite dish is the Flaked Cod with Cornbread and Fried Egg. For dessert, my recommendations are Bairro‚Äôs Pavlova and the Olive Oil and Honey Pudding with Lemon Zest.
Tapisco is a mix of Spanish tapas and Portuguese cuisine, with a food menu that is meant to be shared. My recommendations: Tomato Bread with Jam√≥n Ib√©rico de Bellota, Salted Cod ‚Äú√Ä Br√°s‚Äù and the Dark Chocolate Mousse with Olive Oil and Fleur de Sel.
The first time I went to Osteria was on my first date with my boyfriend. The place is very cozy, and they serve authentic Italian food, prepared according to old family recipes. I highly recommend the Focaccia and the Pasta al Pesto di Rapa Rossa (picture above).
This is one of those restaurants that is always full of cool people. The highlight, which captures the attention of all who pass by, is the giant Instagram-famous Octopus sculpture dangling above the dining room like a nautical chandelier. The food is Peruvian inspired and the signature dish is ceviche (as the name says).
JncQUOI is located in a historic theater that was converted into a fashionable place, with a high-end men‚Äôs store, a DeliBar with gourmet store, and a restaurant. There you will find classic Portuguese and International dishes signed by Chef Ant√≥nio B√≥ia and a wine selection with over 500 references that promise to offer the best wine experience in the country.
Definitely the best sushi in Lisbon. It has the coolest bar area, an elegant dining room, and a beautiful garden for the warmer nights. If you can choose, I would recommend the sushi bar area, where you can see the magic happening. I‚Äôve tried the Tasting Menu, that includes the best selection of creative sushi, sashimi and miso ever. Not to mention the dessert selection, where sugar balance was the rule and things as lime, chocolate, pineapple and flowers were combined in perfect harmony.
Located on the riverside of Lisbon‚Äôs Bel√©m district, overlooking the Tejo River, the SUD Terrazza restaurant is influenced by Italian and Mediterranic cuisine. I highly recommend it for a romantic dinner or a family lunch. The view is amazing!
The Oriental Market is located in front of Martim Moniz Square and have lots of different food stalls. If you like Oriental food, this is the place. I recommend the first restaurant, right at the entrance on the left, and also the Mint House, on the second floor, with the best Pad Thai in Lisbon.
It was the smell of fresh pasta (and truffle) that led me to discover this restaurant, which is close to my house and has become one of my favorite Italian restaurants in Lisbon.
The environment is extremely cozy and the pasta is delicious. I‚Äôve returned several times and keep ordering the same dish over and over again: Tagliatelle al rag√π di carne. You need to try it!

Before we get into this post, I‚Äôll admit I didn‚Äôt travel to Lisbon solo ‚Äî but it felt like I did. I took this trip with my best friend (at the time), but it may as well have been on my own due to us wanting to do different things on the trip.
I‚Äôll get into all that later, but for now, I‚Äôm writing this from the perspective of what I would do (and most things I did) when I travel solo, even if I technically traveled with someone.
In this post, I‚Äôll share my honest review and opinions of Lisbon, Portugal, and what it‚Äôs like for a solo female traveler. I‚Äôll also discuss some of the best things I saw, did, and ate while there.
I‚Äôll also be diving deep into the more personal aspects of this trip, including some of the biggest things I‚Äôve learned from my time there and some of the best people I met who have greatly inspired me.
Before I get into the best things I did in Lisbon, I NEED to talk about where I stayed! This hostel was probably the best I‚Äôve ever stayed at ‚Äî it had everything I could have needed, wanted, and more.
I stayed at Yes! Hostel and could not have chosen a better one. The staff were super friendly, very welcoming, and organized games, nights out, and pub crawls.

If you had ever been to Lisbon, probably you know the Tagus river (Rio Tejo), and Commerce Plaza (Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio), but what many people do not know is what we can find in the other margin of the river.
On the south shore of the Tagus river, in Almada city, but precisely in Cacilhas neighborhood, in addition to the traditional restaurants, very interesting tourist activities and the unmistakable architecture, an abandoned pier and ruinous, little-visited nowadays and commonly known as Cais do Ginjal.
I discovered this pier, by pure coincidence, one day after visiting King Christ, I noticed that a few people were exploring on foot an unpaved street that goes down towards the river, I was curious and decided to follow the path to see what was down there.
The descent is a bit steep, slippery and full of holes, the view is very interesting because above we have the King Christ and below the Tagus river and the April‚Äôs 25 bridge, there were other foreigners exploring the same path, usually equipped with fancy cameras, comfortable shoes, and lots of sunscreen on the face.
The end of the path is surprising when we come across the Tagus River bank and to the right the‚Ä¶

Title: In love at first sight with Lisbon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
‚ÄúOnce you start travelling solo, you wouldn‚Äôt want to go back!‚Äù
It all began in the year 2019. My Easter Break was thoroughly planned out. I was visiting my friend in Finland, and we were going to backpack Estonia. The only problem: This trip started on Monday, and it did not feel right to waste the weekend. And that is how my first solo trip happened.
I chose to go to Lisbon for I heard a lot about it, as well as its proximity to Madrid. I took an overnight bus, spent 16 hours in the city and came back by another overnight bus, thus saving me time and money. I had pre-marked a few things I wanted to experience, like a ride on Tram 29 and visit Belem for sunset. As soon as I reached Lisbon at dusk, I was welcomed by a grey sky and drenched streets. However, it was my first solo trip, and I was too pumped up to let this deter me. So, I proceeded towards my first destination, the Santa-Justa funicular(lift). Most cities in Europe offer a one-day public transport pass and, I could use the same pass for the Funicular. The Santa-Justa funicular, standing at the height of 15 floors, was at the centre of the city. It offered splendid panoramic views of this beautiful city.
Right next to the Funicular was the ruins of the Igreja De Carmo, an ancient church that could not survive the Portuguese war. These ruins reminded me of the fact that chaos can be beautiful. After spending some time there, I proceeded towards the centre of Lisbon- The Sao Nicolau. It was an ancient marketplace, now a wide-open space with the view of the church of Sao Nicolau. Walking through the streets around looking at the Portuguese architecture was an out-of-the-world experience. I stopped for a ‚ÄúUma Bica‚Äù- the Portuguese coffee at one of the numerous cafes in the centre; this was not a typical espresso. The Portuguese roasting process is a bit different, giving the coffee a smoother texture.
Lisbon was one of the reasons I developed an interest in viewpoints. This city had so many of those that made it possible to get amazing views from different angles. Alfama was the second viewpoint, Santa Justa being the first one. Alfama was a little trek towards the top of the park, giving visibility of amazing landscape like the hanging houses. After sinking in the exhilarating beauty, I decided to board the Tram 29. Out of sheer luck on timing, this otherwise bustling tram station was empty. I hopped on the tram, and it took me around the city of Lisbon, and it was magnificent. Dense Portuguese architecture and the grey weather gave me the eighteenth century feels that I only felt from History textbooks. Tram 29 took me around the city, covering all landmarks, while I stood at the rear, looking through the glass with awe for an hour.
It was late afternoon when Tram 29 brought me back to the centre. I walked around the neighbourhood of Sacramento, exploring neighbourhoods, admiring the street art and local markets. By the time I covered quite aground, I had grown hungry. I was in the vicinity of Santa Catarina with no cafes nearby, except this small restaurant that had no customers. Finding vegetarian food initially in Europe was a problem. I went in hoping to find some food, and the kind chef inside asked me what I wanted. I told him that I was hungry and wanted vegetarian food. The guy‚Äôs exact words were ‚ÄúWe are closed right now, but its difficult to find vegetarian food around. We don‚Äôt have it in our menu either but Ill whip up something for you‚Äù. And he did. He made me a special vegetarian platter. My experience with Portuguese was outstanding since the beginning of the day, but this incident took my heart away.
After a hearty lunch, I walked towards Belem. Belem had a great beach, yacht-dock with impressive views and a cultural centre. I walked into the cultural centre, saw some exhibits, and learnt some cool titbits on Portuguese culture and history. After an hour in the museum, I walked outside, along the coast towards the monument of discoveries. That was an immense marble wonder, standing on the banks of Tagus river, dedicated to the wanderer and discoverer, Enrique. By this time, the weather was quite good, and the atmosphere was upbeat. I took a seat and napped of for an hour. Fifteen kilometres of city-walking was a tiresome feat.
As soon as I got up, it was sunset time. And Portugal, the Westernmost country of Europe, offered fantastic sunset views. So, I went to the best sunset point of the city, and the third viewpoint, the Jardim Sao Pedro de Alcantara, a cheery cliffside. For a moment, I paused and reflected what a beautiful sight this was. Orange sky, scents of spring, calm guitar music and cocktails to melt for, it was a perfect conclusion to my first solo trip.
It was a bit scary and took a lot of planning. It was also a test for my confidence and a dip in my savings. But it was totally worth it. For otherwise, I would not have discovered the joy of being called a solo traveller. ‚Äî I left a piece of my heart in Portugal.

Title: Oh, like Wall street? No, think bigger.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The last time I was in Europe was in 2019 when I went to Web Summit Lisbon: the world‚Äôs largest tech conference.
I have the chance to be back in Europe this summer, funnily enough, in Lisbon again.
Turns out I really like coming back to places. I‚Äôve got to reflect on the (massive) personality changes I‚Äôve had since 2019‚Ä¶ as well as the things that really haven‚Äôt changed (spoiler: I still get really loud when I am enthusiastic. And I have a very low bar for things that make me enthusiastic‚Ä¶ things within life are just SO worth raving about).
My recollection of Lisbon in 2019 was entirely fantastical. I didn‚Äôt have one bad thing in my memory‚Ä¶ I even forgot about all those stairs. Youthful bliss.
Adulthood comes with new features: some are good (wine at lunch) and some are not so good (an adult culture of complaining). This second time in Lisbon has me reflecting on my sense of adventure and open-mindedness from before. While places do have their downsides, overall, I think the big picture of life is generally quite positive; it‚Äôs something that adults lose track of among the millions of opportunities to be negative.
For example, Lisbon has many (many!) stairs/hills, but it‚Äôs also filled with stunning view points. I could complain about the stairs or I could appreciate the sheer fact that you can see the ocean, castles and millions of portuguese roofs from the centre of Lisbon.
Anyway, this is the start to yet another ramble about how great it is to be an optimist: to see the world for all its amazingness. While this is not a complex sentiment, it can be overruled with our primitive software (i.e., our brains looking out for danger) or the primitive software of other adults looking out for danger.
Let‚Äôs remember that the commodities of the 21st century are things the wealthiest of the 19th century couldn‚Äôt even dream of buying.
I‚Äôve used the phrase zest for life over the last few years to ground my optimism for the world. I‚Äôll attempt to inject this zest within the 5 lessons I learned (or re-learned) after my recent last 9 days in Lisbon.
While I was walking up a huge hill towards Jardim do Torel I noticed a very peaceful grandma sitting on a bench with her feet dangling and her hands doodling. The skies were perfectly blue and she was all cozy on the cobblestone road tilted 45 degrees.
There‚Äôs something so pleasurable about watching someone pursue their life for themselves, despite other expectations or limitations from terrain.
Similarly, my friend Jake writes a great and intense newsletter about golf, and while I am the furthest thing from a golf fanatic, I love reading his newsletter. He is so passionate and unapologetically a golf nerd that it‚Äôs just refreshing. It‚Äôs cementing to see someone else pursue their interests so boldly.
I like spotting the bullet-journaling grandmas and Jakes in the world.
It‚Äôs an art to pay attention and find these gems. But, if you look close enough, you‚Äôll see many happy people and their passions flowing through their veins.
Our brains get easily flagged down by negative, ugly or scary things. I think the world is more kind than it is mean (re: Factfulness) but our minds have a huge distortion to notice the few mean things rather than the many kind ones. But with the art of attention, you can see beyond this distortion.
I‚Äôm a big fan of spotting cute things. Cute puppies in strollers, cute families with grown children‚Ä¶ all wearing matching bucket hats, cute cartoons on fancy menus, cute babies with fat cheeks. It‚Äôs like a renewable resource of serotonin.
I even feel happy running around Lisbon in circles. Recognising spots from last time and places I‚Äôve walked around a bunch this time.
Attentiveness allows me to log a street I‚Äôve walked on such that when I walk on it again, it gives me a dose of familiarity: a very popular neutron-firing-pattern for the human brain.
I try to be attentive to all the Portuguese words, to recognise sounds and phrases, let them become familiar tunes instead of being drowned by the foreignness and communication barriers.
Essentially, there‚Äôs always a positive twist on my surroundings if I‚Äôm attentive enough. I derive a lot of happiness from hunting.
I‚Äôve noticed a lot of people phrase their wishes in the past-tense:
These ‚Äúwishes‚Äù are just regrets rebranded. I think the utility of regret is its ability to learn for or reframe the future. Why not reflect on regrets briefly, and then make wishes for the future?
Have wishes that aren‚Äôt regrets but plausible ideas:
Better yet, make these wishes more specific so that they‚Äôre not just theoretical.
Other than reflection, I see no reason to wish from the past. I see no reason to hold grudges. I‚Äôd like to learn from the past & pay it forward without dwelling.
One of my lowest points during this trip was when I was really tired and made a snap judgement about someone else. It‚Äôs inexcusable and not something I do often (thankfully), but also not something I‚Äôm immune to. It was a low point because I was really disappointed in myself.
I reflected and realised that I have my snap judgments in moments of desperation or insecurity. It‚Äôs not a them problem, it‚Äôs a me problem.
eople live lives with different compasses. They might achieve things in their lives I wish I could emulate or have, but instead of looking within myself for why I don‚Äôt achieve those things, I judge them to compensate for their gains with a loss. Basically, I will lower one element of themselves to feel less jealous.
I think this is a really rotten mentality. Lessening someone else to feel more secure yourself.
I believe I should appreciate subjectivity, i.e., respecting other people‚Äôs lives to co-exist with mine. Realising my beliefs are not objective and binarily correct, enjoying my life but not at the expense of how others want to live theirs and supporting other humans without being too pushy on my agenda.
Part of this journey has been internalizing that every human has something I can learn from. Everyone. They may lead vastly different lives than me but surely I do not have it all figured out.
Philosophically, my higher mind agrees with the notion of subjectivity and respect. But my monkey-mind can uncontrollably judge when it feels in danger.
I‚Äôve been reading Tim Urban‚Äôs book ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs our problem‚Äù and it‚Äôs undoubtedly inspiring these reflections of higher and primitive minds. The architecture of our brain is soooo ancient while the world is sooooo new; having a deep understanding of both is vital to co-existing in them sustainably.
Ancient = hunter-gatherers running from lions. New = can use a device built in 40+ countries to connect to the world wide web to click a button to borrow a bike for 10 minutes. These are very different scenarios!
The monkey inside my brain can mistake good, kind, different people with a lion trying to eat me. It will panic, judge, run, scream and desire a banana for extra running energy. And when it turns out that the person is in fact uninterested in having me for lunch, the monkey will be embarrassed it was wrong so it will use cognitive dissonance to rationalise how the perfectly fine human was actually a lion 10 seconds ago through the magic of animal-morphing technology that obviously the monkey catalyzed to relieve the threat.
I hope that‚Äôs enough of a vivid scenario to illustrate how silly our minds can be. Hence, I am working on a three-pronged approach to combat monkey-mind judgement:
During a conversation at Bahr Bairro Alto with Ula and Jo√£o, we chatted about a random person pursuing a wealthy life in the more ‚Äòtraditional‚Äô route. We‚Äôre a group of people who thrive on the unconventional route, so it was interesting to discuss someone with similar ambition but a different approach.
I just assumed this person was pursuing wall-street‚Ä¶ because that‚Äôs what most people I know who want to make a lot of money do. But then they were both like no: think bigger.
I didn‚Äôt know there was something bigger than wall street? Turns out there‚Äôs a category well beyond wall-street that takes more insider information. Wall Street just has a good brand. Like Gucci (known luxury) vs Zegna (less known, but more luxury) or Rolex (known luxury) vs Patek Philip (less known, but more luxury)‚Ä¶. It‚Äôs a luxury so luxury that it‚Äôs off the market.
I liked learning this a lot since I get such a high off of learning about less-mainstream paths and more rare experiences.
This concept of thinking beyond the ceiling is so appealing. Our conversation added a new anchor within my pursuit for an interesting and status-quo-challenging life.
I have a very Serbian dad which means after his obedient medium-sized dog comes his stick-shift 2010 car with nearly 300,000 km logged. He taught me how to drive a manual car.
However, it turns out that driving on flatland & wide Canadian roads is VERY different from hilly, 1800s cobble-stone, windy, tiny Portuguese roads!
But you know‚Ä¶ I did it and learned a lot.
There were many miracles along the way. Like how our Peugeot managed to go 120 km/h in 5th gear without falling apart, only getting a handful of honks and successfully avoiding all instances of parallel parking (big miracle, you have no idea).
We also had not 1, not 2, not 3 but 4 Portuguese people actively get in the car, demonstrate some of their manual car life lessons & help with hill-starts or parking. 3/4 were complete strangers who stopped everything to get in the driver seat, not kidnap us, and share their wisdom. Their helpfulness was such an asset and is one of the things I‚Äôll really remember about this trip. It‚Äôs an energy I‚Äôd like to share more in life too.
Another thing I‚Äôve noticed in Portugal that parallels my Serbian culture is how much people like to feed each other! Contrast to Asia, portions are VERY generous. It never feels like someone is optimising their margin. While this isn‚Äôt the most business-forward, life-wise, I really enjoy the vibes of the anti-stinginess. Essentially, I don‚Äôt want to make my wealth by selling the least amount of salmon for the highest possible price.
It‚Äôs been a really beautiful time‚Ä¶ and in what feels like another full circle, I‚Äôm off to London, the place I was supposed to go in April 2020‚Ä¶ :)
I‚Äôm grateful for the strings of the world and for your attention‚Ä¶ now go enjoy something around you :)
Isabella Grandic
PS. I have been watching some great optimistic takes on AI. I really liked this video and this one.

Title: Book Review: ‚ÄúTwo Nights in Lisbon‚Äù by Chris Pavone
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When Chris Pavone‚Äôs Two Nights in Lisbon was initially published in hardcover last May, there was a great deal of pre-release hype behind it. I got a print galley, a digital galley, and then a finished copy of the novel ‚Äî which all came to me by the publisher without much prompting on my part if I‚Äôm recalling things correctly. Thus, it seemed like the publisher was particularly interested in promoting this one quite heavily from my perspective. But that‚Äôs not all. The book was generously blurbed, and quite gushingly, by several A-list American authors, including John Grisham, Stephen King, and Megan Abbott. Grisham and King, in particular, trumpeted the fact that this was a novel that you couldn‚Äôt put down. Indeed, this is a bit of a page-turner ‚Äî if you don‚Äôt mind thinking about taking a nice hot shower as you read this. The thing with Two Nights in Lisbon is that it is more than just an effective thriller: it has something important to say and the ultimate subject matter of this novel is quite unsavory as it might be topical. I don‚Äôt want to reveal too much for those who have yet to wade into this book, but, suffice to say, I found myself putting it aside at certain moments because the real crime presented within it is so repellant and distasteful, if not violent, that I needed to take a break from the mechanization of this tome‚Äôs harrowing plot.
The novel is about a newlywed couple who are vacationing, sort of, in Lisbon, Portugal. I say sort of because it is also something of a business trip for the groom, John. However, he goes missing one morning and his wife Ariel immediately goes to both the police and the American embassy to get them on the case. Neither, of course, is of very much help to her. Then, she receives a phone call: it turns out that John has been kidnapped and Ariel has 48 hours to pull together three million euros in ransom to have him returned to her alive. Ariel, of course, doesn‚Äôt have that kind of money, but she happens to know people in her social circles who might. That is, of course, if they want to help her out ‚Äî and they might have their reasons for not wanting to. And thus begins a bit of a cat-and-mouse game of double-crosses and requisite plot twists, and, naturally, the CIA winds up getting involved ‚Äî which shouldn‚Äôt be saying too much as this is something mentioned near the beginning of this book.
Does that sound like a good premise for a thriller? It does to me, too. However, Two Nights in Lisbon veers off into unpredictable territory even though you can kind of figure out what‚Äôs likely to happen before it happens. This doesn‚Äôt make the book a less-than-stellar read; quite the contrary. This is a well-done slow burn, and the novel does go into important territory that has been covered by many thrillers being released these days: those that detail violence that is implicit against women. To that end, Pavone does a masterful job of creating a believable female protagonist who is quite vulnerable, but who does her fair share of fighting back against all sorts of injustices that are done to her. That‚Äôs probably the big selling point of this novel and what makes it so immensely readable. Having said that, though, this is also a challenging read because the book‚Äôs subject matter is bound to make readers quite uncomfortable. Thus, Two Nights in Lisbon is not an easy book to take. While it is a relatively quick to flip through even at being more than 400 pages in length (and it is a quick read because of its semi-predictability, which is a pleasure of its own and keeps the narrative moving), it could have been trimmed just a little bit. It feels a little overlong, with an epilogue that feels a bit tacked on to give this book a mercifully happy ending. (Or as happy of an ending as you could expect from a book such as this. This is not to say that I‚Äôm not happy it ends the way it does, but these characters really go through the wringer and there could have been, perhaps, a little less of that in the lead-up to the end.)
In the end, I‚Äôm not sure how far I would go in recommending Two Nights in Lisbon as a must-read novel. It is very well done, but it made me squirm. The writing is top drawer for being genre fiction‚Äî flaws are damned. And the book does have them: you can‚Äôt think of the twists and turns too hard, or the plot kind of comes undone. Without meaning to spoil anything, it turns out that the kidnappers go to an awful lot of trouble just to achieve their ends ‚Äî though, at the same time, they must go to the lengths they go to. (For this reason, I guess I‚Äôm of two minds about this book.) In any event, perfection is always hard to come by, so we should be very satisfied with the care and craft that Pavone has put into this novel about the ugliness of American society and how women tend to get treated within it. Overall, Two Nights in Lisbon is going to appeal to readers who like their thrillers to thrill, but perhaps not too much. Me? I liked this, but didn‚Äôt love it ‚Äî and the reason is that I now feel as though I have to have that hot shower to rinse away the griminess of the major crime that is ultimately revealed here. Two Nights in Lisbon is worth a look, but just be prepared to go against what those A-list writers were raving about. This is a novel you‚Äôll want to put down now and then. You‚Äôll need to just get through the repulsiveness of the female protagonist‚Äôs unfavorable experiences throughout this troubling yet searing work of genre fiction.
Chris Pavone‚Äôs Two Nights in Lisbon was published by Farrar, Straus and Giroux / MCD on May 24, 2022.

Title: Lisbon Travelogue
Content:
Sign up

Listen
Share
I was traveling in Lisbon. That day, I went to an old restaurant listed in the Lonely Planet guidebook. A guitarist was playing traditional Portuguese music. Tourists from all over the world were drinking wine and talking, their faces bright with laughter. I had a few glasses of wine.
I began to feel the buzz. I grew tired of the place and left.
I kept walking. Not along the routes tourists take, but deeper into the old city. There were no pretty buildings. The walls were faded, and the windows sat still in the dark. The road wasn‚Äôt smooth ‚Äî just an uneven path of small stones and rough cobbles. Every step caught my toes. I kept losing balance.
As night deepened, dim streetlamps flickered on, one by one.
Women stood along the roadside.
Drunk, I approached them. I stopped in front of one captivating woman. I wanted to say something. She didn‚Äôt understand me ‚Äî but she named a price in English. ‚ÄúWant to fuck,‚Äù she said. I couldn‚Äôt understand anything else she said.
I couldn‚Äôt afford the full price. I handed her a bit of money, then turned and walked away.
I approached another woman. Did the same ‚Äî gave her money, then left. I just wanted to talk to someone.
I kept stumbling forward. The streetlamps swayed.
After midnight passed, fog began to settle.At first it hung loose, then thickened. It sank heavy into the pitch-black streets. Every shop was dark, shutters pulled tight. My sight blurred, then slowly vanished. I couldn‚Äôt tell street from wall. I walked with my eyes on the ground.
There was no one around. Once in a while, a car passed. Its headlights flared into the fog ‚Äî then faded without a trace. The dampness clung to my skin. I kept walking, aimless. I didn‚Äôt want to stop.
Around dawn, the fog began to lift.A narrow alley appeared. Beer cans. Torn snack wrappers. Soggy paper cups. Traces of someone who had been there through the night. But no one remained. No women. No cars. No sound. No people‚Ää‚Äî just what was left behind.
I was tired. I headed back to my room.
Morning was coming. The street had changed. Taxis and buses passed in steady rhythm. The green leaves of roadside trees glimmered in the morning sun.
At an Indian restaurant, the shutter rolled up with a loud clatter. Workers carried boxes inside, turned on the lights, and scrubbed the floor. The scent of spices filled the air. Metal pots clanged, hoses sprayed water, voices echoed. Everything was waking up again.
People walked. Shops opened. The day had begun.
And in the middle of it all, with sunken eyes from a night spent in the street, I quietly walked back to my room.

Every moment in life is part of the journey. I'm still new to writing, but I hope to share something about life through it.

Title: Lisboa: √â Uma Vibe (Lisbon: It‚Äôs A Vibe)
Content:

A global learning experience designed to give Havas employees the opportunity to see how the organization operates across its many agencies, cities & countries.

--
1
Listen
Share
I‚Äôm going to go ahead and assume that 2 Chainz was visiting Lisbon when he made that song. Ok‚Ä¶..maybe that‚Äôs a stretch, but seriously this city is literally vibrating with some of the best energy I‚Äôve EVER been around. And I‚Äôm one of those hippy-dippy, ‚ÄúI need to feel the aura, the mojo, the vibe‚Äù‚Ä¶ whatever you call it, to get a sense of whether I‚Äôll like something. AND THIS PLACE GIVES ME ALLLL THE FEELS.
The best way for me to describe it is to actually borrow from my home office, Havas Chicago. We have 3 major tenants of what it means to be a Chi-town Havaser, they are: All In. Clever. Heart.
You can tell that every single person in the Lisbon Village is beaming with pride for their agency, clients and country. They proudly represent some of the biggest companies in Portugal.. a leading grocery store, a major bank and even the train system. I‚Äôm helping out on NOS, one of the leading telecom accounts in Portugal. About a year ago, NOS came to Havas and said they wanted to completely re-invent the brand. Havas answered in the most ALL IN way ever‚Ä¶‚Ä¶creating Havas Different, a culturally relevant, hyper-village focused model designed to service NOS. The team re-invented the way they work, so that NOS and Havas can fulfill the collective vision and grow together. WOW!
As a strategist, I know that clever insights are both hard to come by, but also imperative to doing good work. My mentor, Joao (The Head of Strategy), and the other strategists in Lisbon have it down pat. The insights they bring to the table are simple, yet poignant and surprising, yet delivered in a way that makes you feel like you knew it all along. For example, when NOS tasked Havas to create a campaign for the Christmas season, the team came to the table with most clever insight around the most prominent fixture of the season, Santa. They asked themselves: if we live in 2018, where technology rules our lives‚Ä¶.why are we still writing letters to Santa? So, they created a campaign all around the idea that Santa MUST have a phone number and NOS was going to bring it to you. Again, WOW! (smart insight jealousy rushes all over).
Upon arrival at the office, I was immediately greeted by Maria Jos√© (a beloved receptionist). She and the others taking a smoke break immediately flashed me smiles, grabbed me for a typical Portuguese double cheek kiss and proceeded to start teaching me Portuguese phrases I needed to know. After that, my mentor Joao took me around the office and introduced me to everyone‚Ä¶.againüëèüèΩ every üëèüèΩsingle üëèüèΩperson got up from their desks, gave me a double cheek kiss and was ready to teach me about their agency and culture. Before the day was up, I was invited to take a walk all around downtown, view the amazing sunset from the River and try a shot of Ginginha, a trademark drink in Portugal. They welcomed possibly the most stereotypical American, midwestern girl with open arms and big smiles. Again, WOW (tear of happiness streams down cheeks).
So, like I said, it‚Äôs truly a vibe here. It‚Äôs hard to put into words. I can‚Äôt even do it justice, but I‚Äôm OBSESSED and I can‚Äôt wait to see where it takes me.

It‚Äôs a question I‚Äôve been asked countless times since moving to Lisbon from Lagos. Sometimes it‚Äôs asked with genuine curiosity. Other times, it feels more like a challenge ‚Äî a polite way of saying, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt look like you belong here.‚Äù
But the truth is, I‚Äôve been asking myself the same thing, too.
When you leave home ‚Äî really leave it ‚Äî you don‚Äôt just pack a suitcase. You carry your culture, your accent, your rituals, and your invisible expectations. You try to wear them lightly, but they cling to you in moments you least expect, like when no one laughs at your jokes, or when your food smells ‚Äútoo much‚Äù in a shared kitchen.
What I didn‚Äôt expect was that losing my cultural footing in Portugal would help me discover who I am.
Growing up in Lagos, everything felt loud and alive. The streets were full of stories. There was always a neighbor knocking, a generator buzzing, a market woman shouting the price of tomatoes like it was breaking news.
I loved it. And I also wanted out.

Title: How I Launched the Product Management Society in Lisbon: Building a Thriving Community for PMs
Content:

Sign up

As a product manager who has navigated through various roles and experiences, I know how important it is to connect with others in the same field. But what happens when there‚Äôs no ready-made community for product managers in your city? You build one.
That‚Äôs precisely what I did when I launched the Product Management Society in Lisbon. The goal was simple: create a space where product managers could share knowledge, network, and help each other grow. But the impact has been far more significant than I ever anticipated.
The Product Management Society began as a small meetup group. We gathered product managers to discuss challenges, solutions, and industry trends. What I didn‚Äôt expect was how quickly the community would grow. To date, we‚Äôve hosted 50+ events and built a community of 1,100+ members from multiple countries, all passionate about product management.
Our community is more than just a group of people ‚Äî it‚Äôs a vibrant network of professionals supporting each other‚Äôs career growth. We connect through our Slack group, where discussions around best practices, job opportunities, and product management challenges take place. We also have a WhatsApp group (invite-only), providing a more immediate and casual way for members to stay in touch, share opportunities, and engage in real-time conversations.
We host regular events on Meetup, from casual networking to in-depth workshops and talks by seasoned professionals.
At the heart of our society is the belief that product management is better when we learn together. From our events and workshops to our blog, we are committed to delivering valuable content and experiences for PMs at every stage of their careers.
Some of the highlights include:
We‚Äôre not just about talk ‚Äî we‚Äôre about action. The Product Management Society has already made valuable connections with companies and other organizations. One of the major highlights was our hiring event with Altar.io, which allowed our members to connect directly with a top product-focused company and potentially land roles in their teams.
We‚Äôve also collaborated with Productized for multiple events, including where our members had the chance to meet industry leaders, expand their networks, and gain insights into the latest product management trends. Additionally, we partnered with Product Weekend for another collaboration that helped our members further their careers and expand their skills.
Furthermore, we have an ongoing collaboration with Radhika Dutt, the author of Radically Rethinking OKRs, as she works on her new book. This collaboration brings exclusive insights into how product managers can rethink their approach to goal-setting and OKRs, providing even more value to our members.
These collaborations are a testament to the growing influence of our society and the opportunities we can provide for product managers looking to advance in their careers.
If you‚Äôre a product manager based in Lisbon ‚Äî or anywhere else in the world ‚Äî we invite you to join us. The Product Management Society isn‚Äôt just about attending events, it‚Äôs about building relationships and fostering a sense of community. By joining our Slack group, you can start contributing to discussions and sharing your experiences. You‚Äôll also find job postings, helpful resources, and answers to your burning questions. Our WhatsApp group (invite-only) takes the conversation to the next level, offering a more immediate space for feedback and quick interactions with fellow PMs.
Our Meetup page is regularly updated with upcoming events, where you can sign up to attend. Whether you‚Äôre looking to connect with peers, gain new insights, or find your next opportunity, there‚Äôs something for everyone.
The Product Management Society also runs a blog where members share their thoughts on the latest trends, challenges, and innovations in the field. Whether you‚Äôre a senior PM or just starting out, you‚Äôll find valuable insights that can help shape your career and approach to product management.
You can check out the blog at blog.productmanagementsociety.com, where we post articles covering everything from product strategy to career advice. Our goal is to make this an ever-growing resource that PMs can turn to for practical advice and thought leadership.
Whether you‚Äôre looking to network, learn, or grow your career, joining the Product Management Society is an opportunity you don‚Äôt want to miss. We‚Äôve created a space that fosters growth, collaboration, and professional development.
The Product Management Society has proven time and again to be a valuable resource for product managers. From hosting multiple events to building a community that supports one another, we‚Äôve created something truly special in Lisbon ‚Äî and we want you to be part of it.
So, come join us! Sign up for our events, join our Slack and WhatsApp groups, and start connecting with other like-minded professionals. Whether you‚Äôre looking to gain new insights, find your next job, or simply connect with others in the industry, we‚Äôve got you covered.
Also, don‚Äôt forget to follow us on our LinkedIn page for updates and more!
Together, we can make the Product Management Society a place where we all grow, learn, and thrive!

Lisbon is Portugal‚Äôs hilly, coastal capital city. It‚Äôs Europe‚Äôs westernmost city and the only one on the Atlantic coast. From imposing S√£o Jorge Castle, the view encompasses the old city‚Äôs pastel-colored buildings, Tagus Estuary and Ponte 25 de Abril suspension bridge. Lisbon‚Äôs geography, weather, and history make it a great city for running. There‚Äôs a terrific 5-mile path along the Tagus (Tejo) River, going by important museums and landmarks. A lovely downtown (Baixa) run along Av. de Liberdade takes you by important squares and buildings, to Eduardo VII Park. For hills, run the narrow streets and lanes of the Bairro Alto or Alfama neighborhoods, up to the Castle or one of the Miradouros (view points). The largest park is Monsanto, which is now well connected to downtown via a recently completed ‚Äògreen corridor‚Äô‚Äì a path through a linear park. And if you like hill running, this is your city!
Our complete guide to running in Lisbon can be found on the Great Runs site.
Riverside Run. 4.7 miles one-way to Belem Tower. Wonderful run along the water, passing under bridge. Numerous landmarks.Alacantra Dock. 2.8 miles west to Belem Tower. 2 miles east to Caise de Sodre.Monsanto Park. The largest park in Lisbon, with many km of trails. Pedestrian & cycle paths, forested trails, open fields, hill opportunities.Eduardo VII Park & Green Corridor. 65 Acre park located near central Lisbon. Highlight is the central walk with box hedges and a hilltop view. Green Route to Monsanto Park. About 2.5 km. northwest between Eduardo VII Park and Monsanto.Parque das Na√ß√µes. Originally the site of Expo 98, now the ultra modern side of traditional Lisbon. Path along the bay-like Tejo River. Lisboa Marina to Vasco da Gama Bridge. A run along the river in the more modern part of Lisbon. Terrific 4 km waterside path. Baixa & Av. De Liberdade. Classic Lisbon run, from the River Tagus to Eduardo VII Park, through the Baixa and along grand Av. de Liberdade.Alfama Area. The oldest district in Lisbon. Enjoy the narrow maze of streets and hills. Bairro Alto. ‚ÄúUpper District‚Äù neighborhood just west of the Baixa. Narrow streets, lanes, and stair paths. Great viewpoints.Est√°dio Universit√°rio de Lisboa. Centrally located sports complex 100 acres of outdoor running trails, tracks and green spaces.

Title: Top Attractions to Visit in Lisbon, Porto and Sintra
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
MeetnGreetMe together with our amazing travel blogger would like to share memories and some tips with you in case you have been thinking about visiting Portugal for a long time, or just decided to go there an hour ago! Today we will explore the best of Lisbon, Porto and Sintra. Together with Anastasia.
‚ÄúAt the beginning I will give you some general information about Portugal. Portugal shares borders with Spain and it‚Äôs the most western country in Europe ‚Äî sounds interesting, am I right? If you want to have a condensed view of European landscapes, culture and the way of life, Portugal might be one of the best options for you. I have been there twice and I am sure I will go there again. My both visits were in February (Yes, it sounds cold but believe me, even in February it‚Äôs +18 and sunny‚Ä¶and nothing can spoil your time there).
I have visited only Lisbon and Porto and some small villages nearby (for me it is better to visit fewer cities but to feel them, rather than explore the whole ‚ÄúEurope on two feet a day‚Äù. That is why today I will tell you about these 2 cities.
How to get there?
As it was a planned trip, I booked flight tickets in advance (Warsaw-Lisbon-Warsaw) and it was only 80 euros (which is very cheap I think). From Lisbon to Porto I travelled by bus ‚Äî 4 hours and 20 euros- may be you will find a cheaper way to get there, but I didn‚Äôt have enough time for it and used a simple intercity bus.
Lisbon is the capital and the largest city of Portugal. Lisbon is one of the oldest cities in the world, and the oldest in Western Europe. There are a lot of tourists all year long and you have to be prepared for much attention (especially if you are a woman), tasty food, good wine and hospitality‚Ä¶.let‚Äôs go!
I will tell you about places I have visited and advice YOU to visit!
Rossio Square (Pedro IV Square)
Lisbon‚Äôs most famous square. There‚Äôs no better place in Lisbon to soak up the local atmosphere than at Pedro IV Square. It has been the city‚Äôs main gathering place since the Middle Ages. Today, it‚Äôs the place where friends meet up and as a result it‚Äôs always crowded ‚Äî you will not miss it.
Monument to the Discoveries
It is the mammoth white-stone Monument to the Discoveries. Do you all remember Vasco da Gama- the first European to reach India by sea‚Ä¶.Yes-yes, he was from Portugal. Now you understand why they have this monument and so proud of it. You can ride an elevator to enjoy the view from the top of this Lisbon landmark.
Alfama
The oldest quarter in historic Lisbon, the Alfama district is dotted with architectural landmarks and it‚Äôs the charm of the neighborhood‚Äôs meandering streets, tasty food and wine, clubs with Fado (amazing music) that make the Alfama a can‚Äôt-miss destination.
And one more life-hack ‚Äî Tram line #28
The historic ‚Äútram‚Äù takes you through the city‚Äôs oldest sectors past some of Lisbon‚Äôs most popular sights and attractions. You don‚Äôt have to pay extra money (the ticket costs like a normal one ‚Äî 3 euro).
Belem Tower
Belem Tower, also known as the Tower of St. Vincent, this statue was designed to protect sailors on their voyages, faces the river and makes an incredible impression on you.

I fell in love with Lisbon probably on the day I was born, even though I never got it until I started to travel through the world.
When I started traveling, I began to look at my city with the eyes of a tourist, and that's the best way to find some hidden secrets or to look at places where you normally just pass through without even looking.
I‚Äôll just share with you some 5 places not to miss in Lisbon and help you get as enamored with my city as I am.
Lisbon is such an old city that one of my favorite neighborhoods is older than Portugal, being over 100 years old.
It‚Äôs one of those more typical neighborhoods in Lisbon where you can Fado houses and still see a bit of an old times type of life, with a thigh community in the middle of a big city.
It had become a very touristy place in the last couple of years, but it‚Äôs still possible to get lost and find some old stores, where you can find fun trinkets.
Fado is part of the tradition not only in Lisbon but specifically in this neighborhood, where you can find a ‚ÄúCasa de Fado‚Äù almost in every corner.

Title: Lisbon
Lisbon ‚Äî Final Day
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The final day on any trip is always a bit odd as there is a more clock watching brief to bear in mind as at some point there is that need to head off to the airport, you can‚Äôt just say sod it and get the next plane instead. And there is the packing, much of which on this trip meant refolding unused clothes we had brought. Mainly because there was the idea that we would come back in the evening, get changed, and then go out for food. Which didn‚Äôt happen at all, plus there was a bit of doubling up with hot and mild weather clothing. The unused side of the main case was a lot fuller than the dirty washing side.
Breakfast was the usual lunacy. We had been noticing little oddities, but I‚Äôve rolled them all up into a leaving day edition. There has been a man in the hotel all week. Easily recognisable as he‚Äôs about 6‚Äô 5‚Äù, bald and shiny at the front of his head, and then a foot long mullet down the back. He‚Äôs been getting a glass (for the fruit juice) and using it for coffee, pressing the americano button on one of the machines, and then whipping the glass out before the milk is poured (there is another machine which does just black coffee). He will then disappear, leaving the rest of the family in the restaurant, and then he would be back ten minutes later to do the same coffee routine all over again. It wasn‚Äôt until this morning that we saw where he was going. He went outside and sat in his car with the door open to drink his coffee, occasionally playing with the windscreen wipers (it wasn‚Äôt raining). I‚Äôm not who was happier with this arrangement, him, or his family.
Coffee in a fruit juice glass may sound weird, but there are always lunatics trying to go one better. In addition to mullet man, I have seen someone take a bowl (which is there for the cereals) and do their coffee into that. And conversely someone using a coffee cup to put their cereals in. Additionally, the breakfast room had a little Danone fridge in the corner, on investigation, it was full of Nestle yoghurts. I thought I wasn‚Äôt a morning person, but shit, I‚Äôm a fully functioning person compared to some of these.
Anyway, after the breakfast fun and games and packing, we checked out, left the cases, and went out for our last little wander of the trip. The fact we had dressed for going home and I had jeans and a jacket on meant it was bright sunshine and no rain.
We headed to the Edward VII park. It had been set out when most of the city was rebuilt after the 1755 earthquake, but they renamed it in honour of the visit of our king to the city in 1903. And for some reason they never renamed it back after he went home. Weirdos.
The park slopes gently uphill. Of course it does, this is Lisbon. You are going to be hard pushed to find anywhere flat to build a park.
About halfway up is the Pavilion Carlos Lopez which has some beautiful blue and white tiled scenes from history upon its walls.
In front of one a woman, and her photographer friend are set up. She has six juggling clubs with bright orange ends which she is juggling in front of the tiles while her friend takes phots from differing lengths away. When I say juggling, perhaps trying to juggle would be a more accurate description. When she drops most of the clubs, Helen and I say in unison, ‚Äòsack the juggler.‚Äô
At the top of the park‚Äôs slope is a modern sculpture to the 1974 revolution.
And in front of it is the wonderful view down the hill, back over the laid out gardens, to the statue to the Marques de Pombal (who laid out the new city after the earthquake) in the middle of the double roundabout, along the main drag of the Avenue de Liberdade beyond and then there in the distance is the river.
Having come up one side of the park we go to amble down the other side and as we do we find ourselves outside the Lisbon Greenhouse.
It is a botanical garden, and we had seen the roof from above and the side and not twigged it was the greenhouse we had seen marked on the map. It is huge.
And full of greenery you may be surprised to know.
And flowers.
None of which I know the name of. Helen does, she knows most of them, and tells me what they are. Contrary to popular belief, I do listen when she tells me stuff, but where plant life is concerned, my mind does not want to keep that stuff. Which is a bit strange considering how much utter crap it is more than willing to keep.
I did retain the names of two, but only because I was been deliberately silly about them. Apparently, Nathan wants a cheese plant. Of which there were loads here, so many in fact it was more like a cheese forest, and I would certainly be happy if there was such a thing as a cheese forest and that cheese would grow on trees.
The other being a wisteria. And that‚Äôs only because I was saying I had heard people were going mad about this flower. ‚ÄòReally?‚Äô came the puzzled response from Helen. ‚ÄòYeah, it‚Äôs wisteria hysteria.‚Äô I will point out I already had my coat and hat on at this point.
It was quite interesting, and I don‚Äôt mean in an air quotes fingers kind of way. Plus I was taking the opportunity to try and get some macro photography of the various flowers done.
I don‚Äôt know what these white ones are called, but trying to get near enough to them to do a macro shot was difficult as the juggler and her photographer mate had set up in front of them and now had another hanger on with them. In the previous half an hour or so since we‚Äôd last seen them hogging things worth taking pictures of, the juggling skills hadn‚Äôt improved.
We had heard the peacocks, but it wasn‚Äôt until we were outside again that we saw them. Just strutting around and not being tortured by moronic tourists into fanning out their feathers in distress.
There was time for a last caf√© stop, a final cappuccino and pastel de nata in the park before it was time to head back to the hotel and pick up the cases ready for the journey to the airport.
Which didn‚Äôt take as long as the journey out seemed to.
I had the camera ready for some of the station art,
and got some blurred shots, some that missed altogether, some with window reflections,
and a feeling that somehow we‚Äôd missed a couple of stations as I was sure I‚Äôd seen some much more striking examples on the journey into the city.
The journey through the airport was smooth, bag drop was easy and for a change it was Helen getting the grilling about bag contents. Security was fine, there was a bit of duty-free shopping (not that there is duty on boxes of pastel de natas, just idiot tourist premium). I had been hoping to find a Forca Portugal store, but there wasn‚Äôt one. Having gotten Sporting Lisbon and Porto pens and magnets the previous day, I thought I would complete the big three, only for the Benfica official store not to have them, and the Football Gate store to have the Sporting and Porto stuff I‚Äôd got the day before, but to do no Benfica stuff because they had their own store.
Passport control was quick, and both coming out and going back the border police have been friendly and efficient. Something that perhaps the US ones could do with coming and getting some training on.
The queue at the gate was the usual bunfight / free for all. No sort of order in being called up, just get your elbows out and shuffle slowly forward in the queue. Or do what we did and sit there and wait for the back of the queue to come to us before joining it. And then find that on the plane there was no one else on our set of three seats, and the overhead lockers were empty. Bonus. Then it is roll to the runway and away we go.
Overall the trip was great.
Lisbon is a wonderful city. There is so much to see and do and four nights is nowhere near enough time to do anything more than scratch the surface. It is good exercise too, rest assured that if you walk for more than a couple of minutes in any direction there will be a hill to climb up or shuffle down.
The food has been wonderful, and it is cheap. Everything has been really tasty, and they certainly don‚Äôt scrimp on their portion sizes (they must know people need feeding up to be able to deal with walking up all those hills). And the people are so friendly.
The Azulejos are wonderful, and there are many splendid examples of art on the tiles. Although the occasional one did make us smile for the wrong reason. This one was designed to represent justice with the scales. But all I can see is saggy tits. Which again, says more about me than anybody else.
The only downsides have been the very showery weather, which no one can really do anything about, and which hasn‚Äôt dampened our spirits anywhere near the amount they have dampened out clothes. And the attempted pickpocket / bag theft thing.
But we would definitely recommend coming back with more time to get around more of the city and beyond (Sintra is only 45 minutes away).

Next up is a collection of drabbles, three hundred and sixty six of the little hundred word stories, under the title of ‚ÄúA Drabble A Day Keeps The Psychoanalyst Away‚Äù, this is available on Amazon at
www.amazon.co.uk
Finally, there is an autobiographical work, released under my alter ego of Kevin Rodriguez-Sanchez, which covers a two year period in the early noughties when I lived in Manchester ‚Äî ‚ÄúFive Go Mad In Manchester‚Äù. Again, this is available on Amazon at
