Lisbon‚Ä¶ I have arrived to this wonderful city two years ago and fell in love with it at the first glance. Lisbon was like my beloved man, like my lover and my soulmate who was waiting for me for all his life, waiting patiently for me to come. I remember that wonderful day in April 2013, I remember that moment when the plane was about to land and my knees started to shiver‚Ä¶.. I had a strange feeling that I am coming home but not going for a vacation to an amazing country with a very old and rich history. And I guess I was right‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ because 2 years later (as I was coming back over and over again to see my beloved Lisbon) I have relocated here.
I love this city and this amazing country for its marvellous landscapes, incredible beaches, breath-taking nature, magnificent sunsets and wonderful sky. Yes, sky. If you have travelled a lot I bet you noticed that sky and clouds in every country are different. But if you have been to Portugal at least once you will never forget its sky, because you will not be able to find something like that in any other place. I would like to share with you my impressions and experience from the places I have visited in Portugal, about the beauty of this country, its history, its architecture and its magnificent charisma, yes charisma because Portugal for me is not just a country, it is like a lifetime partner who is always happy with you, for you and feels saudade (beautiful juicy Portuguese word which actually has no direct translation but describes a deep emotional state of nostalgia for something or someone you really love, e.g. your motherland or beloved person, something important and significant) when you leave it.
For many years it was a forgotten city. It endured a very long dictatorship; and later it accumulated errors of urban planning. :) Nowadays Lisbon is a city with an odd geography comprising different villages, connected by a incomprehensible system of streets, alleys, lanes, travessas (small, narrow but very cosy streets) abandoned tram lines. Perhaps it is the city where it is impossible to make plans at all; because the city grabs you, hugs you and whispers to your ears lots of crazy ideas even if you have strict plans and you need to stick to them. You might have a walk downtown because you have an appointment there with a friend or a lesson of Portuguese language close to Rua Augusta but then‚Ä¶ suddenly you just make a turn to the street you haven‚Äôt been before to grab a coffee and suddenly beauty of new unknown street devours you completely, you call your friend and ask to join you immediately or you give a call to language school to reschedule the lesson because now you have to explore the beauty you haven‚Äôt seen before. And this is a way much more important than studying. :)
Lisbon loves you a lot, you feel this love, you swim at it, and you feel it with your heart, your skin, your fingertips and your soul. Lisbon hugs you and whispers wonderful words to your ears, he sings fado (incredibly beautiful traditional music and songs in Lisbon, which refers to saudade as originally fado are songs about loss and missing something important) for you, he offers you amazing food, and you feel overwhelmed with this city. That is how I felt from the very first minute I have spent in Lisbon. If you come here once and stay for living you realise that in this city you live like the days were never-ending and Lisbon is a boyfriend who does not forgive your absence. Because today you need to be in Gulbenkian museum because the new exhebition is just starting, and at the same day there is a wonderful indie rock band performing in Bairro Alto, and tomorrow you need to wake up early because you have classes but you have no time to study at all because this city offers so many things every day. You need to go to that new restaurant of seafood which has just opened downtown, then your friend has a launch of a book, then you were thinking of going to Alfama and making some great photos, and finally your friend from Germany is calling and saying that she has a day off and you need to go to Carcavelos for surfing. And you have so many things to do, which you REALLY need to do and you have an early morning yoga class. BUT, You cannot resist this city and you are never tired of all the activities he offers you and you cannot refuse all this as you might offend him. But your love for it is so huge and you need to be there for this city all the time so you just flow with it and its rythm.

Lisboa
Is a trip to Lisbon complete without a taste of Natas? or a trip to the Pena Palace? or a visit to the Tower of Belem popularly referred to by the locals as the Torre de Belem? I could go on and on because there is just so much to do in Lisbon in two days, which was all the time we had to spend there.
The visit to Lisbon, Portugal was a short and sweet one, with my oldest friend of 22 years. We spent the first night having a fancy dinner at the Tivoli restaurant (I recommend this restaurant, the service and food were amazing) on Liberdade avenue. Also on Liberdade avenue, you will find many name brand stores, as well as other 5-star hotels.
On the first day, we did a Lisbon city tour through a one hour Tuk Tuk ride. Frankly, I sometimes think this is a better option compared to the hop on hop off buses because of the intimacy and flexibility it offers. We rode through the Alfama district, stopped by the highest viewpoints in Lisbon for a phenomenal aerial view of the city. We went past the Cathedral church of Lisbon where several wedding ceremonies are conducted at once during the San Antonio Festival in June. We also went past the famous Cristiano Ronaldo Bistro and Bar, a stop for a drink at the bar would have been nice, but that did not happen.

Title: Sun, Surf, Sagres and Startup ‚Äî Lisbon Lifestyle
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
I arrived in Lisbon a little over one month ago to start my Erasmus semester abroad. I had previously not visited Lisbon but had heard incredible things, so when I arrived, I wanted to see it all for myself. I couldn‚Äôt wait to get out and get active making use of the last summer days in September/October. I found myself immersed by a city full of beautiful old buildings, cobbled streets (old streets of Alfama), viewpoints (Miradouro Santa Catarina, Nossa Senhora de Monte are two favourites) and rooftop bars at sunset (Park, Topo, LX), great contemporary art (Museu Cole√ß√£o Berardo) not to mention the surfing (Costa de Caparica) and most importantly the incredible nightlife here (cheap drinks in Bairro, great electronic music at Lux and a festival called Brunch). But hands down the best aspect of Erasmus is the exposure to new people, new cultures, new languages and most importantly new food!
But, me being me‚Ä¶I just can‚Äôt seem to ignore my keen interest in startup‚Äôs and Lisbon‚Äôs thriving ecosystems makes it even harder to ignore. Once I got confirmation of my place here at NOVA , I quickly added Web Summit to the list of ‚Äòmust-dos‚Äô whilst here. Building on my past work at Leade.rs and VivaTech earlier this year (check out my medium profile). I am very much looking forward to being part of their Live team covering social media for this momentous event ‚Äî boy do we have a task. Previously based in Dublin ‚Äî 2016 was the first year Lisbon hosted the event and what an event it was‚Ä¶attracting 53,000 people, 15,000 companies, 7,000 CEOs and 700 investors it became Europe‚Äôs largest tech conference, and it‚Äôs poised to grow in 2017. This all demonstrates that Lisbon is not only capable but eager and yearning to establish itself on the world stage as a leader in creativity, technology, and innovation.
Paddy Cosgrove Web Summit founder put it well‚Ä¶‚ÄòLisbon is like Berlin five years ago, but with a southern European climate.‚Äô
Currently Lisbon is a rising star and an underdog ‚Äî ranked by Allianz as the fifth-best-performing startup community in Europe, ahead of front-runners like Stockholm and Dublin. In fact, according to Preqin, the number of VC deals closed in Lisbon 2016 jumped sixfold from 2015, delivering it‚Äôs best year yet $18.5 million spread across 9 deals. But that is just the tip of the iceberg ‚Äî the Portuguese have had to make do without swaths of international investment which countries like the UK and Germany have received and that has translated into making Lisbon one of the best locations to bootstrap a startup.
One of Portugal‚Äôs main attractions is the combination of low-cost of living and high quality of life, two things that are very rarely found in one of Europe‚Äôs capital cities. On top of that, the OECD considered it the 3rd easiest country to start a company. This makes it makes it cheaper and easier to build great products utilising their highly skilled and ubiquitous talent. Fun fact: Lisbon has the highest percentage of founders with Masters or Ph.D. a whopping 82%.
Their rich history also plays its part, their Age of Discovery inspires a sense of exploration and due to Portugal‚Äôs small size; it fosters an outwardly focused mindset. It‚Äôs this very mindset which makes startups here think ‚Äòinternational from day one‚Äô giving them access to a larger addressable market, vital to startup scalability. According to the 2017 Startup Genome Report, Portuguese startups have high proportion of customers from outside Europe. A great example being F*ck Marry Kill, the gamified dating app, was founded in Lisbon but also enjoys popularity in German markets too. Furthermore, another advantage is how widespread and well spoken English is here, EF reports English proficiency at 59.68%.
Picture yourself ‚Äì considering all of the above whilst relaxing in the hot summer sun after a surf on a stunning beach; sipping a caipirinha and eating some freshly caught and perfectly cooked seafood ‚Äîthen you know how it feels to live in Portugal.
It‚Äôs international accessibility, low cost of living and enriching lifestyle is catching ever more attention of global talent and press. All of these factors coalesce to accelerate the momentum it has recently accumulated ‚Äî but to become sustainable, the ecosystem needs founders to nurture the next generation of entrepreneurs by spreading their knowledge and expertise through mentorship and re-investment.
A vital channel for mentorship, funding and networking is incubators such as, Beta-i producing 40 startups and raising more than $166million. They have worked with over 500 startups and run various acceleration programs, including Beta-start and Lisbon Challenge which attract applicants from 60 countries.
Canopy City a social impact-focused coworking space and incubator.
Impact Hub part innovation lab, part business incubator, and part community center.
BET Ventures an events company aimed at empowering entrepreneur‚Äôs.
StartUP Lisboa a government body focused on scale-up innovation. Check out their #ThisisPortugal campaign below.
Talkdesk, joined 500 startups ‚Äî received 21 million dollars of investment from Salesforce.Uniplaces, a disruptive force in the student accommodation industry that started in Lisbon and has spread to 30+ European cities ‚Äî raised $24 million Series A last NovemberCLICK HERE for more.
In many ways Lisbon feels like Europe‚Äôs version of San Francisco ‚Äî not to mention the look-a-like Golden Gate Bridge, tanned surfers, streetcars and hills (lucky no sharks though).
Sheffield‚Äôs Universities Portuguese partner and my host university, Nova School of Business and Economics is in the unique position of having a great interface with the Lisbon startup community due to their newly opened NOVA Venture Lab, running its flagship Zero Gravity incubator/accelerator programme designed to invest in and develop innovative startups both nationally and internationally.
This innovative mindset filters into their teaching here too. In particular one of the main driving forces behind this renewed perspective and practice is Miguel Mun√±oz Duarte my Entrepreneurship professor and CEO of iMatch an innovation, marketing and sales focused collaborative consultancy. He has great connections to the vibrant ecosystem here and often arranges guest speakers to shine some light on the practical workings of the methodologies and techniques that we learn. A great example of this was our first guest Christian Vismara ‚Äî a product manager at Build-Up Labs who came to talk to our class about his role there and specifically his work on F*ck Marry Kill.
First off, Build Up Labs is a Lisbon based Startup Studio also known as a Venture Builder ‚Äî they create startups from start to finish (wherever that may be). A Venture builder is an all in one ideation, building/development, and growth house. They leverage a lean process and a cross-disciplinary team using shared resources to grow successful businesses. Think of it as the diametric opposite of ‚Äòall your eggs in one basket‚Äô ‚Äî instead their approach is ‚Äòput lots of eggs in different basket and nurture them until they either fly or die.‚Äô
Recently parent Startup birdie (Build Up Labs) celebrated it‚Äôs first successful hatch and fly- in other words, their first exit with NVY.LIFE to L‚ÄôOreal, it‚Äôs a beauty and lifestyle club via blog/news/app ‚Äî they help readers to realise the best versions of themselves. Check it out HERE.
Christian however, talked a little more about F*ck Marry Kill (FMK) ‚Äî dubbed ‚ÄúTinder of the university students‚Äù by Jornal de Not√≠cias and as the name suggests, it‚Äôs not your standard dating service it‚Äôs a game that is designed not to be taking seriously and is best at making it more fun to meet new people. They are now attracting a growing and addicted user base in Portugal and Germany too. In total, they have 72,600 users and has already registered 1.2 million hits and more than 550,000 messages sent.
tapmyback ‚Äî a peer-to-peer motivation and feedback tool for teams. ToyToy a kids toy product discovery app.CLICK HERE to check out their Portfolio.
‚ÄúThe only thing worse than starting something and failing‚Ä¶is not starting.‚Äù ‚Äî Seth Godin
Startup is a game of failure and if you fail, you learn and if you learn, you succeed. At Build Up Labs they strongly head the words above. Un-afraid to talk about their past mistakes they view their failures as a portfolio of experience and after all, their motto is‚Ä¶
‚ÄúGrow fast or kill fast‚Äù
The venture building model was new and interesting to me, so after the great talk Christian gave; I approached him to find out more‚Ä¶I was invited to visit their office in the up-and-coming industrial end of town, Marvilla which is located in a co-working space called The Hood ‚Äî I was introduced to all the members of the team; Rui Gouveia CEO, Jo√£o Duarte data scientist, Jo√£o Pereira and Salvador Barros, I am really excited to help develop their social profile and produce an effective strategy.
CLICK HERE to find out more about the venture building model.
Finally, I have to say that I have never felt such a strong affinity to a city, let alone the one I luckily chose to study in. There is so much to do and see and it‚Äôs impossible to tire of it. A trip to Oporto is next on the agenda.
If you are reading this and you are;
A. interested in startup/tech/innovation
B. going to web summit C. need a social media helping hand.
Then reach out to me via email: t.dwyer193@gmail.com

Content:

Welcome to a new edition of the Tales of Ink and Light. In this one, i flip through the pages of a classic photobook and find echoes of the poetry that attracted me to Lisbon.
A decisive factor in my decision to move to Lisboa was the poetic atmosphere that i had felt while walking up and down its streets during a few short-ish stays. Often when i leave the house, i am unexpectedly reminded of that impalpable yet intensely real thing that exudes from the city.
I find it hard to define (and there is also the fact that i‚Äôd be reluctant to name it with precision, even if it were possible). It may be the colours of the walls, it may be the light, it may be a smell, it may be certain clothes people wear, it may be the sounds, it may be attitudes or certain sentences, and the river is certainly a part of it. It is these small things that suddenly appear to incarnate the soul of the place and make you think ‚Äî oh, yes, indeed, i‚Äôm here, this is it. It is the sort of inescapable feeling that seems impossible to describe and that you can only understand if you‚Äôve experienced it personally time and time again.
‚ÄòLisbon, you know‚Ä¶‚Äô is a sentence i read in a poem that appears in Lisboa, cidade triste e alegre (‚ÄòLisbon, sad and joyful city‚Äô), a photobook that started as a series of booklets sent to subscribers by post (at the time, it was a way to circumvent the censorship of the dictatorial regime) and later rose to fame after being prominently featured in Martin Parr and Gerry Badger‚Äôs History of the Photobook. A modern facsimile edition‚Ä¶

Content:

I‚Äôm just back from the WebSummit in Lisbon. I had never been to Lisbon before but I‚Äôve heard that they have great trails. As much as I‚Äôm a technerd and the WebSummit is an massive tech party with endless happenings, there was no way they were going to keep me off the trails all the week! I‚Äôve heard the call of the trails! I contacted WERIDE and booked a full day guided ride including rental bike, at the Sintra-Cascais Natural Park, approximately 25km north-west of Lisbon. I knew that I was pushing it doing a full day Enduro ride after three days of late nights and many drinks..But,
to bike or not to bike ‚Äî was not even the question..
I was picked up by Hugo, the owner of WERIDE who took me to Miguel, my guide for the day. My trail monster for the day was a YT Capra with an amazing √ñhlins rear shock. A Swedish rear shock for a rare Swedish guy, now that‚Äôs how you roll!
After an espresso and a Pastel de nata at the little town of Arneiro, we started the fifty minute non-stop climb up to the trailhead. It was raining and humid but the air was fresh and the surrounding forrest was green and lush. I had asked for Enduro, and enduro is what I got. No Enduro without the obligatory climbs before the fun..
The trailhead, and actually all trails in Sintra all starts next to ‚ÄúTholos do Monge‚Äù, a mass grave built in the Chalcolithic period (2300 BC / 2000 BC) at the top of one of the highest elevations of the Sierra de Sintra. From the top you have a network of 25 different Enduro/HD style trails all decending down the mountains in different directions.
It is very hard to describe the Sintra forrest. It is something like a cross-over between a jungle and a Mediterranean forrest. This coupled with a misty carpet hovering a few meters above your heads turns the whole ride into a mystical-magical journey.
After a fantastic descent on the trails filled with fun obstacles, drops and flow trails, we climbed back up again to connect to another fun DH trail. I stopped counting the climbs up and down the mountain but the fantastic descents was the reward for the long climbs.
After a well deserved freshly grilled mackerel lunch at ‚Äúthe Bikers Refugee‚Äù in the small city of Penedo, we started the devilish climb back up to the top for our final long descent.
The Donkey trail starts at the top on Peninha, a very remote and isolated chapel overlooking the Atlantic with stunning views.
Words cannot justify the stunning views around Peninha. But best of all is the amazing descent.
After all the climbs I was ready for the long, breath taking descent to the towards the sea.
What goes up must come down. And that is a good thing!
We finished off the ride with a cold beer where we had parked. It could not have been better.
I‚Äôm glad that I took a day off the WebSummit craziness for a ride in Sintra despite being very tired from the outset. It was an amazing experience. Magical forrest, endless cool trails and a fantastic guide. I can definitely recommend to anybody who wants to ride in Portugal to contact WERIDE. These guys are pure Pros, attentive, fun and can adapt to any rider style from beginners to Pro-riders. XC, DH or Enduro, whatever makes you tick. They also know how to spice up the ride with espresso, lunch and a beer just at the right time when you really need it. They have top level, state-of-the art well serviced bikes and are very affordable, so it makes absolutely no sense to bring your own bike.
They do: half-day, full-day rides and also organize multiple days or week long rides all over Portugal. They even have their on RVs for maximum comfort for the longer rides. Enduro Magazine just came back from a couple of days with them and published this great piece.
I will definitely come back and I recommend mountain bikers who are searching for their next adventure to go and discover Portugal. You will not regret it.
--
--

Investor & Entrepreneur. Former Facebook Exec. Passionate Mountain Biker. Lover of craft beers. Father of 5.

Title: Short-term Trip to Lisbon: what you need to know for the first visit
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
We just returned from a short business trip to Lisbon with my husband. It was our first time visiting the city, and I can‚Äôt help but share this story.
We visited Lisbon right after our relocation to The Azores, San Miguel Island. It‚Äôs also Portugal but far from the mainland and is located in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean but it‚Äôs another story‚Ä¶ Since we had not visited this country before it was interesting to compare both locations, and got to know the capital of Portugal and the mentality of the locals.
The airport is right in the city, 30 minutes from the center, which is very handy and saves you time.
The old part of the city is pretty compact and no need to use transportation. It‚Äôs very nice to walk around. By the way, did you know Lisbon is one of the oldest cities in the world? And it‚Äôs worth the stroll, but most of the main sights in Lisbon could be seen in 2 days.
Lisbon is a relatively compact city, but it‚Äôs still a good idea to stay as centrally as possible!
Chiado and once again Chiado, and the area surrounding it!!!
It has a really wonderful, relaxed vibe. Everything is extremely close here. We were staying at 9 Hotel Mercy and were completely satisfied with the location and hotel.
If you want to save some money you can choose areas a little farther from the center such as Avenidas Novas and Alcantara ‚Äî they are also good for long-term living. But in this case, you will need to use transportation.
The first thing I recommend after you leave the hotel is to have a glass of Vinho Verde ‚Äî ‚ÄúGreen wine‚Äù ‚Äî which is a traditional Portuguese wine produced exclusively in the northwest of the country. It is lightly sparkling and low in alcohol. It‚Äôs really good!
Ginjinha. Trying ginjinha in Lisbon is a travel must. Actually, it‚Äôs a cherry liqueur that originated in Lisbon. A lot of bars serve ginjinha in small cups made of dark chocolate. Drinking can be fun.
Below I‚Äôll share a list of dishes I‚Äôve tried, of course, it could be longer, but I was only there for a few days. Plus, we had excellent breakfasts at the hotel.
Perhaps I would have started listing famous tourist attractions in the past, but it‚Äôs not so important to me now. I don‚Äôt like the fuss about it. Besides, such places are always so crowded!
Instead of visiting the famous Elevador de Santa Justa, standing in an endless line, and then in the small and stuffy elevator car (I googled and saw pictures of tourists), I‚Äôll choose to sit in a nearby rooftop bar with a panoramic view of the same elevator and enjoy the wonderful view!!!
It‚Äôs good to read a few articles or watch a video before the trip to manage your expectations. Make a few marks on the map of places you want to visit.
I really couldn‚Äôt imagine traveling without a long list of must-see sights. But now I open up a google map with my marks on it and choose on the spot what place I want to visit depending on the mood. And that‚Äôs fine.
If I want to learn more about the city and its history, the best way to do it is to book a city tour for a few hours with a private guide who lives in this city and can share some personal stories from life.
From the beginning, it became clear that there was no point in comparing mainland Portugal and San Miguel Island. Yes, it is one country, but so different in so many ways!Generally, I like that Lisbon is lively enough and full of locals even in the city center. But a few things that were a little embarrassing to me are the tourists‚Äô and emigrants' way of behaving, and it wasn‚Äôt just downtown. I would describe it as unbridled and disrespectful which makes the atmosphere around a little bit cold and not friendly. These are my personal remarks you might not even notice it, but my empathy didn‚Äôt allow me to ignore such things.
This city is a really nice place for tourists, but I would think twice about long-term living.

Hello World! ‚Äî Excited to share with you how my first week in Lisbon with Remote Year went.
The City: Two words: Hills and Festivals. There are hills everywhere. Lisbon is the stairmaster city incarnate ‚Äî I swear, we are all going to have nice butts at the end of this month. June is also a great month to visit because of all the festivals! All the charming little districts (Alfama, Bica, Bairro Alto, Castelo & Mouraria) bring the party to the streets to celebrate St. Anthony. Grilled sardines, bread with sausage, red wine, music and entertainment fill the streets for the entiremonth.
The Workspace: It‚Äôs a 10 minute walk from my apartment and folks shuffle in and out depending on their schedules.
The Gym: Fitness Hut: a 3 minute walk from the workspace and 55 Euros for 5 weeks. The biggest adjustment for me (other than not having my trainer Cheyne to keep an eye on me) is having to ration your water because there are no water fountains! You‚Äôd think they‚Äôd want to make sure you stay hydrated‚Ä¶
The Routine: Currently non-existent. When I wake up, go to sleep, eat, work out, code, and study vary at different hours of the day every single day. I guess my routine is: Do what you want when you want ‚Äî I can‚Äôt lie, it‚Äôs fucking great.
The Work Situation: The UpWork profile is up but I‚Äôm having trouble even finding work to submit bids/proposals for. Most of the jobs require the freelancer to be physically located in the U.S and anything remotely related to Finance requires a lot of Strategy and Business Development experience, none of which I really have. I wallowed a bit for a few days: I realized that my resume was top-notch for a Corporate Finance job but unfortunately only that. Smaller and more nimble firms want someone that can not only manage Budget, Pacings, Close from an Operational side but also someone that can do Strategy, Business Dev and even some sales; coding experience would be a huge plus. It‚Äôs been a humbling experience for sure‚Ä¶
The Coding: The plan is to go through the free version of CodeAcademy (current progress at 35%) before I commit to the paid version. PluralSight was recommended as well so we‚Äôll see. Luckily, I‚Äôve got a team of software engineers on this program who are all so willing to help throughout this process.
Last but not least, the People: Remote Year Denali is a group of 40 amazing individuals, lead by our fearless leader and positivity unicorn, Erica. (She‚Äôs the one wearing the grey jacket on the bottom right of me in the photo below). Everyone is so incredibly talented, driven and passionate about making the most of both their careers and life ‚Äî it‚Äôs impossible to not feel inspired to do the same every single day. Back home, I‚Äôve always felt like the odd one out at work, always questioning things and always pushing the envelope because I wanted more: I wanted more to my career than what people decided for me and I wanted more to life than what I knew. I can‚Äôt tell you how incredible it feels to meet 39 other individuals who feel EXACTLY the same way.
Originally published at https://allthingslil.net on June 5, 2018.

Title: My Favorite Restaurants in Lisbon, Portugal (2022)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen

Lisbon is an incredible energetic place. And since I moved here, in 2016, the city has developed a lot and, fortunately, it continues to innovate.
One of the best parts of living in the capital is being able to closely follow the growth of the gastronomic scene, which is varied and full of good representative chefs.
It wasn‚Äôt an easy task, but I selected my all-time favorite restaurants, from the finest to the tradicional ones ‚Äî for all tastes and budgets.
Belcanto is one of the main references in the Portuguese gastronomy ‚Äî with 2 Michelin stars and in 42nd place on ‚ÄúThe World‚Äôs 50 Best Restaurants‚Äù list. If you are looking for an unforgettable experience, this is the place.
Of√≠cio is one of those restaurants that we want to take everyone to visit. They have a menu of sharable dishes and finger food that are absolutely delicious. My favorites: Spider Crab, Sea Vegetable Taco, Old-fashioned Oven Rice and, of course, the best dessert ever, the Cheese Tart by chef Hugo Candeias.
This Viennese coffee house makes me feel at home. They serve traditional Austrian dishes, like Wiener Schnitzel, and my favorite pastries, Apfelstrudel and the Sachertorte. On weekends, they also serve brunch.
Bairro do Avillez is divided into two main areas: Taberna (a more relaxed space, with small dishes, charcuterie and finger food) and P√°teo (a sea-food restaurant organized in two floors). My favorite dish is the Flaked Cod with Cornbread and Fried Egg. For dessert, my recommendations are Bairro‚Äôs Pavlova and the Olive Oil and Honey Pudding with Lemon Zest.
Tapisco is a mix of Spanish tapas and Portuguese cuisine, with a food menu that is meant to be shared. My recommendations: Tomato Bread with Jam√≥n Ib√©rico de Bellota, Salted Cod ‚Äú√Ä Br√°s‚Äù and the Dark Chocolate Mousse with Olive Oil and Fleur de Sel.
The first time I went to Osteria was on my first date with my boyfriend. The place is very cozy, and they serve authentic Italian food, prepared according to old family recipes. I highly recommend the Focaccia and the Pasta al Pesto di Rapa Rossa (picture above).
This is one of those restaurants that is always full of cool people. The highlight, which captures the attention of all who pass by, is the giant Instagram-famous Octopus sculpture dangling above the dining room like a nautical chandelier. The food is Peruvian inspired and the signature dish is ceviche (as the name says).
JncQUOI is located in a historic theater that was converted into a fashionable place, with a high-end men‚Äôs store, a DeliBar with gourmet store, and a restaurant. There you will find classic Portuguese and International dishes signed by Chef Ant√≥nio B√≥ia and a wine selection with over 500 references that promise to offer the best wine experience in the country.
Definitely the best sushi in Lisbon. It has the coolest bar area, an elegant dining room, and a beautiful garden for the warmer nights. If you can choose, I would recommend the sushi bar area, where you can see the magic happening. I‚Äôve tried the Tasting Menu, that includes the best selection of creative sushi, sashimi and miso ever. Not to mention the dessert selection, where sugar balance was the rule and things as lime, chocolate, pineapple and flowers were combined in perfect harmony.
Located on the riverside of Lisbon‚Äôs Bel√©m district, overlooking the Tejo River, the SUD Terrazza restaurant is influenced by Italian and Mediterranic cuisine. I highly recommend it for a romantic dinner or a family lunch. The view is amazing!
The Oriental Market is located in front of Martim Moniz Square and have lots of different food stalls. If you like Oriental food, this is the place. I recommend the first restaurant, right at the entrance on the left, and also the Mint House, on the second floor, with the best Pad Thai in Lisbon.
It was the smell of fresh pasta (and truffle) that led me to discover this restaurant, which is close to my house and has become one of my favorite Italian restaurants in Lisbon.
The environment is extremely cozy and the pasta is delicious. I‚Äôve returned several times and keep ordering the same dish over and over again: Tagliatelle al rag√π di carne. You need to try it!

I‚Äôll get into all that later, but for now, I‚Äôm writing this from the perspective of what I would do (and most things I did) when I travel solo, even if I technically traveled with someone.
In this post, I‚Äôll share my honest review and opinions of Lisbon, Portugal, and what it‚Äôs like for a solo female traveler. I‚Äôll also discuss some of the best things I saw, did, and ate while there.
I‚Äôll also be diving deep into the more personal aspects of this trip, including some of the biggest things I‚Äôve learned from my time there and some of the best people I met who have greatly inspired me.

Title: In love at first sight with Lisbon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
‚ÄúOnce you start travelling solo, you wouldn‚Äôt want to go back!‚Äù
It all began in the year 2019. My Easter Break was thoroughly planned out. I was visiting my friend in Finland, and we were going to backpack Estonia. The only problem: This trip started on Monday, and it did not feel right to waste the weekend. And that is how my first solo trip happened.
I chose to go to Lisbon for I heard a lot about it, as well as its proximity to Madrid. I took an overnight bus, spent 16 hours in the city and came back by another overnight bus, thus saving me time and money. I had pre-marked a few things I wanted to experience, like a ride on Tram 29 and visit Belem for sunset. As soon as I reached Lisbon at dusk, I was welcomed by a grey sky and drenched streets. However, it was my first solo trip, and I was too pumped up to let this deter me. So, I proceeded towards my first destination, the Santa-Justa funicular(lift). Most cities in Europe offer a one-day public transport pass and, I could use the same pass for the Funicular. The Santa-Justa funicular, standing at the height of 15 floors, was at the centre of the city. It offered splendid panoramic views of this beautiful city.
Right next to the Funicular was the ruins of the Igreja De Carmo, an ancient church that could not survive the Portuguese war. These ruins reminded me of the fact that chaos can be beautiful. After spending some time there, I proceeded towards the centre of Lisbon- The Sao Nicolau. It was an ancient marketplace, now a wide-open space with the view of the church of Sao Nicolau. Walking through the streets around looking at the Portuguese architecture was an out-of-the-world experience. I stopped for a ‚ÄúUma Bica‚Äù- the Portuguese coffee at one of the numerous cafes in the centre; this was not a typical espresso. The Portuguese roasting process is a bit different, giving the coffee a smoother texture.
Lisbon was one of the reasons I developed an interest in viewpoints. This city had so many of those that made it possible to get amazing views from different angles. Alfama was the second viewpoint, Santa Justa being the first one. Alfama was a little trek towards the top of the park, giving visibility of amazing landscape like the hanging houses. After sinking in the exhilarating beauty, I decided to board the Tram 29. Out of sheer luck on timing, this otherwise bustling tram station was empty. I hopped on the tram, and it took me around the city of Lisbon, and it was magnificent. Dense Portuguese architecture and the grey weather gave me the eighteenth century feels that I only felt from History textbooks. Tram 29 took me around the city, covering all landmarks, while I stood at the rear, looking through the glass with awe for an hour.
It was late afternoon when Tram 29 brought me back to the centre. I walked around the neighbourhood of Sacramento, exploring neighbourhoods, admiring the street art and local markets. By the time I covered quite aground, I had grown hungry. I was in the vicinity of Santa Catarina with no cafes nearby, except this small restaurant that had no customers. Finding vegetarian food initially in Europe was a problem. I went in hoping to find some food, and the kind chef inside asked me what I wanted. I told him that I was hungry and wanted vegetarian food. The guy‚Äôs exact words were ‚ÄúWe are closed right now, but its difficult to find vegetarian food around. We don‚Äôt have it in our menu either but Ill whip up something for you‚Äù. And he did. He made me a special vegetarian platter. My experience with Portuguese was outstanding since the beginning of the day, but this incident took my heart away.
After a hearty lunch, I walked towards Belem. Belem had a great beach, yacht-dock with impressive views and a cultural centre. I walked into the cultural centre, saw some exhibits, and learnt some cool titbits on Portuguese culture and history. After an hour in the museum, I walked outside, along the coast towards the monument of discoveries. That was an immense marble wonder, standing on the banks of Tagus river, dedicated to the wanderer and discoverer, Enrique. By this time, the weather was quite good, and the atmosphere was upbeat. I took a seat and napped of for an hour. Fifteen kilometres of city-walking was a tiresome feat.
As soon as I got up, it was sunset time. And Portugal, the Westernmost country of Europe, offered fantastic sunset views. So, I went to the best sunset point of the city, and the third viewpoint, the Jardim Sao Pedro de Alcantara, a cheery cliffside. For a moment, I paused and reflected what a beautiful sight this was. Orange sky, scents of spring, calm guitar music and cocktails to melt for, it was a perfect conclusion to my first solo trip.
It was a bit scary and took a lot of planning. It was also a test for my confidence and a dip in my savings. But it was totally worth it. For otherwise, I would not have discovered the joy of being called a solo traveller. ‚Äî I left a piece of my heart in Portugal.

The first day that I mostly recovered from jet-lag was the Sunday after I got in. I woke up around 11 and then just went for a walk.
I knew before I came here that my apartment would be decently small, but I hope that I won‚Äôt be spending too much time in it. A large motivation for coming to Lisbon was that I have a walk-able city with lots of spaces that I can work in. The only real part of my trip planning was scouting out some coworking spaces that might be good to integrate into my routine.
A little before Covid I heard about WeWork, their wacky CEO, and the company‚Äôs seemingly impending collapse. Before Covid I didn‚Äôt understand why anyone would pay someone money just to rent a desk or a conference room for an afternoon. If you don‚Äôt have to be in a specific office why wouldn‚Äôt you just work from your own place or a cafe or something?
BUT‚Ä¶ now I‚Äôm a fully remote worker and never have any real interest in going into the office (hardly anyone on my team even lives in Atlanta even if I did go in). I find it hard to focus in an office setting. I‚Äôve realized that I‚Äôm part of a weirdly new cohort of workers that have only had full-time work during/after Covid, and by extension during/after the normalization of remote work. I feel awkward going into the office for my work now. In part just because software engineering falls into the category of ‚Äúdeep work‚Äù. Most of the time a super productive software engineering day is when you have no meetings and can just keep your nose to the grindstone for as long as possible and hardly come up for air until you‚Äôre exhausted. This is how I usually worked on all my computer science classes in school.
Now when I rarely have gone into the office (probably less than 10 times total) I feel like an added layer of subconscious pressure to not only be productive, but also to LOOK productive and conform to arbitrary office culture quirks.
Do I look like I‚Äôm on my phone too much? How many times can I get up for the bathroom before people think I‚Äôm slacking off? If I were at home I‚Äôd take a shower and a nap and come back more productive right now. When can I leave for lunch without it being weird? How long can I actually take for lunch? Is it weird to have a YouTube podcast up while I work? Why can‚Äôt I wear shorts? The women in the office can wear skirts? Is it weird to be the only person in this quiet room on a call? Should I move into another room for this even if it‚Äôs just a few minutes?
Sure, most of these concerns are in my head and would likely evaporate after more than a handful of days in an office setting, but they NEVER come up when I‚Äôm working remote. I can just worry about the work. And I like that. The work is stimulating and enjoyable, and I don‚Äôt think I need much more than that out of my work.
The only thing I get out of an office setting is seeing people that I kind of know (not even on my team) walking through the room and the occasional two seconds of ‚Äúwater cooler talk‚Äù before trying to lock back in for 4‚Äì6 hours of straight programming.
Anyways ‚Ä¶ I say that all to say that I don‚Äôt really enjoy going into an office. But really a lot of my objection is going into MY office.
Coworking spaces seem to weirdly solve a lot of my general office anxieties. If these people in the room have no impact on my career why should I care at all what they think of the way that I work? The only exception is maybe for being on a call in a shared space, but usually there‚Äôs a clear separation of:
Before coming to Lisbon I researched a few coworking space options, in anticipation of my apartment being small enough to make me feel cooped up. Also, having a monthly membership that I‚Äôm paying for creates an incentive to actually leave my apartment everyday and walk around, which is half the reason that I came to Lisbon. It‚Äôs like having one of those alarm clocks that shreds money after enough snooze time.
On Sunday I woke up late and just walked around down into Lisbon.
I‚Äôve spent the last few months looking at neighborhoods on maps, but wanted to actually see them in person and then decide where I‚Äôd like to spend more time. I also wanted to verify all the generalizations that I‚Äôd heard about several neighborhoods through loose internet content.
There‚Äôs a main metro line that runs from my apartment, through the city, and down to the water. I spent my walk going along the path of the metro line, which also let me go by the two coworking space candidates that I‚Äôve narrowed down to (Second Home Lisbon and Heden Rossio).
Before I came to Lisbon and I was looking at the city on the map I think I subconsciously assumed that only some parts of the city were actually lively. Lisbon has almost exactly the same population as Atlanta, but I feel like I only ever saw large groups of people in Atlanta on campus, the interstate, and in a few popular dense areas. Parts of midtown, EAV, the mall, the battery, & the Beltline, these are always busy, but they‚Äôre pockets of the city that are dramatically spread out. I think subconsciously I assumed there would be a similar effect in Lisbon, but I was a little surprised while I was walking around that most places have lots of people all the time. At most there will be a pockets of a few blocks that are quiet, but the busier streets and squares are connected in a way that you‚Äôre never in a ‚Äúdead spot‚Äù. I feel like Atlanta (as well as most American cities) are mostly ‚Äúdead spots‚Äù with businesses sprinkled in between.
After my weekend walk I spent the first few weekdays sleeping in late and then working from my apartment. My girlfriend Lauren arrived for a week starting that Wednesday. We went to Paris to visit two of my friends for the weekend, but I‚Äôll write about that in my next post. That threw off settling into my schedule a little, but it was nice to have someone I know here with me for the first few days.
Now that I‚Äôve had a few days to sort-of adjust my sleep schedule and have a few normal work days, here is what I hope my daily routine will look like:
That‚Äôs what I HOPE my daily schedule will look like. Get some nice outside time while it‚Äôs still sunny. Maybe get to enjoy the city for a little before the sun sets before I‚Äôm out of work. What more could you ask for!?
But I‚Äôm afraid that most likely what will happen is I‚Äôll have slow mornings and just start working from my apartment, feeling like I‚Äôll waste time commuting to another location. And then I‚Äôll barely leave my apartment except to occasionally eat.
Am I scared of this because It‚Äôs exactly what happened the first week and the last few days?
‚Ä¶ maybe ‚Ä¶
There is still plenty of time for correction. This will be my first full uninterrupted week, so I‚Äôm hoping that will let me get into a good rhythm.
In general I think my time here can only go one of two ways.
It should be easy for the whole three months to be great. Get outside and walk around a lot more, eat good food, enjoy nice warm-but-not-hot weather, and pick up some Portuguese. There‚Äôs not really much more to say here.
Before I came to PT I knew there was a non-negligible chance that it could get unpleasant by the end. My sleep schedule might not ever be great, I might get bogged down in work, might not make any friends or have much interaction with native English speakers for a LONG time (arguably this could be more socially ‚Äúisolated‚Äù than I ever was during Covid where at least I was living with family or roommates).
I‚Äôm being a little dramatic. The most likely outcome is probably somewhere smack in the middle. But it‚Äôs still frightening to be right at the gate of three potentially very unpleasant months. I decided before I booked any plans that, at the end of the day, it‚Äôs ONLY three potentially unpleasant months.
I feel like I can probably tolerate almost anything for three months.
My walk on Sunday ended when I reached the ocean. Really they call it a river, but it‚Äôs more of a river-fed bay + peninsula situation similar to San Francisco. Hilariously there is also a bridge nearly identical to the Golden Gate.
AND they even have cable cars up the steeper hills like in San Francisco too!
I landed at a little square on the water with some tables and a little drink/snack ‚Äúquiosque‚Äù (kiosk), there‚Äôs lots of those here.
There was a live band setup in a circle playing Samba music. I knew they were serious when I heard one of them playing a flute, hardly any casual bands have flutes.
Here‚Äôs a short video I took of them when I sat down for a second.
I LOVE Samba and Bossa Nova. Here is one of my favorite songs.
A large reason why I came to Portugal is because I listen to so much Brazilian music and want to be more proficient with the language. I realized while I was listening to the band that this is the first time that I‚Äôve ever had the chance to hear music like this performed live. In my mind this kind of music is only still actively performed in Brazil, so I was a little shocked to just stumble upon a live performance on my first outing in Lisbon. I came to Portugal instead of Brazil because they speak a lot more English here and I figured Europe would be less of a culture shock, but also less of the music that I love.
We all have far more music now than ever before. Not just more access to music, but A LOT MORE being made (thanks internet). The tradeoff is that a lot less music is performed live, and what is still live is usually only small bands. I don‚Äôt that‚Äôs all bad, but it is unfortunate.
A lot of my favorite tracks are from large bands (here‚Äôs another favorite of mine and another with big bands). A lot of the complexity of Samba + Bossa Nova really comes through when you have the organized chaos of lots of really different instruments playing unusual rhythms all at once.
I love this music so much that I traveled to another country in large part to attempt to learn the language it‚Äôs performed in. And I just happened to stumble onto some of it on what I thought was the wrong side of the ocean.
Later I walked by again and a big crowd had gathered and people were starting to dance.
The band was amazingly proficient. They play in that square every weekend with a rotating cast of performers.
I sat, and listened, and teared up for a second.
I‚Äôm really lucky.
I think this trip will go well.

Title: Living like a Local in Lisbon. Portugal.
Content:

Sign up

Share
Living Like A Local In Lisbon, Portugal ‚Äî a city of cobbled roads and colourful tram rides.
A place of allure with its unique charm, symmetrically laid Portuguese pavements, brightly painted buildings and viewpoints that reveal layers of terracotta rooftops intermixed with tall church steeples, you can lose your heart to this European city that effortlessly blends traditional heritage with modern design and progressive thinking.
Portugal‚Äôs hilly, coastal capital city sits on the Tagus River with the Ponte 25 de Abril suspension bridge linking its banks. Its beauty takes on all shades of wonder, intrigue, architecture and history and it is famed for its many viewpoints, the most impressive being from S√£o Jorge Castle.
Long-drawn to see the city, I recently bought an air ticket, booked an apartment and spent a month living like a local in the historic Alfama district, and once familiar, in more residential Santos. Arriving with no plans other than to immerse myself into the local living, that is exactly what I did.
Among the attractions discovered were the National Azulejo Museum displaying five centuries of decorative ceramic tiles. In trendy Belem, the Museum of Art, Architecture and Technology (MAAT) is where these three areas intertwine within a space of debate and dialogue. I took time to listen to Fado music and learn more about its origins, visited the Museu do Aljube that showcases Portugal under dictatorship and the country‚Äôs subsequent struggle for freedom and democracy, spent time in the impressive Maritime Museum and lingered in art galleries.
From the imposing S√£o Jorge Castle ‚Äî which is worth walking up to ‚Äî the view encompasses the old city‚Äôs pastel-coloured buildings and Tagus Estuary. Be sure to take a trip across the river to see the Cristo Rei statue ‚Äî you‚Äôd be forgiven for thinking you were in Rio ‚Äî as well as a closer look at residential Almada.
Just outside Lisbon you‚Äôll find a string of Atlantic beaches, from Cascais to Estoril and further inland the charming royal sanctuary resort town on the foothills of Portugal‚Äôs Sintra Mountains, Sintra.
I spent much time at the LX Factory, a regenerated creative island that is home to fashion, food, fine arts, music, and one of the best bookshops I‚Äôve ever seen. I walked for hours to familiarise myself with the lay of the land seeking out the best examples of Cal√ßada Portuguesa pavements and photographing street art. I lingered in restaurants and cafes, shopped at local markets and ate more pasteis de nata than I care to admit to.
Views across the city from the top of Elevador de Santa Justa in the heart of the city are unbeatable. On the popular Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio you‚Äôll find the iconic Rua Augusta Arch, a historical building and visitor attraction built to commemorate the city‚Äôs reconstruction after the 1755 earthquake. Built to resemble the shape of a caravel, the massive, the angular Monument to the Discoveries is a prominent feature of the Belem waterfront well worth seeing.
I‚Äôm already planning my return trip for more, and could quite easily join the half a million lucky ones who get to call Lisboa home. This is a city to live in, no matter the length of your stay, make it your home for those days and pretend you‚Äôre a local soaking up the old-fashioned laidback of this inviting European city.
Getting there: There may not be direct flights to Lisbon from South Africa, but that shouldn‚Äôt deter as many European airlines service the Lisbon Airport, and you can get there from Cape Town or Johannesburg with just one connection. Alternately, the very affordable TAAG Angola Airlines offers easy access via Luanda.
Visas: South African passport holders require a Schengen Visa to visit Portugal.
Accommodation: A wide variety of accommodation options exist, be it for a luxury hotel, or Airbnb apartment. The best areas to base yourself are historic Alfama, Rossio in the heart of the city, Baixa for shopping and the charming Bairro Alto.
Don‚Äôt miss: Arguably the best past√©is de nata in the city can be found at the small bustling Manteigaria, Time Out Market Lisboa.
*** This story first appeared in the newly released SA and Beyond printed magazine. Read my other published articles here.
*** I travelled by my own account on a personal visit, all opinions are my own.
Originally published at http://theincidentaltourist.com on October 18, 2019.

Title: EATING OUT IN LISBON: HOW NOT TO GET RIPPED-OFF.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Who would have known that Portuguese waiters are so smart? They know how to trick tourists into spending more money. Oh Lord, they know how to do it well too!
A few weeks ago, I visited Lisbon. Lovely city.
Everybody speaks a pretty good level of English, so it‚Äôs very easy to communicate when you find yourself lost over the shore, or somewhere between the tiny bohemian uphill streets, or in the subway, or even between shelves of a 24hr grocery store. Yes, I have a terrible sense of direction. And yes, I get lost a lot.
Lisbonian people are not extremely nice or talkative like Spaniards, but they will answer calmly every stupid-sounding question you may have about the dish you are just about to order. They will politely, but with no smile on their face, explain what type of ticket you should or should not buy to get to a certain area of the city. At some point I felt as if I were in Spain, but instead of Spaniards, everyone was German.
I figured they are just different. Would saying they are more civilised offend my Spanish friends? If so, then forget it. Let‚Äôs say they are just more quiet and ‚Äòminding their own business‚Äô all the time.
But when it comes to ripping off tourists, they are masters. They have mastered the art so well; even I got tricked.
Because you know, I don‚Äôt travel like a run-of-the mill tourist. You knew it right?? RIGHT?? A real fan of The Tripventurist should be aware of that! Anywho, I hope I‚Äôve made myself clear.
I can‚Äôt even remember the last time I was ripped-off. I generally keep my eyes wide open, my money deep down in my pocket, and pay only fair prices while traveling. But somehow I let my guard down just for a second and bam-smash, 10 extra euros added to a 12 euros bill. Almost double what I was going to pay in the first place.
You wanna know why, how and where?
My lovely workmate Nazaret and I were wandering through the teeny-tiny streets of Lisbon on a Monday night after a long day mastering our networking skills at a business conference.
We were trying to find a decent restaurant. Please note, we were starving to death and every place we found was touristy looking and run by Turkish men (who we wouldn‚Äôt trust preparing our food). Or pizza places.
Nazaret kept refusing the first ones, and I would keep saying NO to pizza places.
We got ourselves into a tie.
At one point I briefly thought about checking trashcans for leftovers but I zipped my lip, didn‚Äôt share the idea with Nazaret, and kept walking.
It was a daunting task I must say, but we were still trying hard to keep our spirits up while faking smiles.
And then, out of the blue, a tiny restaurant appeared on the corner of the street. It was a sign from heaven.
You can‚Äôt even imagine how excited we got. Even though we kept our cool while entering the place, I knew Nazaret wanted to hug me. And I wanted to hug her too. That‚Äôs how happy we were about finding a quiet, tasty-looking place and finally being fed.
A nice chatty elderly waitress approached our little table and brought us a plate full of tiny round cheeses. By the labels, we learned that these were local goat, sheep and cow cheeses. A kind of delicatessen you might say. We were positively surprised by their hospitality and the fact that they were promoting local products by offering them as a free appetizer, before we‚Äôd even started looking at the menu.
I am not a cheese person but my not fed for 12 hours body gobbled half of the dish immediately. And Nazaret stuffed her face with the remaining half.
A bit happier, we both ordered soup as a first course and decided to split a second course: fried fish with a huge salad and boiled potatoes. No dessert. We were happily full once we‚Äôd finished the second course and the Portuguese white wine.
Since the place was so small, we got into a conversation with the guys dining next to us. Entrepreneurs from Italy, based in Berlin, surf addicted ‚Äî funny and cute.
Nice evening.
Until we were handed the bill.
According to the prices we saw on the menu, our bill was supposed to be around 12 euros. But magically it had been almost duplicated.
We were being charged almost 10 euros for the free treat of cheeses.
Well, it was not a treat anymore. Now it was a rip-off.
Our jaws dropped at the same time. We had been tricked into paying 10 euros for something we hadn‚Äôt ordered in the first place. What‚Äôs more, I am sure it would probably have cost us less than 4 euros in the closest grocery store.
It was a well-paid lesson on local customs, I must say.
At first, we thought it was a ‚Äúdick move‚Äù toward tourists. And we furiously shared the story with every single person we met the next day ‚Äî all of them foreigners attending a business conference like us. Until one of the local entrepreneur explained that this is how things work in Portugal.
Apparently, every single appetizer served the moment you‚Äôre sitting your ass on a chair in a restaurant, will always be charged (a large amount of money).
My Poland-born, Spain-raised mind can‚Äôt understand that. I mean why? Why on Earth?
We were instructed by the local entrepreneur that you won‚Äôt be charged for appetizers unless you touch them.
So guys, if you are in Portugal and a big bottle of Moet champagne lands on your table, do not touch it unless you want an additional 200 euros on your 20 euros dinner bill.
And during the next 3 days, we mastered the skill of screaming ‚ÄúNO NO NO NO NO!!‚Äù to every single waitress approaching us with a plate of cheese or olives, or bread sticks.
Thanks for the lesson in assertiveness, Lisbon!

#Madrid-based #travel blogger with horrible sense of direction. Self taught chef, hooked on hiking and #yoga.

‚ÄúWhen friends come to visit our family in Lisbon, they always say that they don‚Äôt want us to make a big fuss. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt need to do anything special. We just want to see you.‚Äù On the surface this is an endearing and considerate sentiment. It‚Äôs also code for, ‚Äúlet‚Äôs not go out for every meal.‚Äù At first, this is a relief. Dragging (in this case 10 total) people around the city for every meal is a daunting endeavor.‚Äù
Why Restaurants Cringe at "Party of 10" During Rush Hour:
Imagine the scene: it‚Äôs 7 p.m. on a Friday night, the dining room is buzzing with chatter, servers are weaving through tables with plates stacked high, and the kitchen is a symphony of sizzling pans and shouted orders.
‚Ä¢	Then, the phone rings‚Äîor worse, a group strolls in unannounced‚Äîand the host hears those dreaded words: "Party of 10."
‚Ä¢	During rush hour, a large party can send a ripple of unease through even the most seasoned restaurant staff.
‚Ä¢	While customers might see it as just a fun night out, for the restaurant, it‚Äôs a logistical puzzle that threatens to disrupt the delicate balance of service, space, and sanity. So why exactly do restaurants cringe when they hear "party of 10" during their busiest hours?
1.	There‚Äôs the issue of space. Most restaurants are designed to maximize seating efficiency, with tables arranged to accommodate couples, families of four, or small groups.
a.	A party of 10 often requires pushing tables together or commandeering a section of the dining room, which can throw off the floor plan.
b.	During rush hour, when every seat is precious, this reconfiguration might mean turning away smaller, quicker-turnover parties.
c.	A group of two can be seated, served, and out the door in an hour, while a party of 10 might linger for two or more, tying up valuable real estate. In a business where profit margins are notoriously thin‚Äîoften hovering around 3-5%‚Äîlosing that turnover can sting.
2.	Then there‚Äôs the strain on the staff. A party of 10 isn‚Äôt just one table; it‚Äôs a mini-event. Servers must coordinate multiple orders, ensuring drinks, appetizers, and entrees arrive in sync, all while juggling their other tables.
a.	In the kitchen, a sudden influx of 10 orders hitting the line at once can bottleneck the flow, especially if the group‚Äôs requests include substitutions, split checks, or special dietary needs.
b.	Rush hour is already a high-wire act for cooks and servers; a large party can feel like someone tossing an extra ball into the juggling routine.
c.	Mistakes pile up, tempers flare, and the domino effect can leave other diners waiting longer, their Yelp reviews growing sharper by the minute.
3.	Timing is another culprit. Large groups often move at a different pace than the restaurant‚Äôs rhythm.
a.	While smaller tables align with the quick, steady cadence of rush hour‚Äîorder, eat, pay, leave‚Äîa party of 10 might dawdle over drinks, debate entrees, or wait for stragglers to arrive. This unpredictability clashes with the precision restaurants rely on during peak times.
b.	A table that‚Äôs out of sync can disrupt reservations, extend wait times, and leave the host scrambling to explain why the next party‚Äôs table isn‚Äôt ready.
c.	It‚Äôs not just about serving food; it‚Äôs about keeping the machine running smoothly, and a big group can throw a wrench into the gears.
d.	There‚Äôs the unspoken pressure of expectations. Large parties often arrive with a festive mindset‚Äîbirthdays, reunions, celebrations‚Äîexpecting the restaurant to match their energy with flawless service and Instagram-worthy presentation.
e.	But during rush hour, staff are stretched thin, and that extra attention can feel like a tall order. A single misstep‚Äîa forgotten side dish, a delayed refill‚Äîcan sour the mood of 10 people at once, amplifying the fallout.
f.	One unhappy diner might grumble quietly; 10 unhappy diners can turn a table into a chorus of complaints, complete with a generous tip deduction.
4.	Restaurants don‚Äôt hate large parties outright. Many welcome them during slower hours, when staff can lavish attention and kitchens can flex their creativity.
a.	But during rush hour, "party of 10" isn‚Äôt just a reservation‚Äîit‚Äôs a test of endurance. It‚Äôs a high-stakes gamble that the team can pull off without sacrificing the experience of every other guest in the room.
b.	So the next time you call for a big table at peak time, spare a thought for the host‚Äôs tight smile or the server‚Äôs quick glance at the clock. They‚Äôre not ungrateful for your business‚Äîthey‚Äôre just bracing for the storm.
It‚Äôs not the size of the party that‚Äôs the problem‚Äîit‚Äôs the timing. With a little consideration, even a party of 10 can be a welcome guest instead of a rush-hour nightmare. (Grok & DeepSeek AI)

Title: Lisbon with the Children: Even Better Than Expected
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
December 2023
The children and I have developed an annual holiday excursion tradition. Tampa, San Diego, a nice Air BNB out in sticks in Maryland, then Cabo, and now Portugal.
We arrived in Lisbon in the early morning on Christmas Day. After a short Uber ride to the very nice Intercontinental Hotel, having flown overnight with little to no sleep, we got some rest. My oldest and I explored the area as her younger siblings remained asleep. Despite the lack of help from our concierge, we discovered a humongous holiday festival across the street from our hotel. It was lovely. Probably more than 10,000 people visiting the numerous food and trinket vending stations, skating, children's rides, a big Ferris Wheel and gigantic Christmas Tree.
Lisbon is a vibrant, very diverse city of nearly 600,000 residents and a metro area of 3 million people. Add to that an inexpensive city with fabulous wine and food, whose people seem to all also speak English, a short seven-hour flight from New York, and it all makes for an attractive option for retirement locations.
Our first full day was an hour‚Äôs long walk through several neighborhoods to get a feel and view of the city and eventually to Jardim Zoological (Zoo Gardens). The large animal park was far more impressive than what appeared on the outside, which would become a common theme.
Having had just an okay meal for Christmas dinner, we decided to eat at our hotel restaurant, Akra, a fine dining establishment that did not disappoint.
Day three took us to more traditional tourist attractions. The iconic Belem Tower, built 500 years ago in gothic style as a small military fort, it is still gleaming white on the banks of the Tagus River. Then a brisk walk in the cold to the Belem Cultural Center and Museum of Contemporary Art. Like nearly every activity in Portugal this trip, the art museum was far larger and better than expected.
A few blocks away was the Jeronimos Monastery, the imposing structure so beautiful the crowds it drew on this cold day to tour the inside made the queue (line) so long we decided just to take a few pics outside.
Taking advantage of how much my children were into the learning and culture, we kept it going with a visit to the Museum of Art, Architecture and Technology (MAAT) ‚Äî a massive two-in-one museum that combined more art, a huge exhibit on the coal burning factory the building used to be, and a well-done display on the evolution of climate change. Then to the second building featured an incredible art installation of the work of Joana Vasconcelos.
We capped the day with a visit to the Lisboa Time Out Market, the lively, packed-to-the-brim food and wine mart with scrumptious options for everyone.
The original plan for the next day was a train ride to Sintra, but a late start changed things up. We‚Äôd keep the museum vibe going with an interesting ride to the National Tile Museum.
Despite being a first-class city, Lisbon is still the capital of a second-world country and just beyond the splendor of the many tourist attractions of hundreds of years old limestone construction, there are working-class communities, grit, and a ton of graffiti. It all actually brings more appeal to Lisbon.
The National Tile Museum epitomized our more than we expected Portugal experience. The museum is deceptively large, with several floors of exhibits. Extremely impressive craftsmanship dating back more than 500 years. Art including many hundreds of individual tiles that depict Biblical scenes or provincial gardens. There were also more modern tiles with colorful artistic designs. One of the most impressive pieces was a nearly three hundred-year-old tile installation that takes up two large walls displaying the Lisbon shoreline and surrounding neighborhoods with such detail it could be used as a map.
The tile museum is connected to an old Catholic church built in the 1500‚Äôs, fully intact and open to visitors. The ostentatious sanctuary is similar to those built throughout Europe during that age.
After several hours of viewing beautiful tiles, we traveled to the chic LX Factory for shopping and dinner. Then another Uber back to the hotel. Uber has figured something out in Lisbon. No matter where we were, tourist district or further out, of the ten Ubers we took on this trip, not one of them had more than a 3-minute wait and most were 1‚Äì2 minutes.
Our delayed day trip to the nearby town of Sintra did not disappoint. Worried the crowds would swell on the weekend, we were still able to avoid most of the long queues to see the amazing castles and palaces from what was the first center of European Romantic architecture in the 19th century.
There is the Moorish castle that can be seen from anywhere in Sintra, the vibrant colored Pena Palace, several ornate chalets, plus gorgeous beaches on the other side of the city.
We took it all in while riding in sleek, self-guided, two-person vehicles we rented.
We returned the cars a few minutes past our five-hour allocated time, especially after a few wrong turns that I made trying to make sense of the GPS directions on the foreign, winding, thin streets.
The train ride into Sintra gave us a glimpse, but the nighttime train ride back to Lisbon was even more revealing. The suburbs between Lisbon and Sintra are full with Cape Verdeans. Like other European cities, and the converse to what America did with White flight in the 50s and 60s, poor immigrants of color are housed on the outskirts of the major cities, tucked away in very large apartment complexes that we‚Äôd call projects in the States.
Cape Verde is a small island nation off the west coast of Africa that was colonized by Portugal. Cape Verde‚Äôs government says that 300,000 of its countrymen now call Portugal home. While the vast majority of Black people in the Lisbon region are Cape Verdean, there are also people from a few other African countries Portugal colonized, like Mozambique and Angola. And there is a growing population of American expats of all races.
Our last day was relaxed and mostly unstructured. After our daily hotel breakfast buffet that was included with our rooms, we all went back to sleep briefly. Then a short Uber ride to the Pra√ßa do Com√©rcio Square, the largest and most popular square in Lisbon and a major tourist attraction.
Then we basically shopped till we dropped. A few hours of perusing and occasionally buying at the continuous string of shops along the route to Santa Justa Lift then more shopping at an adjacent district up the hill to the Bairro Alto neighborhood, known for its saturation of bars, clubs, and restaurants. A delicious Mediterranean dinner that was yet another high quality, high quantity, very inexpensive meal. We walked it off with an evening stroll back to the hotel. The girls would later head back to Bairro Alto to hang out at a few of the pubs we had walked past. Their very late night almost caused them to miss our morning flight. But we all made it.
An amazing week in Portugal. Even better than expected!
--

2021 was an unbelievably surprising year! At least for me. One of the biggest surprises of this year was discovering the Digital Nomad lifestyle and learning more about it.
I had an opportunity to work remotely from June this year. I was like, alright, it‚Äôs time to get creative now and explore something new! Awesome, right?!
After thinking for like 5 minutes, I decided to spend a couple of months in Lisbon and work from there. Because, why not? I mean, the food is good, they have a great culture, and the people are awesome. Deal!
To give you more clarity, I‚Äôm Content Creator. I love exploring new places that inspire me to generate new ideas. I never miss a chance to meet new people or learn about new things.
So I just bought a one-way ticket from Tallinn(that‚Äôs where I‚Äôm based generally) to Lisbon and decided to see how my life would go.
What a fantastic decision! I loved every second of my experience there. I met soo many incredible people and learned more about‚Ä¶
