Title: Eight Days in Portugal: Porto, Lisbon, & Sintra
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Portugal is a small but mighty country, offering varied landscapes and idyllic scenery at every turn, as you can hop from a medieval castle to a golden beach to a bustling city in less than a day. Whether your priority is food, relaxation, nightlife, or history, you can satiate all of these interests (and more) in Portugal. While I would have loved to spend weeks here, our eight day trip to Porto and Lisbon (with a day trip to Sintra) was wildly fulfilling. We‚Äôre already dreaming about our next visit, this time to the southern tip of the country, along the beaches of Faro and Albufeira‚Ä¶
Porto is windy and whimsical, filled to the brim with delicious (and gloriously cheap) wine, sumptuous food, sweeping views, and loads of charm. Porto certainly has ‚Äúattractions,‚Äù but the best way to experience the city is by simply wandering at a leisurely pace, drinking wine on the riverfront, snacking on petiscos, riding the tram and hopping off whenever you feel inspired, and endlessly pursuing a new vantage point over the city. We spent three nights in this hilly city and could have easily spent a handful more. We‚Äôll certainly be back.
We flew into Lisbon‚Äôs airport and immediately went to the Santa Apolonia train station to catch a train to Porto (to the Porto Campanha station). Trains run pretty frequently throughout the day and don‚Äôt need to be purchased in advance (we bought ours literally seven minutes before the train departed). Though it made for a long travel day, we decided to head to Porto first thing so that we didn‚Äôt have to worry about taking an aggressively early train back to Lisbon for our morning flight on our last day.
We stayed at this delightful Airbnb on a charming car-free street in the heart of the city, filled at all times of day with revelers, street musicians, and wandering pedestrians (it can certainly get noisy, but as New Yorkers, we were completely unfazed). As we worked remotely for half of our time in Porto, we loved the sun exposure and fantastic light ‚Äî it was also lovely to be able to open the French doors and get fresh air. If there‚Äôs a better Porto apartment out there, I‚Äôd like to see it.
Dom Luis Bridge: This bridge is in the foreground of all the most iconic images of Porto, and for good reason. The bridge should be explored and admired both down by the water (the Ribeira) and by walking across (ideally the top level, which you can reach by hiking up to the Cathedral ‚Äî the entrance to the bridge is right next to it). The top level of the bridge can get extremely windy and a bit vertigo-inducing (it‚Äôs really high!) but man, the views are epic. It‚Äôs a short walk across the bridge but will probably take at least 20 minutes, since you‚Äôll be stopping to take pictures every two seconds. After you cross, you‚Äôll end up in the town of Vila Nova de Gaia, where you can stroll along the waterfront looking back over to Porto (this is also where all of the port houses are located).
Port Tour: Whatever your feelings about port might be (mine are admittedly rather lukewarm), you can‚Äôt visit Porto without booking a port tour. While there are several satisfaction-guaranteed options, we decided to book a tour at Graham‚Äôs based on a friend‚Äôs recommendation. The grounds are immaculate, the view of the city is beautiful, and the tour is engaging and informative. We each sampled four different ports, and while I still can‚Äôt say it‚Äôs something I will actively seek out, I now certainly appreciate the nuances in the different categories of port, and the precise way in which they‚Äôre all made.
Porto Cathedral: The best part of the cathedral is the view of Porto, as it‚Äôs perched high above the city (and requires a fairly steep climb). I found the interior of the cathedral to be a bit unimpressive, and instead appreciated the imposing exterior and the views over Porto‚Äôs terra cotta rooftops.
Cl√©rigos Tower: This baroque, slightly odd-looking clock tower is the tallest in Portugal, and affords stunning 360 views of the entire city. Definitely worth the price of admission.
Foz do Douro: Take the old-school tram (el√©ctrico) from Infante (water-front Ribeira area) to Passeio Alegre. You‚Äôll feel like you‚Äôre in another world all together; in just 20 minutes you‚Äôre transported from the city to the beautiful beachy waterfront. Walk out to the Felgueiras lighthouse, situated at the edge of the Douro River and the Atlantic coastline of Foz do Douro, for some epic waves crashing against the pier (but seriously, be careful ‚Äî the waves can take you with them). If you have time, continue your seashore walk up to Matosinhos, where you can grab an ice cream at Bar Tit√£. Matosinhos is also home to some great fish and seafood restaurants (as one would expect), especially at Rua Her√≥is de Fran√ßa, where you can find the cooks grilling the fish outside.
Armazem: If you have only a day or two in Porto, you can skip this, but if you‚Äôre in Porto for 3+ days, an antiques fiend, and/or missing Brooklyn, I‚Äôd add this to your list. It‚Äôs basically a massive antiques shop in a warehouse, complete with a hip(ster) bar (both indoors and outdoors). You can definitely do some fun (read: tipsy) shopping here.
Taberna dos Mercadores: Stop what you‚Äôre doing and make a reservation at this place. No, you can‚Äôt make a reservation online, but get over it and call this number immediately: +351 22 201 0510. It will be the best meal of your trip. Order the clams a bulhao pato and (this is absolutely essential) the arroz com polvo. You will never have experienced anything like it and might never again.
Casa Guedes: Check out this small little shop for a pulled pork sandwich that will blow your mind. Don‚Äôt be alarmed if there‚Äôs a long line (it‚Äôs worth the wait, and it doesn‚Äôt take too long.) Ask for the Sande de Pernil com Queijo. If you really want to live like a local, order a glass of Tinto Bruto (a sparkling red wine) to accompany your sandwich.
Brasao Cervejaria: You can‚Äôt leave Porto without trying the Francesinha, an insane croque madame-like concoction that‚Äôs made with thick bread, Portuguese sausage and steak, then covered in cheese and drowned in a special tomato and beer sauce. Nearly every eating establishment in Porto will proclaim they have the best (and you can wait in line for an hour at Cafe Santiago with other tourists for ‚Äúthe best‚Äù), but our friend who lives in Porto recommended this joint (which takes reservations and involves no wait), and I can‚Äôt really imagine it being better. Protip: order the half size. You absolutely do not need a full serving.
Maioral: If you are itching for a true local experience devoid of tourists, head up to Maioral, a nondescript little place right by the water, a 20 minute drive north of downtown. Our friend (who lives in Porto) took us here for an authentic Portuguese experience, full of the freshest fish and the cheapest (but most delicious) wine.
O Paparico: If you‚Äôre looking for a fine dining experience or a special occasion meal, O Paparico has you covered. It‚Äôs a bit out of the way (about a 15-minute cab ride north of town) and quite pricey, but it‚Äôs a worthy splurge. It‚Äôs romantically rustic and feels upscale (read: white linen) yet totally unpretentious. The service is impeccable, and each dish of the tasting menu is carefully arranged to give you a taste of traditional Portuguese cuisine, but with an inventive twist. After the meal, I echoed the surprise of many other reviewers who are baffled by the fact that it lacks a Michelin star (only four Porto restaurants hold this honor). It seems poised to earn this distinction in the near future.
Bacalhau: Nothing life-changing, but immediately after arriving in Porto we sat on the riverfront and enjoyed a fantastic meat & cheese plate and glasses of crisp white Porto wines. We also sampled their namesake (the bacalhau), which was tasty but nothing to write home about. Overall though, we were more than happy with the outcome.
Base: This is an awesome outdoor bar (and caf√©) right at the base of Cl√©rigos Tower. We grabbed a couple of espressos and enjoyed their bangin‚Äô playlist (I Shazam-ed nearly every song).
Wine Quay Bar: Cozy, intimate little wine bar situated overlooking the Douro River. The wine selection is extensive and on point, rivaled only by the views.
For a bit more of a scene, check out Bonaparte Downtown. It‚Äôs not necessarily anything special, but our local friend from Porto brought us here and we enjoyed the low-key Irish pub vibes.
If we‚Äôd had more time in Porto, there‚Äôs no doubt we would have booked a cruise down the Douro Valley and visited some wineries. It‚Äôs stunningly beautiful, and I‚Äôd highly recommend looking into a day trip. This cruise was recommended to us by our friend who lives in Porto.
Lisbon is Europe‚Äôs capital of cool, and it‚Äôs certainly trying pretty hard. Where Porto is quaint and understated, Lisbon is sprawling and occasionally flashy. The tourist crowds are mostly unobtrusive in Porto, whereas in Lisbon they are swarming and unavoidable. And, the food in Porto simply is better (many a Lisbon native will attest to this). However, Lisbon saddles up right next to its rival by boasting stunning panoramas (reached but punishing yet ultimately rewarding hills), a unique blend of charm and grittiness (cobblestone alleyways juxtaposed against graffiti-saturated walls), an impressive foodie scene (led fearlessly by national treasure Jose Avillez), and breathtaking sights just short train rides away (the monument-filled Belem and the absolutely surreal Sintra). Yet the most magical part of Lisbon is the most simple: one of my favorite experiences in the city was staring out onto the water from Miradouro da Gra√ßa ‚Äî drinking a beer, wrapped in a blanket, listening to the music of the church bells, and watching the sun set dramatically over the rooftops.
We arrived in Lisbon via train from Porto, arriving at the Santa Apolonia station from Porto Campanha. If you‚Äôre arriving from the airport, it‚Äôs an easy metro ride into the city, or a 20-minute cab ride. Uber is common and relatively cheap as a means of transport throughout the city, averaging 5 Euros per trip for really anywhere you‚Äôd want to go. For Tram rides, you‚Äôll need to purchase a metro card in advance, either in a metro station or at any number of kiosks (we found one in Pra√ßa da Figueira).
For five nights, we stayed at this Airbnb in the Baixa neighborhood, pretty much in the center of the city, right on the Pra√ßa da Figueira. The Tram 15 (to get to Belem) was right outside our apartment, the Rossio train station (to get to Sintra) was barely a five minute walk, the main plaza was a three-minute walk‚Ä¶ you get the picture. The apartment was bright, clean, spacious, and stylishly furnished. It‚Äôs certainly in the more touristy area, so the nightlife is sub-ideal, and you will find more tourist shops in the immediate vicinity than local, authentic caf√©s. The location is amazing, but if you‚Äôre looking for a more low-key, residential vibe with some cool shops and restaurants, I‚Äôd look into the Principe Real neighborhood.
Miradouros: The best way to experience Lisbon is on foot, and uphill. Miradouros are viewpoints located at the highest points of each hill, always with a space to rest and chill, and sometimes with caf√©s. Don‚Äôt waste your time paying for something like the Elevador Santa Justa ‚Äî the best views in Lisbon are totally free. Miradouro da Gra√ßa was our favorite, with a spectacular view of the castle, the water, and the 25 de Abril Bridge (plus beers).
Sao Jorge Castle: This is one of the most popular attractions in Lisbon, but for some reason (maybe I‚Äôve just seen too many castles) I came in with low expectations. However, this proved to be a wild misjudgment; we had a grand time exploring the grounds and enjoying 360 views of the city. The best move after visiting the Castle is to walk through the ancient, maze-like Alfama district on your way down, discarding Google Maps and just getting lost in the cobblestone alleyways full of color and character. Protip: there are two public elevators that make the climb up to the Castle way faster and easier. The first lift departs from a nondescript building in Rua dos Franqueros (170/178) and drops you off on Rua da Madalena. From there, walk a few hundred feet to the Pingo Doce supermarket, in which you‚Äôll find an elevator that takes you another seven stories up, dropping you off right at the base of the castle!
Bel√©m: Taking Tram 15 from Pra√ßa da Figueira out to Bel√©m is a great way to spend half a day (or easily more) and experience its iconic landmarks (and equally iconic pastries). Our first stop was the world famous Pasteis de Bel√©m, serving the world-renowned pastel de natas. Believe the hype. I typically won‚Äôt even look at a non-chocolate-based pastry or dessert, but these Portuguese custard tarts (whose 187-year-old recipe is guarded like the Hope Diamond, and only known by 6 people in the world) are truly divine. The protip here is to skip the intimidating queue for takeaway and head straight inside to table service, where the wait will be significantly shorter. Order as many tarts as you wish, but be sure to order the 6-pack for takeaway.
The J√©ronimos Monastery was our next stop (just down the street from Pasteis de Bel√©m), though we opted not to go inside, as the line was absurd, and we didn‚Äôt want to spend an hour or two waiting around (we happened to go on Sunday, 100% the worst possible day if you‚Äôre trying to avoid crowds). But the facade of the building is a sight in and of itself, and worth seeing for the spectacular Gothic architecture. A delightful surprise was the Padr√£o dos Descobrimentos monument right on edge of the Tagus River estuary, which was absolutely stunning and imposing. We capped off our tour of Bel√©m with the aptly named Bel√©m Tower, a 16th-century tower that memorializes Portugal‚Äôs Age of Discovery. It‚Äôs a beautiful building, which we enjoyed from the outside (again, the queue to enter the monument did not seem worth it), sitting on the steps on its periphery, and soaking in the architecture and the history.
Pra√ßa do Commercio: One of Europe‚Äôs biggest squares, this iconic Pra√ßa is bordered by bright, mustard yellow buildings. You‚Äôll probably want to skip any and all restaurants and caf√©s inside the square (tourist traps), but you can‚Äôt miss checking out its grandeur, and walking right up to the river‚Äôs edge where you can sit on the ledge and look out toward the similarly iconic 25 de Abril Bridge.
LX Factory: For some real hipster vibes, check out LX Factory, an old industrial plant that was recently converted into a complex of 200 businesses (caf√©s, restaurants, shops, offices, and more). It basically feels like a mix of DUMBO and Williamsburg. One of the two highlights was Ler Devagar bookstore, any booklover‚Äôs dream. The second must-see is Rio Maravilha, a cool rooftop bar with great views of the river and the 25 de Abril Bridge. Grab a drink, head outside, and feel impossibly cool.
Parque Eduardo VII: This wasn‚Äôt a must-do on my list, but I wandered up the Avenida da Liberdade one day and strolled through this beautifully landscaped park with stunning geometric patterns. Starting at the entrance, you‚Äôll actually walk uphill through the park, which results in a sweeping view over the city down to the river. There‚Äôs all sorts of events happening in the park at any given time ‚Äî I happened to stumble across the Lisbon Book Fair.
A Vida Portuguesa: If you‚Äôre looking for an item to commemorate your trip but are allergic to cheap shot glasses and spoons, check out this beautiful store filled with authentic Portuguese goods ‚Äî everything from soaps to notebooks to tinned fish to olive oils & jams.
Peixaria da Esquina: After Taberna dos Mercadores, this was our second favorite meal in Portugal. This restaurant is totally out of the way (we took an Uber) but we absolutely loved it. The cheese was dreamy, the ros√© was delicious, the mineraly white was even better, the tuna ceviche was bright and refreshing, the clams a bulhao pato were not as good as Taberna dos Mercadores in Porto but were still legit, and the rice dish with shellfish was the absolute bomb. We ended up getting a third glass of wine ‚Äúfor dessert‚Äù and it was one of our best dining choices in recent history. It‚Äôs a small and intimate space where you can watch the chefs in action, which is something I always love.
Bairro do Avillez: This is chef Jose Avillez‚Äôs huge, impressive venue containing four separate restaurants. It‚Äôs worth a visit just to see this place, but the food is pretty great, too. We thoroughly enjoyed our meals at both the Taberna on the bottom floor (get the suckling pig sandwich and the meat & cheese plate) and the Peruvian Cantina on the top floor ‚Äî get the creamy seafood ceviche, the potatoes stuffed with oxtail, the choclo with cheese and basil, and the fried rice (plus a pisco sour, of course). I found it remarkable how all the restaurants inside cultivated their own distinct atmosphere, even when they were practically overlapping. It‚Äôs a gorgeous space and super reliable if you‚Äôre looking for a solid meal with great ambience.
Time Out Market: I was skeptical about this enormous indoor market lined with endless food stalls, but it‚Äôs hard to deny the appeal, and we ended up having a fantastic evening here. There are nearly endless choices (seriously ‚Äî 24 restaurants and 8 bars) and every stall represents the best that Lisbon has to offer (at least according to Time Out magazine). Luckily I had done some research beforehand, or I would have been paralyzed with indecision. I hopped in line at Alexandre Silva‚Äôs place while my boyfriend, Vishal, grabbed us a meat and cheese plate from Manteigaria Silva (and some drinks), which kept our hunger at bay during the 30-minute wait in line plus an additional 30 minute wait for the infamous pork belly confit. Given the experience was entirely pleasant, I‚Äôd say the wait was totally worth it. After our meal, we popped over to Santini for gelato ‚Äî my combination of hazelnut, nata, and chocolate was to die for.
Forno d‚ÄôOro: On my last day, I was craving something less traditionally Portuguese, and decided to check out this pizza place that made Eater‚Äôs list of 38 Essential Lisbon Restaurants. The chef was trained in Italy and makes exquisite Neapolitan-style pizzas, with burrata and mozzarella flown in daily from Italy. I savored every bite.
Bettina & Niccolo Corallo: If you are even remotely a fan of chocolate, or have ever looked at chocolate, you must stop here. This place is incredible. There‚Äôs not really a menu, so luckily I‚Äôd read beforehand (thanks again, Eater) that their 100% cacao sorbet is the hot ticket item, and it is truly otherworldly. Be sure to pick up some of their chocolate bars too, which are studded with any number of treats, from hazelnuts to toffee to cocoa nibs to ginger.
Plans on our last day got a bit foiled due to Vishal being violently ill, so we didn‚Äôt get a chance to check out Ponto Final (a restaurant with a brilliant view of Lisbon from the other side of the river), which was highly recommended by one of our friends (to get there, you take a ferry that‚Äôs right outside of Time Out Market). We also were planning to check out the traditional fado music scene in the Bairro Alto neighborhood, as I had booked a reservation at ‚ÄúFado Inside the Box‚Äù at Adega Machado, which is a daily event from 5 to 6 PM in which two singers present a repertoire focusing on the main genres of fado. I‚Äôd read that it‚Äôs a great way to experience fado, without having to commit to a 3-hour show + dinner at a fado house where the food is pretty average. I also wished we‚Äôd had a chance to check out Cervejaria Ramiro, made infamous by Anthony Bourdain, where you can allegedly find the very best shellfish in all of Portugal (expect a long wait). We also missed out on visiting Park Bar, a rooftop bar which was highly recommended by two of my friends.
If you have more than one day in Lisbon ‚Äî even just two days ‚Äî one of those days absolutely must be spent in Sintra. With just a 45 minute train ride, you‚Äôll be transported to a magical land of castles and palaces and beaches seemingly straight out of fairytales.
We left our apartment at 9:30 am to catch the 10:01 am train at Rossio Station (just five minutes away from our apartment). Huge mistake. We nearly missed the train because the line to refill metro cards was INSANE. A true horror show. Luckily, we caught the train with 4 minutes to spare, but please learn from our mistake and refill your metro card in advance. After a pleasant ride, we arrived in Sintra without a real plan. You‚Äôll be instantly bombarded with folks offering all sorts of tours and tuk tuk rides. I hadn‚Äôt done much planning about the logistics of Sintra once we actually got there (completely out of character for me), so Vishal decided to take a chance on this one guy named Miguel who offered to take us around in his private car all day and show us absolutely everything. I was aggressively skeptical (we New Yorkers always think we‚Äôre being scammed), but this turned out to be possibly the best decision we made our entire trip. The price tag of 100 Euros was more than worth it, as his insider knowledge helped us skip lines, see some off-the-beaten-path sights, and generally just not have to worry about anything. It was a blast.
We started the journey at Chalet e Jardim da Condessa, a house straight out of Hansel and Gretel, where we bought tickets for the Castle of the Moors and Pena Palace. On our way up to the Castle, Miguel pulled over at a few viewpoints along the way, to orient us to the city. Our first real site was the Castle of the Moors, which was absolutely incredible. We walked all around the walls, braving the strong wind and absurd heights (my stomach was flip flopping). I was in total awe.
Next we went to Pena Palace, the stunning mustard yellow palace that seems ubiquitous on Instagram. We mistakenly decided to buy a ticket to go inside the palace, which required not only additional Euros, but waiting in line for 30 minutes, and then being herded like cattle throughout the palace (and it wasn‚Äôt even that interesting). Definitely skip this and just buy the ticket to walk around the terraces, which are a photographer‚Äôs dream.
We quickly checked out the Palacio de Monserrate (famously frequented by Madonna) which had an awesome view of Pena Palace, and the garden was beautiful. Then we headed out to Cabo da Roca, the westernmost point in Continental Europe, which was insane. Incredible views, and beautiful blue water as far as the eye can see. Definitely a bucket list item.
After Cabo da Roca, Miguel took us up to Sanctuario da Peninha which was arguably the show stopper of the whole trip, and there were no tourists to be seen. We basically climbed into the clouds and had a nearly 360 degree view of what felt like all of Portugal. It was windy, misty, and felt like what I imagine Scotland to feel like (Vishal supported the comparison, as someone who‚Äôs actually been there). It was unbelievably serene.
--

As a tourist guide who travels by the palate, and lived here for the last 5 years, you should check these these out.
I worked in Lisbon for the last 5 years as a tour guide.
From walking tours, Tuktuk Tours, Executive Black vans, and even boat tours after I got my Skipper License. I‚Äôve done.
Honestly, I spent more time of my life wandering on the streets of that city than anywhere else in the world. But that‚Äôs for another talk.
It doesn‚Äôt matter the reason why you‚Äôre in Lisbon or where you came from, one thing is for sure.
You have to Eat.
And Lisbon will for sure satisfy your desire if you know where to look for.
I realize I could talk about all the traditional old-school restaurants with famous and amazing Portuguese cuisine. And I will, probably in another article.
But since there are thousands of articles on that already.
Today, I wanna talk about the restaurants that helped me stay on track when I decided to adopt a vegetarian Diet.
Not only that, also made me start loving stuff from vegetarian cuisine.

Lisbon is Portugal‚Äôs hilly, coastal capital city. It‚Äôs Europe‚Äôs westernmost city and the only one on the Atlantic coast. From imposing S√£o Jorge Castle, the view encompasses the old city‚Äôs pastel-colored buildings, Tagus Estuary and Ponte 25 de Abril suspension bridge. Lisbon‚Äôs geography, weather, and history make it a great city for running. There‚Äôs a terrific 5-mile path along the Tagus (Tejo) River, going by important museums and landmarks. A lovely downtown (Baixa) run along Av. de Liberdade takes you by important squares and buildings, to Eduardo VII Park. For hills, run the narrow streets and lanes of the Bairro Alto or Alfama neighborhoods, up to the Castle or one of the Miradouros (view points). The largest park is Monsanto, which is now well connected to downtown via a recently completed ‚Äògreen corridor‚Äô‚Äì a path through a linear park. And if you like hill running, this is your city!
Our complete guide to running in Lisbon can be found on the Great Runs site.
Riverside Run. 4.7 miles one-way to Belem Tower. Wonderful run along the water, passing under bridge. Numerous landmarks.Alacantra Dock. 2.8 miles west to Belem Tower. 2 miles east to Caise de Sodre.Monsanto Park. The largest park in Lisbon, with many km of trails. Pedestrian & cycle paths, forested trails, open fields, hill opportunities.Eduardo VII Park & Green Corridor. 65 Acre park located near central Lisbon. Highlight is the central walk with box hedges and a hilltop view. Green Route to Monsanto Park. About 2.5 km. northwest between Eduardo VII Park and Monsanto.Parque das Na√ß√µes. Originally the site of Expo 98, now the ultra modern side of traditional Lisbon. Path along the bay-like Tejo River. Lisboa Marina to Vasco da Gama Bridge. A run along the river in the more modern part of Lisbon. Terrific 4 km waterside path. Baixa & Av. De Liberdade. Classic Lisbon run, from the River Tagus to Eduardo VII Park, through the Baixa and along grand Av. de Liberdade.Alfama Area. The oldest district in Lisbon. Enjoy the narrow maze of streets and hills. Bairro Alto. ‚ÄúUpper District‚Äù neighborhood just west of the Baixa. Narrow streets, lanes, and stair paths. Great viewpoints.Est√°dio Universit√°rio de Lisboa. Centrally located sports complex 100 acres of outdoor running trails, tracks and green spaces.

MeetnGreetMe together with our amazing travel blogger would like to share memories and some tips with you in case you have been thinking about visiting Portugal for a long time, or just decided to go there an hour ago! Today we will explore the best of Lisbon, Porto and Sintra. Together with Anastasia.
‚ÄúAt the beginning I will give you some general information about Portugal. Portugal shares borders with Spain and it‚Äôs the most western country in Europe ‚Äî sounds interesting, am I right? If you want to have a condensed view of European landscapes, culture and the way of life, Portugal might be one of the best options for you. I have been there twice and I am sure I will go there again. My both visits were in February (Yes, it sounds cold but believe me, even in February it‚Äôs +18 and sunny‚Ä¶and nothing can spoil your time there).
I have visited only Lisbon and Porto and some small villages nearby (for me it is better to visit fewer cities but to feel them, rather than explore the whole ‚ÄúEurope on two feet a day‚Äù. That is why today I will tell you about these 2 cities.
How to get there?
As it was a planned trip, I booked flight tickets in advance (Warsaw-Lisbon-Warsaw) and it was only 80 euros (which is very cheap I think). From Lisbon to Porto I travelled by bus ‚Äî 4 hours and 20 euros- may be you will find a cheaper way to get there, but I didn‚Äôt have enough time for it and used a simple intercity bus.
Lisbon is the capital and the largest city of Portugal. Lisbon is one of the oldest cities in the world, and the oldest in Western Europe. There are a lot of tourists all year long and you have to be prepared for much attention (especially if you are a woman), tasty food, good wine and hospitality‚Ä¶.let‚Äôs go!
I will tell you about places I have visited and advice YOU to visit!
Rossio Square (Pedro IV Square)
Lisbon‚Äôs most famous square. There‚Äôs no better place in Lisbon to soak up the local atmosphere than at Pedro IV Square. It has been the city‚Äôs main gathering place since the Middle Ages. Today, it‚Äôs the place where friends meet up and as a result it‚Äôs always crowded ‚Äî you will not miss it.
Monument to the Discoveries
It is the mammoth white-stone Monument to the Discoveries. Do you all remember Vasco da Gama- the first European to reach India by sea‚Ä¶.Yes-yes, he was from Portugal. Now you understand why they have this monument and so proud of it. You can ride an elevator to enjoy the view from the top of this Lisbon landmark.
Alfama
The oldest quarter in historic Lisbon, the Alfama district is dotted with architectural landmarks and it‚Äôs the charm of the neighborhood‚Äôs meandering streets, tasty food and wine, clubs with Fado (amazing music) that make the Alfama a can‚Äôt-miss destination.
And one more life-hack ‚Äî Tram line #28
The historic ‚Äútram‚Äù takes you through the city‚Äôs oldest sectors past some of Lisbon‚Äôs most popular sights and attractions. You don‚Äôt have to pay extra money (the ticket costs like a normal one ‚Äî 3 euro).
Belem Tower
Belem Tower, also known as the Tower of St. Vincent, this statue was designed to protect sailors on their voyages, faces the river and makes an incredible impression on you.
Would you like to read the full story? Check it out in our full article: https://meetngreetme.com/blog/top-attractions-to-visit-in-lisbon-porto-and-sintra/.

Lisbon is such an old city that one of my favorite neighborhoods is older than Portugal, being over 100 years old.
It‚Äôs one of those more typical neighborhoods in Lisbon where you can Fado houses and still see a bit of an old times type of life, with a thigh community in the middle of a big city.
It had become a very touristy place in the last couple of years, but it‚Äôs still possible to get lost and find some old stores, where you can find fun trinkets.
Fado is part of the tradition not only in Lisbon but specifically in this neighborhood, where you can find a ‚ÄúCasa de Fado‚Äù almost in every corner.

Title: Lisbon
Lisbon ‚Äî Final Day
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
The final day on any trip is always a bit odd as there is a more clock watching brief to bear in mind as at some point there is that need to head off to the airport, you can‚Äôt just say sod it and get the next plane instead. And there is the packing, much of which on this trip meant refolding unused clothes we had brought. Mainly because there was the idea that we would come back in the evening, get changed, and then go out for food. Which didn‚Äôt happen at all, plus there was a bit of doubling up with hot and mild weather clothing. The unused side of the main case was a lot fuller than the dirty washing side.
Breakfast was the usual lunacy. We had been noticing little oddities, but I‚Äôve rolled them all up into a leaving day edition. There has been a man in the hotel all week. Easily recognisable as he‚Äôs about 6‚Äô 5‚Äù, bald and shiny at the front of his head, and then a foot long mullet down the back. He‚Äôs been getting a glass (for the fruit juice) and using it for coffee, pressing the americano button on one of the machines, and then whipping the glass out before the milk is poured (there is another machine which does just black coffee). He will then disappear, leaving the rest of the family in the restaurant, and then he would be back ten minutes later to do the same coffee routine all over again. It wasn‚Äôt until this morning that we saw where he was going. He went outside and sat in his car with the door open to drink his coffee, occasionally playing with the windscreen wipers (it wasn‚Äôt raining). I‚Äôm not who was happier with this arrangement, him, or his family.
Coffee in a fruit juice glass may sound weird, but there are always lunatics trying to go one better. In addition to mullet man, I have seen someone take a bowl (which is there for the cereals) and do their coffee into that. And conversely someone using a coffee cup to put their cereals in. Additionally, the breakfast room had a little Danone fridge in the corner, on investigation, it was full of Nestle yoghurts. I thought I wasn‚Äôt a morning person, but shit, I‚Äôm a fully functioning person compared to some of these.
Anyway, after the breakfast fun and games and packing, we checked out, left the cases, and went out for our last little wander of the trip. The fact we had dressed for going home and I had jeans and a jacket on meant it was bright sunshine and no rain.
We headed to the Edward VII park. It had been set out when most of the city was rebuilt after the 1755 earthquake, but they renamed it in honour of the visit of our king to the city in 1903. And for some reason they never renamed it back after he went home. Weirdos.
The park slopes gently uphill. Of course it does, this is Lisbon. You are going to be hard pushed to find anywhere flat to build a park.
About halfway up is the Pavilion Carlos Lopez which has some beautiful blue and white tiled scenes from history upon its walls.
In front of one a woman, and her photographer friend are set up. She has six juggling clubs with bright orange ends which she is juggling in front of the tiles while her friend takes phots from differing lengths away. When I say juggling, perhaps trying to juggle would be a more accurate description. When she drops most of the clubs, Helen and I say in unison, ‚Äòsack the juggler.‚Äô
At the top of the park‚Äôs slope is a modern sculpture to the 1974 revolution.
And in front of it is the wonderful view down the hill, back over the laid out gardens, to the statue to the Marques de Pombal (who laid out the new city after the earthquake) in the middle of the double roundabout, along the main drag of the Avenue de Liberdade beyond and then there in the distance is the river.
Having come up one side of the park we go to amble down the other side and as we do we find ourselves outside the Lisbon Greenhouse.
It is a botanical garden, and we had seen the roof from above and the side and not twigged it was the greenhouse we had seen marked on the map. It is huge.
And full of greenery you may be surprised to know.
And flowers.
None of which I know the name of. Helen does, she knows most of them, and tells me what they are. Contrary to popular belief, I do listen when she tells me stuff, but where plant life is concerned, my mind does not want to keep that stuff. Which is a bit strange considering how much utter crap it is more than willing to keep.
I did retain the names of two, but only because I was been deliberately silly about them. Apparently, Nathan wants a cheese plant. Of which there were loads here, so many in fact it was more like a cheese forest, and I would certainly be happy if there was such a thing as a cheese forest and that cheese would grow on trees.
The other being a wisteria. And that‚Äôs only because I was saying I had heard people were going mad about this flower. ‚ÄòReally?‚Äô came the puzzled response from Helen. ‚ÄòYeah, it‚Äôs wisteria hysteria.‚Äô I will point out I already had my coat and hat on at this point.
It was quite interesting, and I don‚Äôt mean in an air quotes fingers kind of way. Plus I was taking the opportunity to try and get some macro photography of the various flowers done.
I don‚Äôt know what these white ones are called, but trying to get near enough to them to do a macro shot was difficult as the juggler and her photographer mate had set up in front of them and now had another hanger on with them. In the previous half an hour or so since we‚Äôd last seen them hogging things worth taking pictures of, the juggling skills hadn‚Äôt improved.
We had heard the peacocks, but it wasn‚Äôt until we were outside again that we saw them. Just strutting around and not being tortured by moronic tourists into fanning out their feathers in distress.
There was time for a last caf√© stop, a final cappuccino and pastel de nata in the park before it was time to head back to the hotel and pick up the cases ready for the journey to the airport.
Which didn‚Äôt take as long as the journey out seemed to.
I had the camera ready for some of the station art,
and got some blurred shots, some that missed altogether, some with window reflections,
and a feeling that somehow we‚Äôd missed a couple of stations as I was sure I‚Äôd seen some much more striking examples on the journey into the city.
The journey through the airport was smooth, bag drop was easy and for a change it was Helen getting the grilling about bag contents. Security was fine, there was a bit of duty-free shopping (not that there is duty on boxes of pastel de natas, just idiot tourist premium). I had been hoping to find a Forca Portugal store, but there wasn‚Äôt one. Having gotten Sporting Lisbon and Porto pens and magnets the previous day, I thought I would complete the big three, only for the Benfica official store not to have them, and the Football Gate store to have the Sporting and Porto stuff I‚Äôd got the day before, but to do no Benfica stuff because they had their own store.
Passport control was quick, and both coming out and going back the border police have been friendly and efficient. Something that perhaps the US ones could do with coming and getting some training on.
The queue at the gate was the usual bunfight / free for all. No sort of order in being called up, just get your elbows out and shuffle slowly forward in the queue. Or do what we did and sit there and wait for the back of the queue to come to us before joining it. And then find that on the plane there was no one else on our set of three seats, and the overhead lockers were empty. Bonus. Then it is roll to the runway and away we go.
Overall the trip was great.
Lisbon is a wonderful city. There is so much to see and do and four nights is nowhere near enough time to do anything more than scratch the surface. It is good exercise too, rest assured that if you walk for more than a couple of minutes in any direction there will be a hill to climb up or shuffle down.
The food has been wonderful, and it is cheap. Everything has been really tasty, and they certainly don‚Äôt scrimp on their portion sizes (they must know people need feeding up to be able to deal with walking up all those hills). And the people are so friendly.
The Azulejos are wonderful, and there are many splendid examples of art on the tiles. Although the occasional one did make us smile for the wrong reason. This one was designed to represent justice with the scales. But all I can see is saggy tits. Which again, says more about me than anybody else.
The only downsides have been the very showery weather, which no one can really do anything about, and which hasn‚Äôt dampened our spirits anywhere near the amount they have dampened out clothes. And the attempted pickpocket / bag theft thing.
But we would definitely recommend coming back with more time to get around more of the city and beyond (Sintra is only 45 minutes away).

Title: Lisbon Tried to Kill Me, But in a Sexy Way
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
I came to Lisbon for the vibe.
What I got was a full-body workout, a minor existential crisis, and two pairs of shoes that now live in the trash.
Let me be clear: Lisbon is stunning. Lisbon is magic. Lisbon is the seductive European city that will woo you with pastel buildings, flirt with you using tilework, and then betray you with an incline so steep your knees will write a resignation letter.
This is not a walkable city. This is a city designed by and for mountain goats.
You know when a city greets you gently? When it says, ‚ÄúHey, take it easy. Ease into it. Grab a coffee. Sit by the river.‚Äù
Lisbon doesn‚Äôt do that.
Lisbon hands you a map, points vaguely uphill, and says, ‚ÄúFigure it out, loser.‚Äù
I arrived with optimism. I had good shoes. I had snacks. I had a plan.
Thirty minutes later, I was clinging to a stone wall, sweating through my t-shirt, trying to decide if I should keep walking or roll back down into the harbor and let the Atlantic take me.

Title: EDP Lisbon Half Marathon ‚Äî 2024
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
March 17 has passed, and the EDP Lisbon Half Marathon 2024 is over. I can share my personal impressions about the race. There was a lot of fun, but also things the Lisbon folks should work on.
The race kit was okay, including a T-shirt, a bib, a cap (an excellent choice, as you‚Äôll see why later), a magazine, some bags of tea, a cereal snack, an electrolyte pill, and a magazine. A very useful kit.
The quality of the T-shirt and the cap was very good.
My running buddy and I chose to stay in the downtown area, near the Marques De Pombal, at the Marques De Pombal Hotel, of course.
Access to the race is limited, and you can only get there by train. All participants must use the Fertagus train to reach the starting line at the Pragal station. To access the Fertagus train stations, athletes can use Lisbon‚Äôs public transportation system (subway, buses, and trains) for free by presenting their BIB. You have to take the metro and get off at the Jardim Zool√≥gico station to get there. From there, you don‚Äôt have to go outside; just follow the train sign to reach the train station.
While on the train, I kept looking for the ‚Äú25 April Bridge‚Äù to realize that we were on the bridge, just under the road where we were supposed to be running soon. The train trip was short, about 10‚Äì15 minutes.
We arrived at the last station at 8:55, and the race was supposed to start at 10:05. We thought we had plenty of time to get to our designated start wave. I was supposed to start from Box2, while my running buddy was supposed to start from Box3.
The first thing we noticed was that the only accessway was pretty packed with many people.
We did not panic and just followed the path until we got stuck in a sea of people. We were blocked in that spot for 30‚Äì40 minutes with little information about what was happening. There were no staff or organizing people around, just some policemen blocking the access.
We also thought we had time and space to warm up, but this was almost impossible with so many people trying to get into the designated starting box areas. This was my first half marathon where I did not do any warmup or stretching, nothing. It was impossible.
This was also the first half marathon where I had to stay in line and wait for tens of minutes with little information about what was going on. It was clear we were very far from the starting area.
At some point, the crowd started to move gradually, and we managed to pass the first checkpoint. We reached a zone where someone was yelling instructions about which way you should take to get to your designated starting area. There were no signs whatsoever, just a single volunteer yelling and trying his best.
For me, this was terrible organizing. Although I was at the race one hour and five minutes before the start, I didn‚Äôt manage to get to my box in time, and I had no place to warm up!
By the time I got to the starting areas, the lucky ones had already been in the race for 6 minutes.
I started at last! But it was so crowded on the bridge that I was forced to run on a metal grill next to the asphalt car lane. You could see the water down below, and the running feeling was odd. Most runners avoided the grill, but it was the only option to get in front of other runners. And I kept running on that uncomfortable grill for almost 1-2 km, I believe.
I overcame thousands of runners since I started from the back of the herd, and two days after the race, I am still paying for that effort. Around km 8, getting in front of other runners became easy. Till then, you had to do a lot of maneuvering to get in front.
I give a big F for the start experience.
The weather in Lisbon in March is unpredictable; while in the morning it is a bit cold, clouds cover the sun, but as soon as you pass 10:30, the sun comes out and starts to shine and burn.
My Garmin watch said that the average temperature was 28 degrees Celsius (82F) during the race, with a maximum of 33 degrees (91F). The weather prediction was 24C, measured in the shade, but starting with km 9, the entire race was under a nice shining sun.
Starting with km 18, I began to count the number of people who fainted on the side, and I think I counted 10‚Äì15 of them. Volunteers and medics were trying to relieve their pain, but seeing so many people dropping out of the race kind of made me more cautious.
Nevertheless, I enjoyed this race and loved my time spent in Lisbon. I recommend visiting this city because it is very nice, has good food, is relaxed, is clean, and has many things to do. It was my second time here, and I will come back the third, fourth, and fifth times whenever possible.
In my previous post, I wrote that my Garmin watch was predicting a finish of 1:46:54, and I thought that it was being conservative. I wanted to achieve more of a 1:44 finish time. It seems that Garmin wasn‚Äôt far off from my result. I finished in 1:46:46, which is eerily accurate!
I have mixed feelings about Garmin!
I‚Äôve added some more pictures at the end and recommend doing the Lisbon Half Marathon. It is a race designed for a PB, and you can visit a great city.
The only tip I have is to get to the starting line two hours ahead, and I‚Äôm not kidding!

Content:

No IT Dept: You're On Your Own

--
Listen
Share
This was my fourth Web Summit, Europe‚Äôs if not the world‚Äôs biggest gathering of those plying the tech ecosystem. The conference has grown considerably since its humble beginnings in Dublin where its organizers remain domiciled. It‚Äôs not just the number of conference attendees, but its growing footprint in other regions that sets it apart from other confabs. Its portfolio currently includes Collision in Toronto, Web Summits in Lisbon, Rio and Qatar, and Rise in Hong Kong (2025).
Here are some data points from the just-concluded Lisbon event:
The record-breaking attendance happened despite the conference founder‚Äôs ill-conceived remarks on the Gaza conflict two weeks before Web Summit started. It sparked an exodus of big-named sponsors and speakers, as well as the resignation of the founder himself.
Very quickly, however, Web Summit secured a new CEO, Katherine Maher, the CEO of the Wikimedia Foundation, who plugged the leaks and, within two weeks, righted the ship.
One afternoon back at the hotel, we shared an elevator with Katherine, where we had a chance to let her know how much we enjoyed her opening night presentation. She appreciated the feedback.
Since attending the final Dublin-based Web Summit in 2015, I‚Äôve fallen into a regular cadence at subsequent events, including two on-stage moderation sessions, judging the start-up Pitch competition, participating in Mentor Hours, attending a couple of speaker dinners, and carving out time to listen to some of the more noteworthy speakers.
Two themes permeated this year‚Äôs conference: AI and climate, with the latter dominating many of the startups presenting.
On the AI front, I took the stage with Mikayel Vardanyan, co-founder of unicorn Picsart, the largest all-in-one creative platform of photo, video editing, and design tools ‚Äî now fully immersed in Generative AI for creating images and video.
This is quite an impressive company with 1.5 billion downloads. Still, I had to bring up Gen AI bias after my query on the platform for a ‚Äúsuccessful business person‚Äù turned up four images ‚Äî all of the same 40-year-old white man. I also worried aloud about the likelihood of bad actors using deep fakes to manipulate public opinion. Yes, that means you, Russia.
In my second on-stage session, I sat with some veteran marketing execs to discuss the changing role of the CMO. I reminisced about Y&R Inc‚Äôs ‚Äúwhole egg‚Äù approach wherein advertising, PR, and direct response comprised the three legs of the marketing stool. (Brand identity/design was siloed away back then.) I suggested that Humpty Dumpty fell off the wall, giving today‚Äôs marketers vastly more tools with which to work.
I suppose the greatest satisfaction for me was gleaned from connecting with founders about their early-stage companies‚Äô plans to change the world for the better. This happened on the Pitch Stage where I judged a handful of companies whose solutions to small and big problems didn‚Äôt fail to impress. I also had a chance to mentor three young founders in the climate space: Guillaume Mandolini of EVAS, Dragan Gelevski of EarthCare.ai, and Diogo Costa of EcoCradle, who had these kinds words to share following our session:
There were other notable encounters, including over lunch when former Trump chief-of-staff Mick Mulvaney plopped down beside my wife and me. He, alongside esteemed journalist Michael Isikoff, suggested a political scenario in which both Trump and Biden drop out of the race. I wasn‚Äôt buying it.
You never know who you‚Äôll run into at Web Summit, but everyone there had an affinity for technology and how it will continue to change our lives and livelihoods. Even Mick Mulvaney was there to speak about the tech regulatory environment.

In the heart of Lisbon, a city steeped in history and shrouded in mystery, magic pulses truly under the cobblestone streets. *Whispers of Lisbon* tells the story of Amara, a young historian with a gift for paying attention to the voices of the past, and Rafael, an enigmatic mother or father with ties to a historical magical order.

Chapter 1: Echoes inside the Alfama
Amara Mendes wandered via the slim, winding streets of the Alfama district, the oldest neighborhood in Lisbon.
The scent of grilled sardines and freshly baked past√©is de nata lingered in the air, blending with the faint notes of Fado music drifting from a nearby tavern.
As she traced her fingers along the historic partitions, she felt it once more ‚Äî a faint, ghostly whisper that simply she needed to hear.

I didn‚Äôt mean to get lost in Lisbon.
I had landed with a rough map scribbled on a napkin, a backpack full of enthusiasm, and absolutely no clue how confusing the city‚Äôs steep, winding streets could be. I‚Äôd seen pictures of the iconic yellow trams, the tiled facades, and the miradors overlooking terracotta rooftops. But none of those Instagram posts prepared me for what it actually felt like to be completely disoriented in a foreign city, hungry, sweaty, and mildly annoyed with Google Maps.
It started innocently enough: a walk through Alfama, the oldest district in Lisbon, with its maze-like alleys and whispers of Fado music echoing from open windows. I turned one wrong corner, then another, and before I knew it, I was somewhere between ‚Äúdefinitely not where I should be‚Äù and ‚Äúoh, this looks kind of magical.‚Äù
That‚Äôs the thing about Lisbon ‚Äî it forgives your mistakes by rewarding you with charm. One detour led me to a tiny caf√© run by an old couple who didn‚Äôt speak English but insisted I try their homemade bacalhau. Another wrong turn led to a bookstore with poetry written on the walls and a cat sleeping on a pile of Portuguese novels.
By the time I figured out where I was (eventually ‚Äî thank you, tram 28), I had stopped caring about the original destination. Somewhere between losing the route and finding a rhythm, I realized that this‚Ä¶

Title: Lisbon ‚Äî Day Three
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
To avoid the worst of the carnage at breakfast it was breakfast first then get ready to head out this morning to get more touring done. It had been raining when we got up but was bright sunshine by the time we were leaving the hotel, only for the moment we sat on the tour minibus it to want to start to rain. And we were on a minibus whose roof was broken and stuck in the open position. But we stayed in our seats and toughed it out as it went from rain to bright sunshine, back to rain and back to sun again as we went round.
We were on the green route and done the stretch from Liberatores to the Castle the previous afternoon, but this time we did almost the full route, only getting off when we got back to the second Liberatores stop and hour and a half after the first one.
And I don‚Äôt give a shit if I am repeating myself, I would not want to be driving on most of the roads the minibus travelled on. In fact I would go so far as to say that driving in Lisbon is not for me full stop, but it does lend some insight to the story of the Portuguese taxi driver we had in Leicester back in the late eighties.
There is plenty to see on the way around and it is a struggle to get anything remotely related to good photos. Between dodging raindrops, the vibrations of the cobbled streets, there are angles to consider, bus frame to avoid, and when you think you‚Äôve got it all lined up ready to go the lights change to green or traffic clears and the bus lurches forward with some sudden acceleration.
What the results look like will be interesting viewing once back home and they have all been loaded onto the laptop.
When we got off the bus, we chose a different road to wander down to get to the river, picking one which isn‚Äôt festooned with cafes and restaurants and full of desperate men trying to strong arm you into eating at their particular offering. The number of times you can run that gauntlet without just wanting to scream at them to fuck off is limited. The one we pick has a gentle incline to it, which is somewhat of a concern seeing as we are supposed to be heading down to the river. We reach the crest of the road and find it must have been more than a gentle climb. Either that or we are getting used to the hilly nature of the city, as the road down the other side is seriously steep, and we really didn‚Äôt think we‚Äôd come up so high.
At the top there was a mall, which we took advantage of to use the facilities (that is one thing about Lisbon which isn‚Äôt great, there aren‚Äôt very many public toilets at all, and so when there are, there are always queues). I‚Äôm queuing for a cubicle only for a little brat to queue jump and run in when the old man in there leaves. I take the next available one, and whilst in there I can hear the impatient brat shout to his dad, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm finished.‚Äô His dad tells him to wait while he himself finishes. Only for the kid to yell ‚Äòfor fucks sake, hurry up, the Lego shop is closing.‚Äô (It wasn‚Äôt it was half twelve and they don‚Äôt shut for lunch.) Hopefully, the Lego shop became the Lego-without shop for the little shit.
The road down takes us back to the Commerce Square and across to the river. It‚Äôs time for the next tour, only this time there is no bus, it is on the river. There‚Äôs a big river and tours on the river, so of course we are there, we‚Äôre well-known suckers for a water level view of a city.
We get some refreshments, sort out the correct token for the tour (part of the HOHO ticket), and find the correct queue (not as easy as it sounds) and get on the little boat. And when I say little boat, I mean it. We had seen the larger boats for other tour companies on the river, but this is tiny, like a minibus compared to the double deckers the others are using. But even so it isn‚Äôt full.
Again the weather thinks it is funny. It was bright sunshine as we sit having a bit of lunch, the rain only appears when we set off on the boat. It does have most of its plastic splash protectors down which helps. But not with taking photos.
But the rain does fuck off to be replaced by the sun before too long.
The original route is for the little boat to go down the south side of the river on the westbound leg of the journey, but with the rain, and the threatening clouds, it stays to the north and concentrates on the Lisbon side of the river.
Being out in the vast expanse of the river gives you an unobstructed view of how the city rises away from the river and the layers of buildings of all types rising into the hills.
The cargo terminal is fascinating (to me anyway). Just how huge the container ships are, and how the containers slot together to stack up and stay in place like a giant Lego set. (perhaps drop some on this on that kid from earlier).
And there is the bridge. You can see it is large from a long way away. But the sheer scale really hits home when you are going under it.
It had looked as if our little tour boar was going to ram the yacht, but we only passed close by to it just as we were both going under the bridge, which made a decent photo.
By the time we had made our way past the MAAT buildings we had been on the day before, and out to Belem, the sun was shining.
And there were plenty of opportunities to take decent photographs of the Monument to the Discoveries.
The Belem Tower is a much better photograph from the water than from the top of the tour bus as attempted yesterday.
This is where we turn around to head back and there is a terminal for people to get on and off as even the boat tour is a HOHO. Every other passenger got off, and were replaced by a new set, and off we went back to central Lisbon.
We crossed over to the southside of the river to do so. And besides the obvious tourist photographs of the Christ the King statue, there was much that interested me.
A bit further out to the west from Belem was this, which I am assuming is some kind of refinery type building.
Just before the suspension bridge is another very colourful refinery building.
There are egg shaped structures set into the slopes of the south bank.
And once past the bridge and all the way along the bank until the river opens out into its inland bay was a stretch of abandoned riverside buildings.
We swing back over to the north side of the river and with the sun shining on the city along the stretch of government / municipal eighteenth century buildings painted in assorted colours, and the domes and spires of churches behind them, it has a very Venice-esque look to it.
When the little boat docks at the third of its little stops we get off. The wind whilst on the water has been bitter and we have walked the short stretch back to where the loop would be complete before, so we head off to look for food and to warm up.
The pier is close to where we ate on the first night we were here, and therefore we know that the Time Out Market is only just behind the buildings we can see.
But it is chaotic in there and we want to be able to just sit and relax, order something from a menu and have it delivered to a table, not try and work out which of the forty odd options to order from and then fight to try and find two seats together somewhere in the heaving mass of humanity in the middle of the hall.
We do take the opportunity to use the facilities though. Whilst I am waiting for Helen (the queue for the ladies is unsurprisingly longer and slower moving), I see a bloke go and drag his (I assume) other half out of the queue and shove her into the unused baby change facilities toilet. Once she is in there he is pacing furiously back and forth but gradually further away, and then outside. People who actually have babies to change are now queuing to use it. I get the feeling she‚Äôs had more than enough of his shit and is deliberately taking as long as possible or just hiding. Helen comes back before she reappears, but he‚Äôs not in sight, and we go the other way. Hopefully, there was a backway out and he‚Äôs still pacing there now. Alone.
We use the guidebook to see if there are any recommended eateries near to where we are, and it does mention a place within a couple of minutes‚Äô walk the Rio Grande. A lovely old traditional restaurant with decorative tiles on the walls and old wooden beams.
What we didn‚Äôt realise when we went in from the front door was that the side window where we were seated overlooks Pink Street.
And outside our window as we eat there is a drag act in a skintight purple jumpsuit with a long blonde wig (which keeps trying to escape) on roller skates, and armed with a wheelie bin, who is entertaining / terrorising the passing tourists.
We had found Pink Street as we had wanted, but without even trying.
The food, as all food so far has been, was lush, and after getting past the drag act unmolested, we headed back up another different street towards the hotel. Where it was a case of have a bit of a rest and then change to layer up for yet another tour. This time the night bus tour. And not a single Harry Potter in sight.
Three of the others who had been on the previous evening‚Äôs walking tour were on this tour as well, making the fullest use of their tickets as well then. But on the whole, it was a sparsely populated bus when the tour set off. Which did mean it was good for me as I could move around a bit in the hope of trying to get some decent photographs.
It starts out fine as there is still reasonable light at 8pm.
But night is falling, and it is doing so quickly.
And whereas the camera can cope with any difficulties thrown at it in daylight, at night it struggles. (or to be more precise, I struggle to be able to set it up, so it doesn‚Äôt struggle as much.)
It can cope OK when it is dead still, but as the night tour doesn‚Äôt have and pick up points around it the only stops are at traffic lights, so there is a fair bit of motion to deal with.
And as light fades the camera tries to extend the shutter speed to let more light in, which when moving means blurring.
So there I am hoping for traffic lights to be red, or for magical traffic jams to appear.
To be fair I did get some reasonable shots whilst the bus was stationary.
But the one I wanted was when the route went over the bridge above Pink Street. I knew when it was coming, I had the lens at the right length of focus, I had the timing right, but the bus was moving too quickly as there was no traffic and no traffic lights and so it ended up a bit blurry.
It is dark by the time the hour-long tour is up, and we head back to the hotel. We had seen the caf√© on the roundabout was open as the bus came past. Two minutes later as we pass it walking back it is closed and in darkness, so it is back to the room and chill.
There are no planned tours tomorrow, just us mooching on our last full day.

If there is one thing we understand, it‚Äôs the importance of your student accommodation towards your general student experience. What‚Äôs more, we know a huge factor is your student home‚Äôs location. You want to live in one of the best neighborhoods, one that‚Äôs just as perfect for you as your residence. If this is you, let us guide you through Lisbon‚Äôs best neighborhoods for students!
Definitely one of the best neighborhoods for students, it‚Äôs very, very popular with international students. Marqu√™s de Pombal is known among the locals as the central business district of the city and also as a major transportation hub. With two metro lines crossing here, and something like 20 different bus lines to catch, you‚Äôre always just a shot away from any place in the city. During the day, catch the sun up in the Eduardo VII gardens and after nightfall head down to the Kiosk-bars of Av. da Liberdade for drinks with your friends. There are many student residences nearby, including several that are Erasmus exclusive. Check out our student accommodation in Marqu√™s de Pombal.
An Erasmus favorite! If you don‚Äôt want to have to go to parties, but prefer the parties to come to you, rent a room in the Bairro Alto. From Thursday to Saturday, the crowds fill up every one of the tiny bars here and spill out onto the streets. Thankfully, it‚Äôs quiet enough during the day, so you can party as much as you want throughout the night and then spend your mornings taking it easy inside. Friendly warning, you guys: Bairro is for party-animals only. Check out our student apartments and studios in Bairro Alto.
The large avenue (Alameda d. Afonso Henriques) that gives this area its name has a very wide garden with plenty of places for taking in Lisbon‚Äôs great weather and a kiosk-bar where you can have one of the coldest ‚Äî and cheapest ‚Äî glasses of beer to cool off. The streets to the sides of Alameda have plenty of student flat shares that are popular with Portuguese students, especially students of Instituto Superior T√©cnico (- called IST, or T√©cnico, for short). Click the link if you want to check out some student shared apartments in Alameda.
The neighbourhoods of S√£o Sebati√£o and Saldanha are between three of the main universities of Lisbon: Universidade Nova de Lisboa (Nova), Universidade Cat√≥lica de Portugal (Cat√≥lica) and T√©cnico. It is not surprising, then, that you will find a student in nearly every building of the area. Some places like Bairro Azul are almost entirely occupied by students. It has great transportation options, the Gulbenkian Foundation with its museum, library and gardens (useful whether you feel like art, a stroll or some study time) and El Corte Ingl√©s, the huge department store that also has over 12 cinema rooms. Click the links if you want to browse for student apartments in Saldanha or to rent student accommodation in S√£o Sebasti√£o.
Alfama is not only the historical quarters of Lisbon, it‚Äôs the city‚Äôs heart and soul. This is a personal favourite of mine ‚Äî the neighbourhood where I have always lived. You‚Äôll find there is nothing more charming than Alfama‚Äôs crazy, maze-like streets, and there is no better way of taking in the city‚Äôs culture than getting lost here. At night, you can hear Lisbon‚Äôs traditional music, Fado, being sung from a hundred little restaurants. Houses and apartments are traditionally rather small and hundreds of years old, but some studios and apartments have been recently refurbished and make the perfect student homes to live in. Interested? Click the link to see student accommodation in Alfama.
Thanks for reading this post! We hope to see you soon, coming back for more.
Did you enjoy our article? Just drop us a line in the comment section below to let us know you did. And remember! If you need to find accommodation in Portugal, you‚Äôll find the perfect place to call home on Uniplaces.

Title: The History of the Siege of Lisbon by Jose Saramago (reviewed by Richard Seltzer)
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
This is an excerpt from my book One Family, which is available from Amazon.
At the start of the Second Crusade, troops sailing to the Holy Land, stopped, by chance, at Lisbon and helped defeat the Moors, resulting in Portugal becoming a country and Afonso Henriques (our ancestor) its first king.
Jose Saramago (Nobel winner) wrote a novel with the title The History of the Siege of Lisbon, which questions historical truth in a paradoxical, philosophical, and comical style that resembles that of Borges and Lem. At the same time he tells the love story of two employees at a publishing house in modern-day Lisbon, a proof-reader and his boss.
The proof-reader, succumbing to an inexplicable urge, changes one word in a history book about the 1147 siege of Lisbon. The Crusaders say ‚Äúno,‚Äù instead of ‚Äúyes.‚Äù They sail on rather than stopping to help fight the Moors.
A woman hired to supervise proof-readers and prevent another such egregious error is intrigued by the implications of the mistake and by the proof-reader himself. She surreptitiously suggests that he write a novel that explores the possible consequences if that ‚Äúno‚Äù had been historically true.
The narrative switches back and forth between present-day Lisbon and an alternative medieval past written by the proof-reader. His version of what happened is consistent with the fragmentary historical evidence, and is credibly told, with gritty texture and the addition of a love story that parallels his romance with his new boss. The Crusaders‚Äô decision, rather than creating a tornado of consequences and changing all that came after, only leads to differences in how the battle is won and who deserves credit; the outcome is the same. The rip in time caused by the change from ‚Äúyes‚Äù to ‚Äúno‚Äù closes as if it had never happened. The fictitious version of events, created by the proof-reader, might be closer to what actually happened than the official version.
Saramago turns what might otherwise have become an academic discourse on history, fiction, and truth into an entertaining double love story that plays out in the same city, but separated by 850 years. In this book, facts aren‚Äôt as important as they‚Äôre usually represented to be. There are a few well-known fixed points on a time line, and there are numerous possible story-paths from one point to another, all of which are equally valid, because they lead to the same conclusion. By looking at more than one possible path, you come to know the characters and their circumstances with the texture, ambiguity, and shading of reality, with its dynamic tensions and ever-changing possibilities, rather than with the static view of linear historical narrative. The author succeeds in showing the heroic and passionate potential of everyday people in everyday circumstances.
I wish I could achieve such a result.

Content:

Sign up

At Christmas I got several photography books in the Abandoned / Oblivion series of books published by Jonglez; Abandoned Churches, Abandoned Spain, Abandoned France, Abandoned USSR, Oblivion, Forgotten Heritage, Forbidden Places. I‚Äôve had a look at the other titles in the series (USA, Belgium, Australia, Italy, Japan, Lebanon, Germany) but was surprised to find there isn‚Äôt one for Portugal.
Having spent four days wandering around Lisbon I am sure that an intrepid urban explorer and photographer could fill such a book with examples from Lisbon alone.
There are lots of properly abandoned buildings all over the place of all shapes and sizes.
Some on the main streets of the city, boarded or shuttered up.
Peeling paint or plaster disappearing from the surface of the buildings helped along by the constant weathering.
Nature is trying to reclaim some of these for itself. There is a lot going on.
Unlike a lot of examples included in the series of books I have seen and have mentioned above, these aren‚Äôt necessarily isolated buildings. They sit in and amongst fully functioning, well kept and maintained, houses, shops, restaurants, and other businesses.
It is oddities, it isn‚Äôt like they are whole blocks left to go to rack and ruin. I may have seen one side of a street where all the buildings looked to be abandoned and on their last legs, but that was the exception rather than the rule.
To the south of the city and all the way along the bank of the River Tagus opposite Lisbon, from the April 25th suspension bridge going to the east until the river opens out into its inland bay was a stretch of abandoned riverside buildings.
They look as if they must have been industrial units, but the whole stretch is mainly roofless, and the graffiti artists have been out in force.
It did look as if there was one little bar in amongst it all. But there was no obvious route down to get to the stretch of buildings. How would someone get there?
I am fascinated by this stretch of buildings, but as to how to get in there, I‚Äôm better off not knowing as I would just have spent a lost day wandering around the whole stretch clicking away and filling up my SD card.
And the spare one.
There are other buildings in disrepair, but they at least show signs of being worked on, metal and wooden fences surround them. There are piles of materials around, and there are cranes hovering above them.
I suppose if you went and looked hard enough in any town or city you would find examples of abandonment, but it feels different in Lisbon, I haven‚Äôt gone searching for examples, it is almost as if they have come to me. Though what I find strange now that I am home and I am searching through all the photographs I took, is ones I am sure I took of abandoned and crumbling buildings aren‚Äôt there, which makes me doubt my sanity. Most of the ones I have are of the riverside.
But I don‚Äôt speak the language and therefore don‚Äôt know what any notices on buildings may be saying. I don‚Äôt know what the law is about entering such buildings, and how the police would deal with such things. And most importantly I am on holiday with Helen, so I don‚Äôt go looking for that opening, for a chance to get inside one of these buildings and snap away.
Perhaps someone will, or there is someone already doing it, or even someone has already done it, and it is the next Jonglez abandoned series one to come out.
