Title: How to Match Transit With a City‚Äôs Topography: Lisbon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
By: Joel Epstein
I was lucky enough to get back to Lisbon (Lisboa) recently. I can‚Äôt get enough of the city, especially in the off season when it‚Äôs not overrun with tourists and global nomads looking for a tasty caipirinha or port in Bairro Alto and an evening of Fado in Alfama. I return to Lisboa for both too, but I also visit to ride the Metro and the trams and consider how a hilly city reminiscent of San Francisco gets people around.
As in Madrid and other European capitals, my transit envy for Lisbon always starts with the Metropolitano (Metro) de Lisboa right outside the airport terminals, as it should be.
The ease and comfort of riding the Metro with its cork appointed seats, comes in
contrast to my slog to JFK on an often old A train from Harlem to Lefferts and Liberty, followed by the Q10 Bus to the AirTrain.
Sure, I know I can save a few minutes by taking the A to Howard Beach or the E or LIRR to Jamaica and getting on the AirTrain ($8.25), but why would I? I‚Äôd rather budget more time for the trip and buy a couple of Trinidadan doubles for dinner with the money I save making my ride a single fare OMNY trip.
It is rare to get jostled on the Metro in Lisboa the way one might in New York. And getting on and off a crowded train is not the hassle it can be at rush hour on the A or E, or any of our trains for that matter.
Lisboa isn‚Äôt a massive city like New York or Los Angeles but like so many global cities I have gotten to know over the years, it seems to have figured out how to match its transit with its commuters‚Äô needs and the city‚Äôs often steep topography. Take the romantic trams (amarelos da Carris) that climb up and down Lisboa‚Äôs narrow, winding streets. As with the New Orleans streetcars, San Francisco‚Äôs cable cars and L.A‚Äôs Angels Flight, one doesn‚Äôt have to be a transit lover to swoon over these trams.
Of course the Lisboa Metro and the trams aren‚Äôt perfect or service as frequent on some lines as it needs to be. One night, heading back to my Airbnb in Arroios, I couldn‚Äôt help noticing how packed the train was. Like sardines, as we used to say in New York, or sardinhas, in Lisboa.
The system is also not as disability accessible as it needs to be.
Still, Lisboa and Portugal in general seem years ahead of the U.S. in building a more sustainable transportation network that won‚Äôt cost the country the arm and a leg that the Second Avenue Subway extension is going to cost us.
And transit in Lisboa is still improving and growing. The new loop to Campo de Ourique will bring trains to more Lisboetas or Alfacinhas (little lettuces) as Lisboa residents are called.
The dedication to transit is consistent with the country and the E.U.‚Äôs commitment to sustainability generally. Portuguese cities are places where residents routinely sort their trash and recycling and best of all, drink their coffee at home or in a caf√©, rather than out of a togo cup.
It was great to get back to Lisboa and it won‚Äôt be my last time riding the Metro. And while I am still learning the meaning of saudade, the Portuguese feeling of longing, melancholy, or nostalgia that is supposedly characteristic of the Portuguese temperament, who doesn‚Äôt love an airport with bike parking!
Yours in transit,
Joel
Joel Epstein is a New Yorker and an advocate for public transit, livable cities and public space.

Title: Where and what to eat in Lisbon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

New to South Africa, I‚Äôm exploring the diversity of wine one bottle at a time. English by birth, I spent20 years in Australia writing about food and drink for daily newspapers, glossy magazines and my blog. I now live in Johannesburg.

--
Listen
Share
One month in Lisbon. That‚Äôs some 90 meals. Quite a few I prepared at home. What is remarkable is how cheap fruit, vegetables, meat and fish are in Lisbon compared with Australia. Peppers and onions are sweet and cost pennies.
Tuna and Swordfish are about ‚Ç¨12-‚Ç¨13 a kilo. It‚Äôs a shock to the system.
With cheaper ingredients, property and labour costs it is understandable that Portugal has plenty of quite cheap eats. I say quite cheap as Lisbon isn‚Äôt as cheap as you‚Äôd expect.
It‚Äôs partly that tax is high ‚Äî 23% compared to Australia‚Äôs 10%. And partly that in the inner suburbs around the old town venues are mainly catering to tourists.
Restaurante Ponto Final
R. Ginjal 72, 2800 Almada
I‚Äôd rate this as one of the most essential Lisbon experiences together with its rooftop bars. I was recommended it by my old blogging friend Gill. And boy was it good, rustic, generous local dishes in a superb location.
We went for deep fried fish (of some sardine variation), a big bowl of beans with a fishcake -one pot could feed at least two ‚Äî and a variety of other snacks and wine.
It‚Äôs a short ferry hop from Cais do Sodr√© to Cacilhas and then a 1km walk along a mostly abandoned and graffitied wharf to the restaurant. My only regret is that we didn‚Äôt return here.
Open daily 10am-12am
Av. 24 de Julho 49, Portugal Mainly catering to tourists, the Time Out Market is open all day every day and is worth visiting on Sunday and Monday nights in particular when many other restaurants are closed. It has a curated section of high profile local chefs with some stalls doing great value menu do dia.
You can try traditional local dishes such as prego rolls (steak sandwiches, braised ox cheek, bacaloa, pulvo (octopus) and croquetas at the various stalls. You can buy the amazing local Portuguese cheeses, ham, tinned goods, custard tarts and pastries. There‚Äôs also sushi, pizza, ice cream.
Seating probably 1,000 people it is a huge space with a really lively buzz. If you can‚Äôt decide what to eat, Time Out market will be no help because it will present you with so many choices.
There is a market next door with greengrocers, fish mongers and butchers.
Mon ‚Äî Thu 10:00‚Äì23:00, Fri ‚Äî Sun 10:00‚Äì01:00
106, R. Coelho da Rocha 104, Lisboa
This mercado is the Prahran Market of Lisbon though the focus is more about eating than shopping. It‚Äôs got plenty of steak and burger bars. In addition to others doing fish, ceviche and more. It‚Äôs a bit more pricy than the Time Out market and has less choice. It‚Äôs still fun though.
Saturday mornings
Jardim do Pr√≠ncipe Real This is the local farmers market. You can buy wine, sensational cheese, ham and fruit and veg. I bought an amazing local bread, heavy enough to sink a blogger. There are also a selection of food stalls where you can eat. It‚Äôs worth a Saturday morning stroll here and a coffee at the local kiosk.
R. Dom Pedro V 129, 1250‚Äì096 Lisboa
I‚Äôve already said it‚Äôs worth stopping for a large G&T or a pisco sour here. It‚Äôs also one of the hottest restaurants in town with terrific local variations on ceviche. Arrive early or make a booking.
NB: Don‚Äôt order the NZ sauvignon blanc!
R. Ant√≥nio Maria Cardoso 58, 1200‚Äì330 Lisboa
At first I thought I‚Äôd jumped back a decade at Mini Bar as a Ferran Adria Spherified Olive (2004) was delivered. But perhaps that was just my food nerdiness. The food and drink is good and is a diversion from the traditional rustic fare. The menu took us through an excellent selection of curated wines and tapas-style dishes with Japanese influences. There was tiny ice cream cone with sashimi; a single ceviche of prawn served on a lime that you bite into; chicken skin tapas; tuna tataki. Overall this was one of the best dining experiences in Lisbon. Owner Jos√© Avillez ‚Äî a local has other Lisbon restaurants all nearby ‚Äî Belcanto, Cantinho do Avillez, Caf√© Lisboa, and Pizzaria Lisboa.
R. Duques de Bragan√ßa 5, Lisboa
The crust is thin‚Ä¶really thin on these pricy pizzas.
Rua de O S√©culo 242, Lisboa
Recommended by our Airbnb host, Tascardo is very local and great value. I had the steak in a garlic sauce with a fried egg on top. Pam was surprised that the squid came complete with innards and beak. It‚Äôs tasty and rustic ‚Äî as is most Portuguese food.
R. Nova do Almada 95, 1200‚Äì288 Lisboa Eventually you will crave vegetables. I mean back home do you only eat meat, fish and potatoes? No. This place, off Lisbon‚Äôs main shopping strip, does healthy salads. Top up on vegetables here.
Portugal, R. das Portas de Santo Ant√£o 136, 1150‚Äì265 Lisboa  A grungy cafe doing Australian-style coffee and food. Worth a diversion.
Bengal Tandoori Lisboa
Rua da Alegria 23, Lisbon 1250‚Äì005
Curry in Lisbon? Why not. After all the Portuguese introduced chillis to India and led to the invention of vindaloo, a sour, hot curry containing pork. From savoury (and sweet for dessert) samosas to vindaloo this is a serious curry shop. You‚Äôll need to navigate windy narrow back streets past a few rowdy African bars.
LX Factory
R. Rodrigues de Faria 103, 1300 Lisboa
Mainly burger joints and interesting reclaimed industrial buildings with various boutiques.
Originally published at Tomato.

Back writing. Asking questions, blogging. Digital consultant. Drinks Chablis, rides exotic bicycles. Pats small dogs and trills at cats. Designs stuff.

Share
In November of 2017, I attended the Launch in Lisbon program and WebSummit. By the end of that trip, at a stylish and endearingly gritty aftertparty at the Hub Criativo Beato, I declared that I would be moving to Lisbon.
Now that I live here, people often ask why I picked Lisbon instead of a more obvious tech hub. It‚Äôs not a simple answer, and I get asked this question enough times that I decided to write this article about it:
I first visited Lisbon in the Spring of 2017 when I was attending several startup events across the EU, including cities such as London, Berlin, Milan, and Zurich. Lisbon was actually my stopover on the way to London; I had eight hours and one local friend to show me a preview of the city. We walked through some of the city‚Äôs many scenic areas and had lunch overlooking the river and the 25 de Abril Bridge on a bright sunny day ‚Äî Lisbon is known for its unique light, among other things. With my extra time I wandered the streets and had a casual meeting at Startup Lisboa to talk about their incubator program. There was something relaxed, warm and inviting about that meeting that left an impression on me as I left to visit other European cities.
In the US there was ongoing political tension and a degradation of values such as Net Neutrality (a free and open internet) and data privacy. I realized that launching a startup in the streaming video space would be more challenging and prone to failure in an already risky field. After researching the major European tech hubs, making several spreadsheets, and visiting startup community events, I was still not sure where it would make sense to base myself out of. So after considering the logical factors, I let all of that go and instead tuned into how I felt physically and emotionally in each city. The memories of the first hours in Lisbon kept appearing, and that was enough to justify the fateful trip where I made the decision.
Lisbon wants foreigners to come and build their companies here. They see new technology startups and even new companies with traditional business models as a way to grow their economy, and they are investing in that.
Lisbon offers a combination of loans and grants through its Portugal 2020 program, where you can receive 0% interest loans for almost half of your company‚Äôs initial operating costs without sacrificing any equity. There are also government-sponsored incubators such as Startup Lisboa (full disclosure: I am now in the Startup Lisboa program and a recipient of Portugal 2020 program so I‚Äôm totally biased), where you can have an adorable office in downtown Lisbon and mentorship services for a very small monthly cost. I used to have a discounted ‚Äúhot desk‚Äù at a coworking space in New York and now, for the same price, I have an office that can fit four people with a view of a building with azulejos (those pretty tiles associated with Lisbon) and a small balcony where I can see the Tejo river.
The costs for administrative activities and employees is also lower compared to Western Europe and most of the US, but to be fair, I should point out that those costs will increase in the next few years as the Portuguese economy matures and more tech companies more here for ‚Äúnearshoring‚Äù (yes, that‚Äôs a thing). Because of the lower operating costs, I am able to bootstrap for a longer period of time and achieve more milestones before giving away equity for investment
Portugal is a crossroads between Europe, the Americas and Africa, and the Lusophone (network of portuguese speaking countries) even extends to some parts of South and East Asia. Why does this matter? Aside from business reasons, it helps Lisbon and Portugal to break away from homogeneous thinking. The LGBT, creative, and entrepreneurial communities often intersect and result in social and cultural amenities that are usually reserved for larger cities.
Portugal‚Äôs legendary hospitality and diversity are also a factor that helps Portugal earn the ranking with of best quality of life for expats in the world and helps Lisbon consistently place in the Monocle annual Quality of Life survey. And in the startup scene itself, it lends to a more collaborative, supportive environment rather than a competitive mentality.
Maybe it‚Äôs because Portugal and the UK are in the same timezone and have had a peace treaty for over 600 years. It could also be because Portugal‚Äôs population is 10.3 million (somewhere between the populations of New Jersey and Pennsylvania) and they don‚Äôt expect the world to learn their language. Regardless of the reason, the Portuguese tend to speak really good English. The younger population and tech professionals are almost always fluent. Being a native English speaker is an advantage here, and learning basic Portuguese is sincerely appreciated, but not mandatory.
I‚Äôm surprised that the Portuguese speak English with an accent that often sounds more American than British. They tell me that it is because they don‚Äôt dub their films and they watch a lot of US TV shows on Netflix.
Also, I should note that many Portuguese people speak three or more languages ‚Äî usually English, French, Spanish or German in addition to their native tongue. They do not have the same linguistic reputation as the Swiss, but I think they deserve this acknowledgment.
Launching a company in countries with larger populations and strong domestic economies can cause a company to think about only the local market. That doesn‚Äôt work very well for a tech startup with global ambitions. In Portugal‚Äôs case, they expect you to focus on external markets as soon as you can. And the government has an internationalization program with grants to help you market to other countries.
As I stated previously, Portugal is a crossroads, an international hub that connects to other global markets and cultures despite its relatively small size.
Lisbon is a startup hub that is not held back by old paradigms.
Berlin, London and Paris: they are wonderful places and have thriving startup scenes. But they all have a preconceived notion and a reputation that is hard to change. Lisbon doesn‚Äôt have this burden; Lisbon is creating something new, experimenting and evolving as it discovers its niche. The creative class and digital nomads often come from interesting and wealthy countries and choose to move to Lisbon after seeing many parts of the world.
I‚Äôve heard that Portugal is described as the ‚ÄúNew California‚Äù and Lisbon is the new San Francisco of Europe. I don‚Äôt know if I agree with that assessment but I do imagine that Lisbon has the potential to be a futuristic Starfleet Headquarters-type place. A center of innovation, creativity and a place that embodies the human rights and data policies that were outlined in the Treaty of Lisbon. And I think Lisbon has a strong chance of being associated with new media.
Like many startup founders, I might be extra optimistic and biased. I might fail and Lisbon might not reach its potential. But there is a spirit here that continuously encourages me to embrace Lisbon, and Lisbon has already displayed its ongoing level of commitment to me.
Michael Fiorentino is the Founder of Vixtape, which is building a streaming TV service that combines audio, video and data in new ways. He will have a booth at WebSummit and will be VJing several unofficial night events that week in Barrio Alto, Principe Real and Marvila.
--

New York ad tech / data marketing executive who moved to Lisbon to build a streaming TV startup

Content:

If you‚Äôre planning a summer holiday, why choose between city or beach? Come to sunny Lisbon and have both!
You find beaches for all tastes around Lisbon. Here‚Äôs your ultimate Lisbon beach guide to the main and easily accessible areas.
50 km northwest of Lisbon easily reached by car or public transports.
This quaint fishing village became a Europe‚Äôs top surf spot and is one of the four World Surfing Reserves. Its best surf breaks include Ribeira d‚ÄôIlhas, Coxos and Pedra Branca. Its Atlantic coastline has a handful of unspoiled beaches great to relax and spend some family time, like Foz do Lizandro and S√£o Louren√ßo. During the summer, it comes alive with locals and tourists and there‚Äôs no shortage of beach accommodation, surf schools and lodges, nightlife spots and seafood restaurants.
30 km northwest of Lisbon easily reached by car or public transports.
This UNESCO site town is widely known for its dream-like palaces. However, north of town and included in a protected area, near picturesque villages with local restaurants serving delicious food you find beaches loved for their wilderness and natural beauty. Adraga, Grande and Ma√ß√£s are amongst the best beaches near Sintra.
30 km west of Lisbon easily reached by car or public transports.
In the Portuguese Riviera more than ten Blue Flag beaches have something for everyone ‚Äî family fun, water sports and great spots for surfing and sports alike. Tamariz and Carcavelos are some of the best-known, and there‚Äôs the wild Guincho, a world‚Äôs top windsurf location. There are hip surf hostels and schools galore, Europe‚Äôs biggest casino, top-class beach hotels and golf resorts. These are the beaches most easily accessible from Lisbon and can get busy during the summer.
15 km south of Lisbon easily reached by car or public transports.
Portugal‚Äôs longest strip of sand spreads over 30 km with beaches facing the Atlantic fresh waters. Apart from endless space for sunbathing, you find a variety of watersports including surfing, kitesurfing, windsurfing and scuba-diving, as well as schools and hostels. Affordable seafood, lively beach bars and summer parties complete the scenery for a fantastic sunny time with sand between your toes. During the summer, a small train takes you along 10 km of beaches. As for the other 20 km, car is the best option. The further south you go, the wilder it gets and the fewer people you find. It‚Äôs also home to one of the earliest nudist beaches around the capital ‚Äî Meco.
40 km south of Lisbon easily reached by car or public transports
This picturesque fishing town is home to long strips of sand facing calm waters. It‚Äôs a popular amongst locals, mainly families attracted by the quiet waters of the sheltered bays. Although it became a popular summer resort known for it beach hotels and fresh seafood restaurants, it retains its fishing atmosphere ‚Äî you can still see the fishermen selling the day‚Äôs catch. Located at the mouth of the Sado River, the sea is rich in fish, being one of the best sport-fishing spots around Lisbon. Amongst its most sought after beaches are Calif√≥rnia and Ouro.
45 km south of Lisbon easily reached by car.
The scenery is something you‚Äôll never forget about Arr√°bida‚Äôs beaches ‚Äî the perfect combination of golden sand, green cliffs, and blue sea.
A natural park covering 108 km2 is home to peaceful sandy coves. Its calm blue waters and the diversity of marine life make it one of the best spots for snorkelling and scuba-diving in Portugal. Its sea caves are also an opportunity for those who enjoy caving and diving. Portinho da Arr√°bida and Figueirinha are its most famous beaches. If you‚Äôre a seafood fan, there are excellent and affordable restaurants.
55km south of Lisbon easily reached by car/ferryboat
This peninsula inspires anyone with its magnificent landscape, formed by the Arr√°bida green mountains, the Sado estuary and miles of unspoiled dunes. Its long beaches and the calm transparent waters are ideal for families, like the Tr√≥ia-mar beach. For a break from the sand, there are tours to watch dolphins playing in the sea, watersports and beachfront resorts with tennis courts and golf courses. A casino and superb seafood restaurants complete the picture, making it a top-notch beach destination. Just count with prices above the average.
70km south of Lisbon easily reached by car/ferryboat
In the small village of Comporta things are as simple as long swathes of sand and calm waters sheltered by dunes and pinewoods. In a protected area that impresses by its natural beauty and wildlife, you find a beach that goes by the same name with everything for a tranquil summer holiday and an invigorating contact with nature. There are golf courses and excellent conditions for bird watching, or you can just take a seaside stroll or hop on a horse for a different view of the sands. You can choose from affordable places to eco-friendly villas and house retreats with a touch of luxury. One thing is sure ‚Äî compared with Tr√≥ia it‚Äôs much natural and quieter.
Originally published at www.welovelisbon.net on March 18, 2015.

Title: Moving to Portugal ‚Äî An immigrant experience of Lisbon, Part I (by Lisa Morrow & Kim Hewett)
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
Share
Even before the pandemic, many people, particularly US citizens, have been looking to move somewhere that offered a better quality of life. One of the main criteria is it must be safe, and on the surface Portugal appears to be a good option. Nobody gets killed at school by rampaging gunmen, the country isn‚Äôt always at war, or threatening war, and most people aren‚Äôt openly aggressive towards people of colour. So, what‚Äôs to worry about?
The question of how we learn about the practicalities of immigrating to a new country critically depends on the scope of your enquiries. How deep do you go and how do you rate the sources you use to draw conclusions? My husband and I, both sociologists and writers, lived in Lisbon for three and a half years. We had travelled there several times before and already had a few Portuguese friends before we decided to move. We didn‚Äôt speak much Portuguese but it wasn‚Äôt our first time starting life in a new country where we didn‚Äôt speak the language. We did everything ourselves, there was no relocation agent, and we knew obtaining accommodation, dealing with bureaucracy and getting settled would require patience and a lot of energy. Even having a relocation agent doesn‚Äôt count for much, because once you‚Äôre settled, the problems don‚Äôt end there.

Title: Paper Trails and Power Stamps: Bureaucracy, from Lisbon to Maputo
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
If Portugal invented bureaucracy, Mozambique made it smoke a joint and forget why it walked into the room.
I‚Äôve danced with the bureaucratic devils in both countries ‚Äî Portugal with its deadly seriousness and love of obscure forms, and Mozambique with its spectacular improvisation, where systems are more suggestion than structure. Neither place is designed to facilitate getting things done. They take different approaches to the art of not getting there.
Let‚Äôs start in Portugal. Bureaucracy here is like an elaborate board game where no one explains the rules, the dice are missing, and halfway through, someone switches the language to Legalese. You show up with everything you were told to bring, plus a few extras (because you‚Äôve been burned before). The clerk glances at your papers, sighs, and says you‚Äôre missing a Declara√ß√£o de Exist√™ncia, a certificate proving you still exist ‚Äî and no, your breathing presence isn‚Äôt proof enough.
Everything must be official. Preferably signed and ideally stamped. A document without a stamp is like a Portuguese coffee without sugar: technically functional, but deeply unsatisfying to the authorities.
Now, contrast this with Mozambique. I spent years navigating state offices, where everything takes longer, but somehow no one is in a rush. Want a driving licence? That‚Äôll take weeks. Maybe months. Possibly a goat. You learn to bring your pen, paper, and, ideally, someone who knows someone. In Mozambique, the system is more about who you know than what you know or even what you need.
There, it‚Äôs less paperwork and more social performance. A good handshake and a wide smile can accelerate a process faster than a notarised form. People nod solemnly, take your papers, disappear into the back for what feels like a pilgrimage, then return and say: ‚ÄúCome back tomorrow. Maybe.‚Äù
I once went to collect a simple residency document in Maputo. The office had no electricity, but a woman behind a desk was still diligently stamping papers. I asked how she was managing. She lifted the stamp, thudded it onto a blank form, and said: ‚ÄúWe stamp first. Later, we figure out what it was for.‚Äù
Efficiency? No. But creativity? Absolutely.
In Portugal, the power lies with the rules. In Mozambique, power lies with the person holding the stamp pad ‚Äî usually someone sipping tea behind a dusty desk who may or may not be in today, depending on the weather, the fuel supply, or their cousin‚Äôs wedding.
Portugal loves the illusion of control. Everything is digital now‚Ä¶ sort of. There‚Äôs a national portal, multiple logins, security codes sent by SMS, and inevitably, a crash right when you need it most. You try to upload a form, and the system tells you the document is too large ‚Äî it‚Äôs a one-page PDF. You call the helpline, and they suggest using Internet Explorer in 2025.
Meanwhile, in Mozambique, the system has already crashed weeks ago. The printer doesn‚Äôt work. The person who knew the password is on leave. But someone will eventually scrawl your details in a giant ledger with the confidence of a 16th-century monk, and you‚Äôll leave with a semi-official-looking slip of paper, possibly signed with a Bic pen and blessed by chaos.
The difference is in tone. Portuguese bureaucracy takes itself very seriously. Everything must be done properly, even when it doesn‚Äôt work. Especially then. In Mozambique, no one pretends the system works. It‚Äôs acknowledged with a laugh, a shrug, and a story.
And maybe that‚Äôs the heart of it. In Portugal, the system is king, cold, stubborn, and demanding. In Mozambique, the system is a rumour, and the people are the real structure holding everything together. That may sound romantic, but it also means nothing is predictable, and everything is negotiable.
So, which is worse? Honestly, it depends on the day. In Portugal, I leave the office frustrated but eventually successful, clutching my over-stamped document like a war medal. In Mozambique, I leave smiling, document-free, and slightly unsure what just happened ‚Äî but someone offered me cashew nuts and called me mana.
Different brands of chaos. Same familiar headache.
If you enjoyed this tangled tale, stick around. There‚Äôs plenty more where this came from ‚Äî with laughs, insights, and a few more hair-raising adventures on life, parenting, work, and everything in between.

Member-only story

I wasn‚Äôt sure I wanted to go. We‚Äôve been to many ruined castles before. It‚Äôs just walls, right?
Castelo de S√£o Jorge is pretty much at the top of Lisbon, the city of seven hills, with a steep climb required to reach it. On top of it all, it is scorching in the middle of July ‚Äî do we really want to go?
In the end, what decided it was that we arrived on a Monday. And most Lisbon museums are closed on Mondays.
We didn‚Äôt know ‚Äî one of the gaps in our research ‚Äî and didn‚Äôt have alternate plans ready.
Another factor was that it was open until 9 pm, and we could be there at sunset. We were jet lagged and needed to crash first, and then find something not too demanding to do at the end of our first day.
We set off around 6:30 pm, following Google‚Äôs directions along the twisted and meandering streets. There was a free elevator (Elevador Castelo) about halfway point which allowed us to gain a bit of altitude without climbing. We got there closer to 7 pm ‚Äî and stayed until the end because it was just spectacular.

On my request, my VA compiled a list of museums in and around Lisbon for me. The Museu de Marinha (in Belem) is free on the 1st Sunday of every month (which today, Oct 1, happens to be) so I decided to check it out. I did pay the extra for the temporary exhibition Vikings although it wasn‚Äôt as educational or even as entertaining as I expected it to be so I don‚Äôt recommend it. In fact, if you have a Netflix subscription, watch the series Vikings (its gruesome and probably inaccurate but definitely entertaining)
As for the Museu de Marinha itself, I highly recommend it. Here are some of my random thoughts and photographs of the visit.
The entrance itself is impressive with a tall ceiling of many (probably unnecessary) arches. Beneath it sits a statue of Prince Henry (Infante D. Henrique) who is credited with launching the Age of Discoveries for Portugal.
There‚Äôs also a giant map behind him of the Portuguese exploration. Naturally, I was curious about their conquest of Goa so I zoomed in for a closer look.
According the the map, there‚Äôs a route taken by Pedro Alvares Cabral in 1500 from Portugal to Brazil, then past the Cape of Good Hope onwards to the East Coast of Africa and finally Goa. Vasco da Gama it seems, went straight to Cochin. Some day soon I will research more about these sea routes.
The museum has a large variety of ship models progressing from charming early 14th century merchant ships all the way to the less-impressive 21st century destroyer ships and submarines.
It was a bit disappointing to see the transition of ships as vessels of exploration and commerce into vessels of war over the years.
I did however find a small label in the exhibit that mentioned the ‚Äúmyth‚Äù of the School of Sagres.
Since I had never heard of this School before, I believe the myth even more now.
(hint: This could be the start of a great Dan Brown novel)
If you like Museums and you‚Äôre in/around Lisbon, here‚Äôs the map i referred to earlier with information about free days and museum timings. Feel free to use and share.

Title: What business can learn from a small restaurant in Lisbon
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Kanazawa opens everyday for dinner. On a good day, it sits eight customers. On a bad day too. How a tiny restaurant with pricey menus, slow service and a strict reservation policy is challenging its industry‚Äôs dogmas.
Tomoaki Kanazawa started cooking in 1985. In 1993 he was invited by the Japanese Ambassador in Portugal to come to Lisbon as the Embassy Chef. Years later he opened his own restaurant, Tomo, that would become a reference in traditional Japanese cuisine in Lisbon.
However, Tomoaki wasn‚Äôt happy. He believed that when customers visited his restaurant they should feel as if they were eating at someone‚Äôs home but, because he was serving over 100 meals at lunch and dinner, he couldn‚Äôt spare a minute to be with them, so he couldn‚Äôt provide them with that kind of experience. So he took a bold step: he left Tomo to his employees and, together with his wife Kayo and his daughter Sakura, he opened Kanazawa, the 8 seat restaurant that set up a whole new standard for high end cuisine in Lisbon and may well become a business case study.
1. You can make customers work for your product
Kanazawa‚Äôs first management lesson is that you don‚Äôt need to make your customers‚Äô lives easy, what you need is to have a product they want so badly they will work hard to get.
The waiting list is months-long. When I was there in November, I overheard a fellow customer saying that he was trying to make a reservation since August. Not only that, but the booking experience is in itself a challenge. You can‚Äôt book a table over the phone, the reservations are to be made online. After providing your contact information, you must select three alternative dates for your visit. Then, you have to confirm that you agree with the cancellation policy, which states that, if you cancel your reservation in the 3 day-period prior to the confirmed date, you will pay a cancellation fee, which starts at 60% of the price of the menu if you cancel 3 days before and rises up to 100% if you cancel on the same day. After confirming your agreement, your credit card number is requested, which is to ensure that, if you actually decide to cancel within that 3-day period, the fee is credited from your account.
Finally, you must choose one of the four different menus, prices ranging from 60‚Ç¨ to 150‚Ç¨. It is almost impossible to grasp the differences between the menus, as the dishes names are in Japanese and there are no pictures to illustrate them. Calling the restaurant won‚Äôt work either (I tried), as the language barrier is there too. My very simple solution for this complex problem was to google every dish on each menu, go over the available pictures, and create a global understanding of what to expect.
This extenuating process sends a strong message to the customer: The restaurant is opening for eight people only, and you are one of them. From the moment we accept your reservation, we are deeply committed to provide you with the best experience we can create. Make sure to honor your commitment too. It might sound harsh, but it is easy to understand if you refer back to Tomoaki‚Äôs vision: when you visit his restaurant you should feel as if you were eating at his home. So think about it, if you were invited to an 8-guest dinner party at a friend‚Äôs place and he was counting on you to bring the wine, would you lightly cancel on the same day?
2. You can invest time on your customers
Kanazawa‚Äôs second management lesson is that time spent preparing and delivering a personalized experience to your customers is never ‚Äî ever ‚Äî wasted.
When I arrived at Kanazawa, Kayo took my coat and showed me where I was supposed to sit. While I was seating I was stunned to notice that there was a small, handwritten name tag with my name on it, right next to a line-up of the courses, also handwritten, with that day‚Äôs date on it. It is a small gesture that immediately makes you feel special and welcome. Someone took the time to write this for me, I thought.
The eight seats are placed around the sushi bar. Tomoaki served the first course, calmly explaining what it was, where the ingredients came from (more on that in a second), and how to taste it. The ritual is repeated every time a new course is served. Even though he alternates between groups of customers, he is able to make each group feel unique, as if he was there just for them.
At Kanazawa desserts are cooked by Kayo, so she takes over when the time comes to serve and explain them. She goes individually to each group and speaks in a really soft, delicate manner, that somehow makes you feel all the careful dedication that was put into each of the tiny portions of cake, mousse and ice-cream, all made from local ingredients. She then brings in a small portion of handmade candy, served in a mirrored-plate and accompanied by the tiniest origami I‚Äôve ever seen (someone did this for me, I thought). Before leaving, you still get a package of homemade cookies to take home.
The whole service is perfectly adapted to the rhythm of each group, as if someone was keeping an attentive eye to make sure that you would neither be rushed nor have to wait too long. This probably has something to do with the fact that Tomoaki designed the whole experience based on the Japanese tea ceremony inspired by Sen no Rikyu. I arrived at Kanazawa at 8.30pm and left at 11.30pm, feeling that it was still 9.30pm, just like would have happened if I was having dinner at some old friend‚Äôs place. Tomoaki and his family spent 3 hours of their evening with me. And I can‚Äôt wait to go back.
3. You can work with your family
Kanazawa‚Äôs third management lesson is that working with your family doesn‚Äôt have to be a tense experience for all of those involved ‚Äî it can actually be quite peaceful.
If you‚Äôve ever watched or read about Netflix‚Äôs Chef‚Äôs Table, you know that family plays a big part in Chefs‚Äô careers. Families can either be the solid foundation or the constant source of pressure, questioning, and regret for great Chefs around the world.
Kanazawa employs three people, and they are all related. You might expect that this simple fact could in itself result in a not so simple work dynamics, but that is not the case ‚Äî at all. In fact, all the processes and rituals are so well coordinated among Tomoaki, Kayo and Sakura that you barely hear them speak to each other. Or get into each other‚Äôs space. Sakura mostly helps her father in the kitchen, but she doesn‚Äôt need to be told what to do. She just knows the rhythm and plays according to it. She moves graciously at precise moments. Kayo works her way around customers, picking up finished courses, delivering new tableware, serving tea, so discretely that you can barely hear her steps. It‚Äôs almost as if they are dancing a secret family dance. You don‚Äôt know the moves but it is just beautiful to watch.
Their working choreography not only looks peaceful from the outside, it actually makes you feel calm and relaxed, as when you visit a couple of friends at their place and they naturally take turns going to the kitchen to prepare the meal, just to make sure that you are not left alone in the living room. One of them is always keeping you company. That‚Äôs how you feel at Kanazawa too.
4. You can buy from local vendors
Kanazawa‚Äôs fourth management lesson is that it is possible to run a successful business making it a principle to buy from small local vendors.
Tomoaki not only selects Portuguese fish for his restaurant, he makes sure that each species‚Äô origin is well-known to the customers. One of the highest moments of the dining experience comes when he opens up a wood box containing different fish species, perfectly cut and prepared, and talks in great detail about the provenience and seasonality of each of them, so that the customer can make a well informed choice about the nigiris he should prepare. Most of the vegetables and fruits used have Portuguese roots too. What his suppliers have in common, beyond the nationality, is the compromise towards sustainable production.
This is one direct consequence of Kanazawa‚Äôs very unique operating model. Working in a 100-seat restaurant means preparing food three or four days in advance. You don‚Äôt actually know how many people will come (even those who made a reservation can cancel or simply don‚Äôt show up) and what they will eat, so you need to have a huge stock in place and proceed with as much setting up as possible. Tomoaki, on the other hand, not only has eight customers per night, but he also knows beforehand what they will be eating and he can be quite sure that they will come. So he can focus on preparing the best ‚Äî not the cheapest nor the fastest ‚Äî meal his customers can have, and he can buy fresh ingredients and source them locally.
Isn‚Äôt that what anyone who has guests over does? Buying ingredients from a market or supermarket that is trustworthy and close to home and preparing the meal just before the guests arrive? If you‚Äôve ever been in the host position, you know how good it feels to look for and cook the best ingredients you can find. But as a guest, you also know how good it feels to have a simple but thoughtful meal put together just for you. And this is where Tomoaki‚Äôs brilliance reveals itself once again: you feel that, by putting all this focus in looking for the best ingredients, he is concerned with putting a thoughtful meal together for you.
All in all, Kanazawa‚Äôs main take-away lesson for business is this: if you have a strong vision for your product, invest your time on crafting and delivering a personalized experience for your customers, create a safe and calm working environment, and stay true to your principles, you can focus on what really matters, which is to turn your work into a permanent state of passion.

Content:

Lisbon‚Ä¶ I have arrived to this wonderful city two years ago and fell in love with it at the first glance. Lisbon was like my beloved man, like my lover and my soulmate who was waiting for me for all his life, waiting patiently for me to come. I remember that wonderful day in April 2013, I remember that moment when the plane was about to land and my knees started to shiver‚Ä¶.. I had a strange feeling that I am coming home but not going for a vacation to an amazing country with a very old and rich history. And I guess I was right‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ because 2 years later (as I was coming back over and over again to see my beloved Lisbon) I have relocated here.
I love this city and this amazing country for its marvellous landscapes, incredible beaches, breath-taking nature, magnificent sunsets and wonderful sky. Yes, sky. If you have travelled a lot I bet you noticed that sky and clouds in every country are different. But if you have been to Portugal at least once you will never forget its sky, because you will not be able to find something like that in any other place. I would like to share with you my impressions and experience from the places I have visited in Portugal, about the beauty of this country, its history, its architecture and its magnificent charisma, yes charisma because Portugal for me is not just a country, it is like a lifetime partner who is always happy with you, for you and feels saudade (beautiful juicy Portuguese word which actually has no direct translation but describes a deep emotional state of nostalgia for something or someone you really love, e.g. your motherland or beloved person, something important and significant) when you leave it.
For many years it was a forgotten city. It endured a very long dictatorship; and later it accumulated errors of urban planning. :) Nowadays Lisbon is a city with an odd geography comprising different villages, connected by a incomprehensible system of streets, alleys, lanes, travessas (small, narrow but very cosy streets) abandoned tram lines. Perhaps it is the city where it is impossible to make plans at all; because the city grabs you, hugs you and whispers to your ears lots of crazy ideas even if you have strict plans and you need to stick to them. You might have a walk downtown because you have an appointment there with a friend or a lesson of Portuguese language close to Rua Augusta but then‚Ä¶ suddenly you just make a turn to the street you haven‚Äôt been before to grab a coffee and suddenly beauty of new unknown street devours you completely, you call your friend and ask to join you immediately or you give a call to language school to reschedule the lesson because now you have to explore the beauty you haven‚Äôt seen before. And this is a way much more important than studying. :)
Lisbon loves you a lot, you feel this love, you swim at it, and you feel it with your heart, your skin, your fingertips and your soul. Lisbon hugs you and whispers wonderful words to your ears, he sings fado (incredibly beautiful traditional music and songs in Lisbon, which refers to saudade as originally fado are songs about loss and missing something important) for you, he offers you amazing food, and you feel overwhelmed with this city. That is how I felt from the very first minute I have spent in Lisbon. If you come here once and stay for living you realise that in this city you live like the days were never-ending and Lisbon is a boyfriend who does not forgive your absence. Because today you need to be in Gulbenkian museum because the new exhebition is just starting, and at the same day there is a wonderful indie rock band performing in Bairro Alto, and tomorrow you need to wake up early because you have classes but you have no time to study at all because this city offers so many things every day. You need to go to that new restaurant of seafood which has just opened downtown, then your friend has a launch of a book, then you were thinking of going to Alfama and making some great photos, and finally your friend from Germany is calling and saying that she has a day off and you need to go to Carcavelos for surfing. And you have so many things to do, which you REALLY need to do and you have an early morning yoga class. BUT, You cannot resist this city and you are never tired of all the activities he offers you and you cannot refuse all this as you might offend him. But your love for it is so huge and you need to be there for this city all the time so you just flow with it and its rythm.

Is a trip to Lisbon complete without a taste of Natas? or a trip to the Pena Palace? or a visit to the Tower of Belem popularly referred to by the locals as the Torre de Belem? I could go on and on because there is just so much to do in Lisbon in two days, which was all the time we had to spend there.
The visit to Lisbon, Portugal was a short and sweet one, with my oldest friend of 22 years. We spent the first night having a fancy dinner at the Tivoli restaurant (I recommend this restaurant, the service and food were amazing) on Liberdade avenue. Also on Liberdade avenue, you will find many name brand stores, as well as other 5-star hotels.
On the first day, we did a Lisbon city tour through a one hour Tuk Tuk ride. Frankly, I sometimes think this is a better option compared to the hop on hop off buses because of the intimacy and flexibility it offers. We rode through the Alfama district, stopped by the highest viewpoints in Lisbon for a phenomenal aerial view of the city. We went past the Cathedral church of Lisbon where several wedding ceremonies are conducted at once during the San Antonio Festival in June. We also went past the famous Cristiano Ronaldo Bistro and Bar, a stop for a drink at the bar would have been nice, but that did not happen.

Title: Sun, Surf, Sagres and Startup ‚Äî Lisbon Lifestyle
Content:

I arrived in Lisbon a little over one month ago to start my Erasmus semester abroad. I had previously not visited Lisbon but had heard incredible things, so when I arrived, I wanted to see it all for myself. I couldn‚Äôt wait to get out and get active making use of the last summer days in September/October. I found myself immersed by a city full of beautiful old buildings, cobbled streets (old streets of Alfama), viewpoints (Miradouro Santa Catarina, Nossa Senhora de Monte are two favourites) and rooftop bars at sunset (Park, Topo, LX), great contemporary art (Museu Cole√ß√£o Berardo) not to mention the surfing (Costa de Caparica) and most importantly the incredible nightlife here (cheap drinks in Bairro, great electronic music at Lux and a festival called Brunch). But hands down the best aspect of Erasmus is the exposure to new people, new cultures, new languages and most importantly new food!
But, me being me‚Ä¶I just can‚Äôt seem to ignore my keen interest in startup‚Äôs and Lisbon‚Äôs thriving ecosystems makes it even harder to ignore. Once I got confirmation of my place here at NOVA , I quickly added Web Summit to the list of ‚Äòmust-dos‚Äô whilst here. Building on my past work at Leade.rs and VivaTech earlier this year (check out my medium profile). I am very much looking forward to being part of their Live team covering social media for this momentous event ‚Äî boy do we have a task. Previously based in Dublin ‚Äî 2016 was the first year Lisbon hosted the event and what an event it was‚Ä¶attracting 53,000 people, 15,000 companies, 7,000 CEOs and 700 investors it became Europe‚Äôs largest tech conference, and it‚Äôs poised to grow in 2017. This all demonstrates that Lisbon is not only capable but eager and yearning to establish itself on the world stage as a leader in creativity, technology, and innovation.
Paddy Cosgrove Web Summit founder put it well‚Ä¶‚ÄòLisbon is like Berlin five years ago, but with a southern European climate.‚Äô
Currently Lisbon is a rising star and an underdog ‚Äî ranked by Allianz as the fifth-best-performing startup community in Europe, ahead of front-runners like Stockholm and Dublin. In fact, according to Preqin, the number of VC deals closed in Lisbon 2016 jumped sixfold from 2015, delivering it‚Äôs best year yet $18.5 million spread across 9 deals. But that is just the tip of the iceberg ‚Äî the Portuguese have had to make do without swaths of international investment which countries like the UK and Germany have received and that has translated into making Lisbon one of the best locations to bootstrap a startup.
One of Portugal‚Äôs main attractions is the combination of low-cost of living and high quality of life, two things that are very rarely found in one of Europe‚Äôs capital cities. On top of that, the OECD considered it the 3rd easiest country to start a company. This makes it makes it cheaper and easier to build great products utilising their highly skilled and ubiquitous talent. Fun fact: Lisbon has the highest percentage of founders with Masters or Ph.D. a whopping 82%.
Their rich history also plays its part, their Age of Discovery inspires a sense of exploration and due to Portugal‚Äôs small size; it fosters an outwardly focused mindset. It‚Äôs this very mindset which makes startups here think ‚Äòinternational from day one‚Äô giving them access to a larger addressable market, vital to startup scalability. According to the 2017 Startup Genome Report, Portuguese startups have high proportion of customers from outside Europe. A great example being F*ck Marry Kill, the gamified dating app, was founded in Lisbon but also enjoys popularity in German markets too. Furthermore, another advantage is how widespread and well spoken English is here, EF reports English proficiency at 59.68%.
Picture yourself ‚Äì considering all of the above whilst relaxing in the hot summer sun after a surf on a stunning beach; sipping a caipirinha and eating some freshly caught and perfectly cooked seafood ‚Äîthen you know how it feels to live in Portugal.
It‚Äôs international accessibility, low cost of living and enriching lifestyle is catching ever more attention of global talent and press. All of these factors coalesce to accelerate the momentum it has recently accumulated ‚Äî but to become sustainable, the ecosystem needs founders to nurture the next generation of entrepreneurs by spreading their knowledge and expertise through mentorship and re-investment.
A vital channel for mentorship, funding and networking is incubators such as, Beta-i producing 40 startups and raising more than $166million. They have worked with over 500 startups and run various acceleration programs, including Beta-start and Lisbon Challenge which attract applicants from 60 countries.
Canopy City a social impact-focused coworking space and incubator.
Impact Hub part innovation lab, part business incubator, and part community center.
BET Ventures an events company aimed at empowering entrepreneur‚Äôs.
StartUP Lisboa a government body focused on scale-up innovation. Check out their #ThisisPortugal campaign below.
Talkdesk, joined 500 startups ‚Äî received 21 million dollars of investment from Salesforce.Uniplaces, a disruptive force in the student accommodation industry that started in Lisbon and has spread to 30+ European cities ‚Äî raised $24 million Series A last NovemberCLICK HERE for more.
In many ways Lisbon feels like Europe‚Äôs version of San Francisco ‚Äî not to mention the look-a-like Golden Gate Bridge, tanned surfers, streetcars and hills (lucky no sharks though).
Sheffield‚Äôs Universities Portuguese partner and my host university, Nova School of Business and Economics is in the unique position of having a great interface with the Lisbon startup community due to their newly opened NOVA Venture Lab, running its flagship Zero Gravity incubator/accelerator programme designed to invest in and develop innovative startups both nationally and internationally.
This innovative mindset filters into their teaching here too. In particular one of the main driving forces behind this renewed perspective and practice is Miguel Mun√±oz Duarte my Entrepreneurship professor and CEO of iMatch an innovation, marketing and sales focused collaborative consultancy. He has great connections to the vibrant ecosystem here and often arranges guest speakers to shine some light on the practical workings of the methodologies and techniques that we learn. A great example of this was our first guest Christian Vismara ‚Äî a product manager at Build-Up Labs who came to talk to our class about his role there and specifically his work on F*ck Marry Kill.
First off, Build Up Labs is a Lisbon based Startup Studio also known as a Venture Builder ‚Äî they create startups from start to finish (wherever that may be). A Venture builder is an all in one ideation, building/development, and growth house. They leverage a lean process and a cross-disciplinary team using shared resources to grow successful businesses. Think of it as the diametric opposite of ‚Äòall your eggs in one basket‚Äô ‚Äî instead their approach is ‚Äòput lots of eggs in different basket and nurture them until they either fly or die.‚Äô
Recently parent Startup birdie (Build Up Labs) celebrated it‚Äôs first successful hatch and fly- in other words, their first exit with NVY.LIFE to L‚ÄôOreal, it‚Äôs a beauty and lifestyle club via blog/news/app ‚Äî they help readers to realise the best versions of themselves. Check it out HERE.
Christian however, talked a little more about F*ck Marry Kill (FMK) ‚Äî dubbed ‚ÄúTinder of the university students‚Äù by Jornal de Not√≠cias and as the name suggests, it‚Äôs not your standard dating service it‚Äôs a game that is designed not to be taking seriously and is best at making it more fun to meet new people. They are now attracting a growing and addicted user base in Portugal and Germany too. In total, they have 72,600 users and has already registered 1.2 million hits and more than 550,000 messages sent.
tapmyback ‚Äî a peer-to-peer motivation and feedback tool for teams. ToyToy a kids toy product discovery app.CLICK HERE to check out their Portfolio.
‚ÄúThe only thing worse than starting something and failing‚Ä¶is not starting.‚Äù ‚Äî Seth Godin
Startup is a game of failure and if you fail, you learn and if you learn, you succeed. At Build Up Labs they strongly head the words above. Un-afraid to talk about their past mistakes they view their failures as a portfolio of experience and after all, their motto is‚Ä¶
‚ÄúGrow fast or kill fast‚Äù
The venture building model was new and interesting to me, so after the great talk Christian gave; I approached him to find out more‚Ä¶I was invited to visit their office in the up-and-coming industrial end of town, Marvilla which is located in a co-working space called The Hood ‚Äî I was introduced to all the members of the team; Rui Gouveia CEO, Jo√£o Duarte data scientist, Jo√£o Pereira and Salvador Barros, I am really excited to help develop their social profile and produce an effective strategy.
CLICK HERE to find out more about the venture building model.
Finally, I have to say that I have never felt such a strong affinity to a city, let alone the one I luckily chose to study in. There is so much to do and see and it‚Äôs impossible to tire of it. A trip to Oporto is next on the agenda.
If you are reading this and you are;
A. interested in startup/tech/innovation
B. going to web summit C. need a social media helping hand.
Then reach out to me via email: t.dwyer193@gmail.com

Content:

Welcome to a new edition of the Tales of Ink and Light. In this one, i flip through the pages of a classic photobook and find echoes of the poetry that attracted me to Lisbon.
A decisive factor in my decision to move to Lisboa was the poetic atmosphere that i had felt while walking up and down its streets during a few short-ish stays. Often when i leave the house, i am unexpectedly reminded of that impalpable yet intensely real thing that exudes from the city.
I find it hard to define (and there is also the fact that i‚Äôd be reluctant to name it with precision, even if it were possible). It may be the colours of the walls, it may be the light, it may be a smell, it may be certain clothes people wear, it may be the sounds, it may be attitudes or certain sentences, and the river is certainly a part of it. It is these small things that suddenly appear to incarnate the soul of the place and make you think ‚Äî oh, yes, indeed, i‚Äôm here, this is it. It is the sort of inescapable feeling that seems impossible to describe and that you can only understand if you‚Äôve experienced it personally time and time again.
‚ÄòLisbon, you know‚Ä¶‚Äô is a sentence i read in a poem that appears in Lisboa, cidade triste e alegre (‚ÄòLisbon, sad and joyful city‚Äô), a photobook that started as a series of booklets sent to subscribers by post (at the time, it was a way to circumvent the censorship of the dictatorial regime) and later rose to fame after being prominently featured in Martin Parr and Gerry Badger‚Äôs History of the Photobook. A modern facsimile edition‚Ä¶

Content:

I‚Äôm just back from the WebSummit in Lisbon. I had never been to Lisbon before but I‚Äôve heard that they have great trails. As much as I‚Äôm a technerd and the WebSummit is an massive tech party with endless happenings, there was no way they were going to keep me off the trails all the week! I‚Äôve heard the call of the trails! I contacted WERIDE and booked a full day guided ride including rental bike, at the Sintra-Cascais Natural Park, approximately 25km north-west of Lisbon. I knew that I was pushing it doing a full day Enduro ride after three days of late nights and many drinks..But,
to bike or not to bike ‚Äî was not even the question..
I was picked up by Hugo, the owner of WERIDE who took me to Miguel, my guide for the day. My trail monster for the day was a YT Capra with an amazing √ñhlins rear shock. A Swedish rear shock for a rare Swedish guy, now that‚Äôs how you roll!
After an espresso and a Pastel de nata at the little town of Arneiro, we started the fifty minute non-stop climb up to the trailhead. It was raining and humid but the air was fresh and the surrounding forrest was green and lush. I had asked for Enduro, and enduro is what I got. No Enduro without the obligatory climbs before the fun..
The trailhead, and actually all trails in Sintra all starts next to ‚ÄúTholos do Monge‚Äù, a mass grave built in the Chalcolithic period (2300 BC / 2000 BC) at the top of one of the highest elevations of the Sierra de Sintra. From the top you have a network of 25 different Enduro/HD style trails all decending down the mountains in different directions.
It is very hard to describe the Sintra forrest. It is something like a cross-over between a jungle and a Mediterranean forrest. This coupled with a misty carpet hovering a few meters above your heads turns the whole ride into a mystical-magical journey.
After a fantastic descent on the trails filled with fun obstacles, drops and flow trails, we climbed back up again to connect to another fun DH trail. I stopped counting the climbs up and down the mountain but the fantastic descents was the reward for the long climbs.
After a well deserved freshly grilled mackerel lunch at ‚Äúthe Bikers Refugee‚Äù in the small city of Penedo, we started the devilish climb back up to the top for our final long descent.
The Donkey trail starts at the top on Peninha, a very remote and isolated chapel overlooking the Atlantic with stunning views.
Words cannot justify the stunning views around Peninha. But best of all is the amazing descent.
After all the climbs I was ready for the long, breath taking descent to the towards the sea.
What goes up must come down. And that is a good thing!
We finished off the ride with a cold beer where we had parked. It could not have been better.
I‚Äôm glad that I took a day off the WebSummit craziness for a ride in Sintra despite being very tired from the outset. It was an amazing experience. Magical forrest, endless cool trails and a fantastic guide. I can definitely recommend to anybody who wants to ride in Portugal to contact WERIDE. These guys are pure Pros, attentive, fun and can adapt to any rider style from beginners to Pro-riders. XC, DH or Enduro, whatever makes you tick. They also know how to spice up the ride with espresso, lunch and a beer just at the right time when you really need it. They have top level, state-of-the art well serviced bikes and are very affordable, so it makes absolutely no sense to bring your own bike.
They do: half-day, full-day rides and also organize multiple days or week long rides all over Portugal. They even have their on RVs for maximum comfort for the longer rides. Enduro Magazine just came back from a couple of days with them and published this great piece.
I will definitely come back and I recommend mountain bikers who are searching for their next adventure to go and discover Portugal. You will not regret it.

Title: Short-term Trip to Lisbon: what you need to know for the first visit
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
We just returned from a short business trip to Lisbon with my husband. It was our first time visiting the city, and I can‚Äôt help but share this story.
We visited Lisbon right after our relocation to The Azores, San Miguel Island. It‚Äôs also Portugal but far from the mainland and is located in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean but it‚Äôs another story‚Ä¶ Since we had not visited this country before it was interesting to compare both locations, and got to know the capital of Portugal and the mentality of the locals.
The airport is right in the city, 30 minutes from the center, which is very handy and saves you time.
The old part of the city is pretty compact and no need to use transportation. It‚Äôs very nice to walk around. By the way, did you know Lisbon is one of the oldest cities in the world? And it‚Äôs worth the stroll, but most of the main sights in Lisbon could be seen in 2 days.
Lisbon is a relatively compact city, but it‚Äôs still a good idea to stay as centrally as possible!
Chiado and once again Chiado, and the area surrounding it!!!
It has a really wonderful, relaxed vibe. Everything is extremely close here. We were staying at 9 Hotel Mercy and were completely satisfied with the location and hotel.
If you want to save some money you can choose areas a little farther from the center such as Avenidas Novas and Alcantara ‚Äî they are also good for long-term living. But in this case, you will need to use transportation.
The first thing I recommend after you leave the hotel is to have a glass of Vinho Verde ‚Äî ‚ÄúGreen wine‚Äù ‚Äî which is a traditional Portuguese wine produced exclusively in the northwest of the country. It is lightly sparkling and low in alcohol. It‚Äôs really good!
Ginjinha. Trying ginjinha in Lisbon is a travel must. Actually, it‚Äôs a cherry liqueur that originated in Lisbon. A lot of bars serve ginjinha in small cups made of dark chocolate. Drinking can be fun.
Below I‚Äôll share a list of dishes I‚Äôve tried, of course, it could be longer, but I was only there for a few days. Plus, we had excellent breakfasts at the hotel.
Perhaps I would have started listing famous tourist attractions in the past, but it‚Äôs not so important to me now. I don‚Äôt like the fuss about it. Besides, such places are always so crowded!
Instead of visiting the famous Elevador de Santa Justa, standing in an endless line, and then in the small and stuffy elevator car (I googled and saw pictures of tourists), I‚Äôll choose to sit in a nearby rooftop bar with a panoramic view of the same elevator and enjoy the wonderful view!!!
It‚Äôs good to read a few articles or watch a video before the trip to manage your expectations. Make a few marks on the map of places you want to visit.
I really couldn‚Äôt imagine traveling without a long list of must-see sights. But now I open up a google map with my marks on it and choose on the spot what place I want to visit depending on the mood. And that‚Äôs fine.
If I want to learn more about the city and its history, the best way to do it is to book a city tour for a few hours with a private guide who lives in this city and can share some personal stories from life.
From the beginning, it became clear that there was no point in comparing mainland Portugal and San Miguel Island. Yes, it is one country, but so different in so many ways!Generally, I like that Lisbon is lively enough and full of locals even in the city center. But a few things that were a little embarrassing to me are the tourists‚Äô and emigrants' way of behaving, and it wasn‚Äôt just downtown. I would describe it as unbridled and disrespectful which makes the atmosphere around a little bit cold and not friendly. These are my personal remarks you might not even notice it, but my empathy didn‚Äôt allow me to ignore such things.
This city is a really nice place for tourists, but I would think twice about long-term living.
--

Hello World! ‚Äî Excited to share with you how my first week in Lisbon with Remote Year went.
The City: Two words: Hills and Festivals. There are hills everywhere. Lisbon is the stairmaster city incarnate ‚Äî I swear, we are all going to have nice butts at the end of this month. June is also a great month to visit because of all the festivals! All the charming little districts (Alfama, Bica, Bairro Alto, Castelo & Mouraria) bring the party to the streets to celebrate St. Anthony. Grilled sardines, bread with sausage, red wine, music and entertainment fill the streets for the entiremonth.
The Workspace: It‚Äôs a 10 minute walk from my apartment and folks shuffle in and out depending on their schedules.
The Gym: Fitness Hut: a 3 minute walk from the workspace and 55 Euros for 5 weeks. The biggest adjustment for me (other than not having my trainer Cheyne to keep an eye on me) is having to ration your water because there are no water fountains! You‚Äôd think they‚Äôd want to make sure you stay hydrated‚Ä¶
The Routine: Currently non-existent. When I wake up, go to sleep, eat, work out, code, and study vary at different hours of the day every single day. I guess my routine is: Do what you want when you want ‚Äî I can‚Äôt lie, it‚Äôs fucking great.
The Work Situation: The UpWork profile is up but I‚Äôm having trouble even finding work to submit bids/proposals for. Most of the jobs require the freelancer to be physically located in the U.S and anything remotely related to Finance requires a lot of Strategy and Business Development experience, none of which I really have. I wallowed a bit for a few days: I realized that my resume was top-notch for a Corporate Finance job but unfortunately only that. Smaller and more nimble firms want someone that can not only manage Budget, Pacings, Close from an Operational side but also someone that can do Strategy, Business Dev and even some sales; coding experience would be a huge plus. It‚Äôs been a humbling experience for sure‚Ä¶
The Coding: The plan is to go through the free version of CodeAcademy (current progress at 35%) before I commit to the paid version. PluralSight was recommended as well so we‚Äôll see. Luckily, I‚Äôve got a team of software engineers on this program who are all so willing to help throughout this process.
Last but not least, the People: Remote Year Denali is a group of 40 amazing individuals, lead by our fearless leader and positivity unicorn, Erica. (She‚Äôs the one wearing the grey jacket on the bottom right of me in the photo below). Everyone is so incredibly talented, driven and passionate about making the most of both their careers and life ‚Äî it‚Äôs impossible to not feel inspired to do the same every single day. Back home, I‚Äôve always felt like the odd one out at work, always questioning things and always pushing the envelope because I wanted more: I wanted more to my career than what people decided for me and I wanted more to life than what I knew. I can‚Äôt tell you how incredible it feels to meet 39 other individuals who feel EXACTLY the same way.
Originally published at https://allthingslil.net on June 5, 2018.

Title: My Favorite Restaurants in Lisbon, Portugal (2022)
Content:

Listen
Share
Lisbon is an incredible energetic place. And since I moved here, in 2016, the city has developed a lot and, fortunately, it continues to innovate.
One of the best parts of living in the capital is being able to closely follow the growth of the gastronomic scene, which is varied and full of good representative chefs.
It wasn‚Äôt an easy task, but I selected my all-time favorite restaurants, from the finest to the tradicional ones ‚Äî for all tastes and budgets.
Belcanto is one of the main references in the Portuguese gastronomy ‚Äî with 2 Michelin stars and in 42nd place on ‚ÄúThe World‚Äôs 50 Best Restaurants‚Äù list. If you are looking for an unforgettable experience, this is the place.
Of√≠cio is one of those restaurants that we want to take everyone to visit. They have a menu of sharable dishes and finger food that are absolutely delicious. My favorites: Spider Crab, Sea Vegetable Taco, Old-fashioned Oven Rice and, of course, the best dessert ever, the Cheese Tart by chef Hugo Candeias.
This Viennese coffee house makes me feel at home. They serve traditional Austrian dishes, like Wiener Schnitzel, and my favorite pastries, Apfelstrudel and the Sachertorte. On weekends, they also serve brunch.
Bairro do Avillez is divided into two main areas: Taberna (a more relaxed space, with small dishes, charcuterie and finger food) and P√°teo (a sea-food restaurant organized in two floors). My favorite dish is the Flaked Cod with Cornbread and Fried Egg. For dessert, my recommendations are Bairro‚Äôs Pavlova and the Olive Oil and Honey Pudding with Lemon Zest.
Tapisco is a mix of Spanish tapas and Portuguese cuisine, with a food menu that is meant to be shared. My recommendations: Tomato Bread with Jam√≥n Ib√©rico de Bellota, Salted Cod ‚Äú√Ä Br√°s‚Äù and the Dark Chocolate Mousse with Olive Oil and Fleur de Sel.
The first time I went to Osteria was on my first date with my boyfriend. The place is very cozy, and they serve authentic Italian food, prepared according to old family recipes. I highly recommend the Focaccia and the Pasta al Pesto di Rapa Rossa (picture above).
This is one of those restaurants that is always full of cool people. The highlight, which captures the attention of all who pass by, is the giant Instagram-famous Octopus sculpture dangling above the dining room like a nautical chandelier. The food is Peruvian inspired and the signature dish is ceviche (as the name says).
JncQUOI is located in a historic theater that was converted into a fashionable place, with a high-end men‚Äôs store, a DeliBar with gourmet store, and a restaurant. There you will find classic Portuguese and International dishes signed by Chef Ant√≥nio B√≥ia and a wine selection with over 500 references that promise to offer the best wine experience in the country.
Definitely the best sushi in Lisbon. It has the coolest bar area, an elegant dining room, and a beautiful garden for the warmer nights. If you can choose, I would recommend the sushi bar area, where you can see the magic happening. I‚Äôve tried the Tasting Menu, that includes the best selection of creative sushi, sashimi and miso ever. Not to mention the dessert selection, where sugar balance was the rule and things as lime, chocolate, pineapple and flowers were combined in perfect harmony.
Located on the riverside of Lisbon‚Äôs Bel√©m district, overlooking the Tejo River, the SUD Terrazza restaurant is influenced by Italian and Mediterranic cuisine. I highly recommend it for a romantic dinner or a family lunch. The view is amazing!
The Oriental Market is located in front of Martim Moniz Square and have lots of different food stalls. If you like Oriental food, this is the place. I recommend the first restaurant, right at the entrance on the left, and also the Mint House, on the second floor, with the best Pad Thai in Lisbon.
It was the smell of fresh pasta (and truffle) that led me to discover this restaurant, which is close to my house and has become one of my favorite Italian restaurants in Lisbon.
The environment is extremely cozy and the pasta is delicious. I‚Äôve returned several times and keep ordering the same dish over and over again: Tagliatelle al rag√π di carne. You need to try it!

Before we get into this post, I‚Äôll admit I didn‚Äôt travel to Lisbon solo ‚Äî but it felt like I did. I took this trip with my best friend (at the time), but it may as well have been on my own due to us wanting to do different things on the trip.
I‚Äôll get into all that later, but for now, I‚Äôm writing this from the perspective of what I would do (and most things I did) when I travel solo, even if I technically traveled with someone.
In this post, I‚Äôll share my honest review and opinions of Lisbon, Portugal, and what it‚Äôs like for a solo female traveler. I‚Äôll also discuss some of the best things I saw, did, and ate while there.
I‚Äôll also be diving deep into the more personal aspects of this trip, including some of the biggest things I‚Äôve learned from my time there and some of the best people I met who have greatly inspired me.
Before I get into the best things I did in Lisbon, I NEED to talk about where I stayed! This hostel was probably the best I‚Äôve ever stayed at ‚Äî it had everything I could have needed, wanted, and more.
I stayed at Yes! Hostel and could not have chosen a better one. The staff were super friendly, very welcoming, and organized games, nights out, and pub crawls.

On the south shore of the Tagus river, in Almada city, but precisely in Cacilhas neighborhood, in addition to the traditional restaurants, very interesting tourist activities and the unmistakable architecture, an abandoned pier and ruinous, little-visited nowadays and commonly known as Cais do Ginjal.
